p.emph: FOURTH YEAR OF THE WAR. Chaps. 1-25.

p.hi: Third Peloponnesian Invasion of Attica.

div2.p: *peloponnh/sioi kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi: designation for the whole Peloponnesian alliance, as in c. 26.1, 4; ii. 47. 4; 71. 1; iv. 2. 2. For *peloponnh/sioi alone in this comprehensive sense, cf. c. 2.1, and see on ii. 13. 1.—2.

a(/ma tw=| si/tw| a)kma/zonti: indicates more sharply than tou= si/tou a)kma/zontos (ii. 19. 5; 79. 4) the beginning of the ripening of the corn. For the pred. partic., see Kr. Spr. 50, 11, 13. See App. on ii. 4. 11 (Steup).—3.
h(gei=to . . . basileu/s: parenthetical, as ii. 47. 6; iv. 2. 3; the relation of the other clauses also is the same as there.— 4.
e)gkaqezo/menoi: here, as in iv. 2. 4, indicates more clearly than kaqezo/menoi (ii. 47. 7) a definite place from which raids were made.—5.
prosbolai\ kte(.: cf. ii. 22. 7.—
w(/sper ei)w/qesan: sc. gi/gnesqai. Cf. i. 132. 26.—
e)gi/gnonto: pass. of poiei=n. H. 820. See on i. 73. 1.—6.

o(/ph| parei/koi: wherever opportunity offered, as Arr. Anab. vi. 9. 2. The Schol. explains, o(/pou e)nede/xeto kai\ e)nexw/rei. Cf. iv. 36. 7 kata\ to\ ai)ei\ parei=kon, Plato Symp. 187e kaq) o(/son parei/kei, Rep. 374e o(/son g' a)\n du/namis parei/kh|, Soph. Phil. 1048 ei)/ moi parei/koi.—to\n plei=ston o(/milon: the main body, as opp. to the small predatory bands which kept up the devastation. o(/milos in this sense seems to be Ionic and poetic. See Proc. Amer. Phil. Assoc. vol. xxii. p. xix.—7.

to\ mh\ . . . kakourgei=n: for to\ mh/ with inf. after verbs of hin
dering, see GMT. 811; H. 963, 1029; Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 4; Kühn. 479, 1 and 516, N. 9 l.—
tw=n o(/plwn: camping places, as in i. 111. 6; vi. 64. 20; vii. 28. 8.
e)mmei/nantes: aor. partic., as in ii. 23. 10; viii. 31. 16. See App. on ii. 19. 14.—
ou(=: depends on ta\ siti/a. Cf. ii. 23. 11 o(/sou ei)=xon ta\ e)pith/deia. G. 1085, 5; H. 729 d. See on i. 48. 2. —9.
a)nexw/rhsan . . . kata\ po/leis: the same formula in c. 26. 17; ii. 78. 8; v. 83. 10.
All Lesbos except Methymna immediately revolts from the Athenians, who had been informed of the designs of the Mytileneans.

*le/sbos plh\n *mhqu/mnhs a)pe/sth: Mytilene, which was itself under oligarchical rule, had extended its authority over the three smaller places, Antissa, Pyrrha, and Eresos (c. 18. 5); only Methymna on the northern coast retained its democratic constitution and connexion with Athens. See W. Herbst, Der Abfall Mytilenes, 1861, and Leithäuser, Der Abfall Mytilenes, 1874.—
boulhqe/ntes: agreeing kata\ cu/nesin with *le/sbos. Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 2; Kühn. 359, 3a. Cf. c. 79. 10; i. 24. 9.—3.

pro\ tou= pole/mou: cf. c. 13. 5 kai\ pa/lai . . . e)/ti e)n th=| ei)rh/nh|. It was doubtless after the conclusion of the triakontou/teis spondai/, 445 B.C., as the Schol. says, ou) prosede/canto, i(/na mh\ lu/swsi ta\s triakontou/teis sponda/s. See W. Herbst, ibid. p. 10, 22.—

a)ll) . . . ou) prosede/canto: the full const. would be a)ll) ou)k a)pe/sthsan: oi( ga\r *lakedaimo/nioi ou) prosede/canto. For similar brachylogy, cf. i. 26. 17. As the clause refers only to boulhqe/ntes, it is to be construed parenthetically. prosede/canto, as c. 13. 6; i. 45. 2; ii. 70. 10, without expressed obj., tou\s lo/gous, or a similar word, being understood. —4.
a)nagkasqe/ntes: the explanatory partics. with me/n, de/ are placed after the leading verb with effect similar to the me/n and de/ clauses in ii. 93. 19, 22. —
kai\ tau/thn: i.e. th\n to/te, even this revolt, as opp. to that which they had failed to make.

tw=n te ga\r . . . metapempo/menoi h)=san: explanatory of pro/teron h)\ dienoou=nto, as 9 ff. *tene/dioi ga/r, . . . *le/sbou is of a)nagkasqe/ntes. te is co-ord. with kai/ before o(/sa.—6. th\n xw=sin . . . oi)kodo/mhsin . . . poi/hsin: the art. covers the three substs. with their genitives. Cf. c. 56. 7, and see on i. 120. 10. xw=sis tw=n lime/nwn means the
building of moles, by which the entrance to the harbours was narrowed and could at will be closed by a chain. 7.

e)pe/menon: takes two consts.: a) acc. with inf., th\n poi/hsin telesqh=nai (cf. c. 26. 13; Soph. Trach. 1176); b) the acc. alone, o(/sa e)/dei a)fike/sqai. See Haase, Lucubr. Thuc. p. 110 f. So perie/mene, vii. 20. 16. Thus most of the editt. explain. Cl. makes o(/sa e)/dei a)fike/sqai subj. of a)fike/sqai understood, on the ground that e)pime/nein does not take the acc. alone; but cf. Eur. Suppl. 624; Plato Rep. 361 d.—8.
toco/tas: Seythian bowmen, hired by the ruling aristocracy, and always ready to serve as mercenaries.—

a(\ metapempo/menoi h)=san: whatever they were engaged in fetching. Cf. ii. 67. 9 h(=n poliorkou=n, and see App. on i. 1. 5. Kr. Spr. 56, 3, 1; Kühn. 353, N. 3. Cobet's conjecture metapepemme/noi h)=san is unnecessary, as is shown by L. Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 37-39. On the subject of periphrases with ei)=nai, see Amer. J. of Ph. iv. p. 297.
*tene/dioi: members of the Attic symmachy (vii. 57. 22). They feared the influence of Mytilene on the Aeolic coast, as did Methymna on the island. See W. Herbst, ibid. p. 24.—10.
*mutilhnai/wn: the earlier form, acc. to inscriptions and coins; later, and therefore in many Mss., *mitulhnai/wn. See Meisterhaus, Grammatik der Att. Inschriften^{2} p. 23.—

i)di/a| kata\ sta/sin: on account of factions. Cf. kata\ sta/sin i)di/a|, c. 34. 3; kata\ sta/sin, c. 62. 19; 68. 17; 82. 11; v. 33. 4; kata\ th\n sta/sin, viii. 106. 21. i)di/a| also ii. 67. 4. The phrase gives the motive of mhnutai\ gi/gnontai, to which pro/cenoi *)aqhnai/wn is added by way of explanation. Aristotle, Polit. v. 4, mentions Doxander as the Attic proxenus who, in revenge for the rejection of his proposal of marriage for his sons with the daughters of the aristocrat Timophanes, betrayed the plot to the Athenians.—11.

mhnutai\ gi/gnontai: the same periphrasis as in i. 132. 31; viii. 50. 15. Cf. also c. 58. 13 (eu)erge/ths); i. 4. 3 (oi)kisth/s); i. 37. 12 (dikasth/s); c. 59. 12; i. 136. 9 (i(ke/ths); c. 40. 31 (prodo/ths); ii. 43. 8 (e)rasth/s); c. 23. 13; i. 35. 12; v. 9. 38; viii. 86. 23 (kwluth/s); c. 42. 7; v. 30. 2; viii. 45. 9 (dida/skalos); c. 105. 14; i. 95. 4; vi. 76. 13; vii. 56. 19 (h(gemw/n); viii. 51. 4 (e)ca/ggelos). See Dissen ad Dem. xviii. 72.—12.

cunoiki/zousi/ te th
 *le/sbon e)s th
 *mutilh/nhn: the Schol. explains, a)/kontas tou\s *lesbi/ous a)nagka/zousin e)s th
 *mutilh/nhn oi)kh=sai. e)bou/lonto ga e)k mia=s po/lews o(rmw/menoi polemei=n. Cf. i. 58. § 2. This view is held also by Goell., Bl., Kr. and
Jowett. But it is incompatible with c. 18. § 1; so that political concentration must be meant, as in the case of Athens under Theseus, ii. 15. § 2, the communal independence of the other places being abolished. The purpose (pres. cunoiki/zousi) is in part carried out in c. 18. § 1. So explain also Arn., St., and Böhme. See W. Herbst, ibid. p. 19.—13.
*lakedaimoni/wn: cf. c. 5. 13.—14.
*boiwtw=n: esp. the Thebans. Cf. c. 5. 13; 13. 7.—
cuggenw=n o)/ntwn: since Lesbos was considered a Boeotian colony. Strab. xiii. 1. 3. Cf. vii. 57. 24; viii. 100. 16. See Curtius, Hist. of Greece, i. p. 127 f.—
e)pi\ a)posta/sei: with a view to a revolt. Cf. i. 3. 9; 37. 8; 73. 14.—
e)pei/gontai: trans. also iv. 5. 9; vi. 100. 5; viii. 9. 2.—15.

ei) mh/ tis: with fut. indic. a common expression of warning. Cf. iv. 68. 28; viii. 53. 18; 83. 13; 91. 12. On ei) with the fut. indic. in minatory and monitory conditions, see GMT. 447; Gildersleeve, Trans. Amer. Philol. Assoc. 1876, p. 5 ff., Amer. J. of Ph., ix. p. 491 f., xiii. p. 123 f.—
prokatalh/yetai: shall prevent, abs., as in c. 3. 9; 46. 25; v. 57. 4; vi. 18. 13. See on i. 57. 15. —
h)/dh: forthwith, belongs to the prot., as h)/dh in viii. 91. 13, and e)n ta/xei in v. 57. 5; 64. 2.—
sterh/sesqai: pass. also in c. 39. 44. sterhqh/somai seems to occur only in late writers. See Veitch s.v.—
au)tou/s: i.e. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.

After fruitless remonstrance against the preparations of the Mytileneans and the proposed ‘synoecismus’ of the island, the Athenians detain 10 Mytilenean ships with their crews, and send to surprise Mytilene 40 triremes, whose coming was, however, betrayed to the Mytileneans.
h)=san ga\r kte(.: the causal sent. in parataxis before the main one, not rare in Thuc. See on i. 31. 7. —

tetalaipwrhme/noi: Cl. considers this a mid., as also in c. 78. 3; iv. 27. 2; 35. 12; vii. 28. 10, with the same force as the act. in i. 99. 5; 134. 9. But it seems better, with St., to regard it as pass. in all the passages cited. Cf. Plut. Brut. 37 to\ sw=ma talaipwrou/menon, and Isoc. viii. 19 (o( po/lemos) tetalaipw/rhken h(ma=s. The act. occurs with u(po/ in ii. 101. 19.—2.

a)/rti kaqistame/nou kai\ a)kma/zontos: pred., being just fairly afoot and at its height. a)/rti kaqistame/nou as in c. 68. 29. On a)/rti see Lobeck ad Phryn. p. 20; Rutherford, New Phryn. p. 70 f. a)kma/zein also of pestilence, ii. 49. 27. Steup, comparing both this passage and c. 68. 29 with kaqesthkui=a h(liki/a in ii. 36. 9, understands the reference to be to the middle period of the war, in which case, of course,
the ten years', not the twenty-seven years', war would be meant.—3.
me/ga: great, i.e. difficult. Cf. ii. 45. 2; 89. 45; vi. 12. 16.—
prospolemw/sasqai: obs. the force of the middle. The Schol. rightly explains, pro\s toi=s ou)=si polemi/ois . . . kai\ au)th\n polemi/an poih=sai. Cf. v. 98. 6.— 5.
prw=ton: acc. to most and best Mss., without art. Both forms are about equally common.—

mei=zon me/ros ne/montes . . . ei)=nai: giving too much weight to the wish that it might not be true. For the sentiment, cf. iv. 108. § 4; v. 113, and the evident imitation of the present passage in Philo Leg. ad Caium 10 plei=ston dido/ntes me/ros tw=| mh\ bou/lesqai . . . dokei=n w)mo/n. Also Dio C. xxxvii. 11 th=| boulh/sei ple/on h)\ th=| duna/mei ne/mwn, Dem. iii. 19 o(\ ga\r bou/letai, tou=q) e(/kastos kai\ oi)/etai, Caes. Bell. Gall. iii. 18 fere libenter homines id, quod volunt, credunt. For the phrase mei=zon me/ros ne/mein, cf. c. 48. 2; i. 71. 7; vi. 88. 10. Also Eur. Suppl. 241 ne/montes tw=| fqo/nw| ple/on me/ros, Hec. 868 tw=| t) o)/xlw| ple/on ne/meis, Anliope (frg. 183) ne/mwn to\ plei=ston h(me/ras tou/tw| me/ros.—6.
a)lhqh= ei)=nai: sc. ta\ kathgorhme/na from ta\s katthgori/as. Cl. explains ‘without reference to any definite noun,’ comparing o)/ntwn a)kri/twn, iv. 20. 5.—8.
th\n cunoi/kisin: found only here in Thuc., and prob. not elsewhere unless in late writers.—9.
prokatalabei=n: see on c. 2. 15.

e)capinai/ws: as in c. 34. 17; 70. 25; i. 117. 1; ii. 3. 2; 48. 4; 93. 15; iv. 25. 48; vi. 100. 14. This form, as well as e)capi/nhs (c. 89. 20; i. 50. 21; iv. 36. 10; 111. 12; 115. 13; v. 10. 33,—cf. Plat. Rep. 621 b; Ps.-Dem. lix. 99; Arist. H. An. 636 a 31), seems to be lonic and poetic, being used by Xenophon only, of other Attic prose writers. The regular Attic forms, e)cai/fnhs and ai)fnidi/ws, occur also in both Thuc. and Xenophon. See Diener, de Serm. Thuc. 1889, pp. 24-26.

e)shgge/lqh ga . . . e)pipesei=n a)/fnw: explanation of pe/mponsin e)capinai/ws. Hence the preceding sent, must be considered parenthetical.
The following dependent clause, however, h)
 me
 cumbh=| . . . polemei=n, contains in the usual const., kai\ . . . me
 . . . de/ (cf. i. 19. 1; 22. 1, etc.), the execution of the task implied in pe/mpousin.—13. *malo/entos: this epithet of Apollo seems to occur only in Lesbos. Cf. Schol. Patm. (Rev. de Philol. N. S. i. p. 185; cf. Hellanicus ap. Steph. Byz. s.v. *malo/eis) w(s . . . e(orth/] *malo/eis *)apo/llwn: ou(=tos para\ *mitulhnai/ois e)tima=to, a)po\ toiau/ths de/ tinos ai)ti/as. *mantw\ h( *teiresi/ou quga/thr peri\ tou\s to/pous xoreu/ousa tou/tous mh=lon xrusou=n a)po\ tou= periderai/ou e)kpeso
 a)pw/lesen: eu)/cato ou)=n, ei) eu(/roi, i(ero
 i(dru/sein tw=| qew=|. eu(rou=sa de\ to\ mh=lon to\ i(ero
 i(dru/sato, kai\ *malo/eis *)apo/llwn e)nteu=qen par) au)toi=s e)tima=to. The explanation of Meister (Gr. Dial. i. p. 65) is most prob. correct: god of Malea. Cf. c. 4. 18. For other explanations, see Wilamowitz, Isyllos, p. 99 f. and Preller-Robert, Gr. Myth. I.^{4} p. 252.—14.

e)pipesei=n: aor. without a)/n after e)lpi/s, as ii. 80. 11; iv. 70. 20; v. 9. 27; 102. 4; vi. 87. 18; viii. 40. 14; 86. 34; so after e)lpi/zw, iv. 13. 4; 24. 10; 80. 3; vii. 21. 6. G. 1286; H. 948 a, 952; Kühn. 389, N. 8. See App. on ii. 3. 8. —15.

h)\n me\n cumbh=| h( pei=ra: the Schol. explains cumbh=| by katorqwqh=|. There is an ellipsis of some apod. like eu)= e)/xein or tau=ta a)/rista ei)=nai (cf. i. 82. 12), which is easily supplied from the second member of the hypothetical sentence. Such an ellipsis occurs possibly also in iv. 13. 14. Cf. Hom. A 135; Hdt. viii. 62. 3, and see SauppeTowle on Plato Prot. 311 d. GMT. 482; H. 904 a; Kr. Spr. 54, 12, 12; Kühn. 577, 3 c.—
ei) de\ mh/: otherwise, after h)\n me/n, GMT. 478; H. 906; Kr. Spr. 65, 5, 12.—16.
ei)pei=n: depends on keleu/ousin implied in pe/mpousin.—nau=s, tei/xh: without art. in formulae of conditions of peace, also i. 101. 12; 108. 14; 117. 14.—
paradou=nai: after ei)pei=n, to command, as in i. 131. 9; ii. 6. 7. GMT. 99; H. 946 b.
ta\s de\ de/ka trih/reis: the art. on account of the rel. clause following, as in c. 22. 33; viii. 15. 9. Cf. also viii. 26. 2. Kühn. 465, 13; Kr. Spr. 50, 2, 7.—19.
para\ sfa=s: the reflexive pron. in a dependent clause refers to the subj. of the primary clause. G. 987; H. 683 a. Cf. c. 108. 14; i. 20. 3; 115. 23; vi. 32. 9. —

kata\ to\ cummaxiko/n: the word is rare except in Thucydides. Cf. c. 91. 7; i. 107. 27; ii. 22. 17; 101. 15; iv. 61. 15; v. 6. 6; vii. 20. 5; 33. 22.
—
parou=sai:=parageno/menai, hence para\ sfa=s. Cf. gunai=kes pa/reisin . . . e)pi\ to\n ta/fon, ii. 34. 11. Also c. 8. 3; vi. 62. 19; 88. 51; vii. 50. 1.—20.
e)s fulakh\n e)poih/santo: as viii. 1. 25 e)s a)sfa/leian poiei=sqai. Cf. also e)nto\s poiei=sqai, ii. 83. 26; vi. 67. 9.
diaba\s kte(.: obs. the effect of the five parties., which involuntarily portray the haste of the messenger.—

*geraisto/n: Schol. *geraisto\s a)krwth/rion *eu)boi/as e)/xon lime/na. Cf. Hom. g 177; Hdt. viii. 7. 5; ix. 105. 6. Livy (xxxi. 45) calls the harbour nobilis Euboeae portus, and Strabo (x. 1. 7) mentions the adjacent town with the celebrated temple of Poseidon. It is now called Mantelo. See Leake, Northern Greece, ii. p. 423; Bursian, Geogr. v. Gr. ii. pp. 399, 434.—23.
a)nagome/nhs: the pres. as in i. 117. 4; 137. 7; ii. 90. 13.—
e)pituxw/n: with gen. also vii. 25. 8. Cf. Xen. Oec. 2. 3; 12. 20; Plato Phil. 61 d; Ar. Plut. 245. With the dat. c. 75. 20; viii. 14. 1; 34. 3; Lys. xii. 12. Kr. Spr. 47, 14, 2.—

plw=|: the Schol. explains a)nti\ tou= eu)ploi/a|. Cf. i. 137. 13; Hes. Op. 630; Ant. v. 24; Xen. Anab. v. 9. 33. So most editt. explain. But Arn. takes plw=| xrhsa/menos as merely opp. to pezh=| e)pi\ *geraisto
 e)lqw/n, comparing vi. 97. 8, ou)/te plou=n ou)/te o(do
 pollh
 a)pe/xei, where plou=s is thus opp. to o(do/s.— tritai=os: pred. adj. for adverb. G. 926; H. 619; Kr. Spr. 57, 5, 4.
oi( de\ kte(: ‘illi vero neque in Maloentem exierunt et praeterea etiam imperfecta murorum portuumque opera obstruxerunt et excubias apud eos egerunt.’ Haacke. See App.—
e)s to\n *malo/enta: Steph. Byz. *malo/eis *)apo/llwn e)n *le/sbw|: kai\ o( to/pos tou= i(erou= *malo/eis. Since the reference is to the temple there is no objection to the preposition.—26.
fraca/menoi: having blocked up, the walls prob. by means of palisades and battlements, the harbours by means of ships that were sunk.

Beginning of hostilities. Conclusion of an armistice, during which the Mytileneans send an embassy to persuade the Athenians that their designs are harmless and to induce them to recall their fleet. At the same time they secretly appeal to Sparta for aid.

kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi . . . w(s e(w/rwn:
one of the cases rare in Att. prose where the subj. placed before the conj. does not belong to the leading clause. Cf. c. 5. 1; iv. 78. 1; vii. 32. 1; Hdt. ix. 61. 1. Cobet (Mnem. N. S. viii. p. 123 sq.) would omit oi( strathgoi/. But Thuc. nowhere uses a)pagge/llein with so comprehensive a subj. as oi( *)aqhnai=oi.—2. w(s e(w/rwn: sc. ta\ u(po\ tw=n *mutilhnai/wn prasso/mena, the obj. being unexpressed, as often with ai)sqa/nesqai (c. 22. 22; i. 95. 21, etc.). So i)do/ntes, iv. 25. 49.—
ta\ e)pestalme/na: cf. c. 3. 16.—3.
e)sakouo/ntwn: give heed, comply. See on i. 82. 11.—
e)s po/lemon kaqi/stanto: commenced hostilities (cf. c. 5. 2; i. 23. 28; 99. 14; ii. 9. 2), according to the instructions mentioned c. 3. 17.

a)para/skeuoi kai\ e)cai/fnhs: pred. to a)nagkasqe/ntes polemei=n. Cf. c. 2. 4. For similar combination of adj. (or partic.) and adv., cf. c. 13. 12; 34. 17; 42. 23; 82. 13; i. 39. 2; 63. 7; vii. 32. 11. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3.—6.

w(s e)pi\ naumaxi/a|: with a view to a seafight, as in vi. 34. 34. Placed thus before the prep., w(s implies the ‘purpose’ of the subject. For distinction between the dat. and the acc. in this const., see L. Herbst, Philol. xlii. p. 675.—

pro\ tou= lime/nos: ‘as there were two ports of Mytilene, w(=n o( no/tios kleisto\s trihriko\s nausi\ penth/konta, o( de\ bo/reios me/gas kai\ baqu\s xw/mati skepazo/menos (Strab. xiii. 2. 2), it is evident that the trihriko\s limh/n is meant here.’ St.—7.
h)/dh: now, in their present strait, what before they had not been willing to do. h)/dh often thus indicates a change of conditions. Cf. i. 18. 28; 49. 27.— 8.
to\ parauti/ka: for the present, i.e. until they should be better prepared. Cf. i. 27. 4; iv. 121. 7; vi. 83. 14. —9.

e)pieikei=: i.e. if not strictly in accordance with the right, still fair and acceptable; so also in c. 9. 10; i. 76. 20. Cf. Arist. Rhet. 1374 a e)/stin e)pieike\s to\ para\ to\n gegramme/non no/mon di/kaion.—a)pope/myasqai: get rid of; usually dismiss, as in Hdt. i. 33. 3; 120. 35; ii. 25. 13; vii. 105. 3; Xen. Cyrop. i. 4. 27.
a)pede/canto: sc. tou\s lo/gous. See on c. 2. 4.—11.

*le/sbw| pa/sh|: i.e.
not merely against Mytilene. Cf. ii. 80. 2 *)akarnani/an pa=san, although Oeniadae is excluded, as here Methymna.

a)nokwxh/n: cf. i. 40. 16; 66. 9; iv. 38. 4; 117. 7; v. 25. 13, in all which passages St. (Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 44) has shown this to be the correct form, not a)nakwxh/.—13. tw=n diaballo/ntwn: partic. pres. of an enduring relation, as oi( e)pago/menoi, ii. 2. 22; oi( prodido/ntes, ii. 5. 32. Kühn. 382, 4 b. The pro/cenoi of c. 2. 11 are meant.—14.
ei)/ pws pei/seian ta\s nau=s a)pelqei=n: sc. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous as obj. of pei/seian. The const. of pei/qein with inf. and subj. acc. is unusual. For the const. of the opt., see GMT. 489.—

w(s sfw=n . . . newteriou/ntwn: with the understanding that they did not intend to make any innovation. GMT. 864. Cf. vii. 15. 13. The subj. of the gen. abs. is here the same as that of the leading elause, as in c. 13. 30; vii. 48. 12. GMT. 850; Kr. Spr. 47, 4, 2; Kühn. 494 a.
e)n tou/tw|: i.e. while they were waiting for an answer from Athens. —
a)poste/llousi . . . e)n th=| *male/a| pro\s bore/an th=s po/lews: see App.— 18.

toi=s a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: toi=s is neut. as in i. 127. 5. au)ta/ is to be supplied as subj. of proxwrh/sein. Cf. iv. 92. 36 pisteu/santas tw=| qew=| pro\s h(mw=n e)/sesqai, where the subj. of e)/sesqai is to be supplied from tw=| qew=|. Kr. Spr. 61, 6, 8; Kühn. 476, 2. A comparison with i. 127. 5 and the passages there cited shows that Bk.'s conjecture, *)aqhnw=n, is unnecessary.
talaipw/rws: aegre, in Thuc. only here, and elsewhere in Attic seldom (Ar. Eccles. 54); freq. in late writers.—20.

dia\ tou= pela/gous: i.e. not touching at the intervening islands, as was commonly done for the sake of security and comfort; so also c. 33.4; 69. 2; vi. 13. 12, and, in the same sense, pela/giai ple/ousai, viii. 39. 16; 60. 12. Cf. Hom. g 174 pe/lagos me/son te/mnein.—au)toi=s e)/prasson, o(/pws tis boh/qeia h(/cei: Cl., who understands au)toi=s of the Lacedaemonians, explains au)toi=s e)/prasson, negotiated with them, comparing iv. 106. 11; 110. 8; v. 76. 15; viii. 5. 22. But it seems better, with the other editors, to understand au)toi=s of the Lesbians, and, with Kr. and Bm., to render here, and in all the passages cited,
negotiated (or worked) for them. Cf. Dem. ix. 59 e)/pratte *fili/ppw|, worked for Philip, Plut. Alc. 24 pratto/ntwn *boiwtw=n *lesbi/ois. Moreover, in three passages where it is beyond doubt that Thuc. meant negotiate with, the phrase is pra/ssein pro/s tina, c. 28. 10; i. 131. 6; ii. 5. 32. St., though referring au)toi=s to the Lesbians, makes it depend on h(/cei. Cf. c. 5. 12, and for dat. with such verbs see on i. 13. 12.
Hostilities are resumed, but after an unsuccessful sortie the Mytileneans retire and await help from the Peloponnesian alliance.
oi( e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n: prolepsis, as in i. 8. 8; iv. 16. 17, and frequently. G. 1225, 1; H. 788 a; Kr. Spr. 50, 8, 10; Kühn. 448 a.—2.
ou)de\n pra/cantes: =a)/praktoi. Cf. iv. 97. 8; viii. 91. 2. —
e)s po/lemon kaqi/stanto: the expression is somewhat peculiar, since hostilities had already occurred between the Mytileneans and the Athenians (c. 4. 3).—3.
h( a)/llh *le/sbos: see on c. 2. 2.—

ou(=toi: refers kata\ cu/nesin to *mhqu/mnhs. Cf. c. 2. 2 *le/sbos . . . boulhqe/ntes.—4. *)/imbrioi kai\ *lh/mnioi: Attic cleruchs, often mentioned together as tried allies, iv. 28. 18; v. 8. 7. Lemnos had been occupied by Miltiades (Hdt. vi. 140); Imbros prob. about the same time. —5.

tines: in Attic allowed between the art. and subst. of the dependent gen. only when another modifier follows the article. Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 20. The reference is prob. to the Tenedians. W. Herbst, p. 24.

e)pi\ to\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn strato/pedon: i.e. against the camp which the Athenians had established as a nau/staqmon, a station on land (see on c. 6. 11), near their fleet. The e)/codos, which the Mytileneans made pandhmei/, as well as e)phuli/santo, is to be understood of an expedition by land, and the ma/xh as a pezomaxi/a.—8. ou)k e)/lasson e)/xontes: not being worsted. See on i. 105. 23. Cf. Xen. Anab. i. 10. 8 mei=on e)/xwn. The pres. partic., as with nika=n (i. 13. 31), of enduring results. —

e)phuli/santo: “held the field,” as in iv. 134. 9. Schol. plhsi/on tw=n polemi/wn nukto\s au)li/sasqai. This single exhibition of confidence is co-ord. with the whole (oi)/ te e)pi/steusan sfi/sin au)toi=s); or, perhaps better, the effect (e)phuli/santo) is co-ord. with the cause (ou)/te e)pi/steusan kte(.).

e)/peita: from this time on. Placed emphatically at the beginning of the whole following narration, it includes the events of the next chapter, the explanatory sent. H. 12-17, kai\ ga\r . . . e)kpe/mpousin, being parenthetical.—

e)k *peloponnh/sou . . . ei) prosge/noito/ ti kinduneu/ein: const. ei) e)k *peloponnh/sou prosge/noito/ ti, kai\ met) a)/llhs paraskeuh=s, (ei) prosge/noito/ ti,) boulo/menoi kinduneu/ein. Goeller. Thueydides's propensity to put pred. modifiers before the conj. leads to an irregularity in the construction. Cl. thinks from what follows that Theban help is meant in met) a)/llhs paraskeuh=s, but Steup objects that Boeotia was at that time only a land power (cf. i. 27. 14; ii. 9. 11).
au)toi=s a)fiknei=tai: for the terminal dat., rare in prose after simple verbs, see on *sami/ois h)=lqe, i. 13. 12. Kühn. 423, 5.—14.

e)pi/ploun: i.e. the 40 ships mentioned e. 3. 10, 25; 4. 1. The whole passage clearly shows that Thucydides dates the revolt of the Mytileneans from their refusal of the demands of the Athenians (c. 4. § 1). —

meta\ th\n ma/xhn u(/steron: for the pleonasm, cf. i. 3. 2 pro\ tw=n *trwikw=n pro/teron, v. 24. 9 meta\ ta\s sponda\s ou) pollw=| u(/steron.—15. trih/rh a)/llhn: i.e. besides the one dispatched e. 4. 16, doubtless in order to announce the increased danger.—16.
kai\ e)kpe/mpousin: sc. oi( *mutilhnai=oi, with change of subj. in paratactic narration. Cf. c. 50. 13.

p.hi: The Athenians prepare to invest the city.

div2.p: parh=san: =parege/nonto. See on c. 3. 19.—
ou)de\n i)sxuro/n: the adj. with subst. force, “no energetic effort.” Cf. ou)de\n a)lhqe/s, v. 45. 12; bi/aion ou)de/n, vi. 54. 16; ti ai)sxro/n, iv. 27. 11; viii. 9. 14.— 4.

periormisa/menoi to\ pro\s no/ton th=s po/lews: after they had come around to anchor south of the city. But since a part of the fleet must have continued at anchor north of the city (cf. c. 4. 18), kai/, also, was to be ex
pected, after periormisa/menoi. See App. —5.
e(kate/rwqen th=s po/lews: see App. —6.

tou\s e)fo/rmous e)p) a)mfote/rois toi=s lime/sin e)poiou=nto: the two harbours which Strabo (xiii. 2. 2) describes, were formed, somewhat like the two Syracusan harbours, by an island lying in front of the city. e)pi/, which is wanting with e)formei=n in vii. 3. 21, is repeated, for the sake of clearness, with e)fo/rmous e)poiou=nto.

th=s me\n qala/sshs ei)=rgon mh\ xrh=sqai: unusual limiting inf. after th=s qala/sshs ei)/rgein (see on i. 141. 16); or perhaps the natural obj. of the inf. is construed proleptically with ei)=rgon (Kr. Spr. 61, 6, 8; Kühn. 600, 3 b). For mh/ with inf. after verbs of hindering, see GMT. 807; H. 1029. —9.
oi( a)/lloi *le/sbioi: i.e. from the cities allied with Mytilene. Cf. c. 5. 3, and see on c. 2. 2.—10.

nau/staqmon: here and vi. 49. 18, the base of operations, where material for the ships, as well as provisions for the crews, was kept. In this general sense of station it may properly take both gens., ploi/wn kai\ a)gora=s, after it. —11.
ma=llon: sc. than the southern camp. The station first occupied at Malea was the more important of the two. See on c. 4. 15.—12.

ta\ me\n peri\ *mutilh/nhn: most naturally construed as nom., as in iv. 23. 9. Cf. Xen. Anab. iv. 4. 1 o(/sa e)polemh/qh. This const. is rendered more prob. by the analogy of similar concluding formulae: c. 51. 1; 68. 39; 114. 24; ii. 54. 20; iv. 41. 17; vii. 30. 19; 87. 27. Kr. construes as acc., as in ii. 96. 17; iv. 108. 8; v. 52. 5.
Asopius sent around Peloponnesus with 30 Attic ships, 12 of which go on to Naupactus. Unsuccessful attack upon Oeniadae and Leucas, and death of Asopius.
kai\ peri\ *pelopo/nnhson: as before to Lesbos. On the reading peri/ see App.—4.

tw=n *formi/wnos: of the kindred of Phormio. Kr. Spr. 47, 5, 2. Cf. ii. 34. 5 tw=| au(tou=. h)\ ui(o\n h)\ cuggenh= is epexegetical apposition. Phormio himself, whose close relations with the Acarnanians dated from his
command in Naupactus (ii. 69. § 1; 81. § 1; 102. § 1), seems to have died soon after his return to Athens (ii. 103). But see Müller-Strübing, Aristoph. u. d. hist. Kritik, p. 677 ff.
paraple/ousai . . . e)po/rqhsan: cf. c. 91. 20. paraplei=n, sail along the coast, as in c. 32. 1; 33. 9; 34. 1; 95. 10; 112. 26.
a)nasth/sas: of levying troops, as in ii. 68. 3; 96. 1; iv. 77. 11; 90. 2.—
e)p) *oi)nia/das: sc. to carry out during the summer the undertaking which his father had been unable to accomplish the preceding winter. Cf. ii. 102. § 2.—11.
kata\ to\n *)axelw=|on: along the Achelous. kata/, on, along, as in iv. 25. 29.—
o( kata\ gh=n strato/s: refers, as to\n pezo/n (13), to the Acarnanian troops.
*nh/rikon: the same form also in Hom. w 377; in Strabo x. 2. 8 the Mss. vary between *nh/rikos and *nh/ritos.—15. tw=n au)to/qen: as in ii. 25. 18; iv. 29. 10; vi. 25. 13; vii. 34. 9.—16.
frourw=n: as opp. to tw=n au)to/qen cumbohqhsa/ntwn these must be foreigners, possibly Corinthians, as in iv. 42. 17. Cf. c. 94. 4.
kai\ u(/steron kte(.: i.e. they re-embarked and sailed off, then sent back a herald to ask for their dead, as in iv. 44. §6.—18.
e)komi/santo: used esp. of the recovery of prisoners and the corpses of the slain. See on i. 113. 14.

p.hi: Ambassadors of the Mytileneans present their cause in an assembly of the Peloponnesian allies at Olympia.

div2.p: e)pi\ th=s prw/ths new/s: cf. c. 4. 16 and 5. 16.—2.

ei)=pon: =e)ke/leusan,
as in c. 3. 16. See on i. 78. 10. —
*)olumpi/aze parei=nai: cf. ii. 34. 11; Xen. Anab. i. 2. 2 parh=san ei)s *sa/rdeis. Kühn. 447, N. 4.—3.

oi( a)/lloi cu/mmaxoi: i.e. the rest of the members of the Peloponnesian alliance. Cf. v. 62. 7, and see Steup on Thucydides's freq. use of cu/mmaxoi to indicate members of a confederation or coalition, Rh. Mus. xxxv. p. 323.—4.
h)=n de\ . . . e)ni/ka: explanatory clause inserted parenthetically. The date was Olympiad 88, B.c. 428. —5.

*dwrieu/s: son of Diagoras, victor three times in succession at Olympia (Paus. vi. 7. 1), as well as in numerous other contests (Paus. vi. 7. 4). He fought in the Decelean war on the Spartan side (viii. 35. § 1; Xen. Hell. i. 1. 2; Diod. xiii. 38, 43), and was captured by the Athenians, but on account of his fame as an athlete was released without ransom (Xen. Hell. i. 5. 19; Paus. vi. 7. 4, 5). See Müller, Dorier, iii. 148 ff.—
e)ni/ka: was victor, as in v. 49. 2. For the force of the pres. and impf. of this verb, see GMT. 27; Kr. Spr. 53, 1, 3-4.—

meta\ th\n e(orth/n: generally regarded as celebrated at the first full moon after the summer solstice. But Unger prob. rightly decides for the full moon in August, i.e. the 8th Elean month, Apollonios = Attic Metageitnion. See Philol. xxxiii. p. 227 ff. and Handbuch d. kl. Alterthumsw. i. p. 603 f.; also Nissen, Rh. Mus. xl. p. 349 ff.; and A. Mommsen, Über die Zeit der Olympien, 1891.— 6.
kate/sthsan e)s lo/gous: met in council, sc. as subj. the Peloponnesians. Cf. c. 70. 8; iv. 58. 4.

p.hi: The unfavourable opinion usually held of allies that revoll in time of war ought not to be applied to us.

div2.p: to\ me\n kaqestw\s toi=s *(/ellhsi no/mimon: cf. c. 56. 5 kata\ to\n pa=si no/mon kaqestw=ta. The form kaqestw/s, of the older editions, has been rightly restored by v. H., as also periestw/s, iv. 10. 3. For acc. to the testimony of the ancient grammarians the shorter Attic form was -estw/s (from -ao/s), not -esto/s. Hence the variation of the Mss. between -w/s and -o/s cannot be urged in favor of -o/s in the classical period. See O. Riemann, Bulletin de corr. hellén. iii. p. 440 ff., St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 64. Thucydides uses elsewhere the fuller form (i. 98. 9; iv. 97. 11; vii. 67. 10; viii. 66. 7, 12).—
no/mimon: custom, found only here in the sing., though common in the plur. (c. 58. 17; i. 71. 11; 77. 24, etc.).—3.

cummaxi/an th\n pri/n: this order, by which stress is thrown on
the attribute, is common in Thuc. See on i. 1. 6. On the adv. with art. as adj., see Kühn. 461, 6.—4.
e)n h(donh=| e)/xousi: are pleased with, the periphrastic expression denoting enduring relation. Cf. e)n qerapei/a|, i. 55. 7; e)n o)rgh=|, ii. 21. 22; e)n o)rrwdi/a|, ii. 89. 3.—6.

xei/rous h(gou=ntai: consider them worse (sc. than they otherwise would), as in iv. 114. 13. For the omission of the second member of the comparison, see Kühn. 542, N. 7; Matth. 457; and cf. Lys. xxxii. 1. With the sentiment of the passage, cf. Liv. xxvii. 17 transfugae nomen exeerabile veteribus sociis, novis suspeetum. Also Tac. Ann. i. 58; Dem. xviii. 47.

kai\ ou)k . . . e)stin, ei) tu/xoien: the apod., vividly introduced by kai/ (and indeed), has the indic., while the prot., as if stating a purely hypothetical case (provided etc.), takes the opt. GMT. 501; Matth. 524, N. 3.—

au(/th h( a)ci/wsis: this estimate. h( do/ca, h( kri/sis, o( logismo/s, Schol. Cf. Plut. Per. 28 ou)k h)=n a)/dikos h( a)ci/wsis.—7. a)f) w(=n diakri/nointo: for rel. elause with omitted antee. standing for subst., see Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 5. For the opt. by assimilation, see GMT. 558; H. 919a. —8.
i)/soi me\n th=| gnw/mh| o)/ntes kai\ eu)noi/a|: i.e. having the same political views and being equally well-disposed toward each other. On Thuc.'s use of gnw/mh, see Introd. to Book I. p. 32. —

a)nti/paloi: i)sosqenei=s, i)/soi, Schol. In this sense common in Thuc. and Dio C., rare in other authors. (Bl.) Cf. Eur. I. T. 446 poina\s dou=s) a)ntipa/lous, Alc. 922 u(menai/wn go/os a)nti/palos.—9. pro/fasis: excuse. See on i. 23. 23.—
te: the ‘postseript te)’ introduces the third member, as in i. 2. 6 and freq.—

e)pieikh/s: reasonable, equitable. Cf. c. 4. 9. Bl. compares Dion. H. Antiq. 595, 28 e)pieikei=s ai)ti/as, Polyb. iii. 91. 7 e)pieikh= a)po/fasin.—10. o(/: refers to the three preceding clauses (i)/soime\n . . . a)posta/sews). See on i. 35. 15. Its influence extends to the following clause, mhde/ tw| . . . a)fista/meqa.—11. ei) . . . a)fista/meqa: the actual case is put in cond. form, as in c. 32. 6; 43. 19. mhde/ tw| xei/rous do/cwmen ei)=nai is about=mhde/ tis memfqh=| h(mi=n (cf. iv. 85. 7), and so ei) has the force of o(/ti. GMT. 494, 496; H. 926. —12.

timw/menoi: treated with honour, favoured, esp. in point of autonomy.
Cf. c. 39. 9, 28; 56. 21.—
e)n toi=s deinoi=s: in the hour of danger. Cf. i. 70. 10; 84. 8, and see on ii. 87. 18.

For our alliance with Athens, which rested on the common defence against the Medes, long ago lost the necessary basis of confidence, seeing that the Athenians have reduced the allied cities one after another to subjection.

peri\ ga\r tou= dikai/ou kai\ a)reth=s: “concerning the justice of our cause and the honesty of our intentions.” peri\ tou= dikai/ws au)tw=n a)fi/stasqai, kai\ mh\ dia\ kaki/an te kai\ panourgi/an, Schol. ‘to\ di/kaion corresponds to pro/fasis e)pieikh/s above, a)reth=s refers to xei/rous.’ St. The force of the art. extends to a)reth=s. Kühn. 451, 1; 463, 2. The whole phrase includes everything that is demanded not only by the strict letter of the law, but also by considerations of equity and morality. (On a)reth/, magnanimity, fair or generous dealing, see Introd. to Book I. p. 36.) The reference is, however, not merely to the present revolt of the Mytileneans from the Athenians, but to their whole mutual relation, which is to be the basis of the judgment concerning the Mytileneans for the future. They base their request for admission to the Peloponnesian alliance on grounds, first, of worthiness, showing that for the best reasons and as soon as possible they had revolted from the Athenians (c. 10 to c. 13. § 2), second, of expediency and advantage to the Lacedaemonians (c. 13. § 3-6). The two main ideas are summed up c. 13. 14 i(/na fai/nhsqe . . . bla/ptontes. —2. ei)do/tes ou)/te . . . gi/gnointo kai\ ta)=lla o(moio/tropoi ei)=en: Cl. and Steup understand i)diw=tai kai\ po/leis as subj. of gi/gnointo, which is taken to mean, bear themselves (‘sich benehmen, verhalten’; see on i. 37. 12). The sense would then be: “Friendship between individuals and alliance between states cannot last, unless they bear themselves toward one another with a mutual recognition of honesty of purpose and are in other respects like in character.” But see App.— 4.
e)s ou)de/n: in any respect. Cf. vii. 59. 10; 87. 23.—
met) a)reth=s dokou/shs: =meta\ dokh/sews th=s a)reth=s, and dokou/shs signifies not appearance, but well grounded belief. ou) ga\r dh\ th\n prospoihth\n le/gei, Schol.—5.

o(moio/tropoi: nearly equiv. to i)/soi th=| gnw/mh|. Also i. 6. 24; vii. 55. 6; viii. 96. 27. The adv. occurs vi. 20. 12. Cf. Hdt. viii. 144. 16 h)/qea o(mo/tropa.—e)n ga\r tw=| dialla/ssonti th=s gnw/mhs . . . kaqi/stantai: for on divergence of sentiment rests diversity of action. Bl. cites an imitation of the passage in Procop. Bell. Vand. 145, 32 tw=| dialla/ssonti th=s gnw/mhs. dialla/ssein is
intr., as in Hdt. vii. 70. 4. The use of neut. partic. or adj. for abstract noun is a favourite one with Thucydides. It presents to the mind the abstract quality in operation. GMT. 829 a; H. 966 b; Kühn. 403 a, g.
de/: now, effects the transition to the special case. Cf. i. 32. 7; 121. 1; ii. 64. 28.—

*)aqhnai/ois cummaxi/a e)ge/neto prw=ton: from what follows it is clear that the reference is to the beginning of the closer connexion of the Lesbians with Athens, i.e. the rise of the Delian confederation (i. 95). The orator represents Sparta's withdrawal from the Median war as preceding, not following, the formation of that alliance, in order not only to put the conduct of his state toward Sparta in a favourable light, but also to avoid touching the latter in a sensitive spot. Cf. i. 75. § 2, and see Steup, Rh. Mus. xxxv. p. 330 f.—8.
a)polipo/ntwn e)k: this rare const. occurs also v. 4. 11 a)polipo/ntes e)k tw=n *surakousw=n. Kühn. 447 c.; Matth. 495, 1.—9.
ta\ u(po/loipa: what yet remained, with tw=n e)/rgwn, as i. 75. 5, with tou= barba/rou.

cu/mmaxoi me/ntoi kte(.: we became allies, not to the Athenians for the enslavement of the Greeks, but to the Greeks for their emancipation from the Mede. The dats. *)aqhnai/ois (11) and toi=s *(/ellhsi (12) belong grammatieally to cu/mmaxoi e)geno/meqa, though the influence of the verbal nouns katadoulw/sei and e)leuqerw/sei on these dats., as in vi. 76. 20, is not excluded. This view, which is generally adopted, is supported by the const. in c. 13. 9, 10. But Kr. and Wilkins construe *)aqhnai/ois and toi=s *(/ellhsi as dativi commodi with the verbal nouns alone. By oi( *(/ellhnes are meant, both here and c. 13. 9 (cf. i. 130. 16; 140. 21), the states of the Delian confederation, whose treasurers were called *(ellhnotami/ai (i. 96. 6).—
katadoulw/sei: occurs also vii. 66. 6; Plato Legg. 776 d; elsewhere prob. only in late writers.—11.
e)leuqerw/sei: in this sense, c. 39. 39; Hdt. ix. 45. 18; freedom to slaves, i. 132. 22; Arist. Pol. v. 11. 19; license, Plato Rep. 561 a.—
a)po\ tou= *mh/dou: const. after the verbal noun as after the verb in i. 95. 3; ii. 71. 10; viii. 46. 21.
me/xri: while, as in c. 98. 1. Kühn. 567, 1.—
a)po\ tou= i)/sou: on terms of equality. kata\ th\n i)sonomi/an, Schol. On a)po/ in this sense, see Kühn. 430, 1, 3 h. See on i. 77. 8. —

h(gou=nto: abs., maintained their hegemony, as in i. 19. 2; 77. 23. Cf. e)chgei=sqai, i. 76. 3; 95. 26.—
14.
dou/lwsin: a Thucydidean noun, found also i. 141. 6; Plato Legg. 791 d. —15.

e)peigome/nous: urging on, Ross's and Bk.'s conjecture, for the vulgate e)pagome/nous, seems to be required to contrast with a)nie/ntas, and has been adopted by St. and Cl. Cf. Va. tendentes ad. It is trans. also in c. 2. 14; iv. 5. 9; vi. 100. 5; viii. 9. 2; 82. 9. See App.

a)du/natoi de\ o)/ntes . . . a)mu/nesqai: and disabled by diversity of opinion from combining and defending themselves. Although in the development of the thought the subj. is divided into cu/mmaxoi plh\n h(mw=n kai\ *xi/wn and h(mei=s, the undivided subj. is to be understood with a)du/natoi o)/ntes at the beginning. dia\ poluyhfi/an belongs to a)du/natoi o)/ntes, kaq) e(\n geno/menoi to a)mu/nesqai. poluyhfi/a is diversity of opinion naturally arising from the fact that so many had the right to vote. The disadvantages of the i)soyhfi/a of the Peloponnesian alliance, which resulted in poluyhfi/a, are set forth in i. 141. § 6, 7. The word is not found elsewhere.

dh/: scilicet, intimates what is expressed in tw=| o)no/mati. The ironical force occurs as early as Homer (A 110). Cf. iv. 46. 18, 20; 67. 17; vi. 10. 23; 54. 18; and dh=qen, i. 92. 3; 127. 2. Kr. Spr. 69, 17, 2; Kühn. 500, 3.—19.
pistou/s: to be trusted. Cf. c. 92. 7.—

paradei/gmasi toi=s progegenhme/nois xrw/menoi: since the paradei/gmata must have been facts already accomplished, Weidner's conjecture of the pf. for the pres. (progegenhme/nois for progignome/nois) is necessary here, as well as in i. 23. 25. See Parerga Dinarch. et Thuc., 1875, p. 22. Cf. Procop. B. V. i. 10 paradei/gmasi de\ tw=n progegenhme/nwn xrwme/nous—20. ou) ga\r kte(.: for it was not likely that they after subduing those whom they had made sharers in the treaty with us would not have done the same to us who were left, if ever they had been able. So Bm. correctly explains. dra=sai, as well as katastre/yasqai, refers to the past; hence Dobree's conjecture dunhqei=en, Kr.'s dunhqei/hsan, are unnecessary. The arrangement is paratactic, though the first clause is in sense subord., as in i. 28. 15; 35. 4. On this form of apod. in unreal cond. (ou) ga\r ei)ko\s h)=n au)tou\s mh\ dra=sai tou=to), see GMT. 420, 421; Kr. Spr. 53, 2, 7; Kühn. 392 b, 4. Cf. c. 40. 26; 74. 11; vi. 78. 22.
And that our autonomy has hitherto been spared by their lust for power we owe alone to a regard for their own interests, which would, however, not have protected us much longer.

kai\ ei) me\n . . . a)\n e)pelqei=n a)potre/petai: the second ground of the untenableness of the federal relation: the growing strength of the Atheni ans and the increasing isolation of the Mytileneans.—
bebaio/teroi: pers. const., like di/kaios in i. 40. 13. GMT. 762; H. 944; Kühn. 477 d.—2.
newteriei=n: used to express any innovation in established order, esp. harsh and violent changes. Cf. Lat. res novae. Cf. c. 4. 15; i. 58. 3; ii. 3. 6; iv. 51. 3.— 3.
a)po\ tou= i)/sou: see on c. 10. 12.— 4.

e)/mellon oi)/sein: Thuc. uses the fut. inf. with me/llein far oftener than the present. See on i. 107. 13. The obj. of oi)/sein is to be supplied from h(mi=n . . . o(milou=ntes.—kai\ pro\s . . . a)ntisoume/nou: these words, which are closely connected, give the explanation of xalepw/teron e)/mellon oi)/sein. While u(poxeiri/ous . . . o(milou=ntes states the actual relation from the side of the Athenians, what follows expresses this from the side of the Mytileneans, but from the standpoint of the Athenians. Render: “because our state alone, even though the majority had already yielded, still maintained its equality.” See App. kai/, which belongs esp. to pro\s to\ plei\on h)/dh ei(=kon, emphasizes the andacity of the Lesbians in the eyes of the Athenians. pro/s, as against, as in i. 6. 15; ii. 91. 18. tou= h(mete/rou is neuter. a)ntiso/omai is not found elsewhere except in late writers. See Steph. Thes. s.v.—6.

dunatw/teroi au)toi\ au(tw=n: more powerful than they were before. The comp. with gen. of reflex. pron. measures progress by change in the subj. itself. Cf. i. 8. 13; vi. 72. 22; vii. 66. 14. The const. is freq. in Hdt. H. 644; Kühn. 543, 6.—7.

to\ de\ a)nti/palon de/os mo/non pisto\n e)s cummaxi/an: this clause, containing the second ground of the untenableness of the alliance, is closely connected with the preceding (de/=ga/r), “for fear based on equal power is alone to be relied on
in the case of an alliance.” Cf. iv. 92. 14 pro/s te ga\r tou\s a)stugei/tonas pa=si to\ a)nti/palon kai\ e)leu/qeron kaqi/statai, Tac. Germ. 1 Germania a Sarmatis Dacisque mutuo metu separatur. But Steup gives strong reasons for bracketing de/os. See App.—8.
tw=| mh\ . . . a)potre/petai: the chief stress is on proe/xwn, “is deterred only by the consideration that he would make the attack not with superior force,” i.e. not with prospect of success.

te: introducing third reason (see on c. 9. 10), which covers the remainder of the chapter; viz. that only regard for appearances and for present advantage kept the Athenians from being more aggressive.—10.

o(/son: quatenus, equiv. to kaq) o(/son, c. 9. 4; vi. 54. 25; 82. 11. o(/son instead of o(/ti, in order to restrict the motive to the narrowest limits, to concede as little as possible to good intentions.—

e)s th
 a)rxh
 . . . katalhpta/: “it was clear to them that to extend their dominion they could get control of affairs by fair words and by an assault of policy rather than by force.” The main object of the Athenians, e)s th
 a)rxh/n, ad imperium quaerendum, is emphasized by its position, separated as it is from ta\ pra/gmata e)fai/neto katalhpta/ (cf. c. 30. 11), of which it expresses the motive. But see App. eu)prepei/a| lo/gou is explained by the following a(/ma me
 . . . custrateu/ein, and gnw/mhs ma=llon e)fo/dw| h)\ i)sxu/os first and esp. by e)n tw=| au)tw=| de\ . . . e)xeirw/santo, to which then two further reasons are added (19 and 21).—11.

ta\ pra/gmata . . . katalhpta/: here of securing predominance (cf. Hdt. vi. 39. 4); c. 30. 11, of conquering in battle. Cf. iv. 2. 13 katasxh/sein r(a|di/ws ta\ pra/gmata, c. 62. 11; 72. 3 e)/xein ta\ pra/gmata, c. 28. 1 oi( e)n toi=s pra/gmasi, i. 89. 2 h)=lqon e)pi\ ta\ pra/gmata, vii. 49. 3 to\ boulo/menon toi=s *)aqhnai/ois gi/gnesqai ta\ pra/gmata.
a(/ma me/n: the correlative is e)n tw=| au)tw=| de/ (14), as in iv. 73. 10.—

marturi/w| e)xrw=nto mh\ a)
 . . . custrateu/ein: the inf. clause is the obj. of e)xrw=nto, “they used as a proof (of the propriety of their course) that those at least who had equal votes with them would be unwilling to join in their expeditions, unless those whom they went against were guilty of some wrong.” The condensed statement is about equiv. to a(/ma me
 ga marturi/w| e)xrw=nto, mh\ a)
 toi/s ge i)soyh/fous, ei) mh/ ti h)di/koun oi)=s e)ph/|esan, custrateu/ein, ou) ga a)
 a)/konta/s ge custrateu/ein, i)soyh/fous o)/ntas. (Goeller.) See App.—13.

i)soyh/fous:
‘It seems to be rhetorical exaggeration that the Lesbians, au)to/nomoi and (though after the revolt only the Methymneans) nausi\ kai\ ou) fo/rw| u(ph/kooi (vii. 57. 22), call themselves i)soyh/fous, mindful to be sure of the right and of the ancient statute, long ago abolished by the Athenians, acc. to which the allies consulted a)po\ koinw=n cuno/dwn. Cf. i. 97. § 1.’ St.—14.
e)n tw=| au)tw=| de/: on the position of de/, to emphasize tw=| au)tw=|, see Kühn. 528, 1.—
kai\ ta\ kra/tista: kai\ tou\s krati/stous h(ma=s, Schol. The neut. pl. of the adj. expresses a concrete idea. Kühn. 403, N. 2.—15.

ta\ teleutai=a: as the last, pred. to ta\ kra/tista, as the position of te, kai/ shows. The art., which Kr., St., and Steup strike out, L. Herbst (Philol., 1860, p. 342 f.) explains as intended to sharpen the contrast with what precedes, ‘as the last in the series, as it were the capstone of their work.’ Cf. c. 85. 2; possibly c. 23. 15.—16.

tou= a)/llou perih|rhme/nou: “when all else was stripped from around them,” like a tree lopped of its branches. Cf. ii. 13. 38; Plato Gorg. 502 c; Dem. xxi. 138. tou= a)/llou collective, as in c. 107. 25; i. 48. 6; iv. 96. 8; viii. 42. 7.
a)sqene/stera e(/cein: a favourite turn of Thuc., often used in expressions of change. See on i. 120. 9.—18.
au)tw=n: themselves, intens., not possessive.—

pro\s o(/ ti xrh\ sth=nai: something to rally to. Cf. iv. 56. 17 pro\s th\n e)kei/nwn gnw/mhn ai)ei\ e(/stasan. The usual form is meta/ tinos sth=nai, as in c. 39. 12; i. 33. 22; vii. 57. 4; 61. 12. xrh/ with inf. is a common periphrasis for the delib. subj. in dependent clauses. Cf. c. 53. 9; i. 40. 20; 91. 4; ii. 4. 10; iv. 34. 25; vii. 44. 15. Kr. Spr. 54, 7, 2; Kühn. 394, N. 3.—
ou)k a)\n o(moi/ws: sc. as they did with the course adopted. Cf. i. 2. 22; ii. 60. 21.
to/ te nautiko\n kte(.: third cause of the e)/fodos gnw/mhs ma=llon h)\ i)sxu/os, namely, that the Mytileneans might not become prematurely frightened and make an alliance dangerous to Athens.—20.

mh/ pote kaq) e(
 geno/menon . . . parasxh=|: lest perchance a union might be effected, either by joining you or some one else, which would bring danger to themselves. kaq) e(
 geno/menon, as in c. 10. 16. prosqe/menon, as in viii. 48. 29; 87. 25. Steup, who claims that, as the passage stands, kaq) e(
 geno/menon can only be subord, to prosqe/menon, is inclined to bracket prosqe/menon, and explain kaq) e(
 . . . a)/llw| tw| after the analogy of di) a)nokwlh=s gi/gnesqai/ tini, i. 40. 16.

ta\ de\ kai/: partly also, similar to to\ de/ ti kai/ of i. 107. 19; 118. 12; vii. 48. 7. Kr. Spr. 50, 1, 15; Kühn. 459, 1 c. This introduces the last reason, though only as a subord. one, why the Lesbians were not deprived of their liberty.—

a)po\ qerapei/as: in consequence of our paying court. a)po/, as in i. 12. 5; 17. 4; 23. 27; 24. 10. Müller-Strübing (Aristoph. u. d. hist. Kritik, p. 366 ff.) rightly sees here, with the Schol., an allusion to bribery of Athenian statesmen, more clearly stated in Ar. Vesp. 675 ff.—22.
periegigno/meqa: i.e. au)to/nomoi e)lei/fqhmen (9).

a)\n e)dokou=men dunhqh=nai: sc. perigi/gnesqai. Kr. Spr. 55, 4, 11. e)dokou=men, we thought, as in i. 126. 20; 128. 30; iv. 14. 14; vii. 41. 14. a)/n belongs to dunhqh=nai. Kr. writes dokou=men on the ground that only with the pres. can dunhqh=nai a)/n stand for e)dunh/qhmen a)/n. But Steup cites viii. 2. 3 e)phrme/noi h)=san . . . nomi/santes ka)\n e)pi\ sfa=s e(/kastoi e)lqei=n au)tou/s, ei) ta\ e)n th=| *sikeli/a| katw/rqwsan. For Steup's objections to the impf., see App.—24.
toi=s e)s tou\s a)/llous: their conduct toward the rest. Schol. tekmh/ria h)=n h(mi=n ta\ pro\s tou\s a)/llous u(p) *)aqhnai/wn geno/mena.
The question was simply, which should anticipate hostile action on the part of the other. Considering the circumstances, we have done no wrong in revolting before the Athenians attacked us.

ti/s ou)=n au(/th . . . pisth/: “was this then a friendship or a freedom on which one could rely?” For the position of the subj. au(/th after the interr. (G. 1602; H. 1012 a), after the analogy of consts. with the sup., see on i. 1. 8. e)gi/gneto, not h)=n, to indicate the growing mistrust. pisth/ belongs to fili/a as well as e)leuqeri/a. Dindorf's conjecture h)\ fili/a for vulg. h( fili/a has the support of the Cod. Clarend., and has been generally adopted. Bl., however, thinks the vulg. makes good sense, ‘supposing that the words fili/a and e)leuqeri/a, though written once, are to be taken twice, thus: “What sort of friendship, then, was this friendship of ours? What assured or secure liberty was this liberty of ours?”’— 2.
e)n h(=| . . . e)/mellon: description of the form their relation to Athens had at last taken.—

para\ gnw/mhn a)llh/lous u(pedexo/meqa: we received one another contrary to our real feelings. para\ gnw/mhn, praeter animi
sententiam, not in the usual sense of conviction or expectation (c. 42. 29; 60. 4; iv. 40. 1; v. 14. 12; vi. 9. 12). u(pode/xesqai has been from the earliest period of the language the regular expression for every kindly, esp. hospitable, reception. Cf. Hom. *z 136, c 52, p 70; Pind. Pyth. ix. 9; Hdt. i. 41. 5; Ar. Acharn. 979; Xen. Mem. iii. 11. 10; Plato Legg. 952 e. From that is derived the more general signification of friendly courtesies, esp. between strangers. St. rightly observes that u(pode/xesqai, which in Plato Legg. 952 e is connected with a)gorai=s kai\ lime/si, is the opp. of lime/nwn kai\ a)gora=s ei)/rgesqai (yh/fisma peri\ *megare/wn, i. 67. 14), and therefore about=e)pimei/gnusqai par) a)llh/lous (ii. 1. 3). Cf. Liv. xxx. 14 benigno vultu excepisset. Plato Meno 91 a similarly connects u(pode/xesqai and qerapeu/ein.— 3. e)qera/peuon: cf. c. 11. 22.—

h(mei=s de\ . . . e)poiou=men: not contradictory to c. 9. § 2 e)n th=| ei)rh/nh| . . . a)fista/meqa, for there the reference is only to the outward position of the Mytileneans, which continued to be an honourable one, even though they had assiduously to court the favour of the Athenians.—4.

o(/ te toi=s a)/llois . . . e)xuro\n parei=xe: Cl., St., and Steup strike out pi/stin. If the traditional reading be retained, Kr.'s explanation seems best: ‘The sent., if complete, would read o(/ te toi=s a)/llois ma/lista eu)/noia poiei= (or pare/xei), pi/stin bebaioi=, kte(.’ See App.—6.

katexo/menoi: overmastered, constrained, as in c. 45. 18. Cf. Eur. Hipp. 27 kardi/an kate/sxeto e)/rwti deinw=|. In Arr. Anab. ii. 17. 2 th=s de\ *)aqhnai/wn po/lews fo/bw| ma=llo/n ti h)\ eu)noi/a| th=| pro\s h(ma=s pro\s to\ paro\n katexome/nhs, which is an evident imitation of the present passage, the meaning is restrained. Cf. c. 107. 9.—8.

ou(=toi pro/teroi/ ti kai\ . . . e)/mellon: these were sure to be the first also to transgress. kai/ introduces the immediate accomplishment of the anticipation of the prot., as in ii. 93. 18; viii. 1. 31. With pro/teroi/ ti parabh/sesqai, cf. c. 11. 8; also c. 54. 11 th\n ei)rh/nhn ou) lu/santes pro/teroi, i. 123. 11 sponda\s ou) lu/sete pro/teroi, vii. 18. 10 ta\s sponda\s prote/rous leluke/nai.

w(/ste ei)/ tw| . . . deinw=n: so that if, on account of their postponement of the evils intended for us, we seem to anyone to do wrong in revolting beforehand. me/llhsis seems not to occur elsewhere in trans. significa
tion. tw=n deinw=n, violent measures, as in ii. 77. 3; iv. 98. 1. For the position of me/llhsin between the subj. and obj. gen., see on i. 25. 21.—10.

au)toi\ ou)k a)ntanamei/nantes: without ourselves having waited in turn. a)ntaname/nein, which seems to be found only here, takes a limiting inf., as a)name/nein, iv. 120. 19; 135. 8. Cf. also e)pime/nein, c. 2. 7; 26. 13; perime/nein, vii. 20. 16. —11.
au)tw=n: sc. tw=n deinw=n.

ei) ga\r dunatoi\ . . . i)e/nai: so Cl. reads, putting, with Heilmann, a)ntepibouleu=sai, kai\ a)ntimellh=sai/ ti e)/dei h(ma=s for a)ntepibouleu=sai kai\ a)ntimellh=sai, ti/ e)/dei h(ma=s, and, with Kr., e)p) e)kei/nous i)e/nai for e)p) e)kei/nois ei)=nai, “were we able equally with them to counterplot, so ought we then also in like manner to have delayed to proceed against them.” The proleptic kai/ inserted in the prot., as often in rel. clauses, and repeated in the apodosis. See on i. 83. 7. a)ntimellh=sai (so Bk., with the Schol. and T; most Mss. a)ntepimellh=sai) is chosen with reference to the boasted me/llhsis of the Athenians. Cf. a)ntanamei/nantes above. The sense of the vulg., which all the English commentators retain, is probably: “if we were able on equal terms with them to counterplot and counter-delay, what need was there for us, being on equal terms, to be at their beck and call?” Cf. Schol. ei) ga\r i)/soi au)toi=s u(ph/rxomen . . . ti/ e)/dei h(ma=s e)p) e)kei/nois taxqh=nai h)\ u(pakoi/ein au)toi=s. See App.—14.
e)p) e)kei/nois: in their power. Cf. ii. 84. 11; iv. 29. 18.

Intending to revolt even before the present war, we were hindered by you. Now, invited by the Boeotians, we have promptly taken this step not only in our own interest, but in that of the Hellenes who are enslaved by the Athenians. But as our revolt has been made too hastily and without the necessary preparations, you are the more bound to assist us, in order that your readiness to help in such cases may be known. All the circumstances are favourable. The power of the Athenians, already weakened and divided, will lose by our defection one of its strongest supports, while your fleet will receive a considerable addition.
toiau/tas e)/xontes: in close connexion with the preceding without connecting particle, as in ii. 74. 1; iv. 93. 1, and freq.—

profa/seis, ai)ti/as: not essentially different, except that the former is more the immediate occasion for action, as in i. 23. 23;
118. 3; Dem. xviii. 156. See on c. 9. 10.—2.
safei=s gnw=nai, i(kana\s e)kfobh=sai: for inf. limiting adj., see GMT. 758; H. 952. Cf. i. 50. 25; ii. 61. 12; vii. 14. 6.—4.
pro\s a)sfa/leia/n tina tre/yai: to cause us to turn to some means of safety, i.e. to an alliance with Sparta. Cf. vi. 59. 7.—

boulome/nous me/n, kwluqe/ntas de/: sc. a)fi/stasqai. The partics., though joined to a subord. clause, by their position at the end of the period come to have the force of the leading clause, so that the following nu=n de\ kte(. refers only to them. Cf. c. 2. § 1.—5.
e)/ti e)n th=| ei)rh/nh|: closely connected, as in ii. 2. 19. See on i. 30. 20. 6.
u(mw=n de\ ou) prosdecame/nwn: cf. c. 2. 3.— 7.
*boiwtoi\ proukale/santo: this influence is not definitely mentioned above. But cf. c. 2. 14; 5. 13.—8.

e)nomi/zomen a)posth/sesqai diplh=n a)po/stasin . . . propoih=sai: we thought to effect a twofold withdrawal: from the Hellenes, so as not to become partners with the Athenians in doing them harm, but to aid in frecing them, and from the Athenians, so as not to be destroyed ourselves by them afterwards, but rather to destroy them first (propoih=sai, i.e. prodiafqei=rai). For examples similar to a)fi/stasqai a)po/stasin, see Lobeck, Paralip. ii. 516 f. See also on i. 37. 11. e)nomi/zomen here, as freq., expresses a certain self-confidence. Cf. i. 84. 17; 105. 23; ii. 3. 7. As to te, te, for which kai/, kai/ is more usual in prose, see on i. S. 14; ii. 84. 14. In the const. of the sent. Thuc. evidently had in mind c. 10. § 3. Nominally the Mytileneans revolted not only from the Athenians, but also from the rest of the Hellenes of the Delian alliance, for whose enslavement they had, as they alleged, been obliged to aid the Athenians. But most editt. hold that a)po/stasis is used here in a double sense, first, as regards the Greeks, of absistendi (cf. iv. 118. 40; vii. 7. 9), second, as regards the Athenians, of revolt. The object of the entrance into the alliance is expressed in c. 10. § 3 by e)pi/ with the dat., while here the object of its renunciation is expressed by infs., the pres. (cu\n kakw=s poiei=n, cuneleuqerou=n) in reference to the unlimited future, the aor. (diafqarh=nai, propoih=sai) to the case in hand.—9.

cu\n kakw=s poiei=n: like a)nt) eu(= poiei=n, Ar. Plut. 1029; Xen. Anab. v. 5.21; Plato Gorg. 520 e; Dem. xx. 64. 124, 141;
su\n eu)= pa/sxein, Dem. viii. 65. Cf. Soph. Ant. 523 ou)/toi sune/xqein, a)lla\ sumfilei=n e)/fun. For cu/n as adv., see Matth. 594, 2.
qa=sson: sc. h)\ h)boulo/meqa. For the omission of the second member of the comparison, see Kühn. 542, N. 7. The adv. co-ord. with adj., as in c. 4. 4. As to the facts, cf. c. 2. § 1, 2; 4. § 2.—13.
h(=| kai/: used before a comp. adv. emphasizes an inference. Cf. i. 11. 8; 25. 22; ii. 2. 21; iv. 1. 14.—
cumma/xous . . . a)poste/llein: see App. cumma/xous is pred. to decame/nous h(ma=s, as i. 43. 7.—
dia\ taxe/wn:=taxe/ws, as in i. 80. 8; iv. 8. 18; 96. 4; vi. 66. 10; viii. 101. 4. —14.

i(/na fai/nhsqe a)mu/nonte/s te kte(.: summary of the two chief points on which the Mytileneans base their request. See on c. 10. 1. The grounds for the last clause (tou\s polemi/ous bla/ptontes) are given in what follows.
w(s ou)/pw pro/teron: cf. ii. 20. 5; v. 63. 4.—
e)fqa/ratai, teta/xatai: such Ion. forms of the pf. and plpf. occur also in iv. 31. 7; v. 6. 23; vii. 4. 34. G. 701; 777, 3; H. 464 a; Kühn.^{3} 214, 8; Kr. Spr. 30, 2, 7.—17.
xrhma/twn dapa/nh|: ‘a plena locutio, which has, however, an intensive force.’ Bl. It occurs also in [Dem.] lx. 13. —
nh=es, ai( me/n, ai( de/: part. appos. See on ii. 95. 5; vii. 71. 4. G. 914; H. 624 d; Kühn. 406, 7.—18.

ai( me
 . . . ei)si/n: i.e. the 30 ships sent under Asopius. Cf. c. 7. 3. peri\ th
 u(mete/ran=peri\ th
 *lakwnikh/n, as often in this specch the Lacedaemonians only are to be understood as addressed (e.g. ll. 6, 34). The territory of the Peloponnesian alliance was not such a unity that the orators could properly speak of a fleet as about this territory. See also on c. 16. 4, 12.—
e)f) h(mi=n: in hostile sense, rare instead of the accusative. Cf. c. 16. 4; 63. 8; i. 102. 19; ii. 70. 8.

ou)k ei)ko\s au)tou\s periousi/an new=n e)/xein: considering the statement above, 1. 16, no/sw| . . . dapa/nh|, and that there could hardly have been a prospect of an actual lack of ships (cf. ii. 13. 55), the reference seems to be to the manning and maintenance of more ships. The inf. pres.
with ei)ko/s on account of the notion of duration. Cf. iv. 20. 16, and see on i. 81. 13.—20.

e)pesba/lhte to\ deu/teron: e)pi- is further defined by to\ deu/teron. e)peisbalei=n, meaning attack, is found clsewhere only in a fragment of Palaephatus; in Eur. El. 498 it means insuper inicere. The first invasion was described in c. 1.— 21.
a)p) a)mfote/rwn: sc. h(mw=n te kai\ u(mw=n.
nomi/sh| te mhdei/s: order as in iv. 95. 3; vi. 84. 1. Kühn. 512, N. 1. —
a)llotri/as . . . e(/cein: cf. i. 78. 2.— 23.
makra\n a)pei=nai: procul abesse. Cf. makra\n a)poikei=n, c. 55. 5. Kr. Spr. 43, 3, 8.—24.
th\n w)feli/an au)tw=|: when an oblique ease of au)to/s thus follows its rel., it is equiv. to a weak dem. and cannot stand first in its clause. Kühn. 468, N. 4. Cf. iv. 92. 42; 126. 19; 128. 3.—

ou) ga\r e)n th=| *)attikh=| e)/stai o( po/lemos: for not upon Attica will the war depend, i.e. it will not draw its strength thence. For e)n, not in local sense, cf. i. 74. 2 e)n tai=s nausi\ ta\ pra/gmata e)ge/neto, ii. 35. 7 e)n e(ni\ a)ndri\ . . . kinduneu/esqai, ii. 64. 11 mh\ e)n u(mi=n kwluqh=|. Kr. Spr. 68, 12, 6.—25.
di) h(/n: i.e. e)n tau/th| di) h(/n, nearly=di) h(=s. Cf. i. 83. 4 dapa/nhs, di) h(\n ta\ o(/pla w)felei=. Also c. 39. 43; vii. 68. 18; Dem. i. 12.

e)/sti de\ . . . h( pro/sodos: cf. ii. 13. 20 le/gwn th
 i)sxu
 au)toi=s a)po\ toi/twn ei)=nai tw=n xrhma/twn th=s proso/dou.— 27. kai\ e)/ti . . . katastre/yontai: the proof of the claim made 1. 24. th
 w)feli/an . . . pare/cei. If the subjugation of the Mytileneans will increase the revenues of the Athenians, it is clearly to the interest of the Peloponnesians to prevent this.—28.

ta/ te h(me/tera: nostrae opes. te correl. to ou)/te.—29. pa/qoime/n t) a)\n deino/tera: esp. through an increase of taxes, as it would seem from the context. te introduces a third circumstance. For the opt. with a)/n exchanging with fut. indie., see Kühn. 396, N. 1.—

h)\ oi( pri\n douleu/ontes: than those enslaved before (us), i.e. the cu/mmaxoi u(potelei=s (i. 80. 14; 99. 11). Cf. c. 10. § 4. 5. Arnold explains: ‘Worse than they who were slares before they rerolled; because the Mytileneans would seem
to have revolted on much less provocation. See Cleon's speech c. 39. § 5, where he calls for an exemplary vengeance upon Mytilene on this very ground.’

bohqhsa/ntwn de\ u(mw=n: this alternative, which contains the main point of the thought, or rather of the whole speech, is expressed in gen. abs., although the verbs of the apod. have the same subject. GMT. 850; Kr. Spr. 47, 4, 2; Kühn. 494 a. See on c. 112. 21; ii. 83. 15; viii. 76. 12.— 32.
prosdei=: sc. besides what you already have.—
kaqairh/sete: of violent overthrow of an existing order of things, or a predominant person. See on i. 4. 6; 77. 20.—

u(fairou=ntes: of gradual drawing out. Cf. c. 31. 8; 82. 17. Bl. calls this an architectural metaphor, namely to pull down (kaqairei=n) by undermining or pulling out stones from the foundation (u(fairei=n).—33.
pa=s tis: everyone, as comprehensive as possible. Kr. Spr. 51, 16, 11. Cf. c. 93. 10; ii. 41. 21; vi. 68. 7; vii. 60. 13. —34.
th\n ai)ti/an: the reproach, as in ii. 18. 9; 60. 25; vi. 60. 3. With e)/xein also i. 83. 8; vi. 46. 27.—

a)pofeu/cesqe: cf. ii. 42. 23 to\ ai)sxro\n tou= lo/gou e)/fugon.—h(\n ei)/xete: refers to the period before the Peloponnesian war. Cf. i. 69. § 5. The reading of Vat., e)/xete—with which a)pofeu/cesqe would mean get rid of, not avoid—would ill accord with the relation of the Mytileneans to the Lacedaemonians, and would hardly answer to the actual circumstances, since the Lacedaemonians had indeed, as they had promised and not far otherwise than the Mytileneans now demanded for themselves (c. 13. § 4; 15. § 1), sought to bring aid to the Potidaeans (cf. i. 58. § 1; 71. § 4; ii. 70. § 1, and, as an example of the opposite course in earlier times, i. 101. § 1 f.).—35.

h)\n d' e)leuqerou=ntes fai/nhsqe: if you openly appear as liberators (of the oppressed). Thus fanh=te, which would be the more usual form before e(/cete, is not necessary. There is an allusion to the boast made by the Lacedaemonians at the opening of the war, o(/ti th\n *(ella/da e)leuqerou=sin (ii. 8. 15; iv. 85. 4). Cf. c. 32. 5.—

to\ kra/tos tou= pole/mou: to\ du/nasqai perigene/sqai tw=| pole/mw|, Schol. Cf. ii. 87. 27; Plato Legg. 962 a. Also Dem. xix. 130 kra/tos pole/mou kai\ ni/khn . . . dido/nai, Dio C. (fragm.) 35. 4 to\ kra/tos tou= pole/mou u(poxei/rion e)/sxe. kra/tos in this sense (mastery, victory) seems to be Ion. and poetic.—
bebaio/teron e(/cete: see on c. 11. 16.
Honour and advantage, therefore, alike bid you to assist us.

e)s u(ma=s: free use of the prep., as in i. 41. 8. Kühn. 432, 1, 3 a. Cf. Dio C. li. 13 metagignw/skein e)pla/sato, w(s kai\ e)lpi/da pollh
 me
 e)s e)kei=non, pollh
 de\ kai\ e)s th
 *lioui+/an e)/xousa. —2.
*di/a to\n *)olu/mpion: an exception to the rule that the art. stands with both the name and appellation of a god, or is omitted with both. Kr. Spr. 50, 7, 10.—
e)n ou(= tw=| i(erw=|: this position of the gen. between the prep. and its noun is esp. common in Thuc., and is the usual one with ou(=. Cf. c. 70. 16; 81. 26; 96. 1; v. 47. 66. Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 19.—

i)/sa kai/: H. 1042 a; Kühn. 423, N. 18. Cf. e)n i)/sw| kai/, ii. 60. 20; e)n tw=| o(moi/w| kai/, vi. 11. 15; paraplhsi/ais kai/, v. 112. 3; vii. 70. 2; o(moi/ws kai/, vii. 28. 30; viii. 76. 13; Hdt. viii. 60. 25; w(sau/tws kai/, Hdt. vii. 86. 7; o(/tw| ge nou=s i)/sos kai\ soi\ pa/ra, Soph. O. C. 810; sebi/zw s) i)/sa kai\ ma/karas, Eur. El. 994. i)/sa is adv., as o(moi=a, i. 25. 18. i)/sa kai/ occurs also in late writers, e.g. Aristid. Panath. i. p. 285 i)/sa kai\ a)h/tthtos.—4. i)/dion . . . koinh\n . . . koinote/ran: “we alone make the sacrifice; the results, whether good or bad (the latter in still greater measure, koinote/ran), will fall upon all.”—

i)/dion me\n . . . paraballome/nous: unusual for met) i)di/ou kindu/nou ta\ sw/mata paraballome/nous. sw/mata means life and limb, as in i. 70. 19; 141. 18; ii. 42. 24. paraba/llesqai, to risk (as at play), also c. 65. 12; ii. 44. 16; Hdt. vii. 10. q 3; Hom. i 322. But here the obj. is the danger instead of the thing endangered.—5.
katorqw=sai, sfalhso/meqa: usual antithesis, as in c. 39. 39; ii. 65. 28.—7.
mh/: belongs to the partic. only. Cf. i. 32. 24; 37. 6.—8.
oi( *(/ellhnes a)ciou=si: cf. i. 69. 7. Supply ei)=nai with a)ciou=si and bou/letai.

p.hi: The Mytileneans are received into the Peloponnesian alliance and the Lacedaemonians prepare to invade Attica.

div2.p:
th
 e)s th
 *)attikh
 e)sbolh/n: cf. c. 13. § 4. The acc. placed first, though grammatically dependent on w(s poihso/menoi, is almost abs., and as to the invasion of Attica. Cf. ii. 62. 1; Soph. El. 1364. See on i. 32. 17. —

parou=si kata\ ta/xos . . . me/resin: parou=si is to be connected with i)e/nai and is dependent on e)/frazon (=e)ke/leuon), gave orders to present themselves speedily and march to the isthmus with a contingent of two thirds. So Lupus explains, N. Jahrbb. cxi. p. 166. Steup brackets parou=si. See App.—5.

e)/frazon: with dependent inf., also vi. 58. 7. Kühn. 473, 2. The impf. does not differ here essentially from the aorist. GMT. 57; Kr. Spr. 53, 2, 1. The original subj. oi( *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi is here limited to oi( *lakedaimo/nioi alone. See on c. 10. 16; i. 18. 21.—

toi=s du/o me/resi: i.e. with two thirds of their whole force capable of bearing arms. This was the regular contingent furnished by the Peloponnesian states for expeditions beyond their own borders. Cf. ii. 10. 6; 47. 2.—6.
o(/lkous: o)/rgana oi(=s ai( nh=es e(/lkontai, Schol.—7.

w(s u(peroi/sontes: sc. ta\s nau=s. Cf. c. 81. 3; iv. 8. 8; viii. 7. 7; Dio C. lxviii. 28 u(perenegkw\n ta\ ploi=a o(/lkois, Liv. xlii. 16 per Isthmi iugum navibus traductis Aeginam traiciunt. See Wachsmuth, Ant. Gr. ii. p. 336. Acc. to Strabo viii. 6. 22, the place where the transfer was made was called di/olkos.—9. e)pio/ntes: as fut. partic. co-ord. with u(peroi/sontes and dependent on w(s.
oi( a)/lloi cu/mmaxoi: since just above (ll. 4, 6) toi=s cumma/xois and au)toi/ are opposed, a)/lloi means here doubtless besides. See on i. 2. 12. G. 966, 2; H. 705.—11.

karpou=: collective sing., like Eng. fruit, as in iv. 84. 5; 88. 4; Hom. A 156. Cf. ka/lamos, ii. 76. 2; a)/mpelos, iv. 90. 9; multa fruge, Hor. Ep. i. 16. 10. Kr. Spr. 44, 1, 1; Kühn. 347, 1. The art. is omitted on acc. of the close connexion with cugkomidh=|. Since the summer was already advanced (see on date of the Olympia, c. 8. 5), karpo/s prob. refers here, as in iv. 84. 5, esp. to grapes. See A. Mommsen, Über d. Zeit der Olympien, p. 57 ff.—

e)n . . . h)=san: belongs to both the essentially different expressions, cugkomidh=| (of action) and a)rrwsti/a| (of disposition
of mind); with the former after the analogy of e)n paraskeuh=| ei)=nai, ii. 101. 10; with the latter after that of e)n taraxh=| kai\ fo/bw| ei)=nai, c. 79. 9.—
a)rrwsti/a|: i.e. a)proqumi/a|, despondency, as in vii. 47. 3. Cf. viii. 83. 7 a)rrwsto/teron.

p.hi: But seeing the counter preparations made by the Athenians they give up this plan and fit out a fleet for the protection of Lesbos.

div2.p: dia\ kata/gnwsin a)sqenei/as sfw=n: because they imputed weakness to them. kata/gnwsis of unfavourable judgment, as katagignw/skein (c. 45. 4; vi. 34. 51; vii. 51. 3; Hdt. vi. 97. 7, and freq.)<*>katafronei=n (viii. 8. 19 katafronh/santes tw=n *)aqhnai/wn a)dunami/an). sfw=n, too, stands under the influence of kata-, as in c. 45. 4. The Lacedaemonians had adopted the view of Athenian affairs expressed by the Mytileneans c. 13. § 3, 4.— 3.

mh\ kinou=ntes to\ e)pi\ *le/sbw| nautiko/n: see on c. 13. 18. That here, in spite of the evident reference to c. 13. § 3, 4, Thuc. does not include under mh\ kinou=ntes also the fleet sent around Peloponnesus, is to be explained on the ground that 18 of the 30 ships of Asopius had meanwhile returned (c. 7. § 3). See Steup, Rh. Mus. xxiv. p. 356. As the Mytileneans had said, c. 13. 21 h)\ u(ma=s ou)k a)munou=ntai e)piple/ontas h)\ a)p) a)mfote/rwn a)poxwrh/sontai, the words ou)k o)rqw=s e)gnw/kasin were already justified when the Athenians could, without recalling a ship from Lesbos, easily repel the Peloponnesian fleet.—5.

au)toi/ te . . . kai\ oi( me/toikoi: cf. i. 143. 4. Of citizens usually only the qh=tes, who were yiloi/ on land, served in the fleet (vi. 43. 10); in critical times members of the three upper classes, whose regular duty was hoplite service, might be pressed into service in the fleet (viii. 24. 12). See Bauer in Handbuch der klass. Alterthumsw. iv.^{1} p. 282; Schoemann, Gr. Ant. i. p. 448. The use of au)toi/ where the pentakosiome/dimnoi and i(ppei=s are excepted shows how much more numerous were the two lower classes, zeugi=tai and qh=tes. Regarding the census-classes, see Boeckh P. E.^{3} p. 579 ff.; Hermann Gr. Ant.^{6} i. § 68.— 7.

para\ to\n i)sqmo/n: along the coast of the isthmus. Const. with e)pi/deicin e)poiou=nto. They proposed by the mere display (e)pi/deicin) of a large fleet to show the enemy how hopeless was the execution of their plans. —

a)nagago/ntes: the unusual act. for a)nagago/menoi occurs also in the comp. a)ntana/gein, vii. 37. 18; 52. 4; viii. 38. 19; 83. 5. For the intr. use,
cf. a)polipei=n, c. 10. 8. Kühn. 373, 2a. —8.
th=s *peloponnh/sou: part. gen. depending on h(=|, as i. 46. 17; ii. 4. 22. —
dokoi/h: for the form here, as in ii. 79. 26; 100. 22; iv. 105. 9, instead of dokoi= of the Mss., see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 62. G. 737; H. 374 a.

o(rw=ntes polu\n to\n para/logon: seeing that their miscalculation was great. See on i. 65. 3. para/logos with polu/s also ii. 61. 14; 85. 6; me/gas, vii. 55. 4; o(/sos, i. 78. 3; tosou=tos, vii. 28. 17.—
ta\ u(po\ tw=n *lesbi/wn r(hqe/nta: cf. c. 13. § 3, 4. The form r(hqh=nai is about as common in Thuc. as lexqh=nai. Both together in c. 53. 14, 15.—10.
a)/pora nomi/zontes: regarding it as impracticable. For Thuc.'s freq. use of the neut. pl. of the adj., see on i. 7. 2. Kühn. 366.—11.
ou) parh=san: cf. c. 15. 10.—12.

kai\ h)gge/llonto kai/: the first kai/ is correl. of kai/ in l. 11, the second means also. Cf. c. 21. 10; 31. 8. h)gge/llonto in pers. const. with the partic., as in viii. 79. 21. GMT. 904; Kr. Spr. 56, 7, 3; Kühn. 482, 2. With inf., iv. 25. 23; viii. 94. 4. Oftener impers., as c. 110. 1; i. 114. 3; iv. 93. 7; 125. 2; v. 10. 7; vi. 45. 2.—
ai( peri\ th\n *pelopo/nnhson |
tria/konta |
nh=es: the 100 ships just mentioned, not the fleet under Asopius (c. 7. § 1), as clearly proved by Steup (Rh. Mus. xxiv. p. 355 ff.), who rightly strikes out tria/konta. See App.—13.
th\n perioiki/da au)tw=n: i.e. the district of the Lacedaemonian Perioeci in Laconia and Messenia.

u(/steron de\ . . . e)pipleu/sesqai: Thuc. mentions here, at the close of his account of the first unsuccessful attempt of the Lacedaemonians to aid the Lesbians, the preparations for the second expedition, made in the following summer (c. 25. § 1; 26. § 1). The regular course of the narrative is resumed at a)nexw/rhsan de\ kte(., u(/steron is common where such an anticipation in the narrative occurs. Cf. c. 7. 10; 34. 21; i. 64. 8; 87. 16; ii. 9. 7; 31. 15; 70. 20; 100. 4. —15.
o(/ ti pe/myousin: rel. with fut. indic. to express purpose, as in iv. 22. 2; viii. 1. 28. GMT. 565; Kr. Spr. 53, 7, 8; Kühn. 387, 4.—

e)ph/ggellon: imperabant. Cf. v. 47. 13; vii. 17. 2; viii. 108. 21. So perih/ggellon, ii. 85. 11; vii. 18. 27. The impfs. pareskeu/azon and e)ph/ggellon indicate gradual accomplishment, the aor. pros<*>tacan an ordinance which
took effect immediately.—16.

nau/arxon: the commander of the Lacedaemonian navy was elected for a definite period, prob. a year, and had unlimited power. Cf. Arist. Pol. ii. 6. (9) 22 h( nauarxi/a sxedo\n e(te/ra basilei/a kaqe/sthke. Cf. ii. 66. 6; 80. 12. —17.
o(\s e)/mellen e)pipleu/sesqai: i.e. to sail on them as commander. Cf. c. 76. 6; ii. 66. 4; iv. 11. 6; viii. 39. 5.
e)peidh\ kai\ e)kei/nous ei)=don: sc. a)nakexwrhko/tas. Kr. Spr. 56, 16; Kühn. 599, 2. Cf. i. 78. 10; 80. 2; ii. 11. 34; 86. 14; v. 80. 11; vii. 69. 3.

Reflections evoked by the number of Attie ships then at sea, and remarks upon the exhaustion of the Attic treasury. This chapter is seen upon close examination to be clearly the work of a glossator, as Steup first argued in Rh. Mus. xxiv. p. 350. See App.
o(/n: kata/ is omitted with the rel. after the prepositional phrase, as usual in Attic writers. G. 1025; H. 1007; Kühn. 451, 4; Kr. Spr. 51, 11, 1.—

e)/pleon: were afloat. This pregnant force seems not to occur elsewhere. plei=n is never without pred, modification: whether local, as e)s *ai)/gupton, i. 110. 11; e)k th=s *milh/tou e)s to\n *(ellh/sponton, viii. 108. 12; or qualitative, as a)/rista, i. 48. 12; vii. 31. 22; viii. 104. 11; a)/meinon, ii. 84. 12; ou) spoudh=|, iii. 49. 14; <*>u)=, vii. 23. 11.—

e)n toi=s plei=stai: the purely formulaic e)n toi=s with the sup. is explained by some as intensive (H. 652 a; Kr. Spr. 49, 10, 6 and on i. 6, 6; Kühn. 349^{b}, 7 i; Madv. Syntax^{2} 96, 2, and others); by others as restrictive (Arn. here and vii. 19. 19; L. Herbst, Philol. xvi. p. 345 ff.; C. Spormann, de ellipsis apud Hdt. et Thuc. usu, 1888. p. 29 sqq., and others). Acc. to the latter view, not absolute pre-eminence, but prominence among competitors is indieated, so that e)n toi=s plei=stai would mean, among the most. At any rate, that e)n toi=s plei=stai (fem. with e)n toi=s also c. 82. 2) should be followed by paraplh/siai de\ kai\ e)/ti plei/ous, is very peculiar. With the first view, it must be assumed that the author corrected himself; with the second, it still seems strange that to a number thus emphasized another still greater should be immediately opposed. Steup thinks no absolutely certain case of the restrictive e)n toi=s with sup. has been found. Of the cases cited by Herbst, e)n toi=s is not formulaie in viii. 68. 4, kai\ *qhrame/nhs e)n toi=s cugkatalu/ousi to\n dh=mon prw=tos h)=n, while in viii. 90. 4, *)ari/starxos, a)nh\r e)n toi=s ma/lista kai\ e)k plei/stou e)nanti/os tw=| dh/mw|, the phrase e)n toi=s ma/lista might well mean most of all. On the other hand, in i. 6. 6 and iii.
82. 2 the thought, he claims, suits the context far better with e)n toi=s intensive; and in vii. 19. 19 only the intensive meaning is admissible, since Thuc. could hardly have meant to compare the departure of the o(lka/des carrying hoplites to Sicily (vii. 19. 19) with that of the 25 Corinthian triremes (vii. 17. 14) sent to engage the attention of the Athenian fleet at Naupactus, esp. as the triremes were despatched in the winter, the o(lka/des the following summer. But Steup's objection to rendering e)n toi=s prw=toi (vii. 19. 19) ‘among the first’ does not seem conclusive, and certainly Aristarchus (viii. 90. 4) was, as Herbst and Jow. say, not the ‘very’ foremost among the subverters of democracy. If all the cases of e)n toi=s with the sup. be compared, it is hard to escape Jow.'s conclusion, that the formula is sometimes restrictive, as in vii. 24. 12; viii. 90. 4; sometimes intensive, as in c. 81. 2 (cf. c. 85. 2); Plato Symp. 178 b.—2.

e)nergoi\ ka/llei: e)nergo/s is not elsewhere used of ships, and both words occur only here in Thucydides. Goell., Arn., and Jow. explain, ‘effective by their fine condition’; Bl., ‘effective and handsome’ (by their handsomeness); Sheppard, ‘on active service in handsome trim.’ Peile takes ka/llei as dat. consilii, for display. Of the emendations proposed—by Herbst ka/lw|s, St. kai\ a)/llh|, v. H. a)/llai a)/llh| —none is satisfactory.—3.
paraplh/siai de\ kai\ e)/ti plei/ous: for similar expressions, see on vii. 19. 8. See App.

th/n te ga\r . . . diako/sioi kai\ penth/konta: describes the disposition of the Attic fleet a)rxome/nou tou= pole/mou, which strangely alone of the two armaments here compared is more fully discussed. This follows necessarily from l. 15, kai\ nh=es tosau=tai dh\ plei=stai eplhrw/qhsan, which can only refer to the 250 ships of For if 250 was the highest number reached, this, acc. to 1. 3, paraplh/siai de\ kai\ e)/ti plei/ous a)rxome/nou tou= pole/mou, must refer to the first year of the war. Besides, the reader would be more likely to reckon for himself the number of ships of the summer under consideration (428) than that of 431 B.C. Further the words in l. 6 peri\ *potei/daian kai\ e)n toi=s a)/llois xwri/ois are unintelligible, if § 2 refers to the year 428.—5.

xwri\s de/: besides, abs., without expressed or easily supplied predicate. In the passages cited by St. as parallel (Plato Euthyd. 289 c.; Soph. O. C. 808), xwri/s means of a different kind, not besides. In Thuc. xwri\s de/ either has its own verb (ii. 31. 11),
or the pred. of the preceding clause belongs also to it (i. 61. 15; ii. 97. 16; vi. 31. 29), or is to be supplied with it (ii. 13. 29; 31. 13). Here h)=san cannot be supplied from the preceding clause, since there it means ‘chanced to be.‘—
ai( peri\ . . . xwri/ois: see App.—7.

tou=to: must refer grammatically to the number of ships either of 431 or 428 B.C. But as u(panali/skein, gradually consume (ll. 8, 14), suits neither of these cases, the author of the chapter must have meant to indicate by tou=to “this fitting out of such large armaments,”—a loose form of expression without parallel in Thuc. Besides, there seem to have been in the summer of 429 B.C., if one excepts the ships which may have remained on the Thracian coast after the capture of Potidaea, as well as the few at stations like Salamis and Atalante, only 40 Attie ships at sea at one time (ii. 80. 21; 85. 17).—

u(panh/lwse: gradually consumed. The word is found in Thuc. only here and l. 14 below. With neut. subj., as a)panali/skein, vii. 11. 13. Cf. c. 13. 33 u(f airou=ntes, i. 77. 23 u(pedei/cate. On the augment see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 60; Meisterhans,^{2} p. 137.

meta\ *hoteidai/as: Potidaea had been already for a year and a half again in the possession of the Athenians (ii. 70). But still more strange is the manner in which Potidaea is here set over against the fitting out of large naval armaments, since Potidaea itself had been besieged by a fleet (i. 64. § 3). The costs of this siege had been 2000 talents (ii. 70. § 2). Besides, the building of ships had doubtless entailed considerable expense.—

di/draxmoi: i.e. one drachma each for the hoplite and for his attendant, more than usual, since the average daily pay of a hoplite was 4 obols. Cf. vii. 27. 7. See Boeckh P. E. p. 373; Herm. Gr. Ant. i.^{6} § 112. The word is found here only in Thuc., and seldom elsewhere.—10.

e)frou/roun: obsidebant, as periefrourou=nto, c. 21. 15. Cf. Arr. Anab. i. 7. 10; ii. 1. 4; iv. 3. 4; 5. 2; and Eur. Or. 760 fulasso/mesqa frouri/oisi pantaxh=|. Elsewhere in Thuc., to garrison or guard, as i. 103. 15; 107. 16; iv. 1. 16; v. 33. 6, 10; 35. 28; 64. 12; vii. 60. 11. In the passage cited by Pp. and others, i. 64. 2, 4, there is no reason why both e)frou/roun and frourei=n may not be intr., keep watch (cf. c. 90. 11; ii. 80. 22; 83. 7; iv. 24. 2; 66. 20). —
