au(tw=|: for sing, after preceding plur., cf. i. 120. 20 a)ndrw=n swfro/nwn . . . h(do/menon. Otherwise such a const. is without parallel in Thuc., though common in Hdt. Cf. Plato Prot. 324 a ou)dei\s kola/zei tou\s a)dikou=ntas . . . <*>ou/ion e(/nela, o(/<*>i h)di/lhoen. Kr. Spr.
61, 4, 1.—
u(phre/th|: as in vi. 102. 10. Each Athenian hoplite was accompanied by an attendant, qera/pwn, just as each Spartan by a Helot. Cf. iv. 16. 9.—

e)la/mbane: sc. o(pli/ths e(/kastos, to be supplied from di/draxmoi o(pli=tai. e(/kastos e)la/mbanon was to be expected (cf. vii. 27. 8). The omission of e(/kastos is without parallel in Thuc., or even in Hdt.—11.
trisxi/lioi kte(.: see App.—12.
diepolio/rkhsan: a(/pac ei)rhme/non. Schol. e)/meinan e(/ws a(lw/sews th=s po/lews poliorkou=ntes.— e(cako/sioi de\ kai\ xi/lioi kte(.: cf. i. 64. 8; 65. 13, and see on ii. 31. 11.— 13.
to\n au)to\n misqo/n: i.e. a drachma per man, since the seamen had no qera/pontes. This was double the usual pay of seamen. Cf. vi. 31. 19; viii. 45. 11, and see Boeckh, P. E. p. 377. —
e)/feron; Schol. e)la/mbanon, as vi. 24. 13; viii. 97. 7.
dh/: as l. 2 with the sup., so here with the emphatic tosau=tai. Cf. i. 33. 13; ii. 17. 17; 77. 7.—
plei=stai: pred., as the largest number, i.e. 250.

After the Mytileneans fail in the attack on Methymna, and the Methymneans, on the other hand, are repulsed with loss from Antissa, the Athenians send reinforcements under Paches to Lesbos and invest Mytilene with a wall. Beginning of the winter 428-427 B.C.
*mutilhnai=oi de/: opp. to oi( de\ *lakedaimo/nioi, c. 16. 9, as well as to oi( *)aqhnai=oi, c. 16. 18, and resumes the narrative interrupted at c. 6 fin. —
o(/n: see on c. 17. 1.—2.
peri\ to\n i)sqmo/n: cf. c. 15. 5 to 16. 14.—
e)pi\ *mh/qumnan: cf. c. 2. 2, 9.—
w(s prodidome/nhn: pres. partic. because the betrayal was, as they thought, then being agitated or prepared for. Kühn. 382, 6 b.—3.

oi( e)pi/kouroi: prob. mercenaries, mention of whom is made c. 2. 8. The term, which meant originally allies, was chiefly applied, prob. cuphemistically, to hired soldiers in the service of despots or oligarchical factions. See on i. 115. 18.—4.
ou) prouxw/rei: impers., as in i. 109. 7; ii. 56. 12; iv. 59. 16. See on i. 109. 7.—5.

e)p) *)anti/sshs kai\ *pu/rras kai\ *)ere/sou: which, though already siding with
the Mytileneans, were to be secured against overtures of the democratic party.—6.
katasthsa/menoi: with pred. adj. (bebaio/tera), as i. 118. 8.— 7.
kratu/nantes: a poetic word; act., also i. 69. 2; mid., c. 82. 40; iv. 52. 13; 114. 10. In tragedy it = kratei=n.— tei/xh: without article, see on c. 3. 16.
e)stra/teusan de/: emphatic repetition of the verb, l. 3 (e)panafora/). See on i. 28. 8. A favourite usage of Hdt.—9.
e)kbohqei/as: a sortie, found only here; corresponding to e)kbohqei=n, i. 105. 29; Hdt. ix. 26. 11, and freq. in late writers.—10.

plhge/ntes: mega/lws nikhqe/ntes, Schol. Used only in aor. or pf. pass. and always in sense of a severe defeat. Cf. iv. 108. 25; v. 14. 5; viii. 38. 7; Hdt. v. 120. 7; viii. 130. 10; Soph. O. C. 605; Eur. Rhes. 867.—
tw=n e)pikou/rwn: i.e. those whom the Mytileneans had left there as a garrison, as indicated in katasthsa/menoi . . . bebaio/tera above. —11.
polloi/, oi( loipoi/: const. as in c. 13. 17.

tau=ta: explained by the two following partic. clauses, which are construed with punqano/menoi, as if tau=ta had not preceded. Kühn. 469, 3 c. Cf. Soph. Phil. 1355 tw=s tau=t) e)canasxh/sesqe, toi=sin *)atre/ws e)me\ cuno/nta paisi/n, Ar. Nub. 380 touti/ m) e)lelh/qein, o( *zeu\s ou)k w)/n.—13. th=s gh=s kratou=ntas: cf. c. 6. 8.—14.
ei)/rgein: to shut in the Mytileneans. Cf. —

peri\ to\ fqino/pwron h)/dh a)rxo/menon: cf. c. 100. 6, and see on ii. 31. l. meto/pwron, in vii. 79. 10; viii. 108. 9, seems to be synonymous with fqino/pwron.—15. xili/ous o(pli/tas: cf. Diod. xii. 85. The number of the fleet is not given here, because the object of the expedition is to strengthen the land force, not the fleet.
au)tere/tai: pred. The unusual fact that hoplites here served at the oar, evidently for economieal reasons (cf. c. 19. § 1), is esp. emphasized. Cf. i. 10. 26; vi. 91. 15.—17.

tai: Cl. explains ‘to the historical presents corresponds the pf. e)gkatw|kodo/mhtai, which seems to be used with reference to the forts (frou/ria) first built at suitable points (e)pi\ karterw=n), in which the troops found safety while resting, as well as at night: “they proceed to invest the city with a single wall, and already at strong points in the circuit of the wall forts have been built in.” Hence the changes proposed, e)gkatw|kodo/mhto (Haase), e)gkatoikodomei=tai (Bl.), e)gkat w|kodomh/qh (Bk.), e)gkatw|kodo/mhsan (Kr.) are unnecessary.’ Arn. compares Caes. Bell. Civ. iii. 37 erant enim circum castra Pompeii permulti editi atque asperi colles; hos primum praesidiis tenuit, castellaque ibi communiit; inde ut loci cuiusque natura ferebat, ex castello in castellum producta munitione, circumvallare Pompeium instituit. But Steup, who contends that the frou/ria were constructed at the same time with the wall and built in after the manner of the pu/rgoi in the double wall around Plataea (c. 21. 8), insists that the pf. is out of place here, since a mere statement of an occurrence was to be made, and that the aor. or impf. is required (cf. c. 7. 11; 70. 28 74. 3).—
e)n ku/klw|: also c. 74. 8; elsewhere without e)n, i. 106. 6; ii. 78. 4; 84. 3, etc.—18.
e)/stin oi(=: so most editt. read; Bk. and Bl., e)/stin h(=| with five Mss.—
e)pi\ tw=n karterw=n: cf. c. 110. 7; ii. 100. 3.
kai\ . . . ei)/rgeto: cf. the conclusion of the account of the siege of Potidaea, i. 64. § 3.—
kata\ kra/tos: applied to any energetic use of force, as in i. 64. 14, and freq.—20.
kai\ e)k gh=s kai\ e)k qala/sshs ei)/rgeto: what had been already in part effected (c. 6. 7) is now completed. Cf. viii. 40. 6.
At Athens an extraordinary war tax is levied for the first time. Lysicles, sent out to Caria to collect taxes, is killed there.

kai\ au)toi/: et ipsi, proleptic, referring to the demands made also upon the allies, kai\ e)pi\ tou\s cumma/xous. —e)sfora/n: i.e. the extraordinary war tax often levied in later times. See Boeckh, P. E. p. 612, who says, doubtless correctly, that to/te prw=ton (cf. i. 96. 6; ii. 56. 6) ‘does not mean merely the first property tax levied in the Peloponnesian war, but the first absolutely.’—3.
lanta: appos. to e)sfora/n. Cf. i. 96. 6; ii. 15. 17.—4.

a)rgurolo/gous nau=s: cf. iv. 50. 2; 75. 3. Cl. thinks that the ships were sent out to collect back tribute (see Köhler, Abh. der Berl. Akad. 1869, p. 132 f.), and that the unusual number of strathgoi/ (5 with 12 ships) was due to the fact that this duty would have to be performed at different points. But St. justly insists that kai\ au)toi\ e)senegko/ntes indicates that the same kind of extraordinary tax (e)sfora/) was levied on both citizens and allies.—

*lusikle/a: doubtless the demagogue ridieuled in Ar. Eq. 132 as probatopw/lhs, who married Aspasia after Pericles's death. See Plut. Per. 24; also Curtius, Hist. of Gr. iii. p. 90, and Ad. Schmidt, das Perikl. Zeitalter i. p. 178 ff.

a)/lla h)rgurolo/gei: laid other regions under contribution. The accus. as in ii. 69. 7; viii. 3. 2. The like issue of an expedition sent to the neighbouring coast, as described in ii. 69, shows with what bitterness the half barbarian inhabitants of these regions resisted the collection of the Athenian tribute.—6.
th=s *kari/as e)k *muou=ntos: order as in c. 89. 7; 105. 9; i. 100. 15.—7.
tou= *sandi/ou lo/fou: Meineke (Herm. iii. p. 363) conjectures *sa/ndios (nom. *sa/ndis,—see on i. 64. 10).—8.

*)anaiitw=n: without doubt those mentioned c. 32. 4 as *sami/wn tw=n e)c *)anai/wn, namely those of the oligarchical party, who after the subjugation of Samos (i. 117. § 3) settled on the opposite coast. Cf. iv. 75. 7 ta\ *)/anaia e)pi\ th=| *sa/mw|, and viii. 19. 3. These were always with the enemies of Athens.—

a)/llhs: besides. Cf. c. 112. 7 *dhmosqe/nhs . . . kai\ to\ a)/llo straten/ma. See on i. 2. 12; 128. 21. G. 966, 2; H. 705; Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 11. Cf. Xen. Cyrop. vi. 4. 1; Tac. Hist. iv. 56 legatis . . . interfectis ceterum vulgus facile accessurum.

The beleaguered Plataeans determine upon a sortie and make preparations to that end. The events of this and the following chapters are briefly narrated also by Pseudo-Dem. lix. 103; Polyaen. vi. 19. § 2, 3; Diod. xii. 56.
e)/ti . . . *boiwtw=n: cf. ii. 78. § 2 ff. —3.

si/tw| e)pilipo/nti: partic. in pred.
position in the sense of the verbal subst., = th=| e)pilei/yei tou= si/tou. Cf. c. 29. 9.—4.
timwri/as: = bohqei/as in Thuc. (i. 25. 2, 11; 38. 15; 58. 5; 69. 30, etc.) and Hdt. (iii. 148. 14; vii. 169. 11); later, ‘vengeance.’— 5.

e)pibouleu/ousin: in this signification only here in Thuc. with inf. (e)celqei=n), freq. with verbal subst. (a)poxw/rhsin, c. 109. 21; kata/lusin th=| turanni/di, vi. 54. 15; to\n e)/kploun, vii. 51. 5). For other examples with the inf., cf. Hdt. i. 24. 8; Plato Symp. 203 b; and see Herbst on Xen. Sympos. 4. 52, and Stallbaum on Plato Prot. 343 c.—
*)aqhnai/wn oi( cumpoliorkou/menoi: cf. ii. 6. § 4; 78. § 3. —7.
bia/sasqai: ‘to force their way through,’ abs. in const., as in vii. 67. 24; 79. 8.—
e)shghsame/nou th\n pei=ran: having suggested the attempt. e)shgei=sqai = auctorem esse, also iv. 76. 8; vi. 90. 3; 99. 7; vii. 73. 5. —8.
a)ndro\s ma/ntews: for the subst. indicating vocation used as adj., see on i. 115. 9; Kr. Spr. 57, 1, 1; Kühn. 405, 1. Soothsayers in the army are mentioned also Hdt. ix. 37; Xen. Hell. ii. 4. 19.—9.

*eu)pompidou: so with Bk. (after Palat.) in preference to the clearly incorrect *eu)polpi/dou (of the remaining better Mss.), as also to *eu)molpi/dou (of inferior Mss.), which Pp. prefers. The name occurs nowhere else, but its very rareness made it more likely to be miscopied.—

o(\s kai\ e)strath/gei: who was also strategus, seems to indicate that the attitude of Eupompidas was of esp. importance to the plan of the Plataeans. A similar plan of the strategus Aristeus during the siege of Potidaea (i. 65. § 1) was unsuccessful. Cf. also viii. 51. 8; 98. 4. Cl.'s explanation, ‘who also directed the execution’ of the plan, will not do, since, acc. to c. 22. 1, Eupompidas was not alone in the direction of the scheme. Besides, such an anticipation in the narrative would require the aor. (cf. i. 14. 15).

a)pw/knhsan: as in c. 30. 12 (cf. vi. 92. 23; viii. 12. 2), with ki/ndunon as obj., which belongs also with me/gan h(ghsa/menoi. Bl. compares Dem. xviii. 197 ou)de/na ki/ndunon o)knh/sas i)/dion, and the imitation of Procopius B. G. i., p. 180, 11 tw=n de\ i)o/ntwn oi( u(pe\r h(/misu, katwrrwdhko/tes to\n ki/ndunon, o)pi/sw a)pekomi/zonto. St. takes a)pw/knhsan as abs., as in c. 55. 10; iv. 11. 16; vii. 21. 23, supplying from above e)celqei=n kai\ u(<*> erbh=nai ta\ tei/xh.—pws: with omission
of unnecessary details.—11.

e)s a)/ndras diakosi/ous kai\ ei)/kosi ma/lista: about two hundred and twenty, the prepositional phrase representing the subject, as in c. 85. 5; the object, in c. 111. 17; 114. 22; iv. 80. 17; v. 6. 22; vii. 30. 16. Kühn. 432, 1; Kr. Spr. 60, 8, 1. Though Arn. be right in saying that in the examples collected by Matth., Gr. Gr. 298, 1, e)s = up to, ma/lista certainly gives here the signification about. See on c. 21. 4.— 12.
e)ne/meinan: with dat. in figurative sense also viii. 23. 24.—
e)qelontai/: the resolution adopted by the whole had therefore been annulled.
e)poih/santo: the mid., as with nau=s, i. 14. 14; viii. 56. 21; staurw/mata, vi. 74. 12.—
i)/sas: sc. to\ mh=kos. Cf. vii. 42. 10; viii. 10. 8, and freq., where the term denoting number is omitted.—

cunemetrh/santo: sc. ta\s kli/makas, with Heilm. (cf. l. 20), rather than to\ tei=xos (Pp.). cun- indicates the combination of particulars toward a result, as cuntekmhra/menoi, ii. 76. 5. Cf. Hdt. iv. 158. 6 cummetrhsa/menoi th\n w(/rhn th=s h(me/ras. As further instances of the same expedient adopted under similar cireumstances, Bl. cites Procop. B. G. i. 21; Polyaen. vii. 10. 5; Liv. xxv. 23.—14.
tai=s e)pibolai=s: by the layers, instrum. dative. G. 1181; H. 776; Kühn. 425, 6.—15.

ou)k e)calhlimme/non: ‘not whitewashed, a term found in Proeop. de Aedif. p. 4, 22 and 27, 31; Levit. xiv. 42, 43, and 48. Thus Pollux vii. 124 tita/nw| xri/ein, a)lei/fein, e)palei/fein, katalei/fein, e)calei/fein. And so Eustathius explains a)lei/fein toi=xon by to\ koni/a| xri/ein. Hence it appears that the translators have here wrongly rendered e)calhlimme/non, “plastered over.”’ Bl.—

h)riqmou=nto de\ polloi\ . . . kai\ e)/mellon: paratactic connexion, in effect = e)pei\ polloi\ h)riqmou=nto, e)/mellon kte(.; while, on the other hand, e)/mellon oi( me/n tines a(marth/sesqai, oi( de\ plei/ous teu/cesqai = kai\ ei) oi( me/n tines h(ma/rtanon, o(/mws oi( plei/ous teu/cesqai e)/mellon. The rare mid. h)riqmou=nto does not differ in meaning from the act., as in Plato Phaedr. 270d. For other examples, see Steph. Thes. s.v. Kr. Spr. 52, 8, 4; Kühn. 375, 4.—16.
e)/mellon: see on c. 11. 4; i. 107. 13.—19.

r(a|di/ws kaqorwme/nou e)s o(\ e)bou/lonto tou= tei/xous: sc. kaqora=n. Cf. Hdt. v. 35. 17 katide/sqai e)s th\n
kefalh/n. kaqorwme/nou is grammatically construed with tou= tei/xous, though logically the subj. is e)s o(\ e)bou/lonto tou= tei/xous. The sense of the passage (a(/ma ou) polu\ a)pe/xontes . . . tou= tei/xous) seems to be: “as they were not far off, but easily looked down upon the part of the wall which they wished to see.” It is admissible to supply o(ra=n from kaqorwme/nou. Cf. Eur. Alc. 1065 dokw= ga\r au)th\n ei)sorw=n gunai=x) o(ra=n. For the const. o(ra=n e)/s ti, cf. Dem. vi. 10 ei)s ta\ paro/nta o(rw=n, Aesch. Suppl. 110 i)de/sqw ei)s u(/brin, Eur. Peliad. frg. 7 o(rw=si d' oi( dido/ntes ei)s ta\ xrh/mata, Paus. i. 24. 2 e)s au)tou\s kaiome/nous o(ra=|. The part of the wall referred to is, of course, h(=| e)/tuxe pro\s sfa=s ou)k e)calhlimme/non (l. 15). See App.
th\n cumme/trhsin . . . e)/labon: periphrasis, as in Plut. Aem. Paul. 15 meqo/dw| kai\ di) o)rga/nwn ei)lhfe/nai dokei= th\n me/trhsin. For similar periphrases, cf. Soph. Aj. 345; Phil. 536. —21.

th=s pli/nqou: the sing. used collectively, as to\n a)ristero\n po/da, c. 22. 11; th=s kefalh=s, ii. 49. 5; th=s new/s, vii. 62. 14; 65. 7. One might infer from this passage that one thickness of bricks prevailed at that time in Greece, at any rate, in Boeotia.—
ei)ka/santes: aor. partic., synchronous with e)/labon. Cf. ii. 68. 10. Kr. Spr. 53, 6, 8.

p.hi: Description of the wall of circumvallation and of the manner of guarding it.

div2.p: du/o tou\s peribo/lous: the pred. position of du/o perhaps emphasizes the special precaution against an attack also from without.—
pro\s *plataiw=n: on the side toward Plataea. Kr. Spr. 68, 37, 1. Cf. iv. 31. 5; 100. 15; 130. 2.—4.
ma/lista: as used with statements of quantity implies approximation, though the reality may be more or less. Cf. c. 109. 9; 113. 10; i. 13. 11.

to\ ou)=n metacu\ tou=to, oi( e(kkai/deka po/des . . . w)|kodo/mhto: this interval, the 16 feet, had been buill up as dwelling-places assigned severally to the guards. oi)kh/mata is pred., though Thuc. seems, by a sort of anacoluthon, to have construed w)|kodo/mhto rather with it than with to\ metacu\ tou=to, as the following cunexh= shows. Cl., who thinks the irregularity is caused by the insertion of oi( e(kkai/deka po/des, explains oi)kh/mata as the real subj. of both members, with to\ metacu\ tou=to as adv. modifier. St. strikes out, with v. H. and Widmann, oi( e(kkai/deka po/des, and explains oi)kh/mata dianenhme/na as accus., after the analogy
of o)/noma o)noma/zesqai, i. 122. 25. Bl. cites a case of appos. similar to oi( e(kkai/deka po/des from App. Bell. Civ. iv. 106 to\ de\ me/son tw=n lo/fwn, ta\ o)ktw\ sta/dia, di/odos h)=n.—6. dianenhme/na: cf. ii. 17. 18, where the more unusual katanei/masqai is used.—

kai\ h)=n cunexh=: sc. ta\ oi)kh/mata, though Steup thinks this incompatible with the rest of the sent., and renders, it was continuous (i.e. the peri/boloi were connected), the neut. pl. being indef., as in i. 7. 2; 8. 8; 102. 6.

dia\ de/ka e)pa/lcewn: at intervals of ten battlements, i.e. there were ten battlements or turrets between each two of the greater towers. See Steph. Thes. s. v. dia/. G. 1206, 1 c; H. 795, 1 e; Külm. 434, i. 1 b; Kr. Spr. 68, 22, 3. Cf. di) o)li/gou, l. 13; di<*>e/xontes, c. 22. 8.—8.

i)soplatei=s: rare word for i)/soi to\ pla/tos. Thuc. is fond of compounds in i)so- (i)sodi/aitos, i)soki/ndunos, i)so/nomos, i)sopalh/s, i)soplhqh/s, i)so/rropos, i)so/yhfos). Cf. Aesch. Agam. 1444, 1471.—9.

dih/kontes e)/s te to\ e)/sw . . . kai\ to\ e)/cw: i.e. the towers united the two walls as if by a bridge. The first kai/ means and, the second also. See on c. 16. 12; 31. 8. e)s is omitted before to\ e)/cw with nearly all the Mss. Kühn. 451, 2. See on i. 6. 20; vi. 78. 4. oi( au)toi/, which is pred., stands in the second clause, as in i. 23. 13, not in the first, as in c. 47. 18; ii. 40. 12; iv. 17. 3. It seems unnecessary to omit either the first kai/ with L. Herbst (Philol. xxiv. p. 681), or kai\ oi( au)toi/ with Cobet. —10.

w(/ste pa/rodon mh\ ei)=nai para\ pu/rgon: so that it was impossible to pass by a tower, i.e. either on the inner or on the outer side. ei)=nai in pregnant sense, = u(pa/rxein, as often, particularly after a neg. See on i. 2. 5. para\ pu/rgon is bracketed by St., following Naber (in v. H.'s Stud. Thuc. p. 39). But it makes the sense clearer, and the sing. before di) au)tw=n is used collectively.—11.
dih=|san: sc. oi( fu/lakes, i.e. in going from one metapu/rgion to another. For change from inf. to finite verb after w(/ste, see GMT. 603.

xeimw\n notero/s: the adj. is not pred., but forms with xeimw/n a single conception, rain-storm. Schol. di/ugros kai\ u(eto\n e)/xwn. The same idea is expressed in c. 22. 2 by xeime/rion u(/dati kai\ a)ne/mw|. xeimw/n is so used iv. 6. 6; 103. 5.—13.

o)/ntwn: as usual in supplementary causal clauses, placed
first. Cf. c. 2. 9; i. 124. 4.—
di) o)li/gou: at a little distance, as c. 43. 14; ii. 89. 41; vii. 71. 9.—14.
periefrourou=nto: found only here in Thuc., and elsewhere only in late writers, e.g. Dio C. x See on c. 17. 10.
The 220 Plataeans, who persist in their purpose, scale on a rainy night the encompassing wall.
pareskeu/asto: the impers. pass., rarer in Greek than in Latin. See on i. 46. 1. G. 1240, 2; H. 602; Kr. Spr. 61, 5, 6; Kühn. 378, N. 2.—

thrh/santes . . . a)se/lhnon: thrh/santes also i. 65. 4; iv. 27. 10; vi. 2. 21; as fula/cantes, ii. 3. 17; vii. 83. 15. Cf. Dion. H. Ant. iii. 65. 2 fula/cantes nu/kta xeime/rion u(/dasi kai\ a)ne/mw|, Dio C. lxxxi. 12 e)th/rhse nu/kta a)se/lhnon kai\ u(etw=| la/brw| brontai=s te xeime/rion. For other imitations see Bl.'s translation (note). The rain was mixed with snow, as shown by a)ne/mw| u(poneifome/nh, c. 23. 25.—2.
e)ch=|san: impf. of the act in progress, as i. 26. 23; 49. 2, the details of the execution being expressed by aors. die/bhsan (3), prose/meican (4).—3.
oi(/per kai\ th=s pei/ras ai)/tioi h)=san: see on c. 20. 7, 9.—4.
h(\ periei=xen au)tou/s: i.e. the inner ditch next to the besieged.—
prose/meican tw=| tei/xei: they reached the foot of the wall. prose/meican of approach also c. 31. 12; i. 46. 8; vi. 104. 19. On the form see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 39; Meisterhans, p. 144.—6.
a)na\ to\ skoteino\n me/n: in the darkness. a)na/ of local extension also iv. 72. 11 (Kühn. 433, 1, 2); not found elsewhere in Thucydides. For position of me/n, see Kühn. 528, 1.—

ou) proido/ntwn, ou) katakousa/ntwn: without obj., in the general sense of see and hear. The gens. abs. after preceding accus. (tou\s fu/lakas), on account of the independent importance of the causes expressed. GMT. 850; H. 972 d; Kr. Spr. 47, 4, 2; Kühn. 494 b. Cf. c. 13. 30; i. 114. 2.—

au)tw=n: sc. tw=n fula/kwn.—yo/fw| tw=|: this order, by which stress is thrown on the attribute, is freq. in Thuc. See on i. 1. 6. The dat. depends on a)ntipatagou=ntos, which is found only here in Thuc.; elsewhere only in late writers, e.g. Arr. Anab. v. 12. 3; Dio C. xlviii. 48; Plut. Mor. 1000 b.
die/xontes polu/: cf. ii. 81. 14. The measure of polu/ here of course must not be supposed greater than necessity demanded.—9.
ta\ o(/pla: placed for emphasis between o(/pws and mh/. Cf. viii. 45. 15.—10.
eu)stalei=s th=| o(pli/sei: = yiloi/, 14, 17. kou/fhn o(/plisin peribeblhme/noi, Schol. Cf. Aesch. Pers. 797 eu)stalh= sto/lon. The armour was of various sorts, acc. to § 3.—

to
 a)ristero
 po/da mo/non . . . pro\s to
 phlo/n: the emphasis seems to be on mo/non, i.e. only the left foot was shod, the right being bare to prevent slipping in the mud. Cf. Sall. Jug. 94, Ceterum illi, qui escensuri erant, praedocti ab duce, arma ornatumque mutaverant, capite atque pedibus nudis, uti prospectus nisusque per saxa facilius foret. Arnold quotes from Scott's Lay of Last Minstrel iv. 8, “Each better knee was bared to aid The warrior in the escalade.” But many editt. think the meaning is, that the left foot was shod for security against slipping, the right unshod dia\ koufo/thta, as the Schol. explains. See App.

kata\ . . . prose/misgon pro\s ta\s e)pa/lceis: what is summarily stated at l. 5 in the aor. is here repeated, with somewhat more exact designation of the point of attack, in the impf., which tense prevails as far as e)/mellon, With prose/misgon pro\s ta\s e)pa/lceis, cf. vii. 22. 8 pro\s ta\s e)nto\s prosmei=cai. But see App.—13.
ei)do/tes o(/ti e)rh=moi/ ei)si: sc. on account of the nu\c xeime/rios, as explained c. 21. § 4. —
prw=ton me\n . . . (19)
e)/feron: see App.—14.
prose/qesan, (16)

a)ne/bh: these two particular facts alone of the whole account are expressed by the aorist. Arn. says, ‘The transition from painting a seene to stating a fact is marked by the variation of tense from a)ne/bainon to a)ne/bh; the first represents the party in the very act of mounting the wall, the second records the fact that their commander was the first man who did mount it.’ —
e)/peita, (17)
e)/peita: after prw=ton me/n, cf. Xen. Cyrop. i. 3. 14.—

cu\n cifidi/w| kai\ qw/raki: for the collective sing., see Kr. Spr. 44, 1, 7. Cf. ii. 70. 14. For the use of cu/n, which is chiefly poetic, seldom occurring in Attie prose except in Xen., see G.
1217; Kühn. 431, 2.—16.
meta\ de\ au)to\n oi( e(po/menoi: i.e. Ammeas and his eleven companions, who were to attack in two squads of six each the two nearest towers.—20.
ei)=en: for the form, see on c. 42. 22. St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 62.
h)/|sqonto: without expressed obj. as i. 95. 21; 118. 9, etc.—
oi( e)k tw=n pu/rgwn fu/lakes: for the attraction of the prep., see on c. 5. 1 and i. 8. 9. —23.

dou=pon: Cl. has adopted this reading of one Ms. (A), instead of the vulg. yo/fon, with Bk., Goell., and St., on the ground that it is not only the more appropriate, but also the rarer word, and hence rather to be attributed to Thuc. than to the copyist. It is used chiefly in poetry, but occurs in Xen. Anab. ii. 2. 19. But the vulg. seems to be supported by the imitations which Bl. cites from Dio C. (xliii. 11 and xliv. 17), where yo/fon is read.

to\ de\ strato/pedon e)pi\ to\ tei=xos w(/rmhsen: i.e. the garrison, which had gone into shelter from the rain, now hastened each to his own station on the wall. strato/pedon, troops, without reference to any fixed array, as in ii. 25. 9, and freq.—25.
to\ deino/n: the danger. Cf. 11; 84. 8; 120. 13.—
skoteinh=s nukto\s . . . o)/ntos: the partic. belongs to both substs., skoteinh=s nukto/s being treated as a single word.—26.

tw=n *plataiw=n: the part. gen. in the very unusual position between the art. and partic., as in c. 36. 19; 65. 14; i. 126. 33; vi. 102. 1. See Merriam, Trans. Am. Philol. Assoc. 1882, p. 45. Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 11. —27.

prose/ballon: so Steup reads (for the vulg. prose/balon), with two Mss. (C and f), as being more natural in describing an event that was not momentary, and in accordance with the following impfs. Cf. esp. parani=sxon, 1.35.—28.

e)k tou)/mpalin h)/: from
the opposite side. e)/mpalin h)/ also in Hdt. i. 207. 13; ix. 56. 8. h)/ as in tou)nanti/on h)/, vi. 68. 14; vii. 80. 6; Plato Gorg. 481 c.—29.
u(pere/bainon: with the corresponding oi( u(perbai/nontes (c. 23. 1), of what was at that time going on.—
pro\s au)tou\s to\n nou=n e)/xoien: give attention to them. Cf. vii. 19. 32; viii. 8. 16.
e)qorubou=nto: were in great exeitement. Cf. v. 65. 28.
kata\ xw/ran: at their post. Cf. i. 28. 18. —31.

e)k th=s au(tw=n fulakh=s: from the post assigned to each. au(tw=n, or <*>(autw=n, is both by position and emphasis preferable to au)tw=n of most of the Mss.; for as the ou)dei/s clause is only the complement of kata\ xw/ran me/nontes, the pl. au(tw=n refers back to the subj. of e)qorubou=nto. G. 960; H. 673b. Cf. c. 91. 6; viii. 48. 28. St. reads au)tw=n (intensive). Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 12.—
e)n a)po/rw| h)=san ei)ka/sai to\ gigno/menon: they were at a loss to conjecture what was going on. Cf. i. 25. 2 e)n a)po/rw| ei)/xonto qe/sqai to\ paro/n.

oi( triako/sioi: for the art., see on c. 3. 18. The number is a favourite one for a corps of picked men, esp. among the Lacedaemonians. See Trieber, N. Jahrbb. ciii. p. 443 ff. Cf. ii. 25. 17; iv. 70. 14; 125. 19. —33.
e)te/takto: impers., as in c. 61. 12, and with dat. and inf., as i. 19. 6; v. 31. 10 (Kr., e)pete/takto; Cobet, prosete/takto).—

e)xw/roun e)/cw tou= tei/xous pro\s th\n boh/n: since the towers from which the ery of alarm came were, as all the rest, i)soplatei=s tw=| tei/xei (c. 21. 9), one could not know whether the danger was from the eity or from without; but under the circumstances it was natural to think first of danger from without, i.e. from Athens. And so the 300, as well as the guards of the remaining towers, left the Plataeans, who were crossing, for the time unmolested. e)xw/roun pro\s th\n boh/n, i.e. to the place whence the ery came, in the proper sense of bohqei=n. The fruktoi\ pole/mioi were signals to indicate danger from the enemy. Cf. ii. 94. 1. From this place and c. 80. 7, Arn. infers (against the Schol. and Polyb. x. 40) considerable proficiency in the art of signalling. See Merriam, Telegraphing among the Ancients, Arch. Inst. Am., Classical Series iii. —35.

parani=sxon: lit. raised by the side of, i.e. so as to counteract the others. The compound not found elsewhere in Thuc.; intr. in Plut.
Aemil. Paul. 32.—37.
o(/pws . . . h)=| kai\ mh\ bohqoi=en: the same change of mood as in vi. 96. 18, 19; vii. 17. 15, 17; viii. 87. 14, 17. GMT. 321; Kr. Spr. 54, 8, 2; Kühn. 553, 6.—38.
th=s fruktwri/as: as Ar. Aves 1161; Aesch. Agam. 33, 490. Cf. fruktwroi/, viii. 102. 2; fruktwrei=n, c. 80. 7.—40.
oi( e)cio/ntes: cf. c. 20. 6; 22. 2.—
pri\n diafu/goien: opt. by assimilation after mh\ bohqoi=en. GMT. 643; Kühn. 399, 6b.—41.
tou= a)sfalou=s a)ntila/bointo: reach safety. Cf. iv. 128. 12; vii. 60. 17; 77. 29. For the gen., see G. 1099; H. 738; Kühn. 416, 2.

p.hi: They succeed in crossing the wall and the outer ditch.

div2.p: oi( u(perbai/nontes tw=n *plataiw=n: these words are the general subj. of the whole sent., which is afterwards distributed into oi( me/n (7), oi( de/ (9). The expression stands, as sfw=n oi( a)/ndres oi( e)cio/ntes, c. 22. 40, opp. to oi( e)n th=| po/lei tw=n *plataiw=n u(poleleimme/noi, c. 22. 27, or oi( e)k th=s po/lews *plataih=s, c. 22. 36; 24. 15, and answers to the const. e)k tou)/mpalin h)\ oi( a)/ndres au)tw=n u(pere/bainon, c. 22. 29. The pres. partic. is used to designate all the participants so long as the undertaking lasts. See on c. 4. 13. —2.

w(s oi( prw=toi au)tw=n . . . e)pibohqei=n: parenthetical subord. clause. See Steup, following Pp., Rh. Mus. xxxiii. p. 253 f. Most commentators end the parenthetical clause at e)kekrath/kesan, and make te, in l. 4, correl. to kai/ in But, with this const., a)po\ tw=n pu/rgwn . . . ba/llontes would be a mere repetition of ta/s te dio/dous . . . e)pibohqei=n. The first part of the parenthetical clause is not resumptive, but progressive, since above (c. 22. 21) only a number of the detachment of Ammeas was said to have ascended the wall, while here oi( prw=toi au)tw=n includes not only the whole twelve, but also those armed with spears.—3.
tou= pu/rgou e(kate/rou: cf. c. 22. 17.—4.
ta\s dio/dous tw=n pu/rgwn: i.e. the passages through the lower part of the towers. Cf. c. 21. 11.—5.
au)toi/: opp. to the former guards. See on i. 100. 14.—

e)fu/lasson mhde/na . . . e)pibohqei=n: cf. vii. 17. 5; also ii. 69. 4 fulakh\n ei)=xe mh/t) e)kplei=n.
The const., mh/ with inf., is the same as with kwlu/ein.—6. kai/: also. It was not deemed sufficient simply to guard the passages of the towers. —7.
plei/ous: several, a number, as in c. 22. 21, or possibly, more, sc. than those that guarded the passages below.—8.

kai\ ka/twqen kai\ a)/nwqen: belongs to ei)=rgon, not to e)pibohqou=ntas, and, with a reference to ta\s dio/dous fula/ssontes, as well as to e)panabiba/santes, more fully explains a)po\ tw=n pu/rgwn. Kr. explains, ‘they kept back from the towers the advancing foe, shooting at them from below and from above.’ 9.
oi( de/: i.e. those still at the foot of the wall; oi( plei/ous being appos., as in viii. 80. 13, but not restrictive, as in ii. 4. 19.—
prosqe/ntes: sc. tw=| tei/xei.—10. a(/ma: connects prosqe/ntes closely with a)pw/santes.— 11. u(pere/bainon: includes, acc. to what follows, also the erossing of the outer ditch.

o( de\ diakomizo/menos ai)ei\ i(/stato: always as one came over he halted. ai)ei/ belongs not only to the iterative partic: o( diakomizo/menos (=o(po/te tis diakomi/zoito), but also to i(/stato,—hence its position. Kr. Spr. 50, 10, 5. See on i. 2. 4. The pl. idea implied in this clause finds expression in the verbs that follow.—
e)pi\ tou= xei/lous th=s ta/frou: i.e. the outer ditch (c. 24. 13), to be distinguished from the inner mentioned c. 22. 4. With xei=los, bank, cf. labrum fossae, Liv. xxxvii. 37.—13.
para\ to\ tei=xos: by the side of the wall.—
kwluth\s gi/gnoito th=s diaba/sews: = kwlu/oi th\n dia/basin. See on c. 2. 11.
pa/ntes: sc. except those still on the two towers.—15.

xalepw=s oi( teleutai=oi katabai/nontes: parenthetical, the last descending with difficulty. oi( teleutai=oi is in part. appos. to oi( a)po\ tw=n pu/rgwn, as i. 119. 5; ii. 54. 4. Of the smaller detachment (=oi( a)po\ tw=n pu/rgwn = oi( me/n, l. 7 above), under whose protection the larger division crossed the wall, those who descended last got down with difficulty, being hard pressed doubtless by the enemy, who must have pushed after them through the towers. See Steup, Rh. Mus. xxxiii. p. 255. Arn., Bl., and
Jow. take only xalepw=s oi( teleutai=oi as parenthetical.—16.
oi( triako/sioi: cf. c. 22. 33.
ma=llon: more, i.e. better. Cf. h(=sson, —

e)k tou= sko/tous: cf. Xen. Anab. vii. 4. 18 h)ko/ntizon ei)s to\ fw=s e)k tou= sko/tous.—19. ta\ gumna/: i.e. the unprotected parts of the body, as in v. 10. 17; 71. 6. Cf. Liv. xxii. 50 in latus dextrum quod patebat Numidae iacularentur. —20.
dia\ ta\s lampa/das: i.e. the enemy's torches, which lighted only the space just around the bearers.— 22.
biai/ws: hard pressed. Kühn. 497, 5. Cf. ii. 33. 14 biaio/teron a)nagago/menoi, iv. 31. 15 a)naxw/rhsis biaiote/ra, v. 73. 22 a)poxw/rhsis ou) bi/aios.
kru/stallos e)peph/gei: cf. Aesch. Pers. 501 pera=| krustalloph=ga dia\ po/ron, Eur. Rhes. 441 fush/mata krustallo/phkta.—23. e)pelqei=n: diadramei=n, Schol.—24.

oi(=os a)phliw/tou h)\ bore/ou u(datw/dhs ma=llon: such as (is formed) when the wind is east instead of north, rather watery. This interpretation, given by the Schol. and Va., and adopted by Arn., Bl., and Jow., is doubtless the best that can be made out of the text as it stands. For the omission of ma=llon before h)/, which Jow. thinks is softened by its occurrence after u(datw/dhs, Arn. cites Soph. Ajax 966 e)moi\ pikro\s te/qnhken h)\ kei/nois gluku/s. Dobree brackets h)\ bore/ou. Pp. would transpose u(datw/dhs ma=llon, or bracket u(datw/dhs. For the temporal gens., see G. 1136; H. 759; Kühn. 418, 8 b; Kr. Spr. 47, 2, 1. On the form a)phliw/ths, see Lobeck on Soph. Aj. 805. u(datw/dhs occurs only here in Thuc.—

kai\ h( nu\c . . . u(poneifome/nh: and the night with such a wind somewhat snowy (lit. besnowed). A bold and rather poetic use of u(poneifome/nh that seems not to be found elsewhere. Cf. u(pe/neifen, iv. 103. 5. On the form u(poneifome/nh, which most of the best Mss. have, see J. Schmidt, zur Gesch. d. indogerm. Vokalismus i. p. 134; Stahl Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 39. Cobet, ad Hyper. p. 57, prefers u(ponifome/nh. —26.

o(\ mo/lis u(pere/xontes e)peraiw/qhsan: which they crossed scarcely keep-
ing (their heads) above. o(/ belongs to both partic. and verb. For u(pere/xein with acc. in fig. sense, cf. Eur. Hipp. 1365.—

e)ge/neto . . . ma=llon: Cl. explains that e)ge/neto is not merely passive of poiei=sqai, but has the stronger meaning of successful accomplishment, as in v. 55. 15; vi. 74. 3; viii. 57. 8. “And their escape was accomplished more, etc.” But cf. vii. 41. 3 th\n kata/feucin e)poiou=nto. The idea of successful accomplishment is inseparable from the expression e)ge/neto h( dia/feucis. dia/feucis, which occurs elsewhere only in late writers, for diafugh/, acc. to Thuc.'s preference for forms in -dis, which appears esp. in connexion with the pass. gi/gnesqai. Cf. c. 92. 16; i. 73. 1; 75. 14; ii. 11. 17; 14. 7; 94. 2; iv. 74. 18; 85. 1; 113. 1; 116. 10; v. 82. 18; vi. 103. 17; vii. 42. 7; viii. 21. 2; 66. 9; 89. 26; 97. 13. On Thuc.'s use of verbal nouns in -dis, see Introd. to Book I. p. 49, and Sihler, Trans. Amer. Philol. Assoc. xii. p. 96 ff.—27.
dia\ tou= xeimw=nos to\ me/geqos: for the order, see on i. 32. 8.
212 men, having eluded their pursuers, reach Athens.
to\ tou= *)androkra/tous h(rw=|on: the temenos of the Plataean hero Androcrates, who is mentioned by Plut. Arist. 11, is referred to also by Hdt. ix. 25. 18, and Plut. ibid.—

nomi/zontes . . . e)s tou\s polemi/ous: thinking those would least suspect that they had taken this road, which led to the enemy. The irregularity in the order of words arose from emphasizing sfa=s tau/thn. For the rare verb u(potoph=sai, used by Thuc. elsewhere only in aor. partic., see on i. 20. 9, and for aor. inf. after nomi/zein referring to the future, see note and App. on ii. 3. 9. St. inserts a)/n after h(/kista. GMT. 127; Kühn. 389, N. 8.—5.

th\n pro\s *kiqairw=na kai\ *druo\s kefala/s: through this pass, called by the Athenians, from the wood-covered peaks, *druo\s kefalai/, by the Boeotians, from the three easily distinguishable summits, *trei=s kefalai/ (Hdt. ix. 39. 5), ran one of the three main roads between Boeotia and Attica in a southeasterly direction by Eleutherae. See Vischer, Erinnerungen aus Griechenland, p. 533; Bursian i. p. 249.—7.
meta\ lampa/dwn: cf. c. 23. 17.—

diw/kontas: abs., hastening forward. For the acc. connected with diw/kontas, as well as those with e)xw/-
rhsan and h)=|san below, see G. 1057; Kühn. 409, 1, 7.

th
 pro\s to\ o)/ros . . . *(usia/s: this road, which branched off eastward not far from Plataea, is to be distinguished from that which led directly from Thebes to Hysiae, mentioned by Paus. ix. 1. 6 ou) th
 eu)qei=an a)po\ tw=n *qhbw=n th
 pedia/da, th
 de\ e)pi\ *(usia\s pro\s *)eleuqerw=n te kai\ th=s *)attikh=s.—10. e)s *)eru/qras kai\ *(usia/s: the remoter point is mentioned first, for Erythrae was east of Hysiae. Cf. c. 29. 6, and see on ii. 7. 16. For the accent of *)eru/qras, see Eustathius on Hom. B 499 *)eru/qrai me
 baruto/nws ai( th=s *boiwti/as, *)eruqrai\ de o)cuto/nws ai( th=s *)iwni/as.—labo/menoi: having reached, with gen., as in c. 106. 10; viii. 80. 13. G. 1099; H. 739; Kühn. 416, 2. Cf. a)ntilabe/sqai in the same sense c. 22. 1.—12.
a)po\ pleio/nwn: i.e. the 220 mentioned in c. 20. 11. a)po/ as in c. 112. 30; i. 49. 25; 110. 2; vii. 87. 26. Kühn. 414, N. 4.—
ei)si/ tines oi(/: treated as a single subst., some, hence the pres. is retained. G. 1029; H. 998.

kata\ xw/ran e)ge/nonto: returned to their post. Cf. kata\ cullo/gous gi/gnesqai, c. 27. 7; kata\ custa/seis gi/gnesqai, ii. 21. 15; e)n tai=s xw/rais e(/kastoi e)ge/nonto, Xen. Anab. iv. 8. 15. kata\ xw/ran is found elsewhere only with me/nein (c. 22. 30; i. 28. 18; ii. 58. 17; iv. 14. 28; 26. 3; 76. 26; vii. 49. 24; viii. 71. 21; 86. 16).—15.
th=s bohqei/as: see on c. 22. 34.—
oi( e)k th=s po/lews: the proleptic use of e)k caused by the following kh/ruka e)kpe/myantes. See on c. 22. 22.—18.

e)spe/ndonto a)nai/resin toi=s nekroi=s: conative impf. Schol. sponda\s e)zh/toun poih=sai. GMT. 36; Kühn. 382, 6 b. With acc. of thing and dat. of person also c. 109. 10; 114. 11. Kühn. 424, N. 1 b.— 21.
e)sw/qhsan: cf. c. 20. 12 e)ne/meinan th=| e)co/dw| e)qelontai\ tro/pw| toiw=|de. The fate of the city and of those who remained in it is narrated in c. 52-68.
The beleaguered Mytileneans are encouraged to hold out by the Lacedaemonian Salaethus, who steals into the city.
o( *lakedaimo/nios: the art., suspected by Kr., is protected by c. 100. 11; v. 52. 3; viii. 26. 8; 35. 2. The use of the art. is nowhere more variable than with names of peoples.—
e)s *mutilh/nhn: which was in the condition described c. 18. § 5.—3.
e)s *pu/rran: on the inmost recess of the bay which extends from the west coast deep into the island, whence the distance to Mitylene was shortest.—4.
kata\ xara/dran tina/: i.e. along the dry bed of a torrent. Cf. c. 98. 7; 107. 14; 112. 22.—

h(=| u(pe/rbaton h)=n: if the text be sound, either, as Bl., because the wall of the Athenians had not been completed across the ravine, or, as St., because it was lower there and less carefully guarded. Steup, who assumes that the wall must have been everywhere of the same height—measured from base to top—and hence not easier to cross in the ravine than elsewhere, favors Cl.'s suggestion of an outlet for the water left open in the bed of the torrent, in which case v. Herw.'s conjecture u(p obato/n, for u(perbato/n, would be probable.—5.
dialaqw/n: i.e. la/qra| dielqw/n or u(perba/s. Contrary to the usual const., lanqa/nw takes here the form of the limiting participle. GMT. 893; Kühn. 482, N. 14. —6.

toi=s pro/edrois: prob. the official title of the ruling board under the oligarchical constitution of Mytilene. Cf. viii. 67. 15, where the first five men to be chosen under the constitution proposed by Pisander are called pro/edroi. See Plehn, Lesbos, p. 93.— 7.
ai( tessara/konta nh=es: cf. c. 16. § 3.—8.
proapopemfqh=nai/ te: the particle introduces the third member. For the change from const. with o(/ti to inf., cf. c. 2. 12, 15; 3. 12, 14, and see on i. 87. 11. Kühn. 550, N. 3. —9.
kai\ a(/ma . . . e)pimelhso/menos: for partic. co-ord. with prepositional phrase, cf. c. 34. 17; 42. 23; i. 39. 2; 80. 3; ii. 89. 22.

pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous: Cl. construes with h(=sson ei)=xon th\n gnw/mhn, as v. 44. 7; 48. 10; Xen. Anab. ii 5. 29 (cf. also Thuc. v. 13. 8; 14. 4), they had their mind less turned (were less inclined) to the Athenians, w(/ste cumbai/nein being an explanatory addition. But Steup connects pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous with cumbai/nein, comparing c. 27. 3, in which case the order of words would be as in vii. 86. 12 tou\s ga\r e)k th=s nh/sou a)/ndras tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn o( *niki/as prouqumh/qh . . . w(/ste a)reqh=nai, and w(/ste pleonastic after ei)=xon th\n gnw/mhn, as often after pei/qein (see on c. 31. 10), paraskeua/zein (c. 36. 20), dei=sqai (i. 119. 7), yhfi/zesqai (v. 17. 20; vi. 88. 47), do/can (viii. 79. 2), cugxwrei=sqai (v. 17. 12). Kühn. 473, N. 6. This certainly brings out more clearly the evident sense of the passage.—11.

o(/ te xeimw\n kte(.: only here is this formula for the conclusion of the year introduced by te, and so this winter ended. Generally the connexion is looser: with kai/, as c. 88. 13; ii. 47. 2; 103. 5; iv. 51. 5; 116. 14; 135. 8; v. 39. 18; 51. 10; 56. 19; 81. 10; 83. 20; vi. 7. 24; 93. 20; vii. 18. 32; viii. 6. 32; 60. 16; or with me/n (in resumé), as c. 116. 7; ii. 70. 21. FIFTH YEAR OF THE WAR. cc. 26-88.
The next spring the Peloponnesians send a fleet to succour Mytilene, and make at the same time a fourth invasion of Attica.
oi( *peloponnh/sioi . . . au)toi\ kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi: see on c. 1. 4. 2. [

du/o kai\ tessara/konta]: Cl. explains that here, where the actual sending of the expedition is described, the exact number is given instead of the round number forty used elsewhere in the account (c. 16. 16; 25. 7; 29. 1; 69. 1). Arn. thinks the two additional ships may have been the Spartan contingent, which in such expeditions was always small. Cf. viii. 6. 31. Steup brackets the words. See App.—3.
a)/rxonta: for e)/xonta of the Mss. See App.—
o(\s h)=n au)toi=s nau/arxos: cf. c. 16. 17. Here, as ii. 66. 6; 80. 12, the nauarchy extends from the summer of one year to the next.—5.

o(/pws . . . e)pibohqh/sousin:
the reason why the invasion was made exactly then, not earlier nor later. Cf. § 4 and c. 25. 6 o(/ti e)sbolh/ te . . . pare/sontai.—a)mfote/rwqen qorubou/menoi: i.e. not only threatened by the fleet sailing to Lesbos, but actually attacked by a land force in Attica. —6.

h(=sson: i.e. less than they could but for the invasion then made into Attica, against which part of the Athenian forces would be engaged. The Spartan government did not anticipate, of course, that in consequence of the slowness and cowardice of Alcidas the Athenians would hear of the fall of Mytilene soon after they heard of the sailing of Alcidas, and so would not need to send thither any more ships. Cf. c. 29. § 1.—

tai=s nausi
 e)s th
 *mutilh/nhn katapleou/sais e)pibohqh/sousin: the sense of the whole final clause seems to be, “that the Athenians embarrassed both by sea and land might the less with their ships sail to Mytilene and bring aid” (lit. with their ships sailing to Mytilene bring aid). So St. explains (Goett. Gel. Anz. 1882, p. 97), taking the dat. as instrumental. The text is generally interpreted, “that the Athenians might the less advance against the ships sailing to Mytilene.” But e)pibohqei=n tini means always, if the dat. is not instrumental, hasten to the aid of (cf. i. 73. 24; iv. 1. 11; 29. 23; 43. 15; Hdt. vii. 207. 9; viii. 1. 12; 14. 5); besides, to make katapleou/sais attrib. would require either that nausi/n follow e)s th
 *mutilh/nhn, or that the article be repeated after nausi/n. Steup brackets katapleou/sais. See App. kataplei=n does not differ essentially from the simple verb, as also in i. 51. 13; ii. 103. 3; iv. 26. 20; viii. 35. 4; 108. 1. e)pibohqh/sousin, with the best Mss., instead of e)pibohqh/swsin. GMT. 324; H. 881. c.
h(gei=to th=s e)sbolh=s tau/ths: cf. ii. 10. 9.—

*kleome/nhs u(pe\r *pausani/ou: ou(=tos o( *kleome/nhs kai\ o( *pleistoa/nac pai=de/s ei)si *pausani/ou tou= e)n *plataia=sin a)risteu/santos e)pi\ tw=n *mh/dwn, Schol. See on i. 94. 1; 114. 11. Archidamus, who had led the previous invasions, was prob. still alive, but hindered by illness. His death must have occurred soon after, for his son Agis, as king, leads the expedition of the following year, c. 80. 3. See Kr. Hist.-phil. Stud. i. p. 151. Elsewhere, in narrating Peloponnesian invasions of Attica, Thuc. always adds the father's name to that of the leader (c. 1. 3; i. 114. 11; ii. 19. 6; 47. 6; iv. 2. 3; vii. 19. 3—cf. also c. 89. 3; ii. 71. 3). But everywhere else a Spartan king is the leader. The present passage differs, it is true, also from i. 107. 6, where in the account of the expedition into central Greece, which led to the battle of Tanagra, it is said, *nikomh/dous tou= *kleombro/tou u(pe\r *pleistoa/naktos tou= *pausani/ou basile/ws, ne/ou o)/ntos e)/ti, h(goume/nou. Still one is less inclined to accept, with G. Osberger (Festgruss f. Heerwagen, p. 89 f.), the loss
of o( *pausani/ou before u(pe\r *pausani/ou, since the absence of *lakedaimoni/wn with basile/ws is also unusual. In i. 107. 6, oi( *lakedaimo/nioi occurs as subj. 8.
u(pe/r: in place of. Kühn. 435, i. 2 a. —
ui(e/os: this form of gen. also i. 13. 26; 137. 2; ii. 100. 14; ui(ou=, v. 16. 24. See on i. 13. 26.—9.
newte/rou e)/ti: yet too young, sc. to rule. Cf. vi. 12. 10 new/teros e)/ti w)\n e)s to\ a)/rxein.— patro\s de/: see App. [
kai/]: see App.—11.

o(/sa . . . parele/leipto: cf. ii. 57. 8, where, in the account of the second invasion, th\n gh=n pa=san e)/temon must mean, ravaged all parts of the land, not every point. paralei/pein, spare, as in ii. 13. 7. —13.
meta\ th\n deute/ran: cf. ii. 57. § 2. —
e)pime/nontes . . . ti peu/sesqai: for the const. with inf., see on c. 2. 7; 12. 11.—14.

w(s h)/dh peperaiwme/nwn: as was natural to assume, since the fleet was expected to make all haste (c. 29. 2), instead of proceeding with the utmost slowness, as it did (c. 27. 2; 29. 3). For const. of the partic., see on c. 4. 15.—15.

e)pech=lqon: abs., they went forward, as i. 62. 24. Cf. Plato Gorg. 492 d. Bm. takes ta\ polla\ with e)pech=lqon, comparing c. 67. 1 tau=ta e)pech/lqomen (used fig.), and ii. 94. 13 katadramo/ntes th=s *salami=nos ta\ polla/.—16. e)peleloi/pei o( si=tos: i.e. the corn brought with them. Cf. c. 1. 8; ii. 10. 4; 23. 11.—17.
a)nexw/rhsan kai\ dielu/qhsan kata\ po/leis: for the formula, see on c. 1. 9.
28. In Mytilene the democratic party comes into power, whereupon the authorities surrender the city to Paches, on condition that the fate of the Mytileneans should be decided by the Athenians.
w(s . . . a)po\ th=s *peloponnh/sou: as Salaethus had promised, c. 25. 7. —2.
e)nexro/nizon: only here in Thuc., as e)ndiatri/bein, c. 29. 3; v. 12. 6; vii. 81. 20.—3.

e)peleloi/pei: not entirely,
as may be inferred from l. 8 below. —
cumbai/nein pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous: for the const., see Kühn. 441, iii. 1 b. See on c. 25. 10.

o(pli/zei: i.e. he gives them full hoplite armour (viii. 25. 4), which hitherto the dunatoi/ had reserved to themselves, the lower classes of citizens serving as yiloi/, with spear or bow, without breastplate and shield.
tw=n a)rxo/ntwn: = tw=n e)n toi=s pra/gmasi (c. 28. 1).

kata\ cullo/gous gigno/menoi: i.e. coming together in secret party meetings. So Xen. Anab. v. 7. 1 kai\ cu/llogoi e)gi/gnonto kai\ ku/kloi cuni/stanto, and Arr. Anab. v. 25. 2. Cf. kata\ custa/seis gigno/menoi, ii. 21. 15; and see on c. 24. 14. —8.

to\n si=ton: the dunatoi/ seem to have anticipated the lack of provisions, either by retaining for themselves the corn, which before the revolt had been ordered from the Pontus (cf. c. 2. 7, and see W. Herbst, Der Abfall Mytilenes, p. 11), or, if we suppose, with Steup, that this never arrived, by taking other precautions. —
tou\s dunatou/s: i.e. the optimates or o)li/goi, as i. 24. 13; ii. 65. 8; v. 4. 8; viii. 21. 4.—9.

au)toi/: for themselves alone, as i. 139. 15; v. 60. 4; vi. 37. 3. Cf. c. 28. 2 ei) a)pomonwqh/sontai th=s cumba/sews. au)toi/ belongs with cugxwrh/santes paradw/sein.—cugxwrh/santes pro\s *)aqhnai/ous: as ii. 59. 6. Cf. c. 28. 3; v. 29. 21; vii. 82. 7. See on l. 3; 25. 10.

oi( e)n toi=s pra/gmasin: as in Dem. ix. 56; Arist. Polit. v. 7. 12, <*> oi( a)/rxontes, oi( dunatoi/, c. 27. 7, 8, whose executive committee perhaps were the pro/edroi of c. 25. 6. Cf. oi( e)pi\ toi=s pra/gmasi, Dem. ix, 2, and oi( e)/xontes ta\ pra/gmata, c. 62. 11; 72. 3. See on c. 11. 11, and W. Herbst l.c. —
ou)/te, te: on the correlation see Kühn. 536, 3 a.—
a)pokwlu/sein: for fut. inf. limiting dunatoi\ o)/ntes, see on i. 27. 9; ii. 29. 26; vi. 6. 4. GMT. 113; Kühn. 389, N. 8. St. writes a)pokwlu/ein. See Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 18 sqq.— 2.
dunatoi\ o)/ntes: depends on gno/ntes. GMT. 904.—
ei) a)pomonwqh/sontai: in accordance with the threat contained in au)toi/, c. 27. 9.—3.

kinduneu/sontes: still dependent on gno/ntes. The pres.,
kinduneu/ontes, which several good Mss. have, is doubtless only a slip of the copyist due to the preceding o)/ntes.— koinh=|: i.e. together with the democratic party. Cf. v. 32. 16; 35. 11; 42. 19.—

pro/s te *pa/xhta kai\ to\ strato/pedon: for the const., see on c. 25. 10; 27. 3, 9. Paches doubtless conferred with the most prominent of his officers. The Athenian army could settle only the preliminaries, the final decision belonging to the demos at Athens. to\ strato/pedon is tacitly opp. to po/lis, as in viii. 72. 2; 76. 3.—4.
w(/ste: on condition that, as in See on i. 28. 18. GMT. 587, 2; H. 953 b.—5.
bouleu=sai: aor., to decide, as in i. 85. 5; 132. 28; ii. 6. 10; iv. 41. 1; vi. 39. 5; pres., to deliberate (i. 97. 2; iv. 15. 3), except in c. 42. 25, give advice.—7.

presbei/an de\ . . . *mutilhnai/ous: the natural const. would be *mutilhnai/ous de\ presbei/an a)poste/llein, but the interposition of kai\ th\n stratia\n . . . au)tou/s led to a change of const. a)poste/llein depends on e)cei=nai in spite of the intervening clause.—8.

e)n o(/sw| a)
 pa/lin e)/lqwsi: this concise expression is really a mixture of e)n o(/sw| a)
 a)pw=si (cf. viii. 87. 8) and pri
 a)
 (or e(/ws a)/n, i. 90. 20) pa/lin e)/lqwsin (cf. i. 91. 10). See also i. 14. 12 for similar su/gxusis. e)n o(/sw|, until, also c. 52. 16.
oi( pra/cantes pro\s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous: for the const. (pro/s, with), see on c. 4. 20; i. 131. 7; ii. 5. 32. —12.
ou)k h)ne/sxonto: abs., could not keep quiet, as v. 45. 17. On the augments, see G. 544; H. 361 a. —13.
o(/mws: i.e. notwithstanding safety had been guaranteed them until the return of their embassy. For similar breviloquentia, cf. c. 49. 3; 80. 4; i. 105. 24; ii. 51. 24; iv. 96. 35.—
kaqi/zousi: sc. i(ke/tai, which is expressed c. 70. 18; 75. 22; i. 24. 19; 126. 32. i(ke/tai is omitted also c. 75. 15.—14.
katati/qetai: places for safe-keeping. The mid. always in this sense. See on i. 115. 13.—15.

me/xri ou(=: with subjv. with
out a)/n also iv. 16. 16; 41. 2; 46. 12. GMT. 620; Kühn. 398, N. 2. See on i. 137. 13, and St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 26.— 16.
prosekth/sato: sc. au)th/n. Antissa had resisted the Methymneans, as described in c. 18. § 2.—
kai\ ta)=lla . . . h(=| au)tw=| e)do/kei: and arranged the other matters pertaining to the army as he deemed best. Cf. c. 35. 7; i. 95. 8; ii. 6. 3.

p.hi: Seven days later the Peloponnesian fleet arrives in that region.

div2.p: e)/dei e)n ta/xei paragene/sqai: contrasted with ple/ontes . . . komisqe/ntes, not without irony, a trace of which is observable also elsewhere, when allusion is made to naval operations of the Peloponnesians. See on c. 31. 11; 81. 1; ii. 7. 9; 93. 20.—3.
e)ndie/triyan: see App.—4.
sxolai=oi komisqe/ntes: cf. xro/nioi cunio/ntes, i. 141. 30. For other cases of the pred. adj. used adv., see on i. 12. 3. G. 926; H. 619; Kr. Spr. 57, 5, 4.—

tou\s e)k th=s po/lews *)aqhnai/ous: understood by Cl., St., and Bm., with L. Herbst (Philol. xvi. p. 312 f.—cf. xlii. p. 696 ff.), to be the crew of the 100 ships mentioned c. 16. 5, made up from the citizen classes (and metics). Cf. c. 91. 11; i. 105. 19; ii. 31. 6; iv. 28. 18; 77. 2. But Steup is prob. right in understanding here, with Müller-Strübing (Thuk. Forsch. p. 117 ff.), those in Athens and Attica, as opp. to those that had been sent to Lesbos. For the fleet of Alcidas was not despatched till the summer of 427 B.C.; otherwise Thuc. could not have delayed mention of it till c. 26. § 1, and Salaethus, who departed from Sparta tou= au)tou= xeimw=nos teleutw=ntos (c. 25. 1), could not have said proapopemfqh=nai au)to/s (c. 25. 8). Besides, the return of the 100 Attie ships, which is mentioned c. 16. 18, certainly occurred before Paches was despatched to Mytilene (c. 18. 15). See Müller-Strübing ibid. p. 120. and Jow. ad loc. Further, in three at least of the passages cited by Herbst (c. 91. 11; i. 105. 19; ii. 31. 6), oi( e)k th=s po/lews seems to mean, as here, simply those left in Athens and Attica, as opp. to those sent abroad.— 5.

pri\n dh\ th=| *dh/lw| e)/sxon: until they reached Delos, having thus accomplished the part of the voyage in which there was most danger of being sighted by Athenian ships. For pri/n with indic., see on i. 51. 5; 118. 13; 132. 28; and Gildersleeve, Am. J. of Ph. ii. p. 469. GMT. 635; H. 924. sxei=n with dat. also c. 33. 5; vii. 1. 14; elsewhere with e)s or kata/ with acc. Kr. Spr. 48, 1, 2; Kühn. 423, 5. See
on vii. 1. 14.—6.

th=| *)ika/rw| kai\ *muko/nw|: the reverse of the geographical order, as in c. 102. 4; ii. 7. 16; 77. 10; 93. 1; viii. 88. 10; 108. 3. The place where they first received the news of the fall of Mytilene is named first, and punqa/nesqai prw=ton belongs with this; hence Haase's conjecture (Lucubr. Thuc. p. 23), *pa/rw|, is unnecessary.
to\ safe/s: the exact situation. Cf. l. 10; i. 22. 16; vi. 60. 12, 20.— 8.

*)/embaton: to\ steno\n to\ metacu\ *xi/ou kai\ *)eruqra=s [for *)eruqrw=n], Schol. More correctly Steph. Thes. s.v. to/pos th=s *)eruqrai/as.—9. th=| *mutilh/nh| e(alwkui/a|: the dat. to express the terminus a quo, as tau/th| in i. 13. 14. It was about seven days after the fall of Mytilene when etc. Kühn. 423, 25 f. Kr. Spr. 48, 5, 3. The pred. partic. has the same force as in e)pilipo/nti, c. 20. 3.—11.

e)k tw=n paro/ntwn: under present circumstances. e)k as in iv. 17. 4; v. 40. 19; 87. 2; vi. 70. 18; 93. 10; vii. 62. 4; 77. 1. Kr. Spr. 68, 17, 10; Kühn. 430, 2, 3 g. Different is bouleu/esqai peri\ tw=n paro/ntwn, i. 79. 4.

p.hi: But Teutiaplus the Elean advises to make without delay a night attack on Mytilene.

div2.p: e)moi\ dokei=n plei=n h(ma=s: unusual change of subj., as in iv. 118. 2; vi. 22. 1. For the usual const., cf. i. 31. 9; iv. 15. 2; 71. 6; v. 53. 5; vii. 4. 15; 74. 3.—3.

pri\n e)kpu/stous gene/sqai: as in iv. 70. 14; viii. 42. 2. This expression is used of persons also by Dio C. xli. 44; xlviii. 39; elsewhere of things. Cf. katagge/ltous gi/gnesqai, vii. 48. 6; e)ca/ggeltoi gene/sqai, viii. 14. 2; e)pa/i+stos e)ge/neto, Hdt. ii. 119. 10.—
w(/sper e)/xomen: just as we are, i.e. without delay. See on i. 134. 14.
a)ndrw=n: grammatically dependent on to\ a)fu/lakton, in the loose connexion which is close akin to the gen. abs., on the part of men who—. —

polu\ to\ a)fu/lakton eu(rh/somen: for similar const., cf. viii. 66. 18 h)\ ga\r a)gnw=ta a)\n eu(=ren w(=| e)rei= h)\ gnw/rimon a)/piston. polu/ is pred. with the
same position and effect as e)laxi/stas, i. 34. 10; a)/mikta, i. 77. 24. The use of a neut. partic. or adj. for an abstract noun is common in Thuc. It presents to the mind the abstract quality in operation. See on i. 36. 3. GMT. 829 a; H. 966 b; Kühn. 403 g. —5. kai\ pa/nu: vel maxime, as c. 93. 10; i. 3. 5; ii. 11. 26; 51. 6; 65. 61; vi. 17. 32.—6.
a)ne/lpistoi: active, as also vi. 17. 31; viii. 1. 15; and to\ a)ne/lpiston, ii. 51. 13; elsewhere in Thuc. with passive force, iv. 55. 8; vi. 33. 24.—
e)pigene/sqai: of unexpected attack, as c. 108. 3; iv. 25. 52; 93. 12; vii. 32. 12.—7.

h(mw=n h( a)lkh\ tugxa/nei ma/lista ou)=sa: “and where defence happens to be chiefly our role.” This interpretation of Junghan's (N. Jahrbb. cxix. p. 358) is adopted by Steup. See also Amer. J. of Phil. x. p. 210, where the same explanation is given by C. F. Smith, independently of Junghahn. Cl. follows Herbst (Philol. xvi. p. 305), “where our strength at present chiefly lies.” a)lkh/ as in c. 108. 5; ii. 84. 24; Hdt. ii. 45. 7; iii. 78. 5; iv. 125. 21; ix. 102. 18. On Thuc.'s use of a)lkh/, see Diener, De Sermone Thuc. p. 12, and C. F. Smith, Proc. Amer. Philol. Assoc. vol. xxii. p. xvii.—
ei)ko\s de\ kai\ to\ pezo/n: opp. to kata\ me\n qa/lassan kai\ pa/nu.—8. w(s kekrathko/twn: “in the confidence of victory.”

e)lpi/zw: with inf. (pres. or aor.) and a)/n = think or expect. Cf. i. 127. 5; ii. 20. 4; v. 39. 5; vii. 61. 12, and a)ne/lpistoi e)pigene/sqai a)/n above. Cf. Chaucer, Reeve's Tale, 1. 109, ‘I hope he wil be deed.’—

meta\ tw=n e)/ndon: in agreement with those within (cf. v. 44. 2; vi. 28. 11), as if an act. inf. clause were to follow; but the interposition of the ei) clause has caused a slight anacoluthon. For katalamba/nein ta\ pra/gmata, see on c. 11. 10. —
ei)/ tis a)/ra . . . eu)/nous: intended not to express doubt, but to be as comprehensive as possible, whoever is left well-disposed toward us. For a)/ra, see on c. 56. 15.
a)poknh/swmen to\n ki/ndunon: see on c. 20. 10.—

nomi/santes ou)k a)/llo ti ei)=nai: this const. with nomi/zein or h(gei=sqai gives to an ambiguous expression a definite, and, in the view of the speaker, correct sense. This is the case with e(orth/, i. 70. 29; to\ cumfe/ron, c. 56. 25; and here with the proverbial or formulary expression, to\ koino\n tou= pole/mou. See App.
—13.
to\ toiou=ton: i.e. lack of precaution.—

o(\ ei)/ tis strathgo\s . . . plei=st) a)\n o)rqoi=to: which, if a general both guard against in himself, and when he sees it in the enemy attacks, he would be most likely to succeed. Cf. v. 9. § 4.—14.
toi=s polemi/ois: belongs both to e)norw=n and e)pixeiroi/h, but o(/, which is obj. of fula/ssoito in the first clause, belongs only to e)norw=n in the second.— 15.
plei=st) a)\n o)rqoi=to: cf. c. 37. 26; 42. 20; v. 9. 14.
But Alcidas decides, in spite of the remonstrances of the Ionian fugitives and of those Lesbians who are present, to return to Peloponnesus.

tosau=ta: occurs esp. after short speeches, “so much and no more.” Cf. c. 52. 13; ii. 12. 1; 72. 1, 13; iv. 11. 1; vii. 49. 1; also c. 62. 25, and Plato Prot. 318 a tosou=tos o( h(me/teros lo/gos.—2. a)/lloi tine/s: epexegetically explained by tw=n a)p) *)iwni/as . . . cumple/ontes. For the part. gen., tw=n . . . fuga/dwn, cf. iv. 78. 17. These fugitives are mentioned only here. —3.

oi( cumple/ontes: oi( rightly added by Madvig (Adv. i. p. 315); for the Lesbians on the fleet, not the Lesbians in general, must be meant. Herbst (Philol. xlii. p. 704) justifies the vulgate by assuming oi( *le/sbioi to be the ambassadors at Olympia, c. 8 ff. But oi( *le/sbioi, though a sufficiently explicit designation for this embassy in c. 16. 10, by no means suffices here, after the narration of so many different events, among them the fall of Mytilene, esp. as the sending of a second later embassy is mentioned, c. 5. 16. Prob. the majority of both embassies were with Alcidas; but some representatives of Mytilenean interests must have remained at Sparta.—5.
o(/pws . . . a)posth/swsin: aor. subjv. after o(/pws, as c. 49. 6; 81. 4; v. 85. 3. GMT. 318.—
o(rmw/menoi: o(rmhth/rion e)/xontes, Schol. Cf. c. 85. 7; i. 64. 10; 90. 12; iv. 8. 36; 52. 16.—6.
ou)deni/: sc. tw=n kata\ tau/thn th\n qa/lassan *(ellh/nwn.—a)kousi/ws: unwelcome, unwished for; the passive force, which the adj. a)kou/sios also has.—7.

kai\ th\n pro/sodon . . . gi/gnhtai: kai/ connects a)posth/-
swsin and gi/gnhtai. On the text, see App.—8.
u(fe/lwsi: (so with Laur. and other Mss., not a)fe/lwsi, which Vat. and others have) of gradual withdrawal, as c. 13. 33; 82. 17. —
kai\ a(/ma: also at the same time. See on c. 16. 12; 21. 10.—

h)\n e)formw=si sfi/sin: second condition depending on kai\ (o(/pws) au)toi=s (i.e. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, dapa/nh gi/gnhtai. The subj. of e)formw=si is the Athenians; sfi/sin refers to the Peloponnesians. e)formei=n with dat. as in vii. 3. 21; 12. 18; the pass. in i. 142. 19; viii. 20. 3.— 9.
*pissou/qnhn: satrap of Lydia. Cf. i. 115. 17.—10.
e)nede/xeto: impf. corresponding to parh/|noun (l.3). e)nde/xesqai in this sense also viii. 50. 2.—11.

to\ plei=ston th=s gnw/mhs ei)=xen: he was for the most part of the opinion. There is a touch of irony in the expression. See on c. 29. 2. Cf. iv. 34. 5 tou= qarsei=n to\ plei=ston ei)lhfo/tes, Hdt. i. 120. 19 tau/th| plei=stos gnw/mhn ei)mi/, v. 126. 2 au)tw=| de\ *)aristago/rh| h( plei/sth gnw/mh h)=n, vii. 220. 5 tau/th| kai\ ma=llon th=| gnw/mh| plei=sto/s ei)mi.—th=s *mutilh/nhs: short for th=s a(lw/sews th=s *mutilh/nhs. —12.
u(sterh/kei: with gen., as in Xen. Anab. i. 7. 12; Ages. 2. 1; Hdt. vi. 89. 12. Cf. Dem. iv. 32, 35. G. 1120; H. 749.

p.hi: Alcidas sails along the coast of Asia Minor as far as Ephesus. His barbarous treatment of captives.

div2.p: pare/plei: i.e. southward.—
prossxw/n: see App. on i. 15. 3.— 2.

*muonnh/sw|: Myonnesus promunturium inter Teum Samumque est, Liv. xxxvii. 27. Cf. Strabo, p. 643 (end), h( *muo/nnhsos e)f) u(/yous xerronhsi/zontos katoikei=tai.— kata\ plou=n: without art., as in vii. 31. 14, corresponding to kaq) o(do/n, ii. 5. 3; v. 3. 14; 37. 6. Cf. e)n plw=|. vi. 34. 61.—3.
a)pe/sface: as, acc. to ii. 67. § 4, the custom of the Lacedaemonians was.—
tou\s pollou/s: part. apposition. G. 914; H. 624 d; Kr. Spr. 57, 8, N. Cf. i. 18. 2.

e)s th\n *)/efeson kaqormisame/nou: cf. iv. 45. 3; vi. 97. 5; viii. 34. 11; 42. 20. Müller-Strübing (Thuk. Forsch. p. 128 ff.) denies the possibility of Alcidas having anchored at Ephesus, a city belonging to the Athenian alliance, and holds both *)/efeson here
and *)efe/sou in c. 33. 1 to be corrupt. But it seems, acc. to Strabo, p. 641 c, that at that time the harbour of Ephesus could not be closed, and so it was improbable that Alcidas could be kept out. See St. Gött. Gel. Anz. 1882, p. 98.—4.
*sami/wn tw=n e)c *)anai/wn: see on c. 19. 8.—5.
th\n *(ella/da e)leuqerou=n: this claim of Sparta occurs often. See on c. 13. 35; i. 69. 8.—6.
ei) . . . die/fqeiren: the fact expressed in hypothetical form, in tone of reproach. Cf. c. 43. 19; 55. 7; i. 33. 8; 76. 8; 86. 4; iv. 85. 4.—
xei=ras a)ntairome/nous: cf. Hdt. vii. 209. 19.—7.
u(p) a)na/gkhs: only here in Thuc. (but freq. in the poets; see Steph. Thes. s.v.), = e)c a)na/gkhs, c. 40. 9; vi. 44. 5; vii. 27. 17. Cf. u(po\ spoudh=s, c. 33. 12.—9.
prosa/cesqai: will bring over, as in c. 91. 7; i. 99. 8; ii. 30. 7; iv. 86. 3; vi. 22. 4; vii. 7. 8.
o(rw=ntes . . . parabalei=n: on the relation and position of these words, see App.—13.

e)lpi/da ou)de\ th\n e)laxi/sthn ei)=xon mh/ pote . . . parabalei=n: e)lpi/da, expectation, as in ii. 64. 6; 85. 16; 102. 21; vi. 87. 18; vii. 61. 8. For mh/ with inf., as after a verb of denial, see GMT. 807; H. 1029; Kühn. 516, 3 a. So after a)pistei=n, i. 10. 3; ii. 101. 3; vi. 49. 13; a)pisti/a, c. 75. 18; a)pori/a, ii. 49. 25. Cf. also ii. 93. 14. See on vii. 6. 19.—15.

e)s *)iwni/an parabalei=n: cross over to Ionia. parabalei=n intr., as in Hdt. vii. 179. 3; Dem. xii. 16. So diaba/llein, ii. 83. 16. Kühn. 373, 2 a. Cl. rather favours Heilmann's explanation, risk themselves thither, like e)s *)iwni/an parakinduneu/ein, c. 36. 11, and paraba/llesqai, risk (as at play), i. 133. 11; ii. 44. 16; Hom. i 322; to\n ki/ndunon paraba/llesqai, c. 14. 4; plei/w paraba/llesqai, c. 65. 12; pro/qumos h)=n paraba/llesqai kai\ parakinduneu/ein, Polyb. iii. 90. 6; parabo/lws peraiwqei/s, Polyb. i. 11. 9. Cf. parati/qesqai, Hom. b 237; g 74; i 255. Though the uni
versality of the thought implied in mh/ pote makes it likely that parabalei=n is fut., the aor. after e)lpi/s is not uncommon, c. 3. 14; ii. 80. 10; v. 9. 27; vi. 87. 18.
Alcidas flees through the open sea back toward Peloponnesus, pursued in vain as far as Patmos by Paches.
fugh\n e)poiei=to: cf. e)poiei=to th\n di/wcin, l. 13; Lat. fugam facere. For this favourite form of periphrasis in Thuc., see on i. 50. 8.—

w)/fqh: had been seen, sc. in the voyage from Embaton to Ephesus, as e)/ti shows; with which agrees the position of Clarus on the coast of Colophon, a few miles northwest of Ephesus. Cf. Strabo, p. 642 to\ pro\ *kolofw=nos a)/lsos tou= *klari/ou *)apo/llwnos. After leaving Ephesus he crossed the open sea, touching nowhere. For the further account of his voyage, cf. c. 69. § 1. —

th=s *salamini/as kai\ *para/lou: the two swift Athenian state triremes kept always manned ready for extraordinary occasions and purposes. Cf. c. 77. 12; vi. 53. 1; 61. 20; viii. 73. 25; 74. 1. See Dict. Ant.; Boeckh, P. E. pp. 235, 334, 702. 3.
ai( d' a)p) *)aqhnw=n ple/ousai: they were prob. sent out after news of Alcidas's expedition was received at Athens, to reconnoitre and take orders to Paches.—4.
th\n di/wcin: sc. of the Attic fleet after it should have heard of the Peloponnesian fleet.—
e)/plei dia\ tou= pela/gous: see on c. 4. 20. This is a strengthened repetition of e)/plei kata\ ta/xos, after the parenthetical clause (w)/fqh . . . ple/ousai) stating the cause of the haste.—5.
w(s gh=| e(kou/sios ou) sxh/swn: determined not of his accord to put to land. For sxei=n with dat., see on c. 29. 5.

tw=| *pa/xhti kai\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois: with these dats. the three clauses, that follow in inverse order of importance, are to be closely connected. The clause a)teixi/stou ga\r . . . ta\s po/leis, which gives the ground of pantaxo/qen, being set off from the main sent., the increasing importance of the news that comes to Paches is apparent: h)=lqe me/n, the first fleeting rumour; a)fiknei=to de\ kai\ pantaxo/qen, of repeated urgent messages; au)ta/ggeloi e)/frasan, report based upon personal observation and giving exact details (e)/frasan as in i. 145. 4). The reference of au)to/n to
Alcidas becomes easier now through this closer connexion of the last clause with the two first.—9.

kai\ w(/s: even thus, i.e. although the condition of Ionia (a)teixi/stou kte(.) was a temptation. kai\ w(/s also i. 44. 11; vii. 74. 2; 81. 30; viii. 51. 10; 56. 10; 87. 18. Jow. suggests “in any case,” as in i. 44. 10 e)do/kei ga\r o( pro\s *peloponnhsi/ous po/lemos kai\ w(\s e)/sesqai au)toi=s, viii. 51. 9 kai\ oi( me\n teixismo/n te pareskeua/zonto, kai\ e)k tou= toiou/tou, kai\ w(\s me/llousa, *sa/mos qa=sson e)teixi/sqh.— 10. a(/ma: connects porqw=sin prospi/ptontes with paraple/ontes. “They might in passing take advantage of the opportunity to plunder the cities.”—11.
au)ta/ggeloi: as in Plut. Ant. 71; Cat. Maj. 14; Arr. Anab. iv. 2. § 6; in the sense, bringing one's own message, Soph. O. C. 333; Phil. 568 (cf. au)to\s a)/ggelos, Phil. 500).
u(po\ spoudh=s: as in v. 66. 9; viii. 107. 1; elsewhere spoudh=|, kata\ spoudh/n, or dia\ spoudh=s. Kühn. 442, Id.—13.
*pa/tmou: the correct form, though against most of the Mss., which have *la/tmou. Latmus is a mountain in Caria, not an island.— 14.
e)pedi/wcen: of eager pursuit, also ii. 79. 27; iv. 43. 17; vii. 23. 11; 41. 5; Hdt. iv. 1. 8; 160. 11.—

w(s d' ou)ke/ti e)n katalh/yei e)fai/neto: when he appeared no longer within reach (lit. catching). As Alcidas is to be understood as the obj. of e)pedi/wcen, so here he is subj. of e)fai/neto. That Dio C. so understood is clear from his close imitation (li. 1.), e)pedi/wcan me\n au)tou/s, e)pei\ d' ou)k e)n katalh/yei e)fai/nonto, a)nexw/rhsan. Pp. takes e)fai/neto impers., as vi. 60. 7 ou)k e)n pau/lh| e)fai/neto. See also Pp. on i. 137. 25.—

ke/rdos de\ e)no/misen kte(.: the emphasis is on e)gkatalhfqei=sai. The result of the ships being overtaken at some place is expressed personally by h)nagka/sqhsan and the infs. dependent on it. He thought it fortunate, since he had not come up with them in the open sea, that they had not been hemmed in somewhere and compelled to encamp, and thus give themselves the trouble of watching and blockading them. Such a blockade would have been expensive. See App. on c. 31. 7. Besides, Lesbos was not yet completely subdued (c. 35. § 1).—

metew/rois: Schol. tai=s *)alki/dou nausi/n. mete/wros, in the
sense out at sea, freq. in Thuc. (i. 48. 4; ii. 91. 12; iv. 14. 3, etc.), not in Hdt. or Xenophon.—17.
sfi/si: sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, since Paches is to be understood as subj. of e)no/misen. Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 3.—
e)fo/rmhsin: blockade, as ii. 89. 42; viii. 15. 14.
On his return voyage Paches treacherously brings Notium, the port of Colophon, again into subjection to Athens.
pa/lin: with paraple/wn, on the way back.—

*no/tion: the port of Colophon, about two miles from the latter, or a)/nw po/lis (l. 2), acc. to Liv. xxxvii. 26. 5; acc. to Schuchhardt (Mitt. d. deutsch. arch. Inst., Ath. Abth. xi. p. 410) about nine miles. On the events of this chapter, see Ullrich, Beitr. p. 114, A. 130, Boeckh, Staatsh. ii.^{2} p. 699, Wilamowitz, Philol. Unters. i. p. 86 f. The relation of the *notih=s of the Attic tribute-lists to the Colophonian Notium is doubtful, for Hdt. mentions (i. 149. 3) an Aeolian Notium. See Boeckh ibid. p. 712.—2.

katw/|khnto: with adv. designation of place, as ii. 96. 6; 99. 20; v. 83. 13; with acc., i. 120. 8. Thuc, uses the pf. and plpf. always in the mid. (as in the passages just cited); the pres. and aor., only in the active (l. 6; viii. 6. 4; 108. 19).— 3.
*)itama/nous: not otherwise known. He seems to have been the leader of a Persian band who acted without orders from Pissuthnes.—

tw=n barba/rwn kata\ sta/sin i)di/a| e)paxqe/ntwn: here, as often in Thuc., the attrib. partic. is placed after a noun which is attended by other modifiers. See on i. 11. 19; vii. 23. 14; and Merriam, Trans. Amer. Philol. Assoc. xiii. p. 39. i)di/a| for i)di/an of the Mss. is doubtless correctly restores by Kr. As in c. 2. 10, it is to be taken with kata\ sta/sin, “on account of party-discord by one of the factions.” —4.
ma/lista: used with statements of measure, numbers, dates, to imply that the account given is the best possible approximation, though the reality may be more or less. Cf. i. 13. 11; ii. 36. 9.—

o(/te h( deute/ra *peloponnhsi/wn e)sbolh\ . . . e)gi/gneto: sc. in the spring of 430 B.C. Cf. ii. 47. § 1, 2. The impf. of contemporaneous action. Thus is explained why the antiAthenian party in Colophon ventured at this time to revolt; just as the Lesbians made the attempt when the Athenians h)=san tetalaipwrhme/noi u(po/ te th=s no/sou kai\ tou= pole/mou, c. 3. 4.
oi( katafugo/ntes kai\ katoikh/santes au)to/qi: those who had fled for refuge and settled there. For the nom. in part. appos. (oi( me/n, oi( de/, 10), see G. 914; H. 624 d; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 1.—7.
*pissou/qnou: see on c. 31. 9.—8.
*)arka/dwn: the Areadians appear as mercenaries even in the Persian wars. Cf. Hdt. viii. 26. 2 bi/ou te deo/menoi kai\ e)/nergoi boulo/menoi ei)/nai. Cf. vii. 57. 50.—
e)pagago/menoi: on the form, see App.—9.
e)n diateixi/smati: here and vii. 60. 9, “a space cut off from the rest of the city by an enclosing wall.” Cf. Polyb. viii. 36. 9; xvi. 31. 5, 8; 33. 1; Liv. xxxvii. 11. 10, 11.—

kai\ tw=n . . . e)poli/teuon: supplementary explanation, by which the regular const. (oi( me\n . . . ei)=xon, oi( de\ . . . e)pa/gontai) is interrupted, as in c. 33. 8-11. Among the Colophonians who had left the upper city at the time of the Persian occupation and settled in Notium, a pro-Persian party was again developed, and this, having declared itself by a combination with Pissuthnes, was joined by the original Medizing party in Colophon (cuneselqo/ntes e)poli/teuon). Colophon being thus in the power of the barbarians, the pro-Athenian party had to leave Notium also, but now by treachery and violence on the part of Paches again got the upper hand. Their enemies, oi( mhdi/santes, had to leave Notium, which for security was made an Attic colony.—11.

u(pecelqo/ntes: with acc. only here, as u(poxwrei=n, ii. 88. 11; u(pekfeu/gein, ii. 90. 21; 91. 4; e)canexw/rei ta\ ei)rhme/na, iv. 28. 13. It is intr. iv. 74. 7; vi. 51. 9; viii. 70. 2; 98. 3. Kr. Spr. 46, 6, 8.
tw=n: for to/n of the Mss., since the art. is abs. necessary with *)arka/dwn, while it is not indispensable with a)/rxonta (cf. v. 51. 8; viii. 92. 32).— 13.
w(/ste: see on c. 28. 4.—14.
a)re/skon: for the use of the partic. expressing an adj. notion always in readiness to exert itself, see on i. 38. 8; v. 41. 23; Am. J. of Ph. iv. p. 297.—
katasth/sein: to put back, as in c. 59. 24. For the fut. inf., see GMT. 591, 2.—
sw=n kai\ u(gia=: safe and sound. Similar formulas are salvus et incolumis, salvus et sospes, sain et sauf.—15.

o( me\n e)ch=lqe . . . o( d' e)kei=non . . . ei)=xen: a very striking
anacoluthon. The author instead of continuing with e)celqo/nta au)to\n e)n fulakh=| a)de/smw| ei)=xen, proceeds after the interposed clause, w(/ste . . . u(gia=, by a transition in parataxis to const. with finite verb. See on i. 26. 16. Similar anacoluthon iv. 80. 16. Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 3.—
e)n fulakh=| a)de/smw|: in custodiâ liberâ. Cf. Dio C. xxxvi. 36 e)kei=non e)n fulakh=| a)de/smw| ei)=xen, Diod. iv. 46 e)leuqe/ra fulakh/. —16.
tw=| teixi/smati: the diatei/xisma of l. 9, 13.—17.
ou) prosdexome/nwn: sc. tw=n e)/ntos. Gen. abs. without expressed subj., as often in Thuc., when it can easily be supplied from the context. GMT. 848; H. 972 a. See on i. 2. 8.—19.

w(/sper e)spei/sato: cf. Concerning this horrible perfidy, Grote expresses surprise that ‘Thucydides recounts it plainly and calmly, without a single word of comment.’ Cl.'s explanation, that the historian's indignation can be felt in the short, sharp way in which the occurrences are set one over against the other, e)sagagw\n . . . e)peidh\ e)/ndon h)=n . . . cullamba/nei, is, to say the least, not very convincing. Cf. Polyaen. iii. 2.

plh\n tw=n mhdisa/ntwn: i.e. those mentioned in l. 10, who now either returned, or in their turn fuga/des e)ge/nonto.—22. oi)kista/s: as always in Thuc., not the colonists themselves, but those sent out to arrange the government and laws of the colony to be founded. Cf. c. 92. 22; i. 24. 4; 25. 8; iv. 102. 11; vi. 3. 2; 4. 23; 5. 11. The new Notium, whither were recalled all the Colophonians who had become fugitives during the disturbances, received now under Attic ‘oecists’ an Attic constitution, kata\ tou\s e(autw=n no/mous. —23.
katw/|kisan: re-settled, as vi. 5. 16; 48. 13; 76. 7, 9; 84. 6.—
e)k tw=n po/lewn: i.e. from the neighbouring Ionic cities, whither the adherents of the Attic party had fled at the time of the Persian occupation.

p.hi: After subduing Pyrrha and Eresus, Paches sends the instigators of the revolt of Mytilene as prisoners to Athens.

div2.p:
*pu/rran kai\ *)/ereson: which had
sided with Mytilene, c. 18. 5. Antissa had already been reduced (c. 28. 15). —
paresth/sato: reduced, in Thuc. only in aor., serving as causative to prosxwrei=n tini, to submit. See on i. 29. 22.—
tou\s e)k th=s *tene/dou: for the proleptic const., see on c. 5. 1.— 5.
ou(\s kate/qeto: acc. to c. 28. 15 this was done me/xri ou)= toi=s *)aqhnai/ois ti do/ch|. In sending the instigators of the revolt to Athens, Paches doubtless obeyed a command received thence.—
kai\ ei)/ tis kte(.: for the conditional clause co-ord. with a case, see Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 4; 60, 10, 1.
th=s stratia=s to\ ple/on: as in c. 36. 22; i. 73. 27; 118. 10.—7.
toi=s loipoi=s: as toi=s leipome/nois, ii. 12. 19. It is construed with u(pome/nwn alone, and is the usual dat. of accompaniment, used chiefly in reference to military forces. G. 1189, 1190; H. 774.—
kaqi/stato: see on c. 28. 17.

The Athenians in the first impulse of their anger adopt the severest measures in regard to the Lesbian prisoners, as well as to all the inhabitants of Mytilene, but the matter is reconsidered in the ecclesia on the following day.
parexo/menon: Schol. pra=cai u(pisxnou/menon. Cf. i. 39. 7; iv. 108. 15.—

ta/ t) a)/lla: before kai/, which introduces a definite circumstance, only to emphasize the latter, in which case the use of the art. is regular. “He made various offers and especially—.” Cf. i. 129. 9; 132. 8; iv. 108. 11; v. 46. 21; 52. 12; vi. 8. 7; vii. 65. 6.—
e)/ti ga\r e)poliorkou=nto: cf. c. 20-24; 52. 1.—4.
a)pa/cein: i.e. to effect their withdrawal, as in i. 109. 6; vi. 73. 9.

gnw/mas e)poiou=nto: only here in the sense of deliberated, lit. offered their several views, = gnw/mas sfi/sin au)toi=s prouti/qesan, i. 139. 18. In ii. 2. 24, gnw/mhn poiei=sqai means form a plan; in i. 128. 28; vii. 72. 8, offer a plan.—

e)poiou=nto, kai\ . . . e)/docen: paratactic const., as i. 48. 3; 61. 2.
Concerning the decree, cf. Ael. Var. Hist. ii. 9; Diod. xii. 55.—7.
o(/soi h(bw=si: the orig. mood of the decree is retained in indir. discourse. GMT. 689, 2; H. 933; Kühn. 399, 3. 8.
e)pikalou=ntes: construed loosely with e)/docen au)toi=s, as if e)bouleu/santo had preceded. H. 1063; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 4; Kühn. 493, 1 a. For similar cases of anacoluthon, see on ii. 53. 13.—

th/n te . . . kai\ o(/ti ou)k a)rxo/menoi: Cl. inserts kai/ before o(/ti. St. explains that te is used as if the author had continued, as he seems to have intended, with kai\ o(/ti kte(., or kai\ to\ ta\s *peloponnhsi/wn nau=s tolmh=sai kte(., but after the o(/ti elause the const. is changed to finite verb. For similar changes in const., see on i. 16. 2. Cf. Hdt. i. 85. 5; 129. 4; ii. 44. 5. See App. —10.

proscuneba/leto: this reading of almost all the better Mss. is protected by Thuc.'s usage. The sing. verb before a pl. subj. occasions no difficulty, since ai( nh=es tolmh/sasai = to\ ta\s nau=s tolmh=sai. Cf. iv. 26. 14; viii. 9. 11. proscumba/llesqai, which is used also by Hippoer. 797 e; 807 e, is further protected by the similar use of cumba/llesqai c. 45. 21; Plato Apol. 36 a; Legg. 791 c; Xen. Cyrop. i. 2. 8; Hell. vii. 1. 35. In apparent imitation of the present passage, Arist. says, *)aq. *hol. 19, suneba/lleto de\ ou)k e)la/ttw moi=ran th=s o(rmh=s toi=s *la/kwsin h( pro\s tou\s *)argei/ous toi=s *heisistrati/dais u(pa/rlousa fili/a. Bl. and Kr. read proscunela/bonto (with Laur. and some inferior Mss.), the former citing iv. 47. 3 cunela/bonto de\ tou= toiou/tou ou)x h(/kista, kte(., and Dio C.'s imitation, xliii. 47. 4 prossunela/beto ga\r tou= lo/gou tou/tou, o(/ti kte(.—ou)k e)la/xiston th=s o(rmh=s: = ou)k e)laxi/sthn moi=ran th=s o(rmh=s. Cf. ii. 21. 19, and Arist. l.c. The phrase is to be taken as obj. of proscuneba/leto. Cf. Lys. xxx. 16; Dem. xli. 11. Cf. to\ plei/ston th=s gnw/mhs, c. 31. 11; tou= qarsei=n to\ plei=ston, iv. 34. 5. See on i. 5. 10. Kühn. 416, N. 4. o(rmh/, excitement, impulse. Cf. iv. 4. 4; vii. 71. 32.—11.
e)s *)iwni/an parakinduneu=sai: venture over to Ionia. See on c. 32. 15. parakinduneu/ein also iv. 26. 18. Cf. e)s ta\s *)epipola\s diekindu/neusen, vii. 47. 11. See on i. 63. 3.— 12.

ou)k a)po\ braxei/as dianoi/as: after no slight consideration, i.e. after long premeditation; or, with St. and others, non parvo consilio o)li/gon ou)de\n e)pinoou=ntes (ii. 8. 1). Kr. compares Liban. Basil. 117 d ou)k a)po\ braxei/as gnw/mhs ei)s to\n po/lemon kate/-
sthsan. For a)po/ in this sense, see on i. 91. 28; for braxei/a, see on i. 14. 11.

a)/ggelon: pred. to trih/rh, as viii. 106. 18 a)pe/steilan e)s ta\s *)aqh/nas trih/rh a)/ggelon th=s ni/khs.—15. diaxrh/sasqai: to destroy, as i. 126. 37; vi. 61. 17; Hdt. i. 24. 12; 110. 18; Antiph. i. 23; Aeschin. iii. 244; Xen. Mem. iv. 2. 17.
a)nalogismo/s: not re-consideration, but reflection, as viii. 84. 1. So a)nalogi/zesqai, v. 7. 3; viii. 83. 10. —

w)mo\n to\ bou/leuma kai\ me/ga: the pred. position of the adjs. throws the chief stress on them. me/ga pregnant = deino/n. See on c. 3. 3. ma=llon h)\ ou), as in ii. 62. 18, and often in Hdt. and Dion. H. The neg. implied in ma=llon h)\ sometimes induces a pleonastic neg. in the following clause. Kühn. 516, 6; Kr. Spr. 49, 2, 4.—18.

tw=n *mutilhnai/wn oi( paro/ntes pre/sbeis: Steup thinks this cannot be the same embassy as that mentioned in c. 28. 7, because Paches could not have executed the decree of the Athenians without violating the agreement (c. 28. 8, 9). But it seems more natural, since Thuc. mentions neither the return of the embassy of c. 28. 7, nor the sending of another, to suppose that the pre/sbeis remained at Athens in the hope of persuading the Athenians to milder measures. The spirit of the agreement was fulfilled when orders came from Athens, whether the ambassadors returned or remained.—19.
oi( . . . cumpra/ssontes: cf. c. 101. 4. For the position of the gen. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, see on c. 22. 27.—20.
pareskeu/asan: induced, as in iv. 132. 11; viii. 52. 1; and passive in vii. 35. 2. Kühn. 473, 2. —

tou\s e)n te/lei: i.e. the prytanes, or the ten strathgoi/, the former of whom ordinarily summoned assemblies, though the latter had this right in war and under extraordinary circumstances. See on ii. 22. 4; 59. 11; iv. 118. 53. See Schoemann, Gr. Ant. i.^{3} p. 404.—21.
