au)=qis gnw/mas proqei=nai: to bring the subject again under consideration, also c. 42. 1; vi. 14. 3; and in c. 38. 2, le/gein protiqe/nai. See on i. 139. 18.—22.

e)/ndhlon h)=n: with partic., as in ii. 64. 31.
G. 1589; H. 981. Cf. iv. 41. 14; vi. 36. 6.—
to\ ple/on tw=n politw=n: see on c. 35. 6.—23.
tinas: indef., it is true, as in iv. 69. 4; vi. 41. 4; vii. 29. 14, but referring to tou\s e)n te/lei, —a)podou=nai: with inf. as i. 144. 12; ii. 71. 14.
katasta/shs e)kklhsi/as: as in i. 31. 15, of an assembly convoked for a special purpose, i.e. su/gklhtos. See Schoemann Gr. Antiq. i.^{3} p. 403.
a)f) e(ka/stwn e)le/gonto: a)po/, on the part of, as in c. 82. 41; v. 82. 16; vi. 32. 18; with mhnu/esqai, vi. 28. 1; a)gge/llesqai, vi. 45. 2. See on i. 17. 4, and Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 50.— 25.

th\n prote/ran e)nenikh/kei: here of the person, as ii. 12. 6; 54. 7 of the view that prevails. For the cognate acc. th\n prote/ran sc. gnw/mhn, see G. 1052; H. 716 a; Kr. Spr. 46, 6. Cf. Plato Gorg. 456 a oi( nikw=ntes ta\s gnw/mas, Ar. Nub. 432. See App.— 26.
biaio/tatos: most arbilrary and arrogant, as in i. 95. 1.—27.
para\ polu/: by far. Kühn. 349^{b}, 7 b. Cf. i. 29. 19; ii. 8. 13; 89. 16; viii. 6. 16.—

piqanw/tatos: cf. iv. 21. 10; vi. 35. 9; and see Introd. to Book I., p. 45, 46. Aristotle says of Cleon, *)aq. *holit. 28, dokei= ma/lista diafqei=rai to\n dh=mon tai=s o(rmai=s, kai\ prw=tos e)pi\ tou= bh/matos a)ne/krage kai\ e)loidorh/sato kai\ perizwsa/menos e)dhmhgo/rhse, tw=n a)/llwn e)n ko/smw| lego/ntwn. SPEECH OF CLEON. cc. 37-40.

The demos is too prone to mild treatment of subject states: it incurs thereby great harm, but will incur greater still, if it does not enforce decrees once adopted, and recognize that for the welfare of the state, sober judgment (swfrosu/nh) on the part of citizens is above all things requisite.
polla/kis me\n . . . kai\ a)/llote . . . ma/lista de/: cf. vii. 8. 5.—2.
a)du/naton: incompetent. See Ullrich, Beitr. 1862, p. 20 ff. For the neut. pred. adj. with fem. subj., see G. 925; H. 617. Cf. l. 16; vi. 39. 1; Hdt. i. 62. 6; Ar. Eccl. 236.—
e(te/rwn: in the general and comprehensive sense of any others, as i. 85. 6; ii. 35. 14.
dia\ ga\r to\ . . . e)/xete: cf. similar thought in i. 68. § 1.—4.

ran . . . pro\s a)llh/lous: more fully expressed by Pericles in ii. 37. § 2. pro/s and e)s denoting general relations without difference of meaning here, as l. 7, 9 below; also c. 54. 2; i. 32. 10; 38. 1.—5.

to\ au)to/: sc. to\ a)dee\s kai\ a)nepibou/leuton.—kai\ o(/ ti a)\n . . . malaki/zesqai: and whatever false step you make through being misled by their words, or whatever you yield through pity, you do not consider that your yielding brings danger to yourselces and does not win favour from your allies.—6.

h)\ lo/gw| peisqe/ntes . . . h)\ oi)/ktw| e)ndw=te: i.e. the two chief sources from which Cleon has reason to fear opposition to his advice, to which is added in c. 40 h( e)piei/keia. Instead of e)ndo/ntes, as was to be expected, e)ndw=te is made coord. with a(ma/rthte.—oi)/ktw|: cf. c. 40. 7; 48. 1.—7.
e)pikindu/nws e)s u(ma=s: cf. i. 91. 26 e)s tou\s pa/ntas w)felimw/teron.—kai\ ou)k: and not, differing from ou)de/ as et non from neque. —
ou)k e)s th\n xa/rin: lit. not for the gratitude of. Cf. c. 40. 19; ii. 40. 22. —8.
malaki/zesqai: as in c. 40. 34; vi. 29. 11.—

o(/ti turanni/da e)/xete th\n a)rxh/n: exactly as Pericles had expressed himself in ii. 63. 8. Thuc. prob. purposely puts into the mouth of Cleon turns of thought and expression which are clearly echoes of the speeches of Pericles. Cf. c. 38. § 1; 40. § 4. Far as Cleon was removed from him in mind and mode of thinking, he had yet learned from him what was effective in a speech. —9.

kai\ pro\s e)pibouleu/ontas au)tou\s kai\ a)/kontas a)rxome/nous: emphatically opp. to a)nepibou/leuton pro\s a)llh/lous. And indeed as against those who are themselves plotting against you and bear your rule unwillingly. —10.

ou)k e)c w(=n . . . perige/nhsqe: this explanation of a)/kontas a)rxome/nous is added without connecting word, as c. 63. 8 h(\n au)toi\ ma/lista proba/llesqe: i(kanh/ ge h)=n kte(., iv. 10. 10 to\ duse/mbaton h(me/teron nomi/zw: meno/ntwn h(mw=n cu/mmaxon gi/gnetai. In all three cases a rel. pron. (here oi(/) is read in only a few and inferior Mss. They obey you not in consequence of the kindnesses you do them to your own hurt, but in consequence of the superiority you have acquired by strength rather than by their good will. So Cl. and Bm. explain, but see App. e)c w(=n, for the assimilation, see G. 1032; H. 996 a. ma=llon h)/ completely subordinates the second member. Cf. l. 26; c. 63. 20; 64. 9.

be/baion: the adj. is pred. to kaqesthke/nai, as c. 102. 25; i. 70. 2; 102. 6; ii. 59. 8; iv. 26. 24; 78. 12; vi. 15. 17; vii. 28. 31. Pred. adjs. occur with the pres. kaqi/stasqai, iv. 92. 15; with the aor. katasth=nai, i. 6. 16; 23. 11; vi. 59. 4.—

w(=n a)
 do/ch| pe/ri: i.e. peri\ tou/twn, peri\ w(=n a)
 do/ch|, or, with Ullrich (Beitr. p. 23), = peri\ tou/twn a(\ a)
 do/ch|, in which case it would be an instance of the rare attraction of the nom., as in vii. 67. 19. G. 1033; Kühn. 555, N. 4.—15.
krei/sswn e)sti/n: is stronger, i.e. can use its strength more effectually, as also c. 48. 8.—

a)ku/rois: without authority, i.e. not enforced. The antithesis to a)ki/nhtoi is not logically exact, but suits the case. Alcibiades uses a similar paradox, vi. 18. § 7; but in neither case is the argument fair, because the question is not one of abolishing a fundamental law of the state (kinei=n no/mon), but of rescinding a decree of the demos (kaqairei=n yh/fisma), which could be set aside by another yh/fisma. Cleon's wish seems to be ‘to confound yhfi/smata and no/moi together, and to excite against the repeal of one of the former the same strong feeling which was entertained in Greece against any alteration of the latter.’ Arn. On the relation of no/mos, which, ace. to Aristotle, was a law of general application, to yh/fisma, a decree for an individual case (Eth. v. 14; Pol. iv. 4), see Tarbell, Am. J. of Ph. x. p. 79 ff. See also Hermann, Gr. Ant. i.^{6} § 91. Cf. Dio C.'s imitation of the passage (liii. 10), ta\ ga e)n tau)tw=| me/nonta, ka)
 xei/rw h)=|, sumforw/tera tw=n a)ei\ kainotomoume/nwn, ka)
 belti/w ei)=nai dokh=|, e)sti/n. Junge, zur Rede d. Kleon, 1879, p. 2 ff., thinks that the words mhde\ . . . a)ku/rois, and in § 4, oi( me
 fai/nesqai and oi( de\ . . . ei)=nai, refer to a law against reconsidering, within a certain period, things concerning which there was already a yh/fisma. A comparison with vi. 14 makes this argument seem plausible; but surely in that case Cleon would have made the charge of parano/mwn.—16. a)maqi/a: ignorance, i.e. lack of training and experience. Cf. i. 68. 4; ii. 40. 14. The whole sentiment is like that of Archidamus in i. 84. § 3 (cf. Arist. Rhet. i. 15. 12), and is more in accord with Spartan ideas than with Athenian, as expressed by Pericles in ii. 40.—
decio/ths: cleverness, = cu/nesis, l. 23; c. 82. 50.—17.
oi( faulo/teroi: the simpler, i.e. humbler, inferior, as c. 83. 8. Cf. also vii. 77. 9.—
pro/s: in comparison with, as in c. 56. 16; i. 6. 15; 10. 8; ii. 35. 11. Kühn. 441, iii, 3 c; Kr. Spr. 49, 2, 8.—18.
e)pi\ to\ plei=on: for the most part, only here, like w(s ta\ plei/w, c. 83. 8, for the usual w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/, ii. 13. 23; v. 107. 3. See App. on i. 12. 4.—

a)/meinon oi)kou=si ta\s po/leis: administer their states better. The passive occurs viii. 67. 6 a)/rista h( po/lis oi)kh/setai. Cf. also i. 17. 4; vi. 18. 44. For the sentiment, cf. Eur. El. 386 oi( ga\r toiou=toi ta\s po/leis oi)kou=sin eu)= kai\ dw/mata.

oi( me/n: sc. oi( cunetw/teroi.— 20. tw=n te ai)ei\ . . . perigi/gnesqai: and to surpass whatever is on every occasion said for the public good. le/gesqai e)s to\ koino/n = e)s to\ koino\n bouleu/esqai, i. 91. 29. Cf. in commune consulere, Ter. Andria iii. 3. 16; in commune consultare, Plin. Epist. vi. 15. 16. With the general sentiment Arn. compares Tac. Hist. i. 26 consilii quamvis egregii, quod non ipse adferret, inimicus, et adversus peritos pervicax.—21.

w(s e)n a)/llois . . . th
 gnw/mhn: as if in no other affairs of greater importance could they display their opinion, i.e. show their insight. Cf. Dio C. xlvii. 1 w(s ou)k a)
 a)/llws th
 e)autou= deino/thta diadei/cas. For partic. with a)
 representing aor. opt., see GMT. 215; H. 987 a; Kr. Spr. 69, 7, 1. See on vii. 67. 26.—22.
sfa/llousi ta\s po/leis: cf. vi. 15. 20.— 23.
oi( de/: sc. oi( faulo/teroi.—th=| e)c e(autw=n cune/sei: their own cleverness. Cf. to\ a)f) h(mw=n au)tw=n eu)/yuxon, ii. 39. 6.—

a)maqe/steroi tw=n no/mwn: cf. the expression of Archidamus, i. 84. 13, a)maqe/steron tw=n no/mwn th=s u(peroyi/as paideuo/menoi.—24. a)dunatw/teroi . . . lo/gon: less able to criticise the speech of a good speaker. It is only in the order of the words that the clause is like the preceding. See on i. 69. 32. a)dunatw/teroi, sc. h)\ cunetw/teroi, limited by me/myasqai, tou= kalw=s ei)po/ntos depending on lo/gon.—25. kritai\ de\ o)/ntes . . . a)gwnistai/: being impartial judges rather than contending disputants. For a)po\ tou= i)/sou, see on c. 10. 12; i. 77. 8. a)gwnistai/ has also the secondary meaning of partisans striving for personal pre-eminence and advantage. Cf. l. 27 cune/sews a)gw=ni, and c. 82. 50 cune/sews a)gw/nisma.—26. o)rqou=ntai ta\ plei/w: they are generally in prosperity, and with them the state, which, as the antithesis to sfa/llousi ta\s po/leis shows, is esp. had in mind. o)rqou=ntai as in c. 30. 15; 42. 20; ii. 60. 5; v.
9. 14; 111. 24; vi. 9. 11; viii. 64. 18; Hdt. i. 208. 8. ta\ plei/w is a little stronger than ta\ polla/ in Bl. and Jow. render o)rqou=ntai here judge rightly, or are in the right.

w(/s: for kai\ ou(/tws only here in Thuc. and rare also elsewhere in Attic prose. It occurs in Plato, Prot. 338 a (as here with ou)=n); Rep. 530 d. Cf. Hdt. ix. 18. 11. It is common in Homer and other poets, rare in the Attic poets. See Kr. Dial. 77, 1. Cf. Soph. O. C. 1242; Eur. Bacch. 1068. Kr. Spr. 25, 10, 11; Kühn. 561, N. 4.—27.
h(ma=s: we, who come forward as orators, as opp. to u(me/teron plh=qos. Cf. c. 43. 13. —

deino/thti kai\ cune/sews a)gw=ni: with eloquence and the exercise of elererness. Strietly the gen. deino/thtos was to be expected, but instead of this, one quality (deino/ths) and the ambitious exercise of the other (cune/sews a)gw/n) are loosely connected. deino/thti, Schol. th=| r(htorikh=| duna/mei. Cf. viii. 68. 9. —28.

para\ do/can: “contrary to our own judgment,” as in Plato Crit. 49 c; Prot. 337 b. So Steup explains, citing in support of his view c. 38. § 2, and c. 42. 29 para\ gnw/mhn ti kai\ pro\s xa/rin le/goi. See also Junge, ibid. p. 7 f. But Cl. adopts, with St. and Bm., Reiske's conjecture (see also Ullrich, Beitr. 1862, p. 48) para\ to\ do/can (contrary to the decree of the majority), because para\ do/can means everywhere else in Thuc. contrary to expectation, which is, of course, inadmissible here. Cf. c. 39. 25; 93. 4; i. 141. 21; ii. 49. 28; iv. 106. 10; viii. 42. 13. With this view, to\ do/can is as to\ dokou=n, c. 38. 11; i. 84. 8, and parainei=n, absolute, as in ii. 13. 15; vi. 24. 7; viii. 46. 29; 71. 25.

That our magistrates should suffer a reconsideration of our decision concerning Mytilene is surprising, and attempts to persuade you to a different conclusion can proceed only from dishonest motives. But it is no wonder that attempts are made to mislead you by fine-sounding words, since you are wont to devote yourselves to the enjoyment of brilliant speeches rather than to forming a judgment from actual cireumstances.

e)gw\ me
 o( au)to/s ei)mi: the very words of Pericles, ii. 61. 5. Cf. Soph. O. R. 557 kai\ nu=n e)/q: au(to/s ei)mi tw=| bonleu/mati. Dio C. imitates the passage, xxxviii. 44 e)gw\ me
 ga kai\ to/te kai\ nu=n th
 au)th
 gnw/mhn e)/xw kai\ ou) metaba/llomai. Cf. also Soph. Phil. 521; Eur. Phoen. 920.—2.

qauma/zw tw=n proqe/ntwn . . . le/gein: tw=n proqe/ntwn is short for tw=n proqe/ntwn o(/ti prou/qesan. Cf. u(mw=n qauma/zw, ei) mh\ bohqh/sete, Xen. Hell. ii. 3. 53; also Lys. xii. 86; Lyeurg. in Leocr. 135. For the gen., see G. 1126; H. 744; Kr. Spr. 47, 10, 9; Kühn. 417, N. 9. proqei=nai le/gein for the more usual proqei=nai lo/gon, or proqei=nai gnw/mas (c. 36. 21; cf. c. 42. 1)—a)podou=nai
bouleu/sasqai (c. 36. 23). Cf. Hdt. viii. 49. 2 proqei=nai gnw/mhn a)pofai/nesqai. See Schoemann, de Comit. Athen., p. 104.—3.
e)mpoihsa/ntwn: causing, as in i. 2. 17; ii. 51. 16.—

pro\s tw=n h)dikhko/twn: in the interest of those who have done wrong. For pro/s with gen., see G. 1216 a; H. 805, 1 b; Kr. Spr. 68, 37, 1; Matth. 590, 6. Cf. c. 59. 1; ii. 86. 19; iv. 10. 8; 29. 11; 92. 36; vii. 36. 18; 81. 27; viii. 36. 9.—4.
a)mblute/ra| th=| o)rgh=|: with duller anger, i.e. anger that has already cooled off. The thought must be completed by supplying the words xro/nou diatribh=s e)mpoihqei/shs. Cf. ii. 40. 21.—5.
e)pece/rxetai: with the dat. (tw=| dra/santi), in the sense of revenge (v. 89. 3; vi. 38. 10), as in that of attack (c. 27. 6; ii. 23. 1; v. 9. 8), of pursuit (iv. 14. 20).—

a)mu/nasqai: without art. as subject. Kr. Spr. 50, 6, 3. Cf. ii. 35. 7; 39. 22; 54. 8; 63. 14; Xen. Resp. Laced. 9. 2 e(/petai th=| a)reth=| sw/|zesqai ei)s to\n plei/w xro/non ma=llon h)\ th=| kaki/a|. —tw=| paqei=n: the dat. depends not upon e)gguta/tw alone, which always takes the gen. in Thuc., but upon e)gguta/tw kei/menon, the partic. being pf. pass. of tiqe/nai. Schol. ei) to\ a)mu/nesqai tw=| paqei=n e)ggu\s teqei/h. Cf. e)ggute/rw katasth=sai *)aqhnai/ois, ii. 89. 47. Kr. Di. 48, 9, 2; Matth. 542, N. 1. In Plut. de Sera 2, this passage is cited, and the sentiment approved by the speaker,—not by Plutarch. —6.

a)nti/palon ma/lista th\n timwri/an a)nalamba/nei: takes the punishment that is most adequate. On the omission of o)/n, see App. a)nalamba/nei timwri/an is not found elsewhere, but is to be compared with such expressions as e)/xqran, a)pe/xqeian, ki/ndunon a)nalamba/nein. Reiske and Cl. conjecture lamba/nei, considering the a)na- simply a repetition of the preceding -an, and so St. writes. Kr. suggests a)ntilamba/nei.—7. qauma/zw de\ kai\ o(/stis e)/stai o( a)nterw=n kte(.: as the first clause contains a defiant threat, so by a)ciw/swn a)pofai/nein ta\s me\n *mutilhnai/wn kte(. the presumptive opponent is, with intentional perversion, forced into a false alternative. “Whoever does not vote for the severest punishment of the Mytileneans must show (I wonder who will presume to show) that the revolt of the Mytileneans is helpful to us, while our misfortunes are hurtful to our allies,” i.e. that they, by their revolt, which was certainly detrimental to Athens (h(mete/ras cumfora/s), did us good, but themselves harm. From the impossibility of proving this is to be dedueed the necessity of extreme severity. That the guilt of revolting and the necessity of its punishment do not, however, neces
sarily imply the destruction of the guilty, Cleon purposely does not say. A correct conception of the connexion shows that every change proposed is unnecessary. See Junge, ibid. p. 9 f.

kai\ dh=lon o(/ti . . . a)gwni/sait) a)/n: and it is plain that either he has such confidence in his powers of speech as to contend that what is universally acknowledged is not established (clearly known), or, to use St.'s words, id quod omnibus probatum est non constat. to\ dokou=n is here used in the philosophical sense found in Xen. Mem. iv. 6. 15 dia\ tw=n dokou/ntwn toi=s a)nqrw/pois a)/gein tou\s lo/gous. For the force of e)/gnwstai, cf. Dem. xxi. 41 a)\n ga\r tau=q: ou(/tws e)gnwsme/na u(pa/rxh| par) u(mi=n. For the inf., a)ntapofh=nai, dependent on a)gwni/sai) a)/n, cf. c. 82. 59; iv. 87. 23; viii. 89. 30, and see Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 16. The term a)gwni/zesqai is chosen as if the reference were to the delivery of a show-piece (a)gw/nisma, i. 22. 19), and the figure of an oratorical competition is kept up in what follows (a)gw/nwn l. 14, a)gwnoqetou=ntes and qeatai/ l. 16, a)ntagwnizo/menoi l. 25). The interpretation above is essentially that also of Heilmann, Arn., Kr., and Bm. Others (Portus, Duker, Kistemacher, Bredow, Haacke, Goell., and Bl.), understanding to\ dokou=n to refer to the decree passed the day before, explain, “What was most certainly your resolution has really not been adopted.” But this, it is objected, would require to\ do/can.—12. h)\ ke/rdei e)pairo/menos . . . peira/setai: or incited by gain (i.e. bribed), elaborating what is plausible in words he will try to mislead you. Thus an insinuation of bribery is made in advance against any reply. It is the course which is aptly characterized in c. 42. 12 e)kplh=cai a)\n tou/s te a)nterou=ntas kai\ tou\s a)kousome/nous. For ke/rdei e)pairo/menos, see on a)gw=ni e)pairome/nous, c. 37. 27. In c. 40. § 1 also, Cleon makes a distinction between those of his opponents who would display their oratorical skill and those who are bribed. para/gein as in i. 34. 9; 91. 6; ii. 64. 1. For to\ eu)prepe\s tou= lo/gou, cf. c. 11. 10. For the neut. adj. in place of abstract noun, see on c. 30. 4; i. 36. 3.

e(te/rois: Schol. toi=s r(h/torsi.— 15. a)nafe/rei: Schol. a)nafe/rei, a)nade/xetai. It seems not to occur else
where with ki/ndunon, but cf. a)nafe/rein fqo/nous kai\ diabola/s, Polyb. i. 36. 3; a)nafe/rein fqo/nous kai\ to\n po/lemon, Polyb. iv. 59. 10; a)nafe/rein to\n po/non, Dion. H. x. 24.

ai)/tioi d' u(mei=s: just as unworthy motives are imputed by Cleon to his presumptive opponent, so the hearer who would show himself favourable to the former is charged with perverse conduct throughout, and this is expressed in a series of partics. and pred. adjs., continuing to the end of the chapter. The charges made are threefold: 1) that in the deliberation more value is placed upon words than facts (kakw=s a)gwnoqetou=ntes . . . a)po\ tw=n lo/gw| kalw=s e)pitimhsa/ntwn); 2) that in speeches what is new and unusual is more applanded than what is tried and in the long run wholesome (kai\ meta\ kaino/thtos . . . a)pobhso/mena); 3) that in the hankering after an ideal state actual conditions are neglected (zhtou=nte/s te . . . i(kanw=s); and finally all these errors are traced to the mania for rhetorical and sophistical performances (a(plw=s te . . . bouleuome/nois).—16.

a)gwnoqetou=ntes: cf. Aeschin. c. Ctes. 180 u(pola/bete toi/nun u(ma=s au)tou\s ei)=nai a)gwnoqe/tas politikh=s a)reth=s, Xen. Anab. iii. 1. 21 a)gwnoqe/tai oi( qeoi/ ei)sin.—qeatai\ me\n . . . tw=n e)/rgwn: “instead of seeing facts as they are and listening to speeches with judgment, you are on the contrary hearers of facts and seers of speeches, in that you view facts past and future in the light of what the orators say (a)po\ tw=n eu)= ei)po/ntwn) and attend upon the speeches as spectators of a contest of sophists, in which the prize is awarded for technical adroitness, not for the truth.” Bm.—17.

ta\ me\n . . . e)pitimhsa/ntwn: not in the facts, but in the discussion of them (tw=n eu)= ei)po/ntwn, tw=n lo/gw| kalw=s e)pitimhsa/ntwn), is found the rule or measure by which is determined (a)po\ . . . skopou=ntes) both the practicability of the me/llonta e)/rga, and the truth about the pepragme/na (though these ought to be experienced, not heard about). skopei=n a)po/ as in i. 21. 11; ii. 48. 14.— 19.

ta\ de\ pepragme/na h)/dh: sc. skopou=ntes.—ou) to\ drasqe\n pisto/teron o)/yei labo/ntes h)\ to\ a)kousqe/n: not taking what is done as more to be trusted, because you have seen it, than what is heard. labei=n = u(polabei=n, as in ii. 42. 17; iv. 106. 6. With the sentiment of the whole passage, cf. vii. 48. 20 ff. to\ drasqe/n as in vi. 53. 8.

kai\ meta\ kaino/thtos me\n lo/gou . . . e)qe/lein: the best to be deceived with novelty of words and to be un-
willing to follow with the rest in case of approved advice, i.e. where a proposition (lo/gou) has been tested and approved. With meta\ kaino/thtos lo/gou, cf. Isoc. x. 2 e)pi\ th=| kaino/thti tw=n eu(rhme/nwn. a)/ristoi, sc. o)/ntes, ironieal, adepts. It is equiv. to e)pith/deioi, as the Schol. says, just as in Hdt. i. 193. 13 a)ri/sth . . . *dh/mhtros ka/rpon e)kfe/rein, iii. 80. 21 diabola\s a)/ristos e)nde/kesqai. Cf. also Hdt. i. 136. 2 ma/xesqai ei)=nai a)gaqo/n, and Hes. Op. 763, 779, 813; Soph. O. T. 440; Ar. Nub. 430; Xen. Cyrop. v. 4. 44. G. 1526; H. 952.—23.

dou=loi o)/ntes tw=n ai)ei\ a)to/pwn: slaves of every new extravagance. dou=loi o)/ntes, i.e. xai/rontes kai\ pisteu/onte/s, Schol. a)to/pwn as in ii. 49. 8; Schol. parado/cwn. Cf. Greg. Naz. i. p. 53 dou=loi o)/ntes tw=n a)ei\ paro/ntwn, Aristid. ii. 150 a th=s xrei/as a)ei\ dou/lous ei)=nai.—u(pero/ptai de\ tw=n ei)wqo/twn: scorners of what is established. u(pero/ptai not found elsewhere in Attic; Schol. katafronou=ntes. Both dou=loi and u(pero/ptai are explanatory of a)/ristoi, while tw=n ai)ei\ a)to/pwn represents kaino/thtos lo/gou, as tw=n ei)wqo/twn does dedokimasme/nou. In illustration of the whole passage, Bl. compares Ar. Eccles. 581-588.
ma/lista me/n, ei) de\ mh/: as in i. 32. 4; ii. 72. 8; iv. 104. 20; v. 21. 15; viii. 91. 15.—
au)to\s e(/kastos boulo/menos: the distrib. pron. after pl. subj. (u(mei=s), as in i. 141. 27; ii. 16. 11. —25.

a)ntagwnizo/menoi kte(.: the pl. is resumed. On the partic. depends not only dokei=n, but also ei)=nai with its preds. pro/qumoi and bradei=s. On dokei=n depend both a)kolouqh=sai and proepaine/sai. Vying with those that say such things, in seeming not to follow after them in insight, but when any one says anything clerer to applaud it beforehand. Cf. Dio C. lii. 8 a)ntagwnizo/menoi mh\ dokei=n o)rgi/zesqai.—toiau=ta: sc. kaina/ and a)/topa. So generally explained, but Steup brackets toi=s toiau=ta le/gousi. See App.— 27.
proepaine/sai: found only here. Cf. e)paine/sai, approve, iv. 65. 8; v. 37. 24.—

kai\ proaisqe/sqai te . . . a)pobhso/mena: and (vying) in being both eager to perceive beforehand what is said and slow to anticipate what will come of it. The first kai/ connects ei)=nai with dokei=n; while te, kai/ connect proaisqe/sqai pro/qumoi and pronoh=sai bradei=s, the emphasis being on the former, as in ii. 39. 24. See App.

a)/llo ti . . . zw=men: an entirely
different world, so to speak, from that in which we live. w(s ei)pei=n, as always in Thuc., not w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n, as in Plato and the orators. GMT. 777, 1; H. 956. Cf. i. 1. 9. For the pl. oi(=s after a)/llo, see Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 5.— 31.
a(plw=s te: and in a word, as in c. 45. 29; 82. 34. te inferential, and so, as que in Lat. See on i. 4. 5.—

a)koh=s h(donh=|: cf. c. 40. 7 h(donh=| lo/gwn. —h(ssw/menoi: with dat. as vii. 25. 41 ou) th=| tw=n polemi/wn i)sxu/i . . . h(sshqei=en. Elsewhere in figurative sense with the gen., as iv. 37. 6; v. 111. 15. In connexion with Cleon's placing the source of all evil in the prevailing enjoyment of fine speeches, is to be remembered the fact that about the end of this summer (see on c. 86. 12) Gorgias came to Athens for the first time, as ambassador from Leontini, and though Cleon could not have had him in mind in his real speech, Thuc. doubtless did, as he wrote the speech. —
sofistw=n: only here in Thuc., in Cleon's mouth, in the same unfavourable sense as often in Aristophanes (Nub. 331, 1111), Xenophon (Mem. i. 6. 13), and Plato (Phaedr. 257 d; Prot. 312 a, etc.).—32.

qeatai=s e)oiko/tes kaqhme/nois: the perversity of the practice of the sophists, whose object was not instruction, but vainglorious display, is characterized by qeatai/ (cf. qeatai\ tw=n lo/gwn, l. 16). kaqhme/nois is usually taken as explanatory of qeatai=s, sitting idly, as in Dem. ii. 23, 24; iv. 9, 44; viii. 77—similarly iv. 124. 24. But Kr. objects that no activity is required of spectators, and Steup seems clearly right in considering (with Hude, p. 98) qeatai=s as pred. Like men sitting as spectators of sophists rather than like men deliberating about the welfare of the state.

Do not allow yourselves to be deceived in this case, but recognize that the Mytileneans have been guilty of an unpardonable crime, in that they have taken advantage of our embarrassment, in order to revolt, although they were far more favoured than other allies. § 1-5. All are alike guilty, the demos as well as the aristocrats, and untimely forbearance would only occasion further revolts, and bring upon you greater and greater losses. § 6-8.
w(=n: sc. e)pithdeuma/twn w(=n ei)=pen a)/rti, Schol. It covers the whole course of the Athenians as described in c. 38. § 4-7. The rel. is emphatic, as in c. 43. 1; 46. 20; i. 9. 19, etc.—
a)pofai/nw: I declare, as in ii. 62. 10. Cf. c. 67. 10. v. H.'s conjecture, a)pofanw=, is unnecessary.—2.
dh/: with the sup. as in c. 113. 22; i. 1. 8; vii. 87. 23, and freq.—

mi/an po/lin:
appos. to *mutilhnai/ous, as viii. 40. 7 toi=s *xi/ois . . . mia=| ge po/lei . . . plei=stoi geno/menoi. For similar expressions, cf. c. 113. 21; i. 80. 13; vi. 20. 8; viii. 68. 5. Kr. Spr. 49, 10, 5.
oi(/tines: without tou/tois, as in v. 16. 16, about equiv. to ei)/ tines. Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 3.—

dunatoi/: without o)/ntes, co-ord. with the partic. a)nagkasqe/ntes, as in c. 38. 22 a)/ristoi is with boulo/menos and a)ntagwnizo/menoi. —5. nh=son de\ oi(/tines: nh=son, as strongest security for an au)ta/rkhs qe/sis (i. 37. 11) and for immunity from attack (a)lhpto/n, i. 37. 20), placed before the rel. Cf. vi. 36. 1. Kr. Spr. 54, 17, 7; Kühn. 606, 6. Cf. di/kas de\ o(/ti e)qe/lomen, i. 144. 14. oi(/tines, though hypothetical, has so manifest a reference to the Mytileneans that in l. 8 the neg. is ou) not mh/.—7. e)n w(=| kai\ au)toi/: not entirely dependent, therefore, on Attie protection. e)n w(=|, in which case. See on i. 39. 11.—
paraskeuh=|: force, as in vi. 31. 6; vii. 36. 3. Lesbian triremes are mentioned c. 4. 6; i. 116. 11; ii. 9. 20; 56. 7.—9.
timw/menoi: see on c. 9. 12. —
e)s ta\ prw=ta: imprimis, as c. 56. 22.—10.
ti/ a)/llo h)/: as in c. 58. 24; v. 98. 8, with following finite verb. The same elliptical const. as ou)de\n a)/llo h)/, ii. 16. 10. H. 612; Kr. Spr. 62, 3, 7; Kühn. 587, 18.—

e)pane/sthsan ma=llon h)\ a)pe/sthsan: rose up against rather than revolted from. For the paronomasia, freq. in Thuc., cf. c. 82. 31, and see on i. 33. 26. Cf. Dion. H. Ant. iii. 8. 2 ou) mo/non a)po/stasin e)bou/leusan a)f) u(mw=n, a)lla\ kai\ e)pana/stasin, Dio C. lxxi. 24 dhmosi/a te a)po/stasis, ma=llon de\ e)pana/stasis.— 11. me/n ge: as if the explanation of the e)pana/stasis also were to follow; but this is omitted since it is clear enough from the context. For the combination me/n ge, see on i. 40. 15.— 12.
meta\ tw=n polemiwta/twn sta/ntes: combining with our worst enemies. Cf. i. 33. 22; vii. 57. 4; 61. 12, and see on c. 11. 18.—13.

h(ma=s: emphatic position, as in i. 68. 1; 70.
5; v. 82. 23; vii. 78. 26.—14.
kaq) au(tou/s: of themselves, as in iv. 64. 14, 21, and freq.—
ktw/menoi: seeking to acquire, as in ii. 62. 26. Cf. e)pikta=sqai, i. 144. 2; ii. 65. 24.

para/deigma: warning example. The sing. as in iv. 92. 18, but the plur. c. 10. 20; 11. 24; vi. 77. 4. It is placed first, as if to be pred. to both ou)/te clauses; but as eu)daimoni/a of course cannot be a warning, an anacoluthon arises. For similar const., cf. c. 96. 11.—16.
o(/soi . . . e)xeirw/qhsan: cf. c. 10. § 4 ff.; i. 98. § 4; 99.—17.
pare/sxen o)/knon mh\ e)lqei=n: for the neg., see on c. 32. 14.—
ta\ deina/: dangers. See on c. 22. 26.—18.

e)lpi/santes makro/tera me
 th=s duna/mews, e)la/ssw de\ th=s boulh/sews: the antithesis is well chosen, in order to rouse both contempt and bitterness. “Their hopes went indeed far beyond their strength, but not far enough to satisfy their hate.” Cf. Schol. h)/lpisan, fhsi/n, a)posth=nai h(mw=n, o(/per mei=zon me/n e)sti th=s duna/mews au)tw=n, e)/latton de\ th=s boulh/sews au)tw=n. e)bou/lonto ga ou) mo/non a)posth=nai h(mw=n a)lla\ dh\ kai\ kaqelei=n th
 du/namin th=s po/lews, dia\ to\ loipo
 a)dew=s zh=n. Herbst (Zu Thuk. Erkl. u.s.w. 1892, p. 82) thinks that a contrast is intended between the Mytilenean view of their own power and that of the Athenians, i.e. they expected for themselves more than they could accomplish and from the Athenians less than they (the Mytileneans) could wish, so greatly did they underestimate the strength of the Athenians. —20.

i)sxu\n a)ciw/santes. . . proqei=nai: “having once determined to put might before right.” The clause is all the more effective since a good word (a)ciw/santes) is made to serve in a bad cause. i)sxu/s, as i. 76. 15, of brute force. proqei=nai with acc. and gen. also c. 84. 14; i. 76. 15; Hdt. iii. 53. 16; Soph. O. C. 419.—21.

e)n w(=|: emphasizes here more sharply than usual the moment, when in the hope of getting the better of the Athenians, now hard pressed by war and pestilence (cf. c. 3. § 1; 13. § 3), they made an unprovoked attack. See on

ei)/wqe de\ . . . e)s u(/brin tre/pein: unexpected good fortune is wont to make insolent those cities upon which it has come in the highest degree and in the shortest time. With the sentiment, cf. Liv. xxx. 42. 15 raro
simul hominibus bonam fortunam bonamque mentem dari; also Thuc. iv. 17. § 4; Dem. i. 23; Aristid. ii. 57. a)rposdo/khtos eu)praci/a is subj. of both clauses. For the Mytileneans it consisted in the straits of the Athenians, indicated by e)n w(=| . . . perie/sesqai. ai(=s=tau/tas ai(=s, the terminal dat. with e)lqei=n, as in c. 70. 2 and often. See on c. 5. 12; i. 13. 12. ma/lista and di) e)laxi/stou are adv. with e)/lqh|. Cf. di) o)li/gou, iv. 95. 1; v. 69. 19; vi. 47. 10; vii. 15. 13, and see on ii. 42. 24. e)s u(/brin tre/pein has tau/tas understood as object. Cf. c. 13. 4. See App.—24.

ta\ polla\ kte(.: the Schol. correctly explains = w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/. The subj. is eu)tuxou=nta with its modifiers. “And for the most part success that comes to men in accordance with reasonable calculations is safer than that which surpasses expectation, and mankind apparently find it easier to repel adversity, than to maintain prosperity.” eu)tuxou=nta as in iv. 62. 17; 79. 4. For omission of art., cf. c. 48. 8. GMT. 827. diasw/|zesqai as in v. 16. 11; 46. 9.
xrh=n de\ . . . tetimh=sqai: for the const., see GMT. 415, 419; H. 834, 897.—
kai\ pa/lai: iam pridem. Cf. c. 13. 5; 104. 14.—27.

mhde
 diafe/rontas tw=n a)/llwn: pred. to tetimh=sqai, without any advantage over others. ou(/tw tetimh=sqai u(f) h(mw=n w(s ou)de
 diafe/rontas tw=n a)/llwn, Schol. diafero/ntws, which St. has adopted, is the reading of some of the Mss., and is supported by Thuc.'s usage (i. 38. 10; 138. 11; ii. 40. 11; 51. 2; viii. 68. 17), as well as by the imitation of Dio C. xxxviii. 30. 3 h)\ ou)=n a)po\ prw/ths e)xrh=n mhde
 diafero/ntws h(ma=s tw=n a)/llwn a)nqrw/pwn hu)ch=sqai.— 28. kai\ ou)k: introduces in parataxis the result of the cond. implied in the preceding clause.—
e)s to/de: adeo, as in i. 75. 8.—
e)cu/brisan: also i. 84. 6.—29.
pe/fuke ga\r kai\ a)/llws kte(.: passes from the present case to a general remark, as in i. 99. 6; viii. 45. 6; Plut. Tim. 52 a. With the sentiment, cf. iv. 61. 19.—
to\ qerapeu=on, to\ mh\ u(pei=kon: collective neuters with personal force, as ii. 45. 5; iv. 61. 20. Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 17.— 30.
u(perfronei=n: with acc. also vi. 68. 10. Kr. Spr. 47, 23, 1.

kolasqe/ntwn: on the form, see
App.—
kai\ nu=n: even now, opp. to kai\ pa/lai, —
kai\ mh/: covers both the following clauses.—32.
h( ai)ti/a prosteqh=|: for the act. with acc., cf. l. 38; 42. 25; iv. 20. 12.—
a)polu/shte: for aor. subjv. in prohibition, see GMT. 259; H. 874; Kühn. 397, 3.—33.
h(mi=n ge: i.e. against us at least they were united, even if they were at variance among themselves.—
oi(=s g' e)ch=n: grammatically construed with pa/ntes, though really only the dh=mos is had in mind here, as well as in the next clause. For const., see on l. 26 above.— 34.

trapome/nois: this reading of a few good Mss., is more appropriate with e)n th=| po/lei ei)=nai than the vulg. trepome/nois. “Who might have turned to us and been now reinstated in their city.” As to this rendering, which is essentially that of Va., see also L. Herbst, Philol. xlii. p. 711.—
a)lla\ . . . cunape/sthsan: but considering the danger with the oligarchs safer (than that with us), they joined them in revolt. Cf. c. 47. 3. Const. bebaio/teron with ki/ndunon, as v. 108. 2.

tw=n te cumma/xwn: introduces the new consideration with emphasis. The part. gen. covers not only toi=s te a)nagkasqei=sin . . . a)posta=si, but also ti/na oi)/esqe o(/ntina ou). Both a)nagkasqei=sin and e(kou=sin are pred. to a)posta=si. —38. ti/na . . . o(/ntina ou): as in c. 46. 8, this becomes by attraction one word, as it were, in force and const. like ou)dei\s o(/stis ou), c. 81. 24; vii. 87. 14. Cf. Xen. Cyrop. i. 4. 25 ou)de/na e)/fasan o(/ntin) ou) dakru/ont) a)postre/fesqai. Kr. Spr. 51, 10, 11; Kühn. 555, 5. After the long protasis, oi)/esqe repeats ske/yasqe of —
braxei/a| profa/sei: on a trifling pretext, as in i. 141. 4. For the force of braxei=a, see on c. 36. 12; i. 14. 11.—39.
katorqw/santi, sfale/nti: cf. c. 14. 5, 7; ii. 65. 28, 29; vi. 12. 7, 8.—
e)leuqe/rwsis h)\ paqei=n: for the noun and inf. co-ordinated as subj. of h)=|, see Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3.
h(mi=n de/: what follows, though logically dependent on ske/yasqe, is grammatically independent. — 41.

a)pokekinduneu/setai: pass. prob. only here; in vii. 81. 26 intr. Kr. Spr. 52, 3, 4. Cf. ii. 43. 26 h( e)nanti/a meta-
bolh\ . . . e)/ti kinduneu/etai, Dem. xviii. 278 tw=n o(/lwn ti kinduneu/etai th=| po/lei, xxxiv. 28 ta\ xrh/mata h)/dh kinduneu/etai tw=| danei/santi, xix. 285 ta\ me/gista kinduneu/etai th=| po/lei. For fut. pf. expressing certainty that an action will immediately take place, see GMT. 79; Kr. Spr. 53, 9, 3.—42.
tuxo/ntes: = katorqw/santes, as in c. 42. 18; 82. 31; iv. 63. 13; v. 111. 27.—43.

th=s e)/peita proso/dou: the future revenue, i.e. that which would have accrued if the state had not been destroyed. Cf. i. 123. 2. to\ loipo/n is pleonastie, it is true, but after the inserted rel. clause it is not without force. But see App.—

di) h(/n: elsewhere h(=|per (h(=|) with i)sxu/ein, as i. 142. 12; ii. 13. 18. It is connected kata\ cu/nesin with th=s proso/dou without e)/peita.—44. sterh/sesqe, e(/comen: change of pers., as in v. 9. § 1. Kühn. 371, N. 5.—45.

dei=: Cobet's conjecture, e)/dei, is unnecessary, since Cleon could hardly mean, either here or c. 40. 39, that their enemies would have to be entirely neglected, but only that conflicts with their cu/mmaxoi would cripple opposition to the nu=n kaqesthko/tes e)xqroi/.

As their guilt has been wilfully incurred, do not weakly allow yourselves to be moved by pity, charm of words, or a spirit of fairness to change your decree. They have merited the severest punishment, and this will secure the permanence of your rule; whereas by revoking your decree you would condemn yourselves.

proqei=nai: proponere, not prosqei=nai (although in Vat. and other good Mss.); alone appropriate with e)lpi/da. Cf. c. 52. 18 kathgori/a ou)demi/a proete/qh.—ou)/te lo/gw| pisth\n ou)/te xrh/masin w)nhth/n: neither relying on eloquence, nor to be bought with money. Both here and c. 38. § 2, those who would merely show their cleverness are set over against those who are bribed. pisto/s in this sense also in Plato Legg. 824 b, and freq. in the poets.—2.

w(s cuggnw/mhn a(martei=n a)nqrwpi/nws lh/yontai: that they will be ercused as having erred humanly, i.e. pardonably. Cf. Dem. xix. 238 cuggnw/mh a)delfw=| bohqei=n. cuggnw/mhn lh/yesqai = cuggnwsqh/sesqai, hence the inf. elause, a(martei=n a)nqrwpi/nws, giving the ground of the pardon. Cf. Hdt. i. 89. 14 cuggno/ntes poie/ein se di/kaia.
Kr. Spr. 61, 7, 5; Kühn. 473, 5. cuggnw/mh as in c. 44. 6. For its const. with inf., cf. iv. 61. 17; v. 88. 1; Hdt. i. 39. 1. With the sentiment of the passage, cf. c. 45. 7; Xen. Cyrop. vi. i. 37 cuggnw/mwn tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn a(marthma/twn, Dio C. p. 24 toi=s a(marta/nousi cuggnw/mhn kata\ to\ a)nqrw/pinon.—4. cu/ggnwmon: = cuggnw/mhs a)/cion (Schol.), as in iv. 98. 19. Cf. Dem. xviii. 274 e)ch/marte/ tis a)/kwn; cuggnw/mh a)nti\ th=s timwri/as tou/tw|, Dion. H. Ant. i. 58 a(/pan de\ cuggnw/mhs a)/cion to\ a)kou/sion. On the accent of cu/ggnwmon (not cuggnw=mon) after the analogy of kako/daimon, see Göttling, Accentlehre, p. 329 f.
kai\ to/te: sc. diemaxesa/mhn. Cf. i. 86. 7; vi. 60. 13.—

diama/xomai: with mh/ and inf. as in c. 42. 7; Xen. Anab. v. 8. 23; Eur. Alc. 694. Cf. also i. 143. 25; v. 41. 14; vii. 63. 1. Kühn. 597, 2 k. to/te refers to what happened in the assembly the day before. Cf. c. 69. 2; i. 101. 8.—

mh\ metagnw=nai u(ma=s ta\ prodedogme/na: depends only on nu=n diama/xomai, having no reference to the to/te prw=ton clause. Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 16. metagnw=nai means rather unvote than repent. Cf. i. 44. 4. The view of MüllerStrübing (Thuk. Forsch. p. 187 ff.) and others, that ta\ prodedogme/na refers to a decree adopted before the assembly of the previous day, is inconsistent with to/te prw=ton, whether the assumed decree were a general measure that was of importance for the question of the treatment of the Mytileneans, or a specific decree referring thereto. For Cleon would hardly have made so covert a reference to such a measure, and such an anticipatory decree would be wholly at variance with c. 35 f.— 6.
trisi\ toi=s a)cumforwta/tois: the order as in i. 74. 3.—7.
h(donh=| lo/gwn: cf. a)koh=s h(donh=|, c. 38. 31; also i. 84. 9; ii. 37. 12.—

e)pieikei/a|: fairness (Matthew Arnold's ‘sweet reasonableness’), esp. the benevolent treatment by the a)/rxousa po/lis of her allies, which does not allow her superiority to be felt. Cf. l. 14; 48. 2; also i. 76. 20, to\ e)pieike/s and its result.
e)/leo/s te: the first of the tri/a ta\ a)cumforw/tata, the other two being oi(/ te te/rpontes (10), kai\ h( e)piei/keia (13). Note the different connexion in i. 74. 4 (te, kai/, kai/).—

tou\s o(moi/ous: Cl., St. and Bl. interpret, those who are like-minded, as in i. 71. 7; but Steup rightly follows Kr. in understanding, those who are placed in like circumstances, i.e. only toward equals, and not subject-allies, is mercy in order. Only this view is compatible with e)c a)na/gkhs kaqestw=tas ai)ei\ polemi/ous.— di/kaios a)ntidi/dosqai: for the pers.
const. with inf., see GMT. 762; H. 944 a. The unusual inf. pass., as in c. 94. 22; Xen. Cyneg. 3. 3; Plato Legg. 751 b. GMT. 763; H. 952 a.— 9.
a)ntoiktiou=ntas: found only here. —
e)c a)na/gkhs: necessarily, as in vi. 44. 5; vii. 27. 17.—11.

r(h/tores: here, in Cleon's mouth, as well as in the two other passages in Thuc. (vi. 29. 14; viii. 1. 5), used already in its unfavourable secondary meaning to characterize those who make a profession of oratory (cf. te/rpontes lo/gw|) and use it for personal or party purposes.

e(/cousi kai\ e)n a)/llois e)la/ssosin a)gw=na: i.e. the orators who consider political deliberations as an a)gw/n (c. 38. § 4) will have an opportunity to display their cleverness in other matters of less importance, which will be no hardship to those who treat every matter w(s e)n a)/llois mei/zosin ou)k a)\n dhlw/santes th\n gnw/mhn (c. 37. 21).— 12.
braxe/a: combines the ideas of short duration and slight enjoyment. For the neut. adj. as cognate acc., see G. 1054; H. 716 b; Kr. Spr. 46, 5, 4. —13.

to\ paqei=n eu)=: to\ xrhmati/sasqai u(po\ tw=n *mutilhnai/wn, Schol. The same insinuation of bribery as in l. 2 above and c. 38. 12. The phrase is strengthened by its chiastic relation to the preceding.—14.
e)pithdei/ous: = pistou/s, faithful as allies, as in vi. 46. 8.—15.

o(moi/ws te kai\ ou)de\n h(=sson: on Thiersch's conjecture o(moi/ws for o(moi/ous, see App. With the expression, cf. me/giston de\ kai\ ou)x h(/kista, vii. 44. 32; plei=stos fo/nos kai\ ou)deno\s e)la/sswn, vii. 85. 17.—16.
u(poleipome/nous: who always remain, chiastically opposed to me/llontas.

e(/n te: the reading of one Ms. (C. acc. to Hude), adopted by St. and Cl. for e(\n de/ of the other Mss., acc. to Thuc.'s constant usage in a resumé. So cunelw/n te, ii. 41. 1; vi. 80. 14; a(plw=s te, c. 38. 31; 45. 29; 82. 34; to/ te cu/mpan, c. 92. 17; iv. 63. 9; vii. 77. 33; to/ te cu/mpan ei)pei=n, vii. 49. 18; para/pan te, vi. 18. 41; panti/ te tro/pw|, ii. 21. 21; iv. 4. 11. See Haase, Lucubr. p. 75.—18.
ta\ cu/mfora: sc. u(mi=n au)toi=s. Cf. i. 42. 3.—

toi=s me\n ou) xariei=sqe: you will not win their gratitude. Cf. c. 37. 7 ou)k e)s th\n
tw=n cumma/xwn xa/rin.—19. dikaiw/sesqe: not found elsewhere in Thuc., who uses only dikaiou=n = di/kaion h(gei=sqai. It is chosen here with reference to ta\ di/kaia e)s *mutilhnai/ous poih/sete above, do justice to, i.e. punish. It seems to be an Ionic usage. Cf. Hdt. i. 100. 8; iii. 29. 12; v. 92. b 14; Plato Legg. 934 b. See Diener, de Serm. Thuc. p. 30 f. For the mid., cf. kola/zesqai, l. 22; sfa=s au)tou\s bebaiw/sasqai, i. 33. 23.—

ei) ga\r ou(=toi o)rqw=s a)pe/sthsan . . . a)/rxoite: for if these had a right to secede, it would follow that your dominion is unjust, i.e. a revocation of the former decree (gno/ntes a)/llws) would be a confession that the Mytilenean revolt was just, and consequently the Athenian rule unjust. For the mixture of the prot. of the simple (not unreal) cond. with an apod. of the ideal, to soften the assertion, see GMT. 503; H. 901 b. Cf. c. 9. 6; i. 121. 16.—20.
ou) xrew/n, ou) prosh=kon: acc. abs. GMT. 851; H. 973; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 5. ou) prosh=kon also iv. 95. 4; vi. 82. 10; 84. 1.

ei) de\ dh\ . . . a)ndragaqi/zesqai: not meant, as ei) ga\r . . . a)/rxoite, to substantiate u(ma=s . . . dikaiw/sesqe, but earrying out some such thought, to be supplied, as “which you will certainly not acknowledge.” See App. —
a)ciou=te: are resolved. Cf. ii. 11. 33; 64. 24.—
tou=to dra=n: sc. a)/rxein. For this expression referring to some action just deseribed, see on i. 5. 11. —22.
toi: occurs isolated only twice more in Thuc. (ii. 41. 11; vii. 77. 5), always introducing an emphatic assertion.—
cumfo/rws: tou= cumfe/rontos e(/neka th=| a)rxh=|, Schol. Cf. ta\ cu/mfora, —
kola/zesqai: not pass., but as the whole context, esp. pau/esqai, shows, mid., as dikaiw/sesqe above. Cf. vi. 78. 8; Ar. Vesp. 406, and Steph. Thes. s.v.—
h)/: = ei) de\ mh/, as in ii. 63. 3, which passage is imitated here both in thought and expression (a)ndragaqi/zetai).—23.
e)k tou= a)kindu/nou: adv. periphrasis, as e)k tou= eu)qe/os, i. 34. 10; e)k tou= a)sfalou=s, i. 39. 2; a)po\ tou= profanou=s, i. 35. 17; a)po\ tou= eu)qe/os, c. 43. 5.

th=| te au)th=| zhmi/a| a)ciw/sate a)mu/nasqai: the sentence would properly read h(=| ei)ko\s h)=n au)tou\s u(ma=s a)mu/nasqai krath/santas u(mw=n, but the natural order having been interrupted by kai\ mh\ . . . fanh=nai, expressing the neg. side of the thought, the force of th=| au)th=| is left to be inferred from what follows. Schol. h(=| a)\n e)timwrh/santo kai\ au)toi\ u(ma=s, perigeno/menoi u(mw=n. But Steup would understand, “as on the day before,” objecting that the above interpretation is strained, and that one cannot see how Cleon
could have represented the course of the victorious Mytileneans toward the Athenians as a zhmi/a.—a)nalghto/teroi: elsewhere in prose only in late writers. It means here, like dusa/lghtos, Soph. O. R. 12, without feeling, not sensitive; unfeeling, cruel, in Soph. Aj. 946; Trach. 126; Eur. Hipp. 1386. Cf. a)nalgh/tws, unfeelingly, Soph. Aj. 1333.—25.
oi( diafeu/gontes: the pres. partic. here expresses continued action, as in c. 4. 13; ii. 2. 22. It is appos. to u(mei=s understood. Kr. Spr. 50, 7, 14.—26.
ei)ko\s h)=n: as c. 10. 20. Without a)/n (as e)ch=n, i. 37. 21; kalo\n h(=n, i. 38. 10) as apod. to krath/santas (i.e. e)kra/thsan). See on c. 10. 20. GMT. 420, 421; H. 897.—
krath/santas u(mw=n: Cleon uses every where in c. 40 the second person in speaking of the Athenians. Cf. c. 39. 2, 44. h(mw=n, which many editions have, seems to be unsupported by any good Ms.—27.
trou+pa/rcantas: cf. prw=toi tou= toiou/tou u(pa/rcantes, i. 76. 11; toi=s u(pa/rxousi prote/rois, ii. 74. 17. The same force as the simple verb u(ph=rcan, ii. 67. 29.

ma/lista de\ kte(.: whoever without cause have wronged another, follow him up to destroy him utterly, apprchending always danger from the surviving (i.e. not yet completely destroyed) enemy. The thought agrees in the main with the famous words of Tacitus, Agr. 42 proprium humani ingenii est odisse quem laeseris. Cf. Dryden: Forgiveness to the injured does belong, But they ne'er pardon who have done the wrong; and Gladstone, Nineteenth Century, xxv. p. 151, ‘The hatred which nations . . . are apt to feel towards those whom they have injured.’—28.
mh\ cu\n profa/sei: as is charged against the Mytileneans c. 39. § 1, 2.—
e)pece/rxontai kai\ diollu/nai: so with St. for the unintelligible dio/lluntai of the Mss. See Rh. Mus. xv. p. 475. The inf. of purpose as in i. 50. 3; ii. 65. 44. GMT. 770; H. 951.—29.
to\n ki/ndunon . . . e)xqrou=: the gen. with ki/ndunos, as in ii. 63. 5.—30.

o( ga\r mh\ cu\n a)na/gkh| . . . e)xqrou=: contains at once the ground for the extreme fear and therefore extreme hostility of the Mytileneans, and the justification of the severest punishment by the Athenians. ‘For he who has suffered evil without needful cause is more dangerous, if he shall have escaped, than one who was an enemy on equal terms, i.e. than one who has not suffered more than he has inflicted.’ (Arn.) a)po\ th=s i)/shs as in i. 15. 11.
prodo/tai ge/nhsqe: see on c. 2. 11.—32.

geno/menoi o(/ti e)ggu/tata th=| gnw/mh|: = o(/ti e)ggu/tata dianohqe/ntes (i. 143. 22); from which e)nqumhqe/ntes must be supplied with w(s pro\ panto\s . . . xeirw/sasqai. Recalling as nearly as possible the feelings (of the moment) of suffering, and how you would then have prized above everything to crush them. Schol. ei)s eu)/noian e)lqo/ntes w(=n e)me/llete pa/sxein u(po\ *lesbi/wn. Cf. Aesch. iii. 153 ge/nesqe dh/ moi mikro\n xro/non th\n dia/noian mh\ e)n tw=| dikasthri/w|. pro\ panto/s stronger than pro\ pollw=n with the similar expression in i. 33. 8; vi. 10. 16.—34.
a)ntapo/dote: here abs., in the same signification as with ta\ o(moi=a, c. 66. 8; to\ i)/son, i. 43. 5.— —
malakisqe/ntes: as in c. 37. 8; vi. 29. 11.—35.

pro\s to\ paro\n au)ti/ka: the pleonasm is not greater than in e)n tw=| to/te paro/nti, i. 95. 26; tw=n e)/peita mello/ntwn, i. 123. 2; e)n tw=| nu=n paro/nti, Plato Phaedo 67 c. See also on c. 39. 43. For the position, cf. pa/lin h( a)pokomidh/, i. 137. 26. pro\s to\ paro/n, as in ii. 22. 1. Cf. pro\s ta\ paro/nta, ii. 3. 15; 6. 3; 59. 10; iv. 80. 8; e)pi\ tw=| paro/nti, ii. 36. 18; vi. 20. 3.—
tou= e)pikremasqe/ntos pote\ deinou=: the danger once hanging over you. Cl. and Kr. conjecture to/te, as antithesis to au)ti/ka. See on i. 101. 8.
tou/tous te kai\ toi=s a)/llois: te kai/ on account of the antithesis of the pronouns. See on ii. 46. 1. Observe the chiastic order of the sentence.— 37.

toi=s a)/llois . . . zhmiwso/menon: give to the rest of the allies plain warning that whoever revolts shall be punished with death. ‘The const. of the partic., depending on the phrase safe\s para/deigma katasth/sate, seems to be protected by the similar examples, c. 67. 28 poih/sate . . . para/deigma ou) lo/gwn tou\s a)gw=nas proqh/sontes, a)ll) e)/rgwn, c. 64. 1 dh=lon e)poih/sate . . . ou) mhdi/santes, Lycurg. 50 fanero\n pa=sin e)poi/hsan ou)k i)di/a| polemou=ntes, where the partic. clauses take the place of the objects.’ St. Cf. also Hdt. vi. 21. 8 *)aqhnai=oi dh=lon e)poi/hsan u(peraxqesqe/ntes th=| *milh/tou a(lw/si. The const. is the same as with the simple verb dhlou=n. GMT. 904, 907; H. 981; Kühn. 482, 2. The dat. with zhmiwso/menon as in ii. 65. 12. Elsewhere with para/deigma, that which is to be proved, or of which an example is to be given, is expressed (if it be not clear from the context, as in c.
10. 20; 11. 24; 39. 14; ii. 37. 2; iv. 92. 18; v. 90. 7; vi. 77. 4) in the gen., as c. 57. 1; i. 2. 20; v. 95. 3.—39.

h(=sson . . . cumma/xois: cf. c. 39. 45 kai\ o(\n xro/non toi=s nu=n kaqesthko/si dei= e)xqroi=s a)nqi/stasqai.—toi=s u(mete/rois . . . cumma/xois: the speech concludes with a trimeter, as shown by Meineke, Hermes iii. p. 347. Cf. i. 80. 6; iv. 17. 6, and the hexameters ii. 49. 18; vi. 36. 1.

p.hi: Diodotus replies to Cleon.

div2.p: *dio/dotos: of Diodotus, to whom Thucydides has raised in the following speech a splendid monument, nothing is known historically, not even whether his father Eucrates was the stuppeiopw/lhs among the successors of Pericles (Ar. Eq. 129; cf. CIA. iv. 179 a), or the brother of Nicias. See Roscher, Leben etc. des Thuk. p. 411.—2.
o(/sper kai\ . . . *mutilhnai/ous: cf. c. 36. 25.—

a)nte/lege . . . mh\ a)poktei=nai *mutilhnai/ous: spoke most against putting the Mytileneans to death. Cf. v. 49. 11 a)nte/legon mh\ dikai/ws sfw=n katadedika/sqai, Xen. Anab. ii. 3. 25; Cyrop. ii. 2. 20. For the inf. with mh/ after verbs of denial, see GMT. 807; H. 1029; Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 3. SPEECH OF DIODOTUS. c. 42-48.

Reconsideration of the question can be only helpful. The worst enemies of safe conclusions are haste and passion, and whoever disputes the utility of speeches is either a fool, or has a personal interest in the matter. The latter is the case with those who, in order to support a bad cause, resort to slander and intimidation. Orators should renounce such means, and the state should treat with consideration not only those counsellors that usually give good advice, but even those that are not so fortunate.
th\n diagnw/mhn: used by Thuc. alone of Attie writers. Cf. c. 67. 33; i. 87. 17; and diegnwsme/nhn, c. 53. 22; die/gnwsto, i. 118. 18. The reference is to c. 38. § 1.—2.
memfome/nous: referring to the future, not, as usual, to the past, reproachfully warning. The reference is to c. 37. § 3.— 3.

peri\ tw=n megi/stwn: not from the point of view of the memfo/menoi, but of the speaker; the former would demand peri\ mhdeno\s polla/kis bouleu/esqai, the latter finds fault that this is not to be done even peri\ tw=n megi/stwn.
—4.

te: with the best Mss. instead of de/. It is not correlative to ou)/te, ou)/te, but introduces the third member. Steup follows Bk., with a few Mss., in writing de/, on the ground that the clause nomi/zw . . . o)rgh/n is antithetic to the preceding.—

du/o ta\ e)nantiw/tata: acc. to the analogy of c. 40. 6; 57. 15; 75. 5; i. 74. 3; 122. 22, these words are not to be construed as subj. and pred., but are equiv. to ta\ du/o e)nantiw/tata, so that the subj. is ta/xos te kai\ o)rgh/n, “that the two worst fores of correct conclusions are haste and passion.”—
eu)bouli/a|: cf. 44. 4; and eu)= bouleu/esqai, c. 48. 7.—
ta/xos: cf. c. 38. 3 ff.—
to\ me/n, to\ de/: the former refers to ta/xos, the latter to o)rgh/. “Overhaste generally indicates lack of sense; passion, lack of self-control and shallowness of judgment.”—
filei=: is wont, in Thuc. in this sense only; and in Hdt., except in v. 5. 5. See on i. 78. 5.—
gi/gnesqai: appear, often used of natural phenomena. See on i. 54. 6. —

meta\ a)paideusi/as: cf. c. 84. 7 a)paideusi/a| o)rgh=s e)kfero/menoi, and the Tragic frag. quoted by Stob. Flor. 20. 12 (Nauck, Trag. Gr.^{2}, Adespota 523) po/ll) e)/stin o)rgh=s e)c a)paideu/tou kaka/.— —6. kai\ braxu/thtos gnw/mhs: cf. Dio C. frg. p. 64 taxu\ me\n u(po\ braxu/thtos gnw/mhs o)rgizome/nhn. braxu/ths, shallowness, acc. to the usual sense of braxu/s in Thuc. See on i. 14. 11.
tou/s te lo/gous kte(.: the order as in c. 39. 5. The clause is directed against c. 38. § 4 ff. Cf. ii. 40. 9 ff. —7.
diama/xetai: see on c. 40. 5.— —
didaska/lous . . . gi/gnesqai: see on c. 2. 11.—8.

h)\ i)di/a| ti au)tw=| diafe/rei: or he has some private interest. Cf. tw=n au)toi=s i)di/a| diafo/rwn, i. 68. 8; ta\ i)dia dia/fora, ii. 37. 5; i)/dia/ tina dia/fora, v. 115. 8. Cf. also iv. 86. 23.— 10.
fra/sai: to throw light on. See on i. 145. 4.—11.
eu)= ei)pei=n: sneered at by Cleon, c. 38. 18; 40. 13; here assigned its true value.—

ou)k a)\n h(gei=tai: a)/n, which belongs to du/nasqai, separates the closely connected ou)x h(gei=tai. Cf. c. 37. 7 ou)k e)pikindu/nws h(gei=sqe kte(. On the partiality of a)/n for the neg., see GMT. 219; H. 862. ou) in prot. because it negatives a single word. GMT. 384; H. 1028; Kr. Spr. 67, 4, 1.—12.

eu)= de\ diabalw\n . . . a)kousome/nous:
excellent characterization of Cleon's whole speech, esp. of c. 38. eu)= is bitterly ironical.

xalepw/tatoi . . . tina: most dangerous, however, are just those who charge beforehand rhetorical display for the sake of money. xalepw/tatoi as in iv. 24. 21; vii. 21. 14. kai/, just (erst), as in Hdt. i. 71. 6, and freq.—

e)pi\ xrh/masi: placed for emphasis after oi(, limits e)pi/deicin, the prep. having the same force (for the sake of) as in i. 3. 9; 38. 15; 73. 14; ii. 29. 17; 64. 25. v. H. conjectured e)pidei/cein tina/, the obj. to be supplied, that one will display his art for money. Cf. Ar. Acharn. 765. —

prokathgorou=ntes: this reading of Laur., adopted by St. and v. H. instead of proskathgorou=ntes of most Mss., is in place after the fut. partic. tou\s a)nterou=ntas (l. 13). The charge of venality (cf. c. 38. 12; 40. 2, 13) might well be treated as the worst form of eu)= diaba/llein (l. 12), but not as something additional to this.—16.
a)cunetw/teros h)\ a)dikw/teros: the double comp., as in Lat., implies that of two qualities in the same obj. one predominates. H. 645; Kühn. 543, 5. See on i. 21. 5. —
a)pexw/rei: withdraw. The verb is used in the same unfavourable sense as the Lat. discedere. Cf. Dem. xxxvii. 21.—17.
a)diki/as e)piferome/nhs: when corruption is charged. The a)diki/a is to\ e)pi\ xrh/masi le/gein. e)pife/rein as in c. 46. 26; 81. 20; v. 75. 9.—18.
tuxw/n: see on c. 39. 42. Cf. e)pituxw/n, —meta\ a)cunesi/as: meta/, besides, as in i. 32. 8; ii. 15. 9. —
a)/dikos: sc. gi/gnetai, in the judgment of the many.
e)n tw=| toiw=|de: as in c. 43. 12; ii. 36. 2; v. 88. 1, the art. refers to what is known or just deseribed. The prep. has the same force as in e)n w(=|, e)n tou/tw|. See on i. 39. 11.—

tw=n cumbou/lwn: only here in the general sense of “advising statesmen,” as in Dem. xviii. 66. Elsewhere Thuc. uses it of Spartan officials with specific duties. Cf. c. 69. 7; ii. 85. 1; v. 63. 15; viii. 39. 7; 41. 3.—20.
plei=st) a)\n o)rqoi=to: see on c. 30. 15; 37. 26. For the sentiment of the passage, cf. Eur. Bacch. 270; Or. 907.—21.
tou\s toiou/tous tw=n politw=n: referring to those deseribed in l. 11 ff., esp. oi( e)pi\ xrh/masi proskathgorou=ntes,
e)la/xista: opp. to plei=sta above. It is cognate acc. with a(marta/nein. Cf. c. 40. 12.—22.

peisqei=en: the transition to the plur. is induced by tw=n politw=n in the line above. Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 2. Cf. c. 72. 8; viii. 72. 13. On the shorter form peisqei=en for peisqei/hsan of the Mss., see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 62, who cites Heracleides Milesius (Eustath. on Hom. y 195), h( a)rxai/a *)atqi\s ta\ eu)ktika\ cugko/ptei kat) e)cai/resin mia=s cullabh=s.—23. mh\ e)kfobou=nta . . . le/gonta: the const. is fai/nesqai a)/meinon le/gonta, mh\ e)kfobou=nta . . . a)ll) a)po\ tou= i)/sou. The good citizen must show himself the better speaker, not by intimidation of his opponents, but by meeting them on equal terms. a)po\ tou= i)/sou, as in c. 10. 12 = a)po\ th=s i)/shs, c. 40. 31.— 24.

th
 de\ sw/frona po/lin . . . u(parxou/shs: the wise city should not indeed confer additional honour on him whose counsels are generally sound, but also not lessen that which he already has. bouleu/ein, give advice, as in vi. 39. 5; viii. 76. 33. prostiqe/nai timh/n as in Xen. Cyrop. ii. 2. 18. Cf. c. 39. 32. a)lla\ mhd) e)lassou=n th=s u(parxou/shs seems, as Arn. says, to refer to pei/sas te u(/poptos gi/gnetai (l. 17). Cf. (concerning Antiphon) viii. 68. 8 u(po/ptws tw=| plh/qei dia\ do/can deino/thtos diakei/menos.—26. to
 mh\ tuxo/nta gnw/mhs: the one who is not fortunate in his view, i.e. whose advice is not so good. Cf. gnw/mhs a(marta/nein, i. 33. 17; vi. 92. 3; sfa/llesqai th=s do/chs, iv. 85. 5. Or, perhaps, the one whose advice is rejected, as mh\ tuxw/n, This rendering seems to be sustained by l. 28 f. Cf. th=s e(ka/stou do/chs tuxei=n, ii. 35. 19. Cf. Dio C. lii. 33. 7 tou\s me
 tuxo/ntas th=s gnw/mhs kai\ e)pai/nei kai\ ti/ma, . . . tou\s d' a(marto/ntas mh/t) a)tima/sh|s pote\ mh/t) ai)tia/sh|. Also xliv. 36. 3. See on c. 39. 42.—27.

ou)x o(/pws, a)lla\ mhde/: non modo non, sed ne . . . quidem. When the ou)x o(/pws clause precedes, it always contains the weaker of the two contrasted notions. See on i. 35. 12. GMT. 707; Kühn. 525, 3 b.
h(/kista a)/n: belongs to both following clauses. —
e)pi\ tw=| e)/ti meizo/nwn a)ciou=sqai: i.e. if timh\n prostiqe/nai were the sure reward of every successful speech.—29.
para\ gnw/mhn ti le/goi: cf. vi. 9. 12, and see on c. 37. 28.—

pro\s xa/rin: “to please the people.” Cf. ii. 65. 35 pro\s h(donh/n
ti le/gein, Dem. iii. 3 pro\s xa/rin dhmhgorei=n, iv. 38 pro\s h(donh\n dhmhgorei=n. In l. 30 the expression takes the form xari/zesqai, the clause xarizo/meno/s ti kai\ au)to/s, seeking applause also himself, being explanatory of tw=| au)tw=|. —30. prosa/gesqai: win over, as in c. 43. 7; 91. 7, etc.

But, unfortunately, this is not the case with us. Besides, your inordinate propensity to reject proposals, through suspicion of self-interest on the part of the orators that urge them, makes it difficult to put through good measures. Still, in such important matters, we orators must look further into the future than you, espeeially since we alone are held responsible.

w(=n: see on c. 39. 1. For gen. after ta)nanti/a, see G. 1146; H. 754 f; Kr. Spr. 48, 13, 4. The reference is to c. 42. 24 tw=| te pl:ei=sta . . . a)tima/zein.—h)/n tis kai\ . . . le/gein: u(popteu/htai belongs strietly only to ke/rdous e(/neka, some such word as dokh=| being understood with ta\ be/ltista le/gein. The reverse would be the natural order of the clauses in English. “Even though one seem to say what is best, if he be suspected of speaking for money.” On the correlation, see Kr. Spr. 69, 16, 1.—3.

th=s ou) bebai/ou dokh/sews tw=n kerdw=n: beeause of the unproved suspicion of gain, i.e. begrudging him the gain which we suspect he has got, although the suspicion is unproved. Cf. ii. 35. 9 e)n w(=| mo/lis: kai\ h( do/khsis th=s a)lhqei/as bebaiou=tai. do/khsis, as in c. 45. 6; ii. 35. 9; 84. 4; iv. 18. 21; 55. 16; 87. 2; 126. 17; vi. 64. 15; vii. 67. 3; Hdt. vii. 185. 3. ‘Often in Tragedy and late writers, but avoided in simple Attic prose.’ (Kr.) Cf. Soph. Trach. 426, 427; O. T. 681; Ant. 324; Eur. Hel. 36, 121; Heracl. 395.— 4.

th\n fanera\n w)feli/an th=s po/lews a)fairou/meqa: antithesis to the foregoing. We deprive the city of an undeniable advantage. a)fairei=sqai/ ti/ tinos as in c. 58. 29; vii. 13. 18; viii. 46. 33. G. 1118; H. 748 a.
kaqe/sthke: it has come to pass, with dependent inf., as i. 76. 11; iv. 97. 11.—5.
a)po\ tou= eu)qe/os lego/mena: said right out. Cf. e)k tou= profanou=s, See on e)k tou= eu)qe/os, i. 34. 10.—7.
ta\ deino/tata: the worst measures. Cf. c. 59. 17; 82. 59; 93. 5.—
a)pa/th|, (8)
yeusa/menon, (10)

mh\ e)capath/santa: cf. Cleon's words, c. 38. 12 ke/rdei e)pairo/menos to\ eu)prepe\s
tou= lo/gou e)kponh/sas para/gein peira/setai. —8. yeusa/menon pisto\n gene/sqai: obtain credence by false representations.

mo/nhn te po/lin . . . a)du/naton: the conclusion drawn from the foregoing. And ours is the only city which it is impossible, on account of this overshrewdness, to benefit openly without deceiving it. mo/nhn po/lin is pred. to h(ma=s, or th\n h(mete/ran po/lin, understood. Kr., Cl., and St. take mo/nhn alone as pred. to po/lin, which would make po/lin, a state, the antithesis to individuals. But, as Jow. says, Diodotus cannot mean to say this of every state, nor is there any reason for, or hint in the context of, any greater liability to such suspicions on the part of the state than on the part of the individual. peri/noia, in this sense, is not found elsewhere, but acc. to analogy of periousi/a, periergi/a, perite/xnhsis (c. 82. 22), means an excess of cleverness which will not be content with a simple view of things. Cf. Ar. Ran. 958 a(/panta perinoei=n. The pl. because of its manifestations everywhere apparent. The positive and negative modifiers, e)k tou= profanou=s and mh\ e)capath/santa, without connective, as in c. 59. 4.—11.

a)nqupopteu/etai: coined for the occasion, as is freq. the case with Thuc.'s compounds. Cf. c. 12. 12, 13 a)ntepibouleu=sai, a)ntimellh=sai, c. 40. 9 a)ntoiktiou=ntas, c. 44. 11 a)ntisxurizo/menos, c. 61. 16 a)ntipa/sxein. For forty such a(/pac ei)rhme/na compounds with a)nti-, see App. on iv. 80. 4.—
a)fanw=s th| ple/on e(/cein: that in some underhand manner he will reap some advantage. Arn. compares Arist. Rhet. iii. 16. 9 a)pistou=si ga\r a)/llo ti pra/ttein e)ko/nta plh\n to\ cumfe/ron.

xrh\ de\ . . . skopou/ntwn: “still, with reference to the highest interests and under such circumstances as the present, we must deem it our duty to base our counsels on a somewhat wider forecast than your offhand deliberations allow.”—
pro\s ta\ me/gista: cf. pro\s to\ paro\n au)ti/ka, c. 40. 35.—
kai/: = atque. Steup follows Haase (Lucubr. p. 42) in taking it as = etiam.—
e)n tw=| toiw=|de: as in c. 42. 19; ii. 36. 2; v. 88. 1. Cf. e)n tw=| toiou/tw|, c. 81. 23; iv. 56. 4.— 13.

a)ciou=n ti: Reiske's conjecture (in Abresch, Dilucc. Thuc. p. 319) for a)ciou=nti of the Mss. See Haase, Lucubr. p. 36 sqq., who rightly remarks that an adj. cannot be joined to such a partic. The emendation has been adopted also by Kr., St., and Bm. The subj. is h(ma=s, we orators. Cf. c. 37. 27. But Steup follows Bm., who understands u(ma=s as
subj. and renders a)ciou=n, grant (annehmen). ti belongs to peraite/rw.— pronoou=ntas: cf. c. 38. 28.—14.
di) o)li/gou: temporal, as in i. 77. 22; ii. 85. 9.—
u(peu/qunon th\n parai/nesin: they were liable to the grafh\ parano/mwn. For parai/nesin, cf. parainei=n, c. 37. 28.—15.
a)neu/qunon: as in Hdt. iii. 80. 11; Arist. Polit. ii. 9. Hence v. H.'s conjecture a)nupeu/qunon is unnecessary.—
a)kro/asin: not simply hearing, but hearkening to, as the context shows. Cf. ii. 37. 16.
swfrone/steron: i.e. with greater circumspection and moderation.—

pro\s o)rgh\n h(/ntina tu/xhte: “according to the passion of the moment.” pro\s o)rgh/n, as in ii. 65. 36; Soph. El. 369. Cf. c. 44. 14. h(/ntina without prep. repeated, as in c. 17. 1; 18. 1; and with subjv. without a)/n, as in iv. 17. 6; 18. 13. GMT. 540; Kr. Spr. 54, 15, 3. St. writes h(/ntin) a)/n. As to the elliptieal use of tu/lhte, cf. viii. 48. 37, and see on i. 142. 25. A grammatical supplement is doubtless to be assumed as original, but is not present to the mind of the speaker. Kr., Jow., Bm., and others supply zhmiou=ntes with tu/xhte, while Arn. construes it with sfale/ntes.—18. e)/stin o(/te: belongs to sfale/ntes, as well as to zhmiou=te.—19. ei) . . . cunech/marton: a fact expressed in hypothetical form. See on c. 32. 6.
The affair of the Mytileneans must be treated not as a question of right, but solely of our interest, which certainly cannot be subscrved by Cleon's proposed death-penalty for all Mytileneans.
ou)/te a)nterw=n: sc. tw=| *kle/wni. Cf. c. 38. 7; 41. 2; 42. 13, 23.—2.

ou)/te kathgorh/swn: sc. tw=n *mutilhnai/wn. —ou) ga\r . . . eu)bouli/as: “for, if we consider wisely, we shall find that for us it is a question not of their wrong-doing, but of our right counsel.” The same brachylogy in i. 40. § 2; vi. 11. § 7. See Steup, Thuk. Stud. ii. p. 18.

eu)bouli/as: c. 42. 4.
—
pa/nu: common in cond. sents. with conjs. or partics., vel maxime, ever so. Cf. ii. 13. 35; 51. 6; vi. 17. 32; viii. 50. 22; 71. 5.—5.
cumfe/ron: without e)sti/ also vi. 85. 2, as a)/cion, deino/n, di/kaion, ai)sxro/n, and similar neuters. Cf. c. 59. 9, 23. Kr. Spr. 62, 1, 4; 65, 5, 11.—6.

h)/n te kai\ e)/xonta/s ti cuggnw/mhs: sc. a)pofh/nw. So Cl., St., and Bm. explain, adopting e)/xontas, the reading of the Clarend. Ms., instead of the vulg. e)/xontes. Against Cleon's brutal demand (c. 40. 1 ou)k ou)=n dei= proqei=nai e)lpi/da . . . w(s cuggnw/mhn . . . lh/yontai) Diodotus offers his own view as modestly as possible; hence e)/xontas ti cuggnw/mhs (cf. ii. 49. 30; 51. 29). cuggnw/mh, excuse, as in c. 40. 2.—

e)a=n: Lindau's and Burgess's conjecture for ei)=en, adopted by Dind., St., Bm., and Bl. It depends on ou) dia\ tou=to keleu/sw, and means to let go unpunished. For the const., cf. Plato Euthyphr. 4 b ei) me\n e)n di/kh|, e)a=n, ei) de\ mh/, e)pecie/nai. “And if I show that they have some claim to forgiveness, I will not on that account advise you to let them go unpunished, if this should appear disadvantageous to the state.” See App.
h)\ tou= paro/ntos: without peri/ repeated. Kr. Spr. 68, 9; Kühn. 451, 6. See on c. 43. 17; vii. 47. 16. —

kai\ tou/tou o(\ ma/lista kte(.: tou/tou, which is Steup's emendation for tou=to of the Mss., depends on ta)nanti/a, If tou=to be retained, there would seem to be, as Bm. says, a slight anacoluthon, tou=to being repeated, in part of its idea, in peri\ tou= e)s to\ me/llon kalw=s e)/xontos. Cl., who with Pp. and Kr., connects tou=to grammatically with a)ntisxurizo/menos, explains that it is not really the obj. of the partic., but is placed first with almost the force of an abs. acc., as to that which. See on c. 15. 4; i. 32. 17. So also St. But Steup objects that tou=to o(/ is nowhere else so used, though o(/ alone, in this sense, occurs in other writers (cf. Xen. Anab. v. 5. 20; vi. 1. 29, and see Kr. 51, 13, 13).— 9.
i)sxuri/zetai: maintains, as in v. 26. 19; vi. 55. 2; vii. 49. 1, 23.—
e)s to\ loipo\n kte(.: cf. c. 39. § 7, 8; 40. § 8. The clause is epexegetical to tou/tou o(/. e)s to\ loipo/n also iv. 128. 21; vi. 75. 16.—10.
pro\s to\ h(=sson a)fi/stasqai: sc. tou\s cumma/xous. Cf. viii. 76. 25 pro\s to\ perigi/gnesqai tw=n polemi/wn h( po/lis sfi/si xrh/simos h)=n.—qa/naton zhmi/an: also ii. 24. 9.—

proqei=si: cf. c. 82. 61; ii. 46. 5, and pro/keitai, c. 45. 1. The partic. agrees with u(mi=n understood after cumfe/ron e)/sesqai. Cf. i. 118. 20 ei) polemou=sin a)/meinon e)/stai, Lys. xxv. 27 ou)k a)/cio/n
e)sti tou/tois xrh=sqai polla/kis cumbou/lois oi)=s ou)de\ a(/pac e)lusite/lhse peiqome/nois. —11. a)ntisxurizo/menos ta)nanti/a gignw/skw: I emphatically assert the contrary.
kai\ ou)k a)ciw= u(ma=s . . . a)pw/sasqai: and I demand that you reject not, etc. See on i. 102. 17.—
tw=| eu)prepei=: on account of the seeming fairness, as in c. 38. 12. Schol. piqalogi/a|. Cf. eu)pre/peia, c. 11. 10.—14.
dikaio/teros: i.e. based more on strict justice, as tw=| dikai/w| lo/gw| nu=n xrh=sqe, i. 76. 14.—
pro\s th\n nu=n u(mete/ran o)rgh/n: in your present anger, belongs to e)pispa/saito. See on c. 43. 17. Cf. c. 36. 5; 42. 4.—15.
e)s *mutilhnai/ous: for position after o)rgh/n, freq. in Thuc., see on c. 54. 18; i. 11. 19. G. 968; Kühn. 464, 1; Kr. Spr. 50, 9, 9.—
ta/xa a)\n e)pispa/saito: may perhaps attract you. Cf. v. 111. 15. —16.

h(mei=s de\ ou) dikazo/meqa pro\s au)tou/s: but we are not at law with them. dika/zesqai, as in i. 77. 7; Xen. Cyrop. i. 2. 7. Arn. compares, for the sentiment, Arist. Rhet. i. 3 te/los tw=| me\n sumbouleu/onti to\ sumfe/ron kai\ blabero/n, toi=s de\ dikazome/nois to\ di/kaion kai\ to\ a)/dikon.—tw=n dikai/wn: strict justice, as in c. 54. 1; Dem. xviii. 7.— 17.
o(/pws xrhsi/mws e(/cousin: sc. h(mi=n, how they shall be useful to us, i.e. how best to effect this, whether by severe punishment, or mild treatment.

p.hi: Mankind are so constituted that not even the danger of the deathpenalty will keep either individuals or states from transgressions.

div2.p: e)n ou)=n tai=s po/lesi kte(.: the diseussion announced above (c. 44. § 3 f.), as to whether the interests of Athens will be subserved by inflicting the death-penalty on the Mytileneans, is introduced with a general remark on the inadequaey of punishments, even of the death-penalty, to suppress crime. At the beginning of the next chapter the transition to the present case, for which Cleon had maintained (c. 44. 9 f.), e)s to\ loipo\n cumfe/ron e)/sesqai pro\s to\ h(=sson a)fi/stasqai qa/naton zhmi/an proqei=si, is made with ou)k ou)=n xrh/. Kühn. 508, N. 2. This chapter represents the earliest attempt to combat the theory that men are deterred from crime by fear of punishment. See M. Büdinger. Sitzungsberichte d. phil.-hist. Kl. d. Wiener Akad. xcvi. p. 384.—

pollw=n: be
longs with a(marthma/twn, from which it is only locally separated by the almost parenthetical ou)k i)/swn . . . e)lasso/nwn.—qana/tou zhmi/a: although, acc. to the analogy of c. 44. 10 and ii. 24. 9, qa/natos might have been expected (as Cobet suggests, Nov. Lect. p. 771), still the gen. is sufficiently protected by c. 46. 1 tou= qana/tou th=| zhmi/a|. Also in Isocr. viii. 50 qana/tou th=s zhmi/as e)pikeime/nhs, qana/tou must be considered a limiting genitive.—
pro/keitai: pass. of proqei=nai, c. 44. 10.—3.
th=| e)lpi/di e)pairo/menoi: as i. 81. 11. See on c. 37. 28; 38. 12.—4.

katagnou\s e(autou= mh\ perie/sesqai: passing sentence of failure on himself, lit. deciding against himself that he will not succeed. katagignw/skein of unfavourable judgment, as in vi. 34. 51; vii. 51. 3; Xen. Cyrop. vi. 1. 36 au)to\s e)mautou= kate/gnwn mh\ a)\n karterh=sai. See on c. 16. 1. Kühn. 476, 2.—5.
h)=lqen e)s to\ deino/n: as in c. 39. 17.

po/lis te: and so a state. The subj. placed first before the interr. pron. has almost the same character of generality as before the dem., having nearly the effect of the part. genitive. See on i. 1. 8.—
ti/s pw: no exception to the general rule that pw is used in neg. sents., since the interr. sent. is here equiv. to a negative.—6.
h(/ssw th=| dokh/sei: in its view insufficient. See on c. 43. 3.— 7.
h)\ a)/llwn cummaxi/a|: co-ordinated with oi)kei/an the phrase has almost the force of an adjective.—
tou/tw|: sc. tw=| a)fi/stasqai.

pefu/kasi de\ . . . a(marta/nein: cf. c. 84. 10, and Dio C.'s imitation, lii. 34. 6 polla\ ga\r h( fu/sis kai\ para\ to\n no/mon pollou\s a(marta/nein e)ca/gei, Soph. Ant. 1023 a)nqrw/poisi ga\r toi=s pa=si koino/n e)sti tou)camarta/nein, Eur. Hipp. 1433 a)nqrw/poisi qew=n dido/ntwn ei)ko\s a(marta/nein. Cl. writes de/, for te of the Mss., making the clause epexegetical. Cf. i. 55. 9; v. 10. 21.—9.

diecelhlu/qasi dia\ pasw=n: cf. Dem. ii. 5 pa/nta diecelhlu/qamen, and Xen. Cyrop. i. 2. 15 oi( gerai/teroi dia\ pa/ntwn tw=n kalw=n e)lhluqo/tes.—10. prostiqe/ntes: always adding to, aggravating the punishments. Cf. Dem. iv. 20.—

ei)/ pws: if haply. The real apod. is distinctly implied, but not formally expressed. GMT. 489; H. 907; Kr. Spr. 65, 1, 10. Cf. i. 58. 2; ii. 67. 5; iv. 11. 12.—
—11.
kai\ ei)ko/s: not introducing a new consideration, but confirming the foregoing general remark (diecelhlu/qasi/ ge . . . kakourgw=n).—12.

kei=sqai: here and c. 47. 13 (e)pikei=sqai, c. 70. 17; viii. 15. 6) of punishments, as ii. 46. 6 of rewards, ii. 37. 17 of laws, always as pf. pass. of tiqe/nai. —parabainome/nwn: as transgressions occurred. So with Bm., who compares, for the gen. abs. without expressed subject, i. 7. 2 ploi+mwte/rwn, i. 116. 15 e)saggelqe/ntwn. GMT. 848; H. 972 a. But St. understands tw=n zhmiw=n as subj., and gives parabainome/nwn the more general sense of disregarding, citing Aeschin. iii. 204 ou) tou\s no/mous mo/non parabe/bhken, a)lla\ kai\ to
 kairo
 th=s a)narrh/sews kai\ to
 to/pon, Dem. xxiv. 32 paraba\s to
 xro/non to
 e)k tw=n no/mwn. Cf. also Din. i. 36 parabebhkw\s a(/pantas tou\s parelhluqo/tas kairou/s.—13. tw=| xro/nw| . . . a)nh/kousi: cf. Lycurg. in Leocr. 65 (oi( a)rxai=oi nomoqe/tai) o(moi/ws e)pi\ pa=si kai\ toi=s e)laxi/stois paranomh/masi qa/naton w(/risan ei)=nai th
 zhmi/an. The phrase a)nh/kein e)s, to express highest intensity, occurs only here in Thuc., and is elsewhere unusual in Attie (Soph. Trach. 1018), but common in Hdt. (ii. 104. 8; v. 49. 16; vii. 9. g 4; 13. 6; 134. 13; viii. 111. 12).—14.

ka)n tou/tw| o(/mws parabai/netai: and under these circumstances transgressions occur all the same. ka)n tou/tw| is Kr.'s conjecture for kai\ tou=to of the Mss. Cf. i. 37. 15; 81. 9; ii. 89. 37. If the reading of the Mss. be retained, St.'s explanation is best, namely tou=to =to\ e)s to\n qa/naton ta\s polla\s a)nh/kein, and parabai/netai, is disregarded, as in Jow. explains: ‘tou=to refers to qa/natos, but parabai/netai is said inaccurately, not of death, but of the law which is sanctioned by the penalty of death. So parabainome/nwn really refers to the idea of a law contained in zhmiw=n just above.’ See App.
de/os: terror; fear, for the thing feared, as metus for periculum. —

to/de: used perhaps to avoid repetition of the same pronoun (tou/tou). Cf. Soph. Ant. 296 tou=to kai\ po/leis porqei=, to/d) a)/ndras e)cani/sthsin do/mwn. —e)pi/sxei: Schol., kwlu/ei.—16. a)ll) h( me
 . . . kindu/nous: but porerty, making men bold from necessity, and wealth, making them ambitious from insolence and pride, and the other relations of life, through passion, as each relation is enslared by some mighty and invincible impulse, lure mankind to destruction. a)na/gkh| and u(/brei kai\ fronh/mati belong to pare/xousa, while o)rgh=| belongs to e)ca/gousin and answers to the pare/xousa clauses above. Cl. changes tw=n a)nqrw/pwn of
the Mss. into to
 a)/nqrwpon. St. rejects these words and writes o)rgh/n (libidinem) for o)rgh=|, on the ground that it is demanded by the correspondence to to/lman and pleoneci/an. See App. With the sentiment, cf. Eur. El. 375 peni/a e)/xei no/son, dida/skei a)/ndra th=| xrei/a| kako/n, Arist. Rhet. i. 12 a)dikou=si, o(/soi a)
 e)ndeei=s w)=si: dixw=s de/ ei)sin e)ndeei=s: h)\ ga w(s a)nagkai/ou, w(/sper oi( pe/nhtes: h)\ w(s u(perbolh=s, w(/sper oi( plou/sioi, Dion. H. i. 25 h( a)na/gkh i(kanh/ e)sti toi=s a)poroume/nois bi/ou: to/lman parasxei=n.—17. e)cousi/a: opes, Va. Cf. i. 38. 13; 123. 6; vi. 31. 33.—
fronh/mati: in Thuc. always self-confidence, spirit. See on i. 81. 14.—18.
cuntuxi/ai: conditions of life, as in c. 82. 14. Cf. c. 112. 26; i. 33. 1; v. 11. 17; vi. 54. 2; vii. 57. 5.—19.

u(p) a)nhke/stou tino\s krei/ssonos: it is possible to supply simply o)rgh=s, but better perhaps to take krei/ssonos as neut., as most of the editt. seem to do, and render, by some mighty and invincible impulse. a)nh/kestos has the meaning insatiable, unappeasable, acc. to the const. a)kei=sqai paqh/mata. Cf. also Hom. N 115 a)kestai/ toi fre/nes e)sqlw=n.—e)ca/gousin: as in vi. 89. 22 = para/gein. Cf. Eur. Alc. 1080 e)/rws ti/s m) e)ca/gei, Herc. Fur. 775 a(/ t) eu)tuxi/a fronei=n brotou\s e)ca/getai, ibid. 1212; Ion. 361; Suppl. 79; Dio C. lii. 23. 2; 34. 6.

te: introduces a new consideration, besides; not correl. to kai/.— o( e)/rws: passionate desire. Schol. prw=to/n tis e)ra=|, ei)=ta e)lpi/zei, ei)=ta e)gxeirei=. —e)pi\ panti/: comprehends all the above definite and indefinite cases. Cf. i. 20. 2; iv. 11. 13; v. 100. 4.— 21.

th\n e)piboulh/n: the plot. So Cl. and Steup, with three Mss., for e)pibolh/n, undertaking, which most Mss. have. Hude calls attention to the fact that e)pibou/leuma is used in the same sense in Cf. i. 93. 23; iv. 77. 1; 86. 22; viii. 24. 38. But see App.—
e)kfronti/zwn: thinking out, a rare word found also in Ar. Nub. 695, 697.—22.
u(potiqei=sa: of the delusive suggestions of hope, similarly in i. 138. 8; iv. 65. 18. For the thought, cf. iv. 18. § 3; vii. 61. § 3.— 23.

kai\ o)/nta . . . deinw=n: and being unseen they outweigh the dangers that are seen. o)/nta neut., with the two nouns of different gender. G. 924 a; H. 617 a. o(rw/mena opp. to a)fanh=, as in ii. 42. 21; v. 113. 4.

kai\ h( tu/xh kte(.: as hope had
suggested that fortune would lend its support, so the latter too contributes toward leading men astray. tu/xh is here almost personified, now unexpectedly favouring, but again by that very means luring into danger.—
e)p) au)toi=s: besides these. Schol. meta\ to\n e)/rwta kai\ th\n e)lpi/da.—cumba/lletai: see on proscuneba/leto, c. 36. 10. —26.
e)k tw=n u(podeeste/rwn: even with inadequate resources. Schol. a)po\ mikrote/rwn a)formw=n. Cf. ii. 89. 22.—
proa/gei: leads on, even against their will, as in c. 59. 9.—27.
ou)x h(=sson: i.e. ma/lista, as in i. 8. 1, and freq. —
o(/sw|: in so far as, because, even without comparative. See on i. 68. H. Kr. Spr. 51, 10, 5. kinduneu/ousin, or, perhaps better, o( a)gw/n e)sti is to be supplied. See on iv. 63. 12.—

e)leuqeri/as h)\ a)/llwn a)rxh=s: Cl. explains that h)/ offers not a choice, but an alternative, and a)/llwn is subj. gen. But it would seem more natural to render, with Goell. and Jow., freedom or empire. So Valla.—28.

kai\ meta\ pa/ntwn . . . e)do/casen: the force of o(/sw| continues. The causes by which states are drawn into dangerous undertakings are two: 1) for the whole, greater advantages may be won; 2) the individual, in company with many, easily overestimates his own strength. This overestimate on the part of individuals, however, has a hurtful influence on the decisions of the many.—

meta\ pa/ntwn: Schol. tou= koinou=.—29. e)pi\ ple/on ti: the indef. pron. added to the comp. ple/on, as in ii. 11. 32. Cf. h(=sso/n ti, c. 75. 11; a)mele/stero/n ti, ii. 11. 14; ma=llo/n ti, i. 49. 9; ti ma=llon, ii. 22. 4; iv. 21. 16; vii. 57. 4; ti a)nepieike/steron, c. 66. 7.—
au(to\n: for the unintelligible au)tw=n of most good Mss.—
e)do/casen: esp. used of erroneous estimate. Cf. i. 120. 28; Dio C. lxxv. 9 e)pi\ plei=on e)doca/sqh. The aor. is gnomic. GMT. 155; H. 840; Kühn. 386, 7. See on i. 69. 31.
a(plw=s: see on c. 38. 31.—

a)du/naton: const. with a)potroph/n tina e)/xein . . . deinw=|.—30. pollh=s eu)hqei/as: sc. e)sti/n. Cf. i. 83. 4; 142. 24. G. 1091, 1; H. 732 d. This elliptical gen. is much less freq. than in Lat. —

o(/stis: so very hypothetical in foree that it is loosely connected, almost like ei)/ tis, with the leading clause. On this free connexion of the pers. rel. pron. with a neut. adj. or pred. gen., see Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 11; Kühn. 563, 3 d. Cf. the similar const. with o(\s a)/n, ii. 44. 4; vi. 14. 7; vii. 68. 4. So the eonst. is usually explained, but Steup thinks, if o(/stis oi)/etai were so intended, Thuc. would have written pollh\ eu)h/qeia. He pre
fers to take o(/stis as used by Diodotus c. 42. 7; 48. 7, and to construe pollh=s eu)hqei/as (sc. e)sti\ with pers. subj.) as gnw/mhs tino\s ei)=nai (see on i. 113. 10). Cf. Hdt. i. 107. 13 oi)ki/hs me\n e)o/nta a)gaqh=s, tro/pou de\ h(suxi/ou. Kr. Spr. 47, 6, 10.—31.

a)potroph/n tina e)/xein: can be deterred. Cf. Dio C.'s imitation of the passage (lv. 16), h( fu/sis h( a)nqrwpi/nh pa/ntws a(marta/nein tina\s a)napei/qei, kai\ a)mh/xano/n e)stin au)th\n pra=cai/ ti w(rmhme/nhn e)pisxei=n.

If therefore we cannot, even by accepting Cleon's proposal, attain certainty for the future, we ought not by pitiless severity to drive those who revolt to desperate resistance, thereby depriving ourselves of the basis of our own power, in that we shall have recovered the cities only after they are ruined.

ou)k ou)=n xrh\ ou)/te tou= qana/tou . . . bouleu/sasqai, ou)/te kte(.: only the first ou)/te clause is strictly a deduction from the argument of c. 45; hence the two ou)/te clauses stand related to each other as the te . . . kai/ clauses in c. 38. 27; ii. 39. 24, the emphasis being on the first.—

e)xeggu/w|: Schol., bebai/w|, i)sxura=| w(s e)gguh=sai duname/nh|. The word seems to be found elsewhere only in Tragedy and late Greek. Cf. Soph. O. C. 284; Eur. Med. 386; Andr. 191; Phoen. 759; Dio C. xliv. 25 e)xeggu/w| pi/stei to\ be/baion pronoh/sete. Cf. feregguw/tatos, viii. 68. 22. —2.
xei=ron bouleu/sasqai: as in i. 73. 7; here a euphemism for qa/naton yhfi/sasqai *mutilhnai/wn. Cf. eu)= bouleu/etai, c. 48. 7; eu)bouli/a, c. 42. 4; 44. 4.—
