ou)/te a)ne/lpiston katasth=sai . . . w(s ou)k e)/stai: i.e. ou)k a)ne/lpiston poih=sai to\ metagnw=nai. Cf. c. 40. § 8. The const. a)ne/lpiston katasth=sai toi=s a)posta=sin, as in i. 140. 30; ii. 89. 47; vii. 44. 26; viii. 66. 24.—3.

w(s ou)k e)/stai: pleonastic neg. after a)ne/lpiston. Cf. a)nte/legon w(s ou) kte(., i. 77. 13. H. 1029 a; Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 2; Kühn. 516, 3 b. See on c. 32. 13; i. 77. 13. ou)k e)/stai, it will not be possible, with inf.; in this sense usually with subst. This pregnant force of the verb is freq., esp. after a neg. See on i. 2. 5.—4.

o(/ti e)n braxuta/tw|: the prep. regularly stands after o(/ti, w(s, thus used with a superlative. Kr. Spr. 49, 10, 1; Kühn. 452, N. 3. Cf. o(/ti e)p) e)la/xiston, See on i. 63. 5; ii. 34. 24; and for similar const. in Lat., Madvig on Cic. de Fin. v. 9. 26.—

th\n a(marti/an katalu=sai: suum peccatum eluere. Cf. mei=zon e)/gklhma lu=sai, i. 42. 11; e)gklh/mata katalu=sai, i. 82. 24; dialu/sein th\n diabolh/n, i. 131. 12; lu=sai ta\s pro/teron a(marti/as, Ar. Ran. 691. For the act., where the mid. might have been expected, see Kühn. 375, 2.
nu=n me/n: of the present situation, analogous to the more common nu=n de/, and opp. to e)kei/nws de/ below, as in vi. 11. 9.—
kai/: emphatic with a)posta=sa. Not, as Kr. and Steup, with h)/n. There is a reference to c. 45. § 2, but the emphasis is here on the tense, even after it has revolted. —6.
periesome/nh: as in c. 45. 4.—
e)/lqoi a)/n: softened expression for the regular fut. ind. GMT. 505; H. 901 a. Cf. the reverse form of condition, i. 121. 13.—7.
e)/ti: belongs to ou)=sa.— a)podou=nai, u(potelei=n: aor. of single act of payment of war costs; pres. of regular tribute.—8.
e)kei/nws de/: as in i. 77. 13; vi. 11. 10.—
ti/na h(/ntina ou)k: see on c. 39. 38. This const., as well as the form of expression throughout, shows that outward similarity to Cleon's words, though with opposite purpose, is sought.—9.

paraskeua/sasqai: the aor. is the reading of nearly all the Mss. for the vulg. paraskeua/s esqai. Steup retains the aor., comparing for similar change of tense, as here from paraskeua/saqai to paratenei=sqai, iv. 28. 26, 28; 52. 16, 17; vi. 24. 3, 13; viii. 5. 35. It would seem better, with St., to write the future. See Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 10 sq. But see App. on this passage and on ii. 3. 8.—

poliorki/a| te paratenei=sqai e)s tou)/sxaton: will suffer themselves to be reduced by siege to the last extremity. Cf. Ar. Nub. 213 (of Euboea) u(po\ ga\r h(mw=n pareta/qh kai\ *herikle/ous (explained by Schol., e)cetruxw/qh kai\ kateponh/qh), Plato Symp. 207 b tw=| limw=| paratei/nesqai. Also Xen. Cyrop. i. 3. 11; Mem. iii. 13. 6. On fut. mid. used as pass., see Kühn. 376, N. 1; Kr. Spr. 40, s.v. Cf. vii. 48. 37. The meaning hold out, resist to the last, seems not to occur except in Dio C. and other late writers. te, correl. to me/n joined to an emphatic word, marks a change from an adversative const. to a simple connexion. Kühn. 530, l. Cf. i. 144. 10; ii. 70. 12.—10.
du/natai: valet, means, cumbh=nai being subj., to\ au)to/ object. Cf. i. 141. 5; vi. 36. 9.
h(mi=n te kte(.: answering and almost parodying c. 39. § 8, hence possibly de/ (for te) should be written as there.—
kaqhme/nois: sc. in tedious siege. Cf. iv. 124. 24; v. 6. 22.—

dia\ to\ a)cu/mbaton: on account of the impossibility of coming to terms. The cu/mbasis implied has reference to both sides; neither is inclined to it. The final capitulation is here not regarded as a cu/mbasis. The word a)cu/mbaton,
though rare, is sufficiently explained by l. 6 and 10. It seems to be used elsewhere only in late writers, e.g. Polyb. xv. 9. 1. Cf. a)sumba/tws e)/xein, Plut. Cic. 46; Cam. 17; Dion 21.—12.
kai\ h)\n e(/lwmen: corresponding to tuxo/ntes in c. 39. 42, and without expressed object.—13.
a)p) au)th=s: for omission of art. after th=s proso/dou, see Kr. Spr. 50, 9, 9. Cf. ii. 52. 2. —

i)sxu/omen . . . tw=|de: sc. tw=| ta\s proso/dous eu)= e)/xein. Cf. c. 39. 43; i. 122. 2. With the sentiment of the passage, cf. also v. 93. 2 h(mei=s de\ mh\ diafqei/rantes u(ma=s kerdai/noimen a)/n. Jow. quotes Burke's speech on Conciliation with America: ‘A further objection to force is, that you impair the object by your very endeavours to preserve it. The thing you fought for is not the thing which you recover; but depreciated, sunk, wasted, and consumed in the contest. Nothing less will content me than whole America. I do not choose to consume its strength along with our own; because in all parts it is the British strength that I consume.’
w(/ste ou) dikasta\s o)/ntas kte(.: cf. the concluding sent. of c. 44. With dikasta\s o)/ntas bla/ptesqai, cf. i. 71. 6 a)muno/menoi mh\ bla/ptesqai. bla/ptesqai is passive.—17.

e)s xrhma/twn lo/gon i)sxuou/sais: strong in point of money. The unusual form of expression (for xrh/masin i)sxuou/sais) is used to emphasize the restriction of the i)sxu/ein of the allied cities to the matter of money, whereas the Athenians pro\s tou\s polemi/ous i)sxu/ousin. With e)s xrhma/twn lo/gon, cf. Dem. xix. 142 ei)s a)reth=s lo/gon kai\ do/chs, Lys. xix. 61 ou) mo/non pro\s do/can a)lla\ kai\ e)s xrhma/twn lo/gon lusitelei= ma=llon u(mi=n a)poyhfi/sasqai, Hdt. iii. 99. 12; vii. 9. b 13 e)s tou/tou lo/gon, iii. 125. 14 e)n a)ndrapo/dwn lo/gw|, vii. 222. 5 e)n o(mh/rwn lo/gw|, also Plut. Lys. 30; Dion. H. v. 34; xi. 17.—18.
th\n fulakh\n poiei=sqai: = fula/ttesqai, with a)po/ to indicate source.—

tw=n no/mwn th=s deino/thtos: for the order, see on c. 23. 27; i. 32. 8. The context shows that the reference is merely to the principle of extreme punishment which would be established by the adoption of Cleon's proposal (cf. § 1 a)ne/lpiston katasth=sai toi=s a)posta=sin . . . katalu=sai). Holzapfel (Rh. Mus. xxxvii. p. 455) therefore wrongly assumes a reference to laws already existing.—19.
tw=n e)/rgwn th=s e)pimelei/as: by having care of our own actions, as explained in l. 23 ff.

e)leu/qeron kai\ bi/a| a)rxo/menon: i.e. a state which is free acc. to the terms of alliance, and therefore u(ph/koos against its will. Diodotus openly acknowledges the true relation (cf. c. 10. 18 au)to/nomoi dh\ o)/ntes kai\ e)leu/qeroi tw=| o)no/mati), in order to show that the revolt was not unreasonable.—21.

ei)ko/tws: because bi/a| a)/rxetai.—a)posta/nta: with pro/s elsewhere of the party which revolters join (v. 14. 25; vii. 58. 10), here with pro\s au)tonomi/an applied by a sort of word-play to the new political situation.
ou)k a)fistame/nous: (not a)posta/ntas) to indicate the moment when it is too late, not when they are revolting.—24.
sfo/dra fula/ssein: the adv. repeated, as eu)= in c. 42. 12.— 25.
prokatalamba/nein: see on c. 2. 15.—

o(/pws mhd) . . . i(/wsi: that this may not even occur to them. Cf. iv. 92. 1. tou/tou, sc. tou= a)fi/stasqai.— 26. o(/ti e)p) e)la/xiston: of extent, to put the blame on as few as possible. For position of the prep., see on The assertion of this principle introduces the argument against Cleon's demand, c. 39. 32 mh\ toi=s me\n o)li/gois h( ai)ti/a prosteqh=|, to\n de\ dh=mon a)polu/shte, to which c. 47 is devoted.—
th\n ai)ti/an e)pife/rein: see on c. 42. 17.
We shall also, if we punish the whole population without merey, turn everywhere the democratic party against us and drive them over to the enemy.
o(/son: in indir. question, as in i. 78. 3. Cf. i. 136. 11 (o(/s), and see on c. 62. 6. On such consts. of the rel. pron., see also Dufour, Rev. de Philol. N. S. xiv. p. 57 ff.—
tou=to: the acc. is cogn., as in c. 37. 5 o(/ ti a)\n a(ma/rthte.
nu=n me\n ga\r kte(.: in answer to c. 39. § 6.—4.

e)a\n biasqh=|: sc. cunafi/stasqai.—u(pa/rxei . . . pole/mios eu)qu/s: i.e. as soon as war begins. Cf. iv. 78. 14 toi=s *)aqhnai/ois ai)ei/ pote
to\ plh=qos tw=n *qessalw=n eu)/noun u(ph=rxen. The result is expressed in kai\ th=s a)ntikaqistame/nhs . . . e)pe/rxesqe. to\ plh=qos for to\n dh=mon to emphasize the numerical superiority.—5.
th=s a)ntikaqistame/nhs po/lews: of the city opposed to you, as in i. 71. 1.—6.

e)s po/lemon e)pe/rxesqe: unusual const., for the more usual e)s po/lemon kaqi/stasqe (see on ii. 75. 1), or pro\s po/lemon tre/pesqe (v. 114. 3). But cf. e)s timwri/an e)pe/rxontai, iv. 25. 35; e)pecie/nai e)s ma/xhn, iv. 68. 16. Hence there is no need to bracket e)s po/lemon, with v. H., or to write e)s po/lemon e)/rxesqe (cf. i)e/nai e)s tou\s pole/mous, i. 78. 7; 118. 11), with Badham and Cobet, Mnem. N.S. viii. p. 137.

e)peidh/ te kte(.: cf. c. 27. § 3; 28. Diodotus exaggerates somewhat the services of the demos of Mytilene; still the course of the demoeratic party after arms were received was the cause of the capitulation.—10.

katasth/sete . . . ma/lista: you will bring to pass what the aristocrats most wish. Cf. iv. 92. 31 pollh\n a)/deian th=| *boiwti/a| me/xri tou=de katesth/samen. In this sense kaqista/nai takes, as a rule, a pred. adjective. See on c. 46. 2. For the part. gen. in pred. position, cf. c. 37. 17; 67. 16; iv. 17. 14; 28. 25; vii. 61. 7. G. 965; H. 730 d.—12.

prodeica/ntwn u(mw=n: because you will have taught them beforehand. Cf. proudh/lou, i. 130. 9. Or perhaps, as Steup explains, prodeiknu/nai, proclaim, as proagoreu/ein, i. 26. 20; 29. 3; 43. 2; 140. 22, etc.— 14.

dei= de\ kai\ . . . prospoiei=sqai: the orator, wishing to be as consistent as possible, assumes the view of his opponent to be true, you must, even if they did wrong, ignore it, lit. pretend that they did not. The fact is expressed in hypothetical form, as in c. 43. 19. mh\ prospoiei=sqai, sc. a)dikh=sai au)tou/s. Kr. Spr. 67, 1, 5. Schol. mh/ toi/ ge deiknu/ein to\ gnw=nai. Cf. Theophr. Char. 1 a)kou/sas ti, mh\ prospoiei=sqai, Diog. Laert. ix. 29 e)a\n loidorou/menos mh\ prospoiw=mai.

kai\ tou=to: explained by e(ko/ntas . . . diafqei=rai. Steup explains as cogn. acc. with a)dikhqh=nai, referring to what precedes. Cf. c. 65. l; i. 38. 10; 67. 10; v. 30. 14; viii. 99. 8. But its position is against this view. —
ka/qecin: maintenance, found only here in Thuc. It means retentio in Arist. Pol. iv. 15. 6 and Plut. de Sol. Animal. 968 c. See Lobeck, ad Phryn. p. 351.—17.
dikai/ws: as in c. 44. 14.—

ou(\s mh\ dei=: i.e. ou(\s ou) cumfe/rei th=| po/lei.—18. to\ *kle/wnos to\ au)to\ di/kaion kai\ cu/mforon: “Cleon's claim of a union of right and justice in the punishment.” Cf. c. 40. 17 ff. to\ au)to\ . . . cu/mforon is not appos., but the whole expression is closely connected. to\ au)to/ in its pred. sense. Cf. oi( au)toi/, as in ii. 40. 12. —19.
eu(ri/sketai: used of the results of careful investigation, as in historical inquiry. Cf. i. 21. 7; iv. 62. 2; vi. 2. 8, and see on i. 1. 11.—

e)n au)tw=|: sc. e)n tw=| diafqei=rai au)tou/s. Not with Dobree e)n tw=| au)tw=|, or Kr. e)n tau)tw=|; for right and advantage might often be combined. Since e)n au)tw=| makes th=s timwri/as rather pleonastic, and a(/ma is tautological after to\ au)to\ di/kaion kai\ cu/mforon, Steup suggests that possibly Thuc. used ou)x eu(ri/sketai abs. (is not found), and that e)n au)tw=| . . . gi/gnesqai was a marginal remark that erept into the text.
Pass judgment calmly on the instigators of the revolt, but let the rest continue to live upon their island. Thus you will best provide for your own interests.

gno/ntes . . . parainoume/nwn: the motive proposed by Diodotus as the only right one, and recapitulated here, is fully expressed in gno/ntes a)mei/nw ta/de ei)=nai, having concluded that this is better for Athens; but Diodotus deems it necessary to disclaim positively (mh/te . . . prosa/gesqai) the motives (oi)=ktos or e)/leos and e)piei/keia) imputed by Cleon, c. 40. § 2 f., and to rest his case solely on the considerations just urged by him (a)p) au)tw=n tw=n parainoume/nwn).—
gno/ntes: having decided, followed by the inf., as in i. 43. 5; 69. 15.—
ta/de: refers to *mutilhnai/wn ou(\s . . . oi)kei=n. The connexion is rendered a little obscure by the intervening clauses, but the repetition of ta/de in l. 6 makes it clear.—2.
ple/on nei/mantes: see on c. 3. 5.—3.

prosa/gesqai: not pass.
(as Kr. and Bm.), but mid., as in c. 42. 30; 43. 7, with indef. subject.—

a)p) au)tw=n de\ tw=n parainoume/nwn: solely in accordance with the arguments made. For a)po/ in this sense, see on c. 36. 12; 64. 4; i. 21. 11; 91. 28. tw=n parainoume/nwn, the word contemptuously used by Cleon, c. 37. 28, is purposely repeated here.—4.
ou(\s me\n *pa/xhs a)pe/pemyen: cf. c. 35. § 1. —5.
kaq) h(suxi/an: calmly, i.e. without haste or passion, as in i. 85. 5; vi. 25. 6. Cf. c. 42. 4, where Diodotus designates ta/xos te kai\ o)rgh/n as the two worst foes of just decisions.—
oi)kei=n: used in a pregnant sense as antithesis to kri/nesqai, as in c. 75. 6. The idea is to let them continue to dwell upon their island without danger to life. Cf. c. 50. § 2.
h)/dh: opp. to e)s to\ me/llon, although the emphasizing of toi=s polemi/ois has changed the natural order. —7.

o(/stis ga\r . . . e)piw/n: substantiating the words kai\ toi=s polemi/ois h)/dh fobera/. He who deliberates wisely is more formidable toward opponents than he who rushes on inconsiderately with brute force (material strength). Bl. compares Hdt. iii. 127. 13 e)/nqa sofi/hs dei=, bi/hs e)/rgon ou)de/n.—eu)= bouleu/etai: cf. eu)bouli/a, c. 42. 4; 44. 4, and xei=ron bouleu/sasqai, c. 46. 2.—

pro\s tou\s e)nanti/ous: with krei/sswn e)sti/n, as i)sxu/omen pro\s tou\s polemi/ous, c. 46. 14; pro\s tou\s prosoi/kous i)sxu/os, i. 7. 5; pro\s *peloponnhsi/ous i)sxu/os, vi. 83. 5. It repeats toi=s polemi/ois of the preceding line, and is similarly placed first for emphasis. Bk., Kr., and Cl. follow Reiske in connecting pro\s tou\s e)nanti/ous with eu)= bouleu/etai, but, as Pp. remarks, the deliberation was concerning the Mytileneans who had surrendered, not against the enemy (the Peloponnesians), and the speaker presents in a general truth the idea that good counsel about the former would be profitable against the latter.—8.
krei/sswn e)sti/: as in c. 37. 15.—
e)piw/n: Kr. and Cobet would write o( e)piw/n, but cf. c. 39. 24 kata\ lo/gon eu)tuxou=nta. e)pie/nai as e)pe/rxesqai, iv. 86. 21. Cf. also e)s po/lemon e)pe/rxesqe, c. 47. 6.

The view of Diodotus having prevailed by a small majority, this decree is immediately despatched to Paches by a trireme, which, making all possible speed, arrives in time to prevent the execution of the first decree.

toiau=ta de/: resumptive after meta\ d' au)to/n in c. 41. 1. Cf. c. 68. 1; i. 44.
1; 79. 1; ii. 90. 1; vi. 88. 1. See on vi. 19. 1.—2.

ma/lista a)ntipa/lwn: pred. to r(hqeisw=n, with about equal weight. Va., followed by Arn. and some others, renders, most opposed to; but a)nti/palos in Thuc. means everywhere opposed with equal strength. ma/lista, as in c. 34. 4; i. 13. 11.— 3.

h)=lqon me
 e)s a)gw=na o(/mws th=s do/chs: the sense seems to be, as most editt. understand, “in spite of the reaction (meta/noia, c. 36. 15), there was a struggle between the two opinions.” Cf. vii. 71. 1 o( e)k th=s gh=s pezo\s . . . polu
 to
 a)gw=na kai\ cu/stasin th=s gnw/mhs ei)=xe. Cl.'s explanation, ‘they proceeded to a vote nevertheless (o(/mws, i.e. without waiting for further arguments from either side),’ seems untenable, and the various emendations proposed for o(/mws (o(moi/ws Bredow, o(/lhs Badham, o(mo/se Weidgen) are unnecessary. St. and Bm. render e)s a)gw=na th=s do/chs, in certamen de decreto (faciendo).—4.

a)gxw/maloi: nearly equal. This word, which occurs also iv. 134. 7; vii. 71. 21, is found elsewhere only in late writers. It is called traxu/ by Poll. v. 157. The choice of expressions here (a)nti/palos, a)gw\n th=s do/chs, a)gxw/malos) indicates how precarious was the situation of the Mytileneans. Everything points to the concluding words of the chapter, para\ tosou=ton . . . kindu/nou.—h( tou= *diodo/tou: sc. gnw/mh.
a)/llhn: cf. c. 36. 13.—
a)pe/stellon: the impf. combining the notion of ‘continued action’ with that of ‘outset.’ See on i. 10. 34; 26. 2.— 6.

prote/ras: though in only a few Mss. (most having deute/ras or e(te/ras), adopted by most editt., and clearly correct, since proei=xe necessarily presupposes mention of the first ship. Cf. 1. 15. Va.'s interpretation, non assecuta haec priorem, also supports this reading.—7.
ma/lista: about. See on l. 2; 34. 4; i. 13. 11.
tw=n *mutilhnai/wn pre/sbewn: cf. c. 28. 7; 36. 18.—10.
fqa/seian: as nomi/seian, v. 111. 6, for -aien of most of the Mss., since Thuc. has everywhere except in these two passages only -eian in aor. opt. 3rd pl. See St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 62 sq.—

w(/ste h)/sqio/n te kte(.: as F. Herbst observes (Wochenschrift f. Kl. Philol. 1890, p. 788 f.), this passage is against the view of Breusing (Lösung d. Tric-
renrätsels, p. 117 f.), that a trireme was always rowed by only one class of rowers, i.e. by the thalamitae or the zygitae or the thranitae.—11.

oi)/nw| kai\ e)lai/w| a)/lfita pefurame/na: barley-cakes kneaded with wine and oil. Usually the barley meal was kneaded with water and oil. Hesych. (s.v. ma=za), ma=za a)/lfita pefurame/nh u(/dati kai\ e)lai/w|. Cf. Xen. Cyrop. vi. 2. 28.—
u(/pnon h(|rou=nto: as in ii. 75. 12; si=ton h(|rou=nto, iv. 26. 9.—12.
kata\ me/ros: as in iv. 26. 10. Cf. e)n tw=| me/rei, iv. 11. 11. Schol. kata\ diadoxh\n merikh/n. Usually all hands slept on shore at night.

th=s me\n prote/ras new\s . . . pleou/shs, tau/ths de\ . . . e)peigome/nhs: the gen. abs., though the subjs. are the same with those of the leading verbs. GMT. 850; H. 972 d. See on c. 13. 30; 112. 21.—14.

pra=gma a)llo/koton: an unnatural, and therefore disagreeable business. a)llo/kotos is of uncertain etymology, not found in Xen. and the orators, and seldom in other Attic authors except Plato. Cf. Soph. Phil. 1191; Ar. Vesp. 47, 71; Plato Prot. 346 a; Legg. 747 d; Theaet. 182 a; Rep. 487 d; Hipp. M. 292 c. It is common in Plut. and other late writers.—16.
e)/fqase tosou=ton: cf. Diod. xii. 55.—
o(/son: with inf. with restrictive force, only so much that. Cf. i. 2. 8. GMT. 759; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 5.—17.

h( d' u(ste/ra au)th=s e)pikata/getai: while the other comes to land after it. After the adj., if thus taken pred., the prep. is pleonastic; hence Steup suggests au)ti/k) for au)th=s, comparing c. 22. 24; Hom. B 322; Hdt. i. 79. 1; ii. 181. 16. In that case h( d' u(ste/ra would be subject.— 18.
e)pikata/getai: also viii. 28. 2. Cf. Dio C. xlii. 7; Jos. A. J. xviii. 7. 2. —

mh\ diafqei=rai: sc. th\n po/lin. But Steup finds this complement rather harsh after what has gone before, and suggests that mh\ diafqei=rai may have crept into the text from a marginal remark. diekw/luse would then be used abs., as in vii. 2. 6; 79. 16. —

para\ tosou=ton . . . kindu/nou: such a narrow escape had Mytilene from danger (i.e. destruction). This const., which occurs also vii. 2. 23, is to be explained acc. to the analogy of para\ tosou=ton e)ge/neto or h)=lqe with the inf. (iv. 106. 18; viii. 33. 12; 76. 15). para\ tosou=ton, within so much, so close. That to which it had almost come is, when expressed by a clause, in the
inf.; when by a subst., in the gen., which is to be construed as the gen. with e)ggu/s, etc. G. 1149; H. 757.

The Mytileneans whom Paches had sent to Athens as the most guilty are put to death, the walls of the city pulled down, the ships seized, and the whole of Lesbos except the territory of Methymna given to Attic cleruchs, to whom the Lesbians as tenants paid a yearly rental.

*pa/xhs: mentioned here for the last time in Thucydides. He was accused of shameful deeds of violence toward Lesbian men and women (Agath. Epigr. 57; see Grote, Hist. of Greece, ch. 50), and when brought to trial committed suicide in the presence of his judges. Cf. Plut. Arist. 26; Nic. 6 eu)qu/nas didou\s th=s strathgi/as e)n au)tw=| tw=| dikasthri/w| spasa/menos ci/fos a)nei=len e(auto/n.—3. *kle/wnos gnw/mh|: on Cleon's motion, which he doubtless offered in the assembly held for reconsideration. Cf. i. 90. 14; 93. 16; vi. 50. 2.— 4.
xili/wn: Steup thinks this number incompatible with what is stated in c. 28. § 1, 2; 35. § 1, and conjectures tria/konta (*l/ for */a). See App.— 5.
nau=s pare/labon: i.e. caused to be delivered to them, corresponding to paradou=nai on the part of the Lesbians. Cf. i. 19. 5.—6.
klh/rous de\ poih/santes th=s gh=s kte(.: see App.

triakosi/ous toi=s qeoi=s i(erou/s: i.e. the tenth usually consecrated to the gods. ‘The portions of land thus assigned to the gods in ancient. Greece and Rome were considered a part of the property of the state, and like other public lands were usually let out to individuals, who were bound to keep up the sacred buildings, to provide victims and all things necessary for the sacrifices, and to maintain the priests and inferior ministers of the temples.’ Arn. Cf. Arist. Pol. vii. 10. 11; Xen. de Vect. 4. 19, and see Boeckh, P. E. book iii. ch. 2.—9.

tou\s laxo/ntas: those on whom the lot fell. The lands were distributed among a definite number of citizens by lot, ‘doubtless in such a manner that all who wished to participate in the benefit of the distribution voluntarily announced their desire, and then the lot determined who should receive a share.’ Boeckh, P. E. p. 548. See also Schoemann,
Gr. Ant. ii. p. 84 f.; Grote, Hist. of Gr. vi. p. 257. Of the 2700 cleruchs thus sent out Boeckh says further (p. 554): ‘Undoubtedly many of them returned home. But a part of them must have remained as a garrison, and probably they together with the original inhabitants composed the body politic.’—10.
taca/menoi: getting themselves rated, i.e. engaging to pay. See on c. 70. 19; i. 99. 11.— 11.
du/o mna=s: so that the whole rent paid to the cleruchs amounted to 90 talents (2 x 2700 = 5400 minas).—

fe/rein: as i. 99. 11, with two accusatives, du/o mna=s being a sort of part. appos. to a)rgu/rion. But it is possible to construe a)rgu/rion taca/menoi, to which the inf. clause adds a more definite explanation. See Cl.'s note on i. 99. 11.
ta\ e)n th=| h)pei/rw| poli/smata: called in iv. 52. 10 *)aktai=ai po/leis (cf. Kirchhoff, C. I. A. i. p. 23), Antandros being mentioned as the most important.—12.
u(ph/koon: with change of subj. after kai/. See on c. 5. 16.

p.hi: The Athenians under Nicias occupy the island of Minoa before Megara.

div2.p: ta\ me\n . . . e)ge/neto: for this formula, see on c. 6. 12.—2.
*niki/ou: already long held in high esteem on account of his wealth and honourable character (Plut. Nic. 2), he appears here first in Thuc. as a participant in the war.—3.
e)pi\ *minw/|an: on the i subscript, see Lobeck, Pathol. Serm. Gr. Elementa, i. p. 452. The expedition was occasioned by the experience of the autumn of 429 B.C. (ii. 93, 94).—

th\n nh=son: already in Strabo's time (p. 391) it had become an a)/kra of the mainland. See Bursian, i. p. 378 ff. On the situation of the island, see Lolling, Nisaea u. Minoa (Mitt. d. dtsch. Arch. Inst. i. Athen v. p. 1 ff.).—4.
pro\ *mega/rwn: properly before the port of Megara (Nisaea), which was eight stades from the city.—
e)xrw=nto de\ au)th=|: directly connected with the preceding rel. clause. For au)th=| in second member of a rel. sent., see on i. 42. 2. G. 1040; H. 1005; Kr. Spr. 60, 6, 2.—
pu/rgon: Steup thinks the text corrupt. See App.—5.
frouri/w|: in order to protect the port Nisaea.
au)to/qen: i.e. from Minoa.—
di) e)la/ssonos: at a less distance, as in vi. 75. 3; vii. 4. 19.—7.

a)po\ tou= *boudo/rou kai\ th=s *salami=nos: the part is joined to the whole, as e)pi\ *kau/nou kai\ *kari/as, i. 116. 15. See on ii. 69. 9. It seems from this passage that, in consequence of the events of the autumn of 429 B.C., Nisaea was guarded no longer only from Budorum (cf. ii. 93. 22; 94. 14), but from several points on Salamis.—8.
ei)=nai: in pregnant sense, almost=u(pa/rxein. See on i. 2. 5.—

tou/s te *peloponnhsi/ous: proleptic for o(/pws mh\ oi( *peloponnh/sioi, almost=abs. acc., as to the Peloponnesians, that they might not—. The freedom of const. is perhaps not more striking than th
 me
 xalepo
 . . . po/lin a)nti/palon paraskeua/sasqai, i. 142. 6; or to
 po/non to
 kata\ to
 po/lemon, mh\ ge/nhtai . . . a)rkei/tw me
 u(mi=n kai\ e)kei=na kte(., ii. 62. 1. tou/s te *peloponnhsi/ous seems to have been written as if mh\ poiei=sqai were to follow; but if the sent. had read thus, the inf. clause would have seemed to be co-ord. with fulakh
 ei)=nai, depending on e)bou/leto (as indeed Kühn. 473, N. 6, following the Schol., construes the o(/pws clause); whereas both o(/pws mh\ poiw=ntai and mhde
 e)splei=n depend on toi=s *)aqhnai/ois th
 fulakh
 ei)=nai=tou\s *)aqhnai/ous fula/ssein. te correl. to te in With this explanation of the const., St.'s conjecture, skopw=n before o(/pws, is unnecessary. See Rh. Mus. xxiv. p. 629 f. Steup would read, with Hünnekes, pro/s te *peloponnhsi/ous. See App.—
poiw=ntai lanqa/nontes: the usual const. is reversed. GMT. 893. Cf. laqo/ntes diekomi/sqhsan, c. 74. 16; laqw\n hu)li/sato, vii. 29. 10. See on c. 25. 5.—9.

au)to/qen: a)po\ th=s *minw/|as, Schol. Rather from Nisaea, the only Megarian harbour on the Saronic gulf. The fact that au)to/qen is used here in a slightly different sense from l. 6 is not sufficient cause for assuming, with C. F. Müller (N. Jahrbb. exli. p. 362), that the text is corrupt. —
oi(=on kai\ to\ pri\n geno/menon: sc. h)=n, referring to the attempt of Brasidas described in ii. 93, 94.—10.

lh|stw=n: taken by Cl. in its literal sense, plunderers. But it seems better, with Bl. and Jow., to render it as privateers. Cf. iv. 9. 7 e)k lh|strikh=s *messhni/wn triakonto/rou kai\ ke/lhtos. Cf. also iv. 67. 11 a)ka/tion a)mfhriko\n w(s lh|stai/.—e)kpompai=s: found only here in Thuc. Cf. Plato Legg. 740 e.—
toi=s te *megareu=sin . . . e)splei=n: cf. ii. 93. 23 new=n triw=n fulakh\ tou= mh\ e)splei=n *megareu=si mhd) e)kplei=n mhde/n.

a)po\ th=s *nisai/as: away from Nisaea, i.e. on the side turned from
Nisaea. Cf. i. 7. 6; 46. 10; 99. 10; vi. 64. 20. See App.—12.
mhxanai=s: with reference to this enterprise, cf. Ar. Av. 363 w)= sofw/tat), eu)= g' a)neu=res au)to\ kai\ strathgikw=s: u(perakonti/zeis su/ g' h)/dh *niki/an tai=s mhxanai=s. —
e)k qala/sshs: the attack upon the towers was made from the ships.— 13.

kai\ to
 e)/sploun . . . e)leuqerw/sas: by the capture of the two projecting towers Nicias freed the entrance to (i.e. opened to ships) the part of the island lying between these towers. e)leuqerou=n in this sense seems not to occur elsewhere in Attic, but cf. Dio C. xlii. 12. 2 to
 e)/sploun h)leuqe/rwse, Procop. de Aedif. v. 2 e)leuqe/ras poiei=sqai tw=| potamw=| ta\s e)s th
 qa/lassan e)kbola/s. —to\ metacu/: as in vii. 34. 11.—14.

a)petei/xize kai\ to\ e)k th=s h)pei/rou: opp. to a)po\ th=s *nisai/as prw=ton. After the Athenians had secured a safe landingplace, they walled off (a)petei/xize) the exit from the bridge, which crossed the lagoon at the point nearest the mainland, so that no enemy could cross over from that quarter. The bridge itself they left for use in further operations.—
dia\ tena/gous: see on —15.
e)piboh/qeia h)=n: the noun seems to occur in Attic only here and Xen. Cyrop. v. 4. 47, though the verb e)pibohqei=n is common. h)=n (= parh=n). Cf. ei)=nai in l. 7.
e)ceirga/santo: transition to the pl. from a)petei/xize. Some Mss. have the sing., but for similar transitions from the general to the army, cf. c. 112. 17; ii. 75. 3; iv. 127. 7.—17.
u(/steron dh\ . . . stratw=|: the text is prob. corrupt. See App.—
froura/n: with e)gkatalipw/n, as in i. 115. 14. Cf. fulakh\n e)gkatalipo/ntes, iv. 96. 34.
The Plataeans who had remained in the city surrender to the Peloponnesian besieging army, and agree to submit their cause to the Lacedaemonians as judges.
kai\ oi( *plataih=s: cf. c. 24. fin. kai/ refers to the similar fate of the Mytileneans, esp. cc. 27, 28.—2.
poliorkei=sqai: as in c. 109. 3, = u(pome/nein th\n poliorki/an, or, as expressed in ii. 70. 2, poliorkou/menoi a)nte/xein.
prose/balon . . . oi( de\ ou)k e)du/nanto: paratactic connexion, with change of subj.—5.
o( *lakedaimo/nios a)/rxwn: the name not given here, nor in c. 20 ff., nor in ii. 78.—6.

ei)rhme/non ga\r h)=n: on the reading, see App. bi/a| mh\ e(lei=n is to be supplied. Cf. Xen. Cyrop. iv. 5. 14 oi( fu/lakes, w(/sper ei)rhme/non h)=n [sc. mh\ ei)safei=nai] u(po\ *ku/rou, ou)k ei)safh=kan au)tou/s.—8. cugxwroi=en: sc. oi( *lakedaimo/nioi, since precisely these wish by their present course to secure themselves in advance against a forced concession, such as really was made v. 17. § 2. e(ka/teroi belongs only to e)/xousi. So Cl. explains; but it seems equally natural to supply oi( *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ *)aqhnai=oi from e(ka/teroi as subj. of cugxwroi=en.—9. a)na/dotos: found only here. For the accent and ending, cf. a)na/graptos, i. 129. 14. Kühn. 147 c b. Cf. Poll. vii. 2. 13 to\ meta\ th\n pra=sin a)podoqe\n a)na/doton a)/n tis ei)pei=n du/naito, ei)po/ntos *qoukudi/dou, “mh\ a)na/dotos ei)/h *pla/taia.”— 10. au)tw=n: intensive, which does not, however, make e(ko/ntwn superfluous.—11.

le/gonta: pres. partic., as in vi. 88. 62; vii. 3. 4; 25. 40. On this depends tou/s te a)di/kous kola/sein . . . ou)de/na, which is apod. to ei) bou/lontai . . . xrh/sasqai. The const. is exactly the same as in vii. 3. 4 prope/mpei au)toi=s le/gonta, ei) bou/lontai e)cie/nai e)k th=s *sikeli/as pe/nte h(merw=n labo/ntes ta\ sfe/tera au)tw=n, e(toi=mos ei)=nai spe/ndesqai.—13. tou/s te a)di/kous: te correl. to the following de/, as i. 11. 2; 25. 11; v. 9. 35; vii. St. 12; viii. 16. 12. Hence C. F. Müller's conjecture (N. Jahrbb. exli. p. 363 f.), tou/s ge a)di/kous, is unnecessary. Kr. Spr. 69, 16, 6; Kühn. 520, N. 3.—

kola/sein: the subj. is tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous or tou\s dikasta\s tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn. The fut. has been correctly restored by Kr. for kola/zein of the Mss., since it depends on le/gonta. See Kr.'s note and St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 13.

e)n tw=| a)sqenesta/tw|: in the last stage of weakness. Cf. Dio C. lxxiv. 12. 52 e)n tw=| a)sqenesta/tw| e)ge/nonto, Paus. ix. 7. 4 e)s to\ a)sqene/staton proh/xqhsan.
—15.
*plataia=s: (not *plataie/as) acc. to analogy of *(alia=s, i. 105. 1; *dwria=s, i. 107. 4; *(estiaia=s, i. 114. 16. Cf. v. 51. 3.—16.
e)n o(/sw|: until. See on c. 28. 8.—17.
pe/nte a)/ndres: one of whom is named by Paus. iii. 9. 1.
proete/qh: cf. gnw/mas protiqe/nai, c. 36. 21; i. 139. 18; vi. 14. 3; diagnw/mhn proqei=nai, c. 42. 1.—19.
e)pikalesa/menoi: calling forth. In this sense found only here in Thuc. Cf. Hdt. v. 39. 7.—
tosou=ton mo/non: cf. tosou=toi mo/noi, iv. 110. 12.—21.

a)gaqo\n (ti) ei)rgasme/noi: cf. the question of the Romans on the capture of Capua, Liv. xxvi. 33 ecquis Campanorum bene meritus de republica nostra esset. As in the three other passages where this formula is repeated (c. 54. 7; 68. 3 and 11) a second ti is not found, it has been rightly rejected here by Bm., Cl., and St.
oi( d' e)/legon: the subj. is all the Plataeans, while in l. 25 the subj. is Astymachus and Laco.—22.
ai)thsa/menoi: cf. c. 53. 10.—
makro/tera ei)pei=n: instead of simply answering ‘no,’ as they did when asked a second time (c. 68. 12).—
prota/cantes sfw=n au)tw=n: having appointed as their advocates.—23.
*ai)eimnh/stou: leader of the Platacans at Marathon and Plataea. See Valck. on Hdt. ix. 64. 7, and Siebel on Plut. Aristid. 19. —
e)pelqo/ntes: as in i. 72. 15; 90. 29; 91. 16; 119. 9, of appearing before an assembly or magistrate, particularly of foreigners. parie/nai, of coming forward to speak. See on i. 72. 15.— 25.

e)/legon: on the tense, see GMT. 57; H. 831. ‘The impf. has only to do with the vision of the narrator.’ Gildersleeve (Am. J. of Ph. iv. p. 160). See on i. 72. 15. Thuc. introduces extended speeches twenty-two times with impf. (i. 72. 15; 119. 10; 139. 25; ii. 10. 11; 34. 25; 71. 6; iii. 36. 28; 41. 4; 52. 25; 60. 6; iv. 84. 9; 91. 13; 94. 12; v. 8. 19; vi. 8. 23; 15. 21; 19. 8; 32. 21; 35. 10; 67. 19; 75. 23; vii. 76. 3), eighteen times with aor. (i. 31. 16; 36. 22; 67. 18; 79. 8; 85. 14; ii. 59. 14; 86. 26; 88. 14; iii. 8. 6; 29. 11; iv. 9. 23; 16. 24; 58. 9; 125. 22; vi. 81. 2; 88. 65; vii. 60. 30; 65. 10).
DEFENCE OF THE PLATAEANS. c. 53-59.

The form of procedure begun and the composition of the court cause us anxiety, lest we may have deceived ourselves in the expectations with which we surrendered; but we dare not even under unfavourable circumstances and hostile influences refrain from trying to defend ourselves. On this famous and beautiful oration, cf. Dion. H. de Thuc. hist. iudic. 42 u(pe\r a(pa/sas ta\s e)n tai=s e(pta\ bi/blois ferome/nas (dhmhgori/as) th\n *plataie/wn a)pologi/an teqau/maka, par) ou)de\n ou(/tws e(/teron, w(s to\ mh\ bebasani/sqai mhde\ katepitethdeu=sqai, a)lhqei= de/ tini kai\ fusikw=| kekosmh=sqai xrw/mati. ta/ te ga\r e)nqumh/mata pa/qous e)sti\ mesta/, kai\ h( le/cis ou)k a)postre/fousa ta\s a)koa/s: h(/ te ga\r su/nqesis eu)eph/s, kai\ ta\ sxh/mata tw=n pragma/twn i)/dia.

th
 me
 para/dosin . . . e)poihsa/meqa . . . oi)o/menoi: the emphasis of the sent. is on the parties., oi)o/menoi and h(gou/menoi, opp. to which is nu=n de\ fobou/meqa, l. 6, although me/n is joined with the decisive fact (th
 para/dosin e)poihsa/meqa) placed first in the sent. for emphasis.—2.

pisteu/santes u(mi=n: as in c. 59. 22. Cf. also c. 59. 27 e)k th=s u(mete/ras pi/stews. The aor. as in c. 38. 11; 46. 2. Steup takes pisteu/santes as dependent on oi)o/menoi, but enticing as is the parallelism which he suggests between pisten/santes oi)o/menoi and deca/menoi h(gou/menoi, its position shows that the partic. is to be closely connected with e)poihsa/meqa. oi)o/menoi and h(gou/menoi contain the twofold grounds of pisteu/santes u(mi=n th\n para/dosin e)poihsa/meqa, i.e. expecting due process of law and impartial judges.—

toia/nde: sc. oi(/an u(pe/xomen, i.e. by the question, ei)/ ti *lakedaimoni/ous a)gaqo\n ei)rga/smeqa.— di/khn u(pe/cein: iudicium subituros, as in c. 81. 12. Cf. th\n timwri/an u(fe/cete, vi. 80. 24.—3.

e)n dikastai=s ou)k e)n a)/llois: on the repetition of the prep., see Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 31. Kühn. 451, 2. Cf. vi. 82. 18. For the const. (e)n dikastai=s gene/sqai), St. compares Plato Legg. 916 b; Soph. Ant. 459. Cf. also i. 73. 5 para\ dikastai=s u(mi=n . . . oi( lo/goi a)\n gi/gnointo.—4. deca/menoi: i.e. ei) decai/meqa, prot. to ma/lista a)\n fe/resqai, both dependent on h(gou/menoi. “Since we believed that, if we agreed to appear before a court of Lacedaemonians, we should receive an impartial decision.” Steup explains deca/menoi as causal to h(gou/menoi, which is admissible; for an actual stipulation may have been e)n dikastai=s ou)k e)n a)/llois gene/sqai h)\ u(mi=n. de/xesqai with inf. (gene/sqai), as i. 143. 8; v. 94. 3; Plato Rep. 606 b.—

w(/sper kai\ e)sme/n: as we now are. ei)=nai is the result of gene/sqai. By emphasizing the outward fultillment of their expectation, or perhaps of the condition of the sur
render, they indicate their anxiety lest they may be deceived in the result.—5.
to\ i)/son: aequum ius, as i. 34. 7; ii. 37. 5. Cf. c. 67. 21.—
fe/resqai: with to\ i)/son, as th\n a)ci/wsin fe/resqai, i. 69. 7; do/can fe/resqai, ii. 11. 36; ai)ti/an fe/resqai, ii. 60. 25.
fobou/meqa mh\ h(marth/kamen: for mh/ with pf. ind. after verb of fearing, see GMT. 369, 2; H. 888; Kr. Spr. 54, 8, 12; Kühn. 589, 6.—

a)mfote/rwn h(marth/kamen: cf. duoi=n a(ma/rtwsin, i. 33. 23. a)mfo/tera, i.e. a di/kh nomimwte/ra and impartial judges. Their disappointment in the first respect is expressed by peri\ tw=n deinota/twn (Schol. peri\ tou= qana/tou), for there could be no thought of this in a di/kh nomimwte/ra.—8. u(ma=s: proleptic const., as ii. 21. 3; 67. 23.—
koinoi/: impartial. Cf. c. 68. 7; iv. 83. 16.—
a)pobh=te: evadatis, as Xen. Mem. iv. 8. 8; Plato Legg. 878 c.—9.
prokathgori/as . . . ou) progegenhme/nhs: for similar pleonasms, cf. i. 23. 21; ii. 36. 1; vi. 57. 10; viii. 66. 6.—
h(=| xrh\ a)nteipei=n: see on c. 11. 18.— 10.
lo/gon h)thsa/meqa: sc. a makro/teros lo/gos. Cf. c. 52. 22; 60. 5; 61. 1. Cf. lo/gon dido/nai, Dem. ii. 29, 31.—

to/ te e)perw/thma braxu\ o)/n: the acc. after the parenthesis in loose connexion with the preceding gen., as if not tekmairo/menoi, but logizo/menoi or skopou=ntes had preceded; or perhaps better, with Pp., to explain as acc. abs., to\ e)perw/thma with braxu\ o)/n being construed as a)/llo ti do/can, v. 65. 10; kurwqe\n ou)de/n, iv. 125. 5. Kühn. 487, N. —11.

w(=| ta\ me\n . . . gi/gnetai: to answer which truly is adverse to our interests. ta\ a)lhqh=, as well as ta\ yeudh=, is obj. of a)pokri/nasqai, which is subj. of e)nanti/a gi/gnetai and of e)/legxon e)/xei. e)nanti/a is used instead of e)nanti/on, perhaps by assimilation to a)lhqh=, or the neut. pl. may be compared with a)du/nata, c. 88. 4; i. 59. 4; 125. 5; vii. 43. 13. Kr. and Cl. take ta\ a)lhqh= and ta\ yeudh= as subj., and a)pokri/nasqai as epexegetic of ta\ a)lhqh= (see on i. 50. 25). St. and v. H. write e)nanti/on.— 12. e)/legxon e)/xei: refutes itself. e)/xei =pare/xei, as i. 97. 13; ii. 41. 9; 61. 9; 87. 3; iv. 95. 3.

pantaxo/qen a)/poroi kaqestw=tes: cf. ii. 59. 8 pantaxo/qen th=| gnw/mh| a)/poroi kaqestw=tes.—13. kai a)sfale/steron dokei= ei)=nai: this second reason, though almost parenthetically inserted, de
termines the const. of the following inf.—14.

ei)po/ntas ti kinduneu/ein: i.e. not to risk our lives without having said something. Cf. i. 20. 12 dra/sante/s ti kinduneu=sai. The emphasis is on the participle. Cf. c. 105. 1; i. 23. 25; 82. 10; 144. 6; ii. 61. 3; vii. 14. 1.—
o( mh\ r(hqei\s lo/gos:=to\ to\n lo/gon mh\ r(hqh=nai. Cf. c. 36. 11; 66. 15; Xen. Cyrop. iii. 3. 51.—
toi=s w(=d) e)/xousin: as in c. 59. 18; Plato Crito, 46 d.—15.
ai)ti/an: reproach, or, more exactly, ground for reproach, as i. 140. 26.
h( peiqw/: “the possibility of persuading you.” Only here in Thuc. —17.
a)gnw=tes . . . w)felou/meq) a)/n: the subj. of a)gnw=tes is h(mei=s te kai\ u(mei=s, but with e)pesenegka/menoi and w)felou/meq) a)/n it is h(mei=s. See on c. 10. 17; i. 18. 21.—
e)pesenegka/menoi: ‘dynamic middle,’ implying that the powers of the subject are exerted, as pare/xesqai, c. 54. 1; i. 32. 9. Kr. Spr. 52, 8, 2.—18.

h)=te: impf. through the influence of the cond. partic. (e)pesenegka/menoi ei) e)neohnegka/meqa. pro\s ei)do/tas pa/nta: to men who know all, and hence without hope of effect. pro\s ei)do/tas, as ii. 43. 5; Aesch. Agam. 1402; or e)n ei)do/si, ii. 36. 14; iv. 59. 5; vi. 77. 2. 19.

lele/cetai: the fut. pf. is required by the context, and not le/cetai (the reading of Laur., preferred by Hude), which the Tragic writers use for the fut. passive (Soph. O. C. 1186; Eur. Alc. 322; Hec. 906). St. See Kr. Spr. 53, 9, 3.—

ou)xi/: used by Thuc. six times (c. 67. 22; i. 120. 6; ii. 87. 4; vi. 40. 16; vii. 56. 17), always as emphatic neg., generally to intensify the adversative idea. Here the Plataeans reject emphatically the thought that the Lacedaemonians might consider the merits of the Plataeans in the Persian wars less than their own.—

prokatagno/ntes: cum praedamnaveritis nos statuentes. St. The same brachylogy as in katafronou=ntes, c. 83. 13. Or the meaning may be, having already formed the unfavourable judgment against. Cf. c. 16. 1; 45. 4. With the former view, h(mw=n would be taken with ta\s a)reta/s alone; with the latter, it would belong also to prokatagno/ntes.—20. h(/ssous ei)=nai tw=n u(mete/rwn: are inferior to yours. Steup suggests that as the Plataeans acknowledge in c. 57. 6 the superiority of the Lacedaemonians (a)ndrw=n a)gaqw=n pe/ri au)tou\s a)mei/nous o)/ntas), tw=n u(mete/rwn may be an interpolation, in which case h(/ssous would mean in-
sufficient, as in c. 45. 6.—21.
au)to/: referring to the whole preceding clause. Cf. i. 2. 11; 68. 3.—

a)lla\ . . . kaqistw/meqa: but lest we to gratify others appear before a court that has already decided against us. With bitter irony, in view of the foregone conclusion of the trial, the Plataeans ascribe to themselves the evident purpose of the Lacedaemonians. kaqi/stasqai e)pi\ kri/sin, with the kritai/ in mind, as katasta\s e)pi\ to\ plh=qos, iv. 84. 8; e)pi\ *)aqhnai/ous, iv. 97. 9. kaqi/stasqai is not passive (cf. c. 92. 14; 93. 3; v. 51. 6), but middle. For diegnwsme/nhn, see on c. 42. 1.
parexo/menoi: bringing forward. Cf. e)pesenegka/menoi, c. 53. 17. Bl. compares Dion. H. Ant. vii. 32 di/kaia . . . parexo/menoi pro\s u(ma=s mega/la. —2. di/kaia: just claims, as c. 44. 16.—
pro/s, e)s: change of prep., as in c. 37. 4, 5; i. 32. 10, 11; 38. 1; Dem. iii. 1. —

ta\ *qhbai/wn dia/fora: the quarrels with the Thebans. Cf. iv. 79. 10 ta\ palaia\ dia/fora tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, ii. 27. 9 to\ *)aqhnai/wn dia/foron.—3. dedrasme/nwn: this unusual pf. form, found in most Mss., for dedrame/nwn, is after the analogy of drasqe/n, c. 38. 19; vi. 53. 8. St., Bm., and v. H. write, with two inferior Mss., the usual form dedrame/nwn, after the analogy of dra=ma.—u(po/mnhsin poihso/meqa: as in i. 72. 9; ii. 88. 12.

§ 2-5. To your unfair question as to our services rendered to you during the war, we reply that we did not break the peace, and not only in the Persian war supported the Hellenes, but also in the uprising of the Helots vigorously aided you.
to\ braxu/: the emphatic position betrays indignation at the wicked intention.—7.
ei) me\n w(s polemi/ous kte(.: by referring to the possible conditions affecting the question a direct reply is evaded, it is true, but its unwarrantableness in either case is shown. —8.

mh\ eu)= paqo/ntas: these words, notwithstanding their hypothetical character, contain an indirect confession that ou)de\n a)gaqo\n pepoih/kasi tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous, but in the apod., ou)k a)dikei=sqai u(ma=s, any guilt from such conduct is denied.—
fi/lous de\ nomi/zontas: i.e. ei) de\ fi/lous (h(ma=s) nomi/zete.—9. au)tou/s: sc. u(ma=s.—
a(marta/nein: for the approach to the pf. sense, see GMT. 27; Kr. Spr. 53, 1, 3. Cf. c. 67. 30.—
tou\s hmi=n e)pistrateu/santas: appos. to au)tou/s. Kr. Spr. 50, 7, 12.

ta\ d' e)n th=| ei)rh/nh| kai\ pro\s to\n *mh=don: the pl. ta/ indicates the particular events in a considerable period. Cf. ta\ pro\ *(/ellhnos, i. 3. 4. The order of time is reversed, as in i. 97. 4; 118. 6.—11.
nu=n: as opp. to the following to/te, refers to the beginning of the po/lemos o(/de (ii. 2).— 12.
mo/noi *boiwtw=n: rhetorical inaccuracy, for the Thespians did the same (Hdt. vii. 132. 4; viii. 50. 8), and acc. to Pausanias (ix. 32. 4) the Haliartians also. Cf. c. 62. 2; 64. 2.
kai\ ga/r: nam et. kai/ correl. to kai/ in Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 21.—

h)peirw=tai/ te kte(.: te which is joined to the emphatic h)peirw=tai rather than to e)naumaxh/samen, where it strictly belongs, is correl. to te in l. 14, while te in ei)/ te/ ti a)/llo introduces the third member. See App. Since kai\ u(mi=n . . . e)pikouri/an cannot be an explanation of th\n me\n . . . pro/teroi, as kai\ ga\r . . . mete/sxomen is of tw=| de\ . . . *boiwtw=n, the former clause (kai\ u(mi=n kte(.) must be considered as rather loosely connected with the main sent., ta\ de\ . . . gegenh/meqa.—14. ma/xh| te genome/nh|: for the dat. without prep. denoting time when, see G. 1192; H. 782; Kr. Spr. 48, 2, 9. Cf. i. 44. 3; 128. 17; ii. 20. 3. For the order, see on c. 9. 3.—15.
paregeno/meqa . . . *pausani/a|: cf. Hdt. ix. 28. 26; Plut. Aristid. 20; Diod. xi. 32.—17.
pa/ntwn: connected kata\ cu/nesin with ei)/ ti a)/llo.—para\ du/namin: beyond our strength, as c. 57. 18; i. 70. 9; viii. 2. 12.
o(/teper dh/: just when.—

perie/sth: with acc., also iv. 10. 3; 55. 10; v. 73. 6; viii. 2. 22; 15. 3; without expressed obj., iv. 34. 24; viii. 1. 9. Cf. Dem. xviii. 195 tosou=tos ki/ndunos kai\ fo/bos perie/sth th\n po/lin, Tac. Hist. iv. 79 circumsteterat Civilem et alius metus. 19.

tw=n e)s *)iqw/mhn *ei(lw/twn a)posta/ntwn: obj. gen. after fo/bos. Kr. Spr. 47, 7, 2. The attrib. partic. is placed after its noun when attended by other modi
fiers, as often in Thuc. G. 969; Kühn. 464, 8. See on i. 11. 19. For the facts, cf. i. 101. § 2. 20.
h(mw=n au)tw=n: i.e. of our citizens. Cf. ii. 39. 16.—21.
w(=n: the rel. serves as an emphatic connective. Cf. i. 9. 19; 33. 13, etc.

The alliance with the Athenians we sought only when you had rejected our appeal for aid against Thebes and referred us to them; to abandon it would have been shameful. The responsibility, furthermore, for what happens in war belongs to the leaders.
h)ciw/samen: we regarded it our duty, as in i. 22. 9.—3.
deome/nwn: sc. h(mw=n. For subj. of gen. abs. thus freq. omitted, see on c. 34. 17.—

e)bia/santo: did violence to, with acc. as in i. 38. 12; viii. 53. 9. This account of the occurrence, which acc. to c. 68. 31, happened in 520 or 519 B.C., is corroborated by Hdt. vi. 108. 6 piezeu/menoi u(po\ *qhbai/wn oi( *plataie/es e)di/dosan . . . sfe/as au)tou/s.—5. u(mw=n . . . a)poikou/ntwn: gen. abs., co-ord. with w(s e)ggu\s o(/ntas, though u(meis precedes. See on c. 13. 30; 112. 21.—
makra\n a)poikou/ntwn: cf. makra\n a)pei=nai, c. 13. 23; h(mei=s e(kaste/rw oi)ke/omen, Hdt. vi. 108. 9.
ou)de\n e)kprepe/steron: nothing very unusual. Cf. e)kprepw=s, i. 38. 9. —7.
e)mellh/sate: sc. paqei=n. Cf. c. 11. 4; 20. 16.
ei) de\ . . . ou)k h)qelh/samen: the fact in hypothetical form. See on c. 32. 6. ou) belongs to the verb only. GMT. 384; Kr. Spr. 67, 4, 1; Kühn. 513, 4. —8.
u(mw=n keleusa/ntwn: referring to the demand of Archidamus, ii. 72. Cf. c. 64. 13; 68. 6.—9.
e)nanti/a: acc. of inner obj. as adv., as in i. 29. 6. Cf. o(moi=a, i. 25. 18; a/gxw/mala, vii. 71. 21; bohqh=sai/ moi ta\ di/kaia, Dem. xxxviii. 2. Kühn. 410, N. 5.—10.

a)pwknei=te: you held back, abs., as iv. 11. 16; vi. 18. 1; vii. 21. 23; with acc. c. 20. 10; 30. 12; vi. 92. 23;
viii. 12. 2.—11.
tis: here for h(mei=s. Cf. on in French Comedy. Kr. Spr. 51, 16, 8.—12.

kai\ politei/as mete/laben: sc. au)tw=n. In Greek, when the rel. would appear in successive clauses in different cases, it is usually omitted in the second, often being represented by a dem. or pers. pronoun. Cf. i. 10. 20; 42. 2; ii. 4. 25; 84. 9. G. 1040; H. 1005; Kr. Spr. 60, 6, 2; Kühn. 561, 1. The reference is to the relation of i)sopolitei/a, acc. to which a citizen of the one city on removing to the other immediately became a citizen of the latter. See Niebuhr, Hist. of Rome, ii.^{2} p. 58 ff.—
i)e/nai e)s ta\ paraggello/mena: as in i. 121. 5. ta\ paraggello/mena is used esp. of military orders. Cf. ii. 11. 39; 84. 18; 89. 40; iv. 34. 23.—13.
proqu/mws: placed last for emphasis. Cf. i. 77. 19.
a(\ de\ e(ka/teroi e)chgei=sqe: whatsoever each of you directed as ‘Hegemones.’ a(/ is cogn. acc. Cf. c. 93. 15; v. 66. 10. —15.

e)dra=to: Reiske's conjecture from Bk.'s Aneed. p. 143; preferable to e)dra=te of the Mss., since here in the prot. an impersonal reference to acts in general suits the context better and is more forcible. For the thought, cf. c. 65. 10.

The Thebans have wronged us in many other respects, and now finally by the wanton surprise of our city, for which we have justly punished them. It would not be right that we should now suffer on their account. If you regard justice and your own true interests, you cannot permit this.
cu/niste: i.e. of your own knowledge. Cf. i. 73. 13; ii. 35. 10; iv. 68. 24.—
di) o(/per: Pp.'s conjecture, for di) a(/per of the Mss., is necessary, since it refers to to\ teleutai=on, which, as opp. to polla\ kai\ a)/lla, is clearly not adv., but the obj. of cu/niste.
po/lin ga\r au)tou\s kte(.: cf. ii. 2-6; iii. 65, 66. For the order (po/lin th\n h(mete/ran), see on c. 9. 3; 54. 14. —
katalamba/nontas: pres. partie., of the unsuecessful attempt. Cf. ii. 3. 3; 5. 21.—4.
e)n spondai=s: temporal, as c. 65. 2; i. 55. 14; ii. 5. 20; vii. 18. 13. Cf. e)n tw=| pole/mw|, c. 52. 20; 54. 6; 68. 11.—

i(eromhni/a|: on a holi-
day, as in c. 65. 2. This circumstance is not mentioned in the detailed account of the event, ii. 2. ff.—
o)rqw=s e)timwrhsa/meqa: the Plataeans pass lightly over the especial charge concerning their conduct, while the Thebans emphasize just this point most strongly, c. 66. § 2.—5.
to\n . . . kaqestw=ta: for the order, see on c. 54. 19. For the thought, cf. vii. 68. 3 ff.—
pole/mion: emphatic pred., as an enemy. Cf. c. 65. 6; 66. 1.— 6.
ou)k ei)ko/tws: cf. c. 58. 9 ei)ko/tws timwrh/sesqe, and c. 57. 2 ei) de\ peri\ h(mw=n gnw/sesqe mh\ ta\ ei)ko/ta.—di) au)tou/s: cf. c. 57. 12 dia\ *qhbai/ous.

ei) ga\r . . . to\ di/kaion lh/yesqe: to\ di/kaion (see on c. 10. 1; v. 86. 6) lamba/nein, measure justice, with which the dat. is connected, as with metrei=n, tekmai/resqai/ ti/ tini. The unworthy motive for such a decision is indicated by the closely connected tw=| au)ti/ka xrhsi/mw| u(mw=n te kai\ e)kei/nwn polemi/w|, in which one art. covers both subst. phrases (see on c. 2. 6; i. 6. 1; 120. 10). Cf. Dem. xviii. 31 to\ . . . e)n th=| presbei/a| prw=ton kle/mma me\n *fili/ppou, dwrodo/khma de\ tw=n a)di/kwn tou/twn a)nqrw/pwn. The chiastic arrangement (xrhsi/mw| u(mw=n . . . e)kei/nwn polemi/w|), by which the close connexion of the prons. with the adjs. is shown, accounts for the unusual position of te kai/. “If you, influenced by your present advantage and their hostility, shall decide the question of right.”—9.

to\ cumfe/ron: in the sense of immediate advantage, expediency (cf. ii. 40. 23), as opp. to o)rqo/n, which here and c. 66. 20 (ta\ o)rqa/) is the result at once of right judgment and honest intention. In v. 90. 2 to\ cumfe/ron is similarly opp. to to\ di/kaion. In l. 25 it means true advantage. For the const. with qerapeu/ein, cf. vi. 79. 1 to\ di/kaion . . . qerapeu/sete, Soph. Phil. 149 to\ paro\n qerapei/ein, Polyb. xi. 4. 2 kairo\n pa/nta qerapeu/ein.
nu=n: sharply contrasted with to/te in l. 12, both occupying emphatic positions at the beginning and end of their respective clauses. Cf. c. 54. 11, 12.—11.
ma=llon to/te: sc. w)fe/limoi h)=men. Cf. c. 40. 5; i. 86. 7; vi. 60. 13.
h(mw=n: belongs to both th=s nu=n a(marti/as and th\n to/te proqumi/an, and by its position acquires almost the force of a dat. of interest. See on i. 30. 14.—
a(marti/as . . . a)ntiqei=nai: the gen. as in ii. 85. 9. Kr. Spr. 47, 23, 2.—

a)/ra: intimating doubt, a force retained from its interr. use, it is here, as c. 67. 4, rather negatively inclined (if indeed); but generally after ei) and h)/n it is positive in force (if perhaps, c. 30. 10; i. 27. 9; 70. 23; 84. 9; 93. 30; 123. 5; 136. 12; 140. 7, etc.).—
h(ma/rthtai: impers. pass., as parabai/netai, c. 45. 14.—16.
a)ntiqei=nai: as in ii. 85. 8.—
mei/zw pro\s e)la/ssw: Schol. mei/zw proqumi/an pro\s e)la/ssw a(marti/an. pro/s, as against; see on c. 43. 15.—18.
a)ntita/casqai: to array against. Here lit., in ii. 87. 22 it is fig. —19.

e)ph|nou=nto/ te . . . pra/ssontes: and they were more commended who did not with respect to the attack seek their own advantage in security. pra/ssontes has reference to negotiations with the enemy. a)sfalei/a|, as opp. to meta\ kindu/nwn, equiv. to di: a)sfalei/as, i. 17. 3. It is used adv. also Soph. O. R. 51. Some editt. take it with au(toi=s, for their own security. —20.

e)qe/lontes de\ . . . ta\ be/ltista: the order is chiastic with regard to the preceding clause. The open e)qe/lontes tolma=n is opposed to the secret pra/ssontes, meta\ kindu/nwn to a)sfalei/a|, ta\ be/ltista (“what was wholesomest for all”) to ta\ cu/mfora au(toi=s.
w(=n: partitive genitive with geno/menoi. G. 1094, 7; H. 732 a; Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 2.—
timhqe/ntes e)s ta\ prw=ta: as in c. 39. 9. On the matter, cf. ii. 71. § 2 f., and Plut. Aristid. 20, who says that the a)ristei=a were adjudged to the Plataeans.—22.
e)pi\ toi=s au)toi=s: for the same conduct, to be taken with diafqarw=men. Cf. e)pi\ prodosi/a|, i. 138. 31; e)pi\ braxei/a| profa/sei, i. 141. 4.— 23.
e(lo/menoi: with acc. (tina or ta/ tinos) of party attitude, as c. 63. 11; 64. 6; ii. 7. 9.—24.
kerdale/ws: for mere advantage, as kerdale/on, ii. 53. 11. It is contrasted with dikai/ws, as to\ cumfe/ron above (9) with to\ di/kaion.

kai/toi . . . kaqisth=tai: these words are directed (see Stahl, N. Jahrbb. xcvii. p. 117 f.) against a change of
judgment on the part of the Lacedaemonians with regard to the consistent conduct of the Plataeans, which would have the saddest results for them (e)pi\ toi=s au)toi=s de/dimen mh\ diafqarw=men, as quite similarly in the transition from c. 57 to c. 58, kai/toi a)ciou=me/n ge kte(. is opp. to de/dimen mh\ ou) be/baioi h)=te). They are, therefore, not a justification of the Plataeans, but an admonition to the Lacedaemonians. This view necessitates Heilmann's conjecture e)/xousi (agreeing with u(mi=n) for e)/xwsi. “You must, however, show yourselves consistent in your judgments concerning the same course of conduct, and consider your true advantage to be only this—to have an ever-enduring sense of gratitude toward good allies for their virtue, while your own immediate interest is secured,” i.e. your true interest is subserved only where the advantage of the moment comports with lasting gratitude to deserving allies. From the first general claim (xrh\ . . . o(moi/ws fai/nesqai gignw/skontas) there is a transition with the aor. nomi/sai to the present case, and with u(mi=n definitely to the Lacedaemonians. While tw=n cumma/xwn oi( a)gaqoi/ is a general term for all deserving allies, the Plataeans have esp. in mind the a)reth/ displayed by themselves in the Persian wars (as just described in § 5), for which they claim ai)ei\ be/baion th\n xa/rin. The matter of present advantage (kai\ to\ parauti/ka w)fe/limon) is placed in the background by the emphatic position of ai)ei\ be/baion th\n xa/rin, by the particle kai/ (also), and by pou.—25. mh\ a)/llo ti nomi/sai: see on c. 30. 12.—27.

e)/xousi: for the position, cf. i. 39. 9 diafo/rous o)/ntas h(mi=n de/xesqai sfa=s.—to\ parauti/ka pou w)fe/limon: that these words belong together seems clear from tw=| au)ti/ka xrhsi/mw| (7), and from the consideration that, from 1. 7 on, above all the narrow regard for immediate advantage is to be proved inadmissible. parauti/ka, as in ii. 64. 27; vii. 57. 46. For the emphatic position of u(mi=n, cf. i. 68. 1; 70. 5; v. 82. 23; vii. 78. 26. —28.

And if Sparta should for the sake of Thebes inflict upon Plataea a cruel punishment, it would be universally regarded as an unnatural deed, and your present reputation among the Hellenes for justice would be gone.

prosske/yasqe: praeterea considerate, which Meineke (Herm. iii. p. 364) and v. H. (Stud. Thuc. p. 44) conjecture and St. adopts, is preferable here, where the orators pass to a new consideration, to proske/yasqe of the Mss. Nor is
the look into the future, which Cl. considers the main thought here, expressed in (5) o(ra=te o(/pws mh\ ou)k a)pode/cwntai and (8) deino\n de\ do/cei, any more than in c. 56. 8 tou= me\n o)rqou= fanei=sqe ou)k a)lhqei=s kritai\ o)/ntes.—para/deigma: an example, as ii. 37. 2. See on c. 40. 37.—2.
a)ndragaqi/as: here in the general sense of uprightness (not bravery, as c. 64. 16; ii. 42. 11; v. 101. 2), and a)ndrw=n a)gaqw=n and a)mei/nous follow in the same general signification.—3.

mh\ ta\ ei)ko/ta: cf. c. 56. 6. The neg. here, as well as in ou)d) h(mw=n memptw=n below, is out of its regular place, since mh/ belongs to ei)ko/ta, ou)d) to memptw=n. Cf. c. 67. 7; i. 5. 5; 78. 1; ii. 67. 34; 102. 22.—
ou) ga\r . . . memptw=n: the causal clause, thus placed in parataxis before the main one, is not rare in Thuc. See on i. 31. 7. For the sentiment, cf. Sall. Cat. 51. 12.—
a)fanh=: pred. adj. with adv. force, as c. 30. 4.—4.

e)painou/menoi . . . memptw=n: sc. krinei=te th\n di/khn th/nde. The antithesis, if strictly carried out, would have been perhaps e)pifanesta/thn de\ e)painou/menoi ou)de\ h(ma=s memptou\s krinou=ntes. Against the assumption of an a)fanh\s di/kh two grounds are advanced, the nature of the judges and that of those to be judged.—

peri\ ou)d) h(mw=n memptw=n: this order, since in independent const. the sent. would have been ou)d) h(mei=s memptoi/ e)smen. As to resemblances here and elsewhere in this and the following chapter to expressions in the Palamedes (§ 35 f.) attributed to Gorgias, see Maass, Herm. xxii. p. 580 f.; also Scheel, de Gorg. discipl. vestigiis, 1890, p. 55 ff.—5.
ou)k a)pode/cwntai: ‘litotes,’ for me/mfwntai, as vii. 48. 18. With dependent inf., as de/xesqai, c. 53. 4.—6.
au)tou/s: for u(ma=s au)tou/s. Cf. c. 54. 9.—
a)prepe/s ti: cf. c. 67. 16.—

e)pignw=nai: seems to have reference to the preliminary decision made at the surrender of the city, decide further or afterwards. Cf. i. 70. 8; ii. 65. 48. But as it is used of judicial decision in Dion. H. Ant. xi. 52 h(\n au)toi\ meq) o(/rkou dika/santes e)te/rwn e)pe/gnwsan ei)=nai (cf. also C. I. G. ii. 1845, l. 71 f. peri\ de\ tou= a)duna/tou boula\ kai\ a(li/a e)pigignwske/tw), this may be the meaning here.—
ou)de/: sc. a)pode/cwntai.—7. i(eroi=s toi=s koinoi=s: order, as in c. 54. 14; 56. 3. As in v. 18. 3, the temples at Olympia and Delphi are esp. meant.

*pla/taian *lakedaimoni/ous porqh=sai: that Lacedaemonians lay waste Plataea. The use of the proper name
instead of u(ma=s emphasizes the unnaturalness (deino/n) of the deed, since the mind recurs at once to the Spartan claim to be the liberators of Greece (see on c. 13. 35), as well as to the honour they had once paid to Plataea. So in l. 12 the mere word *qhbai/ous recalls their betrayal of the Greek cause in the Persian wars (cf. Hdt. vii. 132. 4).—9.

kai\ kte(.: in the double clause introduced by kai/ as a further element of the deino/n, the former (tou\s me\n . . . th\n po/lin), though in parataxis, is subord. to the latter (u(ma=s de\ . . . e)calei=yai). Cf. i. 28. 15. —10.

to
 tri/poda to
 e)n *delfoi=s: cf. i. 132. 10 to
 tri/poda/ pote to
 e)n *delfoi=s, o(
 a)ne/qesan oi( *(/ellhnes a)po\ tw=n *mh/dwn a)kroqi/nion, Hdt. ix. 81. 3 o( tri/pous o( xru/seos a)nete/qh o( e)pi\ tou= trikarh/nou o)/fios tou= xalke/ou e)pestew\s a)/gxista tou= bwmou=. The gold tripod was carried off by the Phocians in the sacred war (Paus. x. 13. 5). The bronze column of three intertwined snakes, which was removed by Constantine to Byzantium and placed in the hippodrome, the modern Atmeidan (Gibbon, chap. 17, note 48), was brought to light in 1856. It bears the names of all the Greek states which took part in the Persian war. —11.
panto\s tou= *(ellhnikou=: sc. e)/qnous, as in c. 82. 3. Cf. i. 1. 6; 6. 23.—

panoikesi/a|: cf. ii. 16. 4; Dio C. xli. 7. For the form, see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 46. The word is generally considered to mean here, house and all, ‘root and branch’; but Steup, who renders ‘with all its houses,’ maintains that both this expression and *pla/taian *lakedaimoni/ous porqh=sai refer to the fate of the city (cf. 68. 19), not of its inhabitants, since the women, children, old people, and other non-combatants, besides nearly half of the original defenders, were in Athens (cf. 24. § 2; ii. 6. 18; 72. 17; 78. § 3).—12.
dia\ *qhbai/ous: cf. di) au)tou/s, c. 56. 6.—

e)calei=yai: to blot out, forms with e)k panto\s tou= *(ellhnikou= a striking antithesis to a)nagra/yai e)s to\n tri/poda. There is the same antithesis in the examples compared by Bl., Ar. Pax 1181 tou\s me\n e)ggra/fontas h(mw=n, tou\s d' e)calei/fontas, Eur. Pel. (frg. 4) o(/n g' e)calei/fei r(a=|on, h)\ gra/fei, qeo/s. The same literal and fig. use obtains in e)calei/fein as in delere. In the fig. sense as here used, it seems to be mainly Tragic and Ionic. Cf. Aesch. Choeph. 503; Sept. 15; Eur. Hec. 590; Hel. 262; Hipp. 1241; I. T. 698; Hdt. vii. 220. 10; Plato Theaet. 187 b, Plut. de Fort. 4, and Aristides's imitation (ii. 857), e)calei=yai *lakedaimoni/ous e)k th=s *(ella/dos.

e)s tou=to cumfora=s: cf. e)s tou=to a)na/gkhs, i. 49. 31; Plato Theaet. 170 d; e)s tou=to dustuxi/as, vii. 86. 25; e)n tou/tw| paraskeuh=s, ii. 18. 1; ei)s tou=q) u(/brews, Dem. iv. 34; xxii. 16. G.
1088; H. 730 c.—14.

a)pwllu/meqa: Steup renders were ruined, since the reference is to the burning of their city by Xerxes (Hdt. viii. 50). Even with this reference, however, the rendering were all but ruined is admissible. GMT. 38.—

kai\ nu=n kte(.: Steup explains that kai/ co-ordinates a)pwllu/meqa with both the following clauses, and that nu=n e)n u(mi=n does not refer to the present trial, but is more general. But surely the evident reference in c. 67. 27 to this very passage shows that the present case is meant. —
e)n u(mi=n: before you (as judges). For the prep., see on c. 53. 3.—
*qhbai/wn: the mere name here implies tw=n e)xqi/stwn pa/ntwn. See on — 15.
h(ssw/meqa: used in a forensic sense.—
du/o a)gw=nas tou\s megi/stous: for the order, see on c. 42. 4.—16.
to/te me/n: i.e. before we decided to surrender. Cf. c. 52. § 1, 3; 59. 20. to/te is often thus used of a time assumed as well known. Cf. c. 69. 2; i. 101. 8; vii. 31. 12.—
ei) mh\ pare/domen: nisi tradidissemus, the apod. being a)gw=nas u(pe/sthmen (=e)kinduneu/samen) diafqarh=nai. GMT. 427 a. Cf. c. 74. 11.—17.

qana/tou kri/nesqai: to be tried on a capital charge. For the gen., see G. 1133; H. 745 b; Kr. Spr. 47, 22, 1; Kühn. 419, N. 11. Cf. Xen. Cyrop. i. 2. 14 qana/tou ou(=toi kri/nousin, Hdt. vi. 136. 4 qana/tou u(pagagw\n u(po\ to\n dh=mon *miltia/dea e)di/wke th=s *)aqhnai/wn a)pa/ths ei(/neken. Steup thinks that di/kh|, which is found in all the best Mss. except Vat., should be inserted after qana/tou. Cf. di/kh| kri/nesqai, i. 39. 1; iv. 122. 16, and qana/tou di/khn a)pologhsa/menos, viii. 68. 16.

periew/smeqa e)k pa/ntwn: we have been spurned by all, lit. thrust out from all. Cf. c. 67. 27; Arist. Pol. 1304 a, 1306 a. Note the wonderful pathos of the sent., brought out esp. by the antithesis *plataiei=s . . . *(/ellhnas (cf. c. 59. 25). See on l. 8 and 14.—18.
para\ du/namin: cf. c. 54. 17.—19.
e)rh=moi kai\ a)timwrhtoi/: deserted and unaided (cf. timwri/a, c. 20. 4), pred. of effect after periew/smeqa. Cf. i. 90. 20; ii. 75. 22; vii. 4. 11; 29. 17.—
tw=n to/te . . . ou)dei/s: i.e. none of the other members of the alliance formed at the time of the Persian war.—20.

ou)dei/s, u(mei=s te kte(.: the chiastic order produces a fine effect, as also the antithesis h( mo/nh e)lpi/s, de/dimen.—h( mo/nh e)lpi/s: cf. h( megi/sth e)lpi/s, Luc. Piscat. 3; unica spes, Liv. xxi. 11; Curt. iii. 8. 1.—21.

ou) be/baioi: not to be
depended on, i.e. not faithful to the old alliance and its consequences, mh\ ou) be/baion th\n xa/rin th=s a)reth=s e)/xhte. Cf. c. 56. 26.
Instead of Theban hate, let rather the thought of our former close association with you, the recollection of our merits, and the simple instincts of humanity influence you.

kai/toi a)ciou=me/n ge kte(.: the chief emphasis is on kai\ qew=n e(/neka . . . *(/ellhnas. Over against the anxiety just expressed are now placed those weighty considerations, which should induce the Lacedaemonians not to pass sentence against the Plataeans.—

qew=n e(/neka . . . genome/nwn: for the sake of the gods that once protected our alliance. The order as in c. 57. 7 i(eroi=s toi=s koinoi=s.—2. th=s a)reth=s: Schol. sc. th=s h(mete/ras. Cf. c. 54. § 4; 56. 16; 57. 10, 18.—3.
kamfqh=nai: found only here in Thuc. (cf. Aesch. Prom. 237, 306; Plato Prot. 320 b; Rep. 494 e; Plut. Per. 36), = e)piklasqh=nai, c. 59. 5; 67. 5; iv. 37. 5. —4.

th/n te dwrea
 . . . pre/pei: u(ma=s is the subj. of ktei/nein, as shown by ou(\s mh\ u(mi=n pre/pei, as well as of a)ntapaith=sai, komi/sasqai, and a)ntilabei=n, that you in turn ask of them the boon that you should not kill those whom you ought not, i.e. as the Thebans have asked the favour of our death (as hinted in ei)/ ti u(po\ *qhbai/wn e)pei/sqhte—cf. also c. 53. 21 a)/llois xa/rin fe/rontes), do you demand as a counterfavour, etc. Cl. explains, “that you request of them (in return for much favour shown them) the counterfavour, etc.” But in that case there should be some explanation of the favours that had been shown by the Lacedaemonians to the Thebans. St. and Kr. explain a)nti-, “in return for our former merits.” Kr. makes au)tou/s, sc. u(ma=s, subj. of ktei/nein. But to this is opposed the fact that all the rest of the infs. have u(ma=s as subject. For the inf. limiting th
 dwrea/n, cf. c. 66. 16 th
 peri\ au)tw=n h(mi=n mh\ ktei/nein yeusqei=san u(po/sxesin.—au)tou/s: i.e. tou\s *qhbai/ous, pers. obj. of a)ntapaith=sai.—5. sw/frona/ te . . . xa/rin: that you receive an honest gratitude (from us) instead of a disgraceful gratitude (from them). While the Plataeans designate the gratitude that would be acquired from the Thebans by the Lacedaemonians for their destruction as an ai)sxra\ xa/ris, the Thebans, c. 67. 26, demand the death of the Plataeans as a xa/ris di/kaia for their merits. komi/zesqai is used commonly of good things, as i. 43. 3; iv. 98. 25. Cf. Dem. xxi. 171 keko/mistai xa/rin par) u(mw=n.— 6. kaki/an: as in c. 61. 7, the result
of unworthy conduct, shame, more plainly expressed in du/skleian below. Cf. fe/rein a)reth/n, i. 33. 11.
braxu/: a small matter, as i. 140. 23, 27; viii. 76. 25.—8.
au)tou=: i.e. tou= diafqei=rai. au)to/ thus emphatically used c. 59. 20; i. 68. 9; 74. 3; 122. 20; 138. 11.—9.
ei)ko/tws: see on c. 56. 6. 10.
kat) a)na/gkhn: as shown c. 55. For the asyndeton, which Cl. was inclined to remove by inserting kai/, cf. c. 43. 10.
w(/ste kai\ tw=n swma/twn kte(.: see App.—11.
a)/deian poiou=ntes: (sc. h(mi=n) as in viii. 76. 34. Cf. vi. 60. 15 a)/deian poihsa/menon, obtaining security for one's self.—
o(/sia a)\n dika/zoite: you would render a righteous judgment, i.e. in accordance with divine law.—

pronoou=ntes: rendered by Cl., St., Jow., and others, if you consider beforehand, i.e. before you decide. But Steup follows Pp. and Kr. in supplying h(mw=n with pronoou=ntes (as h(mi=n with poiou=ntes). Cf. Xen. Cyrop. viii. 1. 1; 7. 15; and pronoei=sqai with gen., Thuc. vi. 9. 10.—12.
e(ko/ntas te e)la/bete kte(.: the Plataeans would have their voluntary surrender regarded as a i(ketei/a.—xei=ras proisxome/nous: Schol., i(keteu/santas. Cf. c. 66. 12; 67. 22.—

o( no/mos: i.e. the international custom based on religion. Cf. c. 59. 2 ta\ koina\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn no/mima, 67. 24 o( tw=n *(ellh/nwn no/mos. iv. 97. 10 ta\ no/mima tw=n *(ellh/nwn. See Hermann, Staats-Alt.^{6} p. 70, N. 3.—13.
eu)erge/tas gegenhme/nous: see on c. 2. 11.— 14.
dia\ panto/s: constantly, of time as usual. See on i. 38. 2.

qh/kas: see on c. 104. 5; ii. 52. 14. The place of the art. is supplied by the preceding gen., as often. Cf. c. 59. 6; i. 1. 11; 3. 1; 11. 2. As to these sepulchres, cf. Hdt. ix. 85; Paus. ix. 2. 5. In the sense of tomb, the word seems to occur, outside of Thuc., mainly in Hdt. (ii. 67. 4; ix. 85. 4) and Tragedy (Aesch. Agam. 453; Pers. 405; Soph. O. C. 1763; El. 896). Cf. Xen. Cyrop. vii. 3. 5. —17.

e)sqh/masi/ te . . . o(/sa te: over against the honours usually paid to the dead is placed as something espe
cial the offering of the first fruits of the land, and instead of continuing with the dat. there is a change of const. to the participle.—

e)sqh/masi: this much, but unjustly, suspected word seems, as Duker explained, to refer to the garments that were offered to the dead. Cf. Soph. El. 452; Eur. Or. 123, 1436. See Pasanisi, Rivista di Filol. Class. xv. p. 518 ff. As to the view of Cl. and St., that e)sqh/masi refers to the mourning clothes of the participants in the festival, no reason can be conceived why among the honours publicly paid every year to the dead especial mention should be made of the mourning garments. Nor is the difficulty removed by the circumstance emphasized by St., that, acc. to Plut. Aristid. 21, the archon of Plataea only at this annual festival put on xitw=na foinikou=n. Plut.'s omission, in his description of the festival, of any mention of the offering of garments may be explained on the assumption that the custom was obsolete in his time. e)/sqhma is a poetic word, acc. to the Schol. on Soph. El. 270. Cf. Aesch. Ag. 562; Pers. 536; Soph. El. 270; Eur. Troad. 991. Elsewhere only in late prose.—
toi=s a)/llois nomi/mois: Plut. l.c. mentions the slaughter of a bull, a drink-offering, etc.— 18.
a)nedi/dou: just as in Xen. Mem. iv. 3. 5.—
w(rai=a: products of the land, as in i. 120. 10.—
e)pife/rontes: of offerings to the dead, as in ii. 34. 5. —19.
e)k fili/as xw/ras: sc. th=s h(mete/ras e)pife/rontes.—o(mai/xmois: found only here in Thucydides. Cf. o(maixmi/a, i. 18. 25; Hdt. vii. 145. 12; viii. 140 a 21.

ske/yasqe de/: as in i. 143. 21, introduces an explanatory addition. Cf. c. 46. 4 ske/yasqe ga/r, i. 33. 7 kai\ ske/yasqe.—22. e)/qapten: for the force of the impf., see GMT. 35, and compare 56. Cf. a)pedi/dou oi)kei=n, ii. 71. 14.—23.

toiou/tois: sc. fili/ois, as toiou=tos often represents a preceding adjuective; cf. Plato Phaedo 108 b th\n a)ka/qarton (yuxh\n) kai/ ti pepoihkui=an toiou=ton. Esp. is this the case with e(/teros and a)/llos. Cf. Plato Phaedo 58 d.—24.
*qhbai+/da poih/sete: acc. to c. 68. § 3, the territory of the Plataeans was after a year rented to the Thebans.—
ti/ a)/llo h)/: see on c. 39. 10.—25.

toi=s au)qe/ntais: toi=s foneu=si: au)qe/ntai kuri/ws oi( au)to/xeires kai\ pole/mioi, Schol. See Lobeck ad
Phryn. p. 120. The Thebans are called au)qe/ntai, because they had sided with the Persians.—26.
a)ti/mous gerw=n: as ii. 65. 32 xrhma/twn a)dwro/tatos. G. 1141; H. 753 c; Kr. Spr. 47, 26, 10. ge/ra, as in i. 13. 5; 25. 15, of honours based on ancient precedent and sacred usage.—
i)/sxousi: possess, enjoy, as in ii. 68. 17; Hdt. i. 62. 3.—27.
pro\s de/: moreover, adv. only here in Thuc., but found also in Xen., Plato, and Demosthenes. Kühn. 443, 2; Kr. Spr. 68, 2, 2.—28.

i(era/ te . . . a)fairh/sesqe: and you desolate the temples of the gods to whom they prayed when they conquered the Medes, and you will take away the hereditary sacrifices from those who founded and built (the temples). As to the last clause, where i(era/ is supplied, with St. and Bm., as obj. of the parties., Cl. explains, ‘you will take away the hereditary sacrifices from those who founded and established them, where one would expect, “you will take from the sacrifices their founders,” i.e. the citizens of Plataea, who also in later generations were regarded as founders of those saerifices.’ Steup suggests that as Thuc. in i. 40. 7 uses a)posterei=n (tina/ tinos) in the sense ‘withdraw,’ not as usual ‘deprive’ (c. 42. 19; i. 69. 3; 136. 19), so here, on the contrary, a)fairei=sqai/ (tina/ tinos) may mean not ‘withdraw,’ but ‘deprive.’ Cf. Dem. xx. 82 th=s dwrea=s a)fh|re/qh. Also Xen. Cyneg. 6. 4; Lys. xxiv. 6; Plut. Aem. Paul. 31; Anton. 60. But see App.—29.
e)rhmou=te: the pres. between two futs. is rather remarkable. For the pres. thus co-ord. with a single fut., cf. ii. 44. 2; iv. 10. 11. Cl. considers this a contracted future form. See App. —
e(ssame/nwn: with the best Mss.; a few, ei(same/nwn or e(same/nwn. See Curtius, Verbum, I.^{2} p. 129. The archaic form is due possibly to some old formulary usage.—30.
a)fairh/sesqe: with acc. and gen. also c. 43. 4; viii. 46. 33.
By all that is sacred to gods and men, we beg you to spare us. But if you will not do this, then place us again in the position in which we were when we surrendered.
pro\s th=s . . . do/chs: for your glory. See on c. 38. 3.—2.

ta/de, ou)/te . . . a(marta/nein ou)/te . . . diafqei=rai: ta/de sums up the various features of an unfavourable decision as developed in the foregoing, and the special points of view to be con
sidered are epexegetically added in the ou)/te, ou)/te clauses.—

e)s ta\ koina\ . . . no/mima . . . a(marta/nein: see on c. 58. 12. a(marta/nein e)s with neut. acc., as Plato Legg. 759 c ta\ ei)s ta\ qei=a a(martano/mena.—e)s tou\s progo/nous: acc. to c. 58. § 4 f., the graves of the Spartans who fell at Plataea, and the gods who then aided the victors, would be neglected.—3.
tou\s eu)erge/tas: cf. c. 58. 13.—4.
mh\ au)tou\s a)dikhqe/ntas: in cond, form, though referring to the present case. For the asyndeton, see on c. 43. 10.— 5.
fei/sasqai de/: sc. pro\s th=s u(mete/ras do/chs e)sti/.—e)piklasqh=nai th=| gnw/mh|: as iv. 37. 5; without th=| gnw/mh|, c. 67. 5.—6.

labo/ntas: with reference to the wretched condition of the Plataeans, taking (i.e. regarding) our case, judging. The use of labei=n similar to that in c. 56. 8; iv. 17. 8; vi. 27. 9; 53. 18. In vi. 61. 3 likewise without obj. expressed, peri\ tou= *)alkibia/dou . . . xalepw=s oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)la/mbanon. To the adv. xalepw=s there corresponds in the present passage oi)/ktw| sw/froni, with reasonable compassion, ‘reasonable, a) because we are innocent, b) because all men are liable to the same.’ (Jow.)—
mh\ mo/non . . . a)lla/: without kai/, as in iv. 60. 1.—
katanoou=ntas: explanatory of oi)/ktw| sw/froni labo/ntas. St. construes mh\ w(=n deino/thta with labo/ntas, and considers katanoou=ntas a gloss. —7.

w(s a)sta/qmhton . . . cumpe/soi: how uncertain it is on whom misfortune may fall, however (kai/) undeserving he may be. (Jow.) Bl. compares Herodian v. 1. 11 ta\ th=s tu/xhs dw=ra kai\ a)naci/ois peripi/ptei. to\ th=s cumfora=s as to\ th=s tu/xhs, iv. 18. 9; vii. 61. 12; to\ th=s e)pisth/mhs, vii. 62. 8. H. 730 c; Kr. Spr. 47, 5, 10. The phrase is placed proleptically before w(/|tini (Kr. and others, with one Ms., o(/ tini).
h(mei=s te: opp. to th=s u(mete/ras do/chs above. “As your reputation is at stake, so there remains for us only the prayer—.”—
pre/pon: without e)sti/, as di/kaion (23), cumfe/ron (c. 44. 5), xrew/n (i. 77. 13), ei)ko/s, ai)sxro/n, deino/n, etc.—
proa/gei: draws us on, as in c. 45. 26.—10.

o(mobwmi/ous: i.e. having altars both among you and among us, as the context seems to require. Cf. ii. 71. 21 qeou\s tou\s u(mete/rous patrw/|ous kai\ h(mete/rous e)gxwri/ous. Most editt. explain, those deities who were worshipped together at the same altar, called o(mwxe/tai, iv. 97. 17; su/mbwmoi,
Strabo, p. 512. Arn. supposes these to be the magni dii (oi( dw/deka). Goell. explains, those gods at whose altars all Greece might jointly sacrifice, e.g. Olympian Jupiter and Pythian Apollo.—11.

e)pibow/menoi: signifies, as Bl. says, like e)pikalou/menoi, magna voce invocantes ad auxilium. Cf. c. 67. 9; vii. (69. 20); 75. 15; viii. 92. 50. The word seems to be Ionic and poetic. Cf. Hdt. i. 87. 4; ix. 23. 3; Hom. K 463; a 378; b 143; Eur. Med. 168. Elsewhere only in late writers.—

pei=sai ta/de: which Kr. and v. H. bracket, is to be construed with e)pibow/menoi. Just so in l. 14 the purpose of e)pikalou/meqa tou\s kekmhw=tas is expressed by mh\ gene/sqai u(po\ *qhbai/ois kte(. The subj. of both infs. is the Plataeans. If pei=sai ta/de be taken with ai)tou/meqa u(ma=s, as Cl., St., and Jow. explain, pei=sai is not only superfluous, but out of place. On the other hand, ai)tou/meqa u(ma=s can dispense with the neuter object (cf. iv. 18. 4). ta/de refers to the course which the speakers beg the Lacedaemonians to take (l. 5, fei/sasqai kai\ e)piklasqh=nai th=| gnw/mh|). To refer ta/de to what follows, as Cl. does, and make the request proper begin with profero/menoi is impossible, because the invocation of the gods could not thus be separated from that of the oaths. —
profero/menoi <q)> o(/rkous: q) is added, against the Mss., with St., who rightly judges that Thuc. could not have let the second part of the invocation follow the first without a connective.—

profero/menoi: the mid. emphasizes personal interest. “Bringing forward the oaths for our protection.” Cf. Plato Phil. 57 a. Elsewhere in Thuc., either act. (c. 64. 7; vi. 7. 11; 31. 21), or passive (v. 26. 22; vii. 69. 19). Most of the Mss. have prosfero/menoi, but the examples just cited seem sufficiently to establish the vulgate.—12.

mh\ a)mnhmonei=n: explanatory of w)/mosan, unless the words be considered, with Steup (following Cobet and v. H.), a marginal explanation of w)/mosan. Cf. ii. 73. 14, where the purport of the oath is not given. To connect mh\ a)mnhmonei=n with profero/menoi, as Cl., or with i(ke/tai gigno/meqa, as St., is inadmissible, since the Plataeans cannot be the subj. of this inf., as of pei=sai and mh\ gene/sqai. —i(ke/tai gigno/meqa: see on c. 2. 11.— 13.

u(mw=n tw=n patrw/|wn ta/fwn: joined with pathetic effect to i(ke/tai gigno/meqa, u(mw=n receiving special emphasis from its position. “We put ourselves under the protection of the graves in which your fathers rest.” Cf. i. 136. 9 th=s gunaiko\s i(ke/ths geno/menos, Hdt. i. 73. 28 *)alua/ttew i(ke/tai e)ge/nonto, Isocr. vi. 23 i(ke/tai kate/sthsan tau/ths th=s po/lews, Cic. Tusc. i. 29 iudicibus supplex fuit. Cobet, N. L. p. 346, conjectures u(mw=n pro\s tw=n patrw/|wn ta/fwn, which would
weaken the effect.—14.

tou\s kekmhw=tas: euphemism for tou\s teqnew=tas, as in Plato Legg. 718 a; 927 b; and often in Tragedy, e.g. Aesch. Suppl. 158; Eur. Suppl. 756; Troad. 96. The archaic poetic form, which is retained with most of the Mss., like e(ssame/nwn in c. 58. 29, is more appropriate to the solemn invocation.—
u(po\ *qhbai/ois: with gene/sqai as u(po\ *surakosi/ois, vi. 86. 3; vii. 64. 7. Cf. u(f) au(toi=s poiei=sqai, c. 62. 19. For the const., see G. 1219, 2; H. 808, 2; Kr. Spr. 68, 44.—

toi=s e)xqi/stois fi/ltatoi o)/ntes: sc. toi=s kekmhw=si. Cf. c. 58. 25 para\ toi=s au)qe/ntais.—15. h(me/ras te . . . e)kei/nhs: for the art. omitted, cf. gh=n th/nde, ii. 74. 11; stratia=| th=|de, iv. 85. 25. Kühn. 465, N. 6 a.—

a)namimnh/|skomen: sc. tou\s kekmhw=tas.— 16. h(=| ta\ lampro/tata . . . paqei=n: two clauses are united in one; the full form would be h(=| . . . e)pra/camen, o(/mws de\ nu=n kte(. In pra/cantes the Plataeans identify themselves with their ancestors.—
met) au)tw=n: sc. tw=n kekmhw/twn. The best Mss. have au(tw=n or e(autw=n, which is impossible.— 17.
e)n th=|de: the prep. is added to emphasize the important point.
o(/per de/: for the rel. sent., where pauo/menoi de/, o(/per a)nagkai=on kte(. would seem more natural, see Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 13; Kühn. 562, 2.—
toi=s w(=de e)/xousi: see on c. 53. 14.—19.

lo/gou teleuta=n: epexegesis of o(/per, as iv. 125. 8 a)safw=s e)kplh/gnusqai. The gen. as in c. 104. 28; Xen. Cyrop. viii. 7. 17 tou= a)nqrwpi/nou bi/ou teleuth/sw. Kr. Spr. 47, 13, 7; Kühn. 421, 3.—
met) au)tou=: i.e. tou= teleuta=n. See on c. 58. 8.—20.

pauo/menoi le/gomen h)/dh: repeating the idea of the rel. clause, and more forcible than tou=to nu=n poiou=ntes.—21. tw=| ai)sxi/stw| o)le/qrw| limw=|: connected as qa/naton zhmi/an, c. 44. 10. See note there. Cf. Hom. m 342 limw=| d' oi)/ktiston qane/ein kai\ po/tmon e)pispei=n, Dion. H. Ant. vi. 86 tw=| kaki/stw| tw=n mo/rwn limw=|, Sall. Ep. Pomp. 1 fame, miserrima omnium morte, Liv. xxi. 41 ultimo supplicio humanorum, fame, xxvii. 44 fame et frigore, quae miserrima mortis genera sunt, Amm. Marcell. xvii. 9 fame ignavissimo mortis genere tabescentes. ai)/sxiston, most shameful, because manly resistance is impossible. Cf. App. Hisp. 97 tw=| limw=| sfa=s katergazome/nous, a)ma/xw|
kakw=|—22. u(mi=n pisteu/santes: cf. 53. 2.—23.
prosh/lqomen: cf. c. 52. 10 w(s au)tw=n e)ko/ntwn pros xwrhsa/ntwn, v. 17. 15 o(mologi/a| au)tw=n prosxwrhsa/ntwn. —e)s ta\ au)ta\ katasth/santas: cf. c. 34. 14.—24.

to\n cuntuxo/nta ki/ndunon: the first danger that presents itself (o(\s a)\n cuntu/xh|, fut. ex., Kr.). Cf. toi=s e)ntuxou=sin e)pitre/pein, iv. 132. 18; e)k tou= paratuxo/ntos punqano/menos, i. 22. 8.—
e)a=sai: sc. as subj. u(ma=s.
