e)piskh/ptome/n te a(/ma kte(.: even after the last despairing request they cannot refrain from summing up once more in a solemn adjuration (e)piskh/ptomen, as in ii. 73. 13) all the grounds for mercy already advanced, and, with the appeal w)= *lakedaimo/nioi, bringing these motives home to the consciences of the Lacedaemonians. ‘The conclusion of the speech is confused with the accumulation of most passionate admonitions, e)piskh/ptome/n te a(/ma mh/, 1) *plataih=s o)/ntes oi( proqumo/tatoi peri\ tou\s *(/ellhnas geno/menoi, 2) *qhbai/ois, 3) toi=s h(mi=n e)xqi/stois, 4) e)k tw=n u(mete/rwn xeirw=n kai\ th=s u(mete/ras pi/stews, 5) i(ke/tai o)/ntes, w)= *lakedaimo/nioi, paradoqh=nai . . . diole/sai, where the anxiety and perplexity of the speaker are well depicted, and the minds of the readers greatly moved by the unusual position of the voc. (w)= *lakedaimo/nioi), by the omission of the acc. u(ma=s with gene/sqai. although u(ma=s would naturally be expressed since a different subj. immediately precedes, and by the two phrases e)k tw=n u(mete/rwn xeirw=n kai\ th=s u(mete/ras pi/stews.’ Heilmann.—26.
oi( proqumo/tatoi: as in c. 57. 18, of a disposition ready for any sacrifice. Cf. c. 56. 16; ii. 71. 18.—
*qhbai/ois toi=s h(mi=n e)xqi/stois: cf. ii. 71. 20.—27.
th=s u(mete/ras pi/stews: cf. pisteu/santes u(mi=n, l. 22 and c. 53. 2; dia\ ponhrw=n a)nqrw/pwn pi/stin, vi. 53. 10.—29.
gene/sqai de/: sc. u(ma=s, the abrupt change of subj. is induced by the address, w)= *lakedaimo/nioi. Cf. i. 43. 4.—
tou\s a)/llous *(/ellhnas e)leuqerou=ntas: see on c. 13. 35; 32. 5.

p.hi: The Thebans ask permission to reply to the speech of the Plataeans.

div2.p:
pro\s to\n lo/gon: in view of the
speech. Cf. pro\s to\ paro/n, c. 40. 35; ii. 22. 1; v. 9. 14. It belongs to dei/santes. To connect it also with e)ndw=si, as Cl. does, is unnecessary, since e)ndw=si depends on dei/santes. —3. parelqo/ntes: regularly used of orators coming forward to speak. Cf. i. 67. 16; 72. 15, etc. Ullrich's suggestion, proselqo/ntes (Beitr. iii. 7), approved by Cl., is inappropriate, since the Thebans had attended the trial from the beginning.—
ei)pei=n: i.e. to make a set speech. Cf. 53. 10 lo/gon h)|thsa/meqa, 61. 1 tou\s lo/gous ou)k a)\n h)|thsa/meqa ei)pei=n.—4. gnw/mhn th\n au(tw=n: order as in c. 56. 3; 58. 14. —6.
w(s e)ke/leusan: sc. the five Lacedaemonian judges. Cf. c. 52. 17. REPLY OF THE THEBANS. c. 61-67.

Since the Plataeans, instead of simply answering the question propounded, have in a lengthy speech attacked us and glorified themselves, we too must make a fuller statement. The Plataeans early renounced the Boeotian alliance and our hegemony, and placed themselves with hostile intent under the protection of Athens.

tou\s lo/gous: const. with ei)pei=n. “These (lengthy) speeches,” implying the reluctance with which they have recourse to them. The effect of the art. seems to be similar to that of the appos. tou\s pollou/s in i. 86. 1 tou\s lo/gous tou\s pollou/s. Cf. c. 53. 10 lo/gon h)|thsa/meqa, and c. 60. 3 e)/fasan kai\ au)toi\ bou/lesqai ei)pei=n.—2. kai\ au)toi/: i.e. ou)=toi kai\ au)toi/, et isti. Cf. i. 50. 18; 51. 6. Hude (Comm. Crit. p. 106) suggests kai\ ou)=toi. But to refer kai\ au)toi\ . . . a)pekri/nanto to the Plataeans is not harder than in c. 60. 6 w(s d' e)ke/leusan, to understand the Lacedaemonians.—

to\ e)rwthqe\n a)pekri/nanto: ‘such an acc. with a)pokri/nesqai is not found elsewhere in Thuc., though freq. in Plato. This const. seems, however, to be confined to neut. prons. (to/de, tou=to, etc.) and to\ (ta\) e)rwtw/menon (a).’ Bm. See Kr. Spr. 46, 6, 3; Matth. 409, 6.—3.

kai\ peri\ au(tw=n . . . a)pologi/an: and had not made concerning themselves a long defence aside from the question, and especially of points which were never charged. As to the matter, cf. c. 52. 18 kathgori/a ou)demi/a proete/qh, and c. 53. 9 prokathgori/as h(mw=n ou) progegenhme/nhs. peri\ au(tw=n opp. to e)pi\ h(ma=s. With e)/cw tw=n prokeime/nwn (i.e. to\ e)rw/thma to\ braxu/, c. 54. 5) cf. ii. 65. 26 e)/cw tou= pole/mou, Dem. xviii. 9 toi=s
e)/cwqen lo/gois.—4. kai\ a(/ma: not a simple copula, but, like a)/llws te kai/, introducing an esp. important circumstance. See on i. 2. 8.—

h)|tiame/nwn: pass. of dep. verb. H. 819 d; Kr. Spr. 39, 14, 3; Kühn. 377, 4 a. Cf. ai)tiaqei/s, vi. 53. 14; viii. 68. 15. It depends on a)pologi/a, as w(=n upon e)/painon. Steup follows Cl. in connecting h)|tiame/nwn with au(tw=n, though he suggests that h)|tiame/nwn may have been a slip of the copyist for h)|tiame/noi, due to the influence of the preceding genitives. pollh
 th
 a)pologi/an kai\ e)/painon he takes together (both limited by w(=n), about as oi( au)toi\ o(/rkoi kai\ cummali/a, i. 102. 21, comparing further vi. 49. 21 ou)/te plou=n polu
 ou)/te o(do/n, 92. 17 e)s ki/ndunon kai\ e)s talaipwri/an pa=san, 97. 8 ou)/te plou=n ou)/te o(do
 pollh/n.—6. pro\s me
 ta/: order as in c. 82. 52; vi. 45. 5; 66. 6; vii. 12. 4. Cf. Soph. Ant. 557 kalw=s su\ me
 toi=s, toi=s d' e)gw\ )do/koun fronei=n. Kr. Spr. 50, l, 13; Matth. 288, N. 3. ta\ me/n refers to kathgori/an (cf. c. 53. 9), ta\ de/ to th
 a)pologi/an kai\ e)/painon.— a)nteipei=n, e)/legxon poih/sasqai: cf. c. 53. 9, 12. The former is done in c. 62, the latter in c. 63. 64.—7.

h( h(mete/ra kaki/a: refers ironically (cf. c. 58. 6) to the effect of the kathgori/a. and h( tou/twn (cf. l. 12 ou(=toi) do/ca to that of the a)pologi/a and of the e)/painos. —au)tou/s: for the position, cf. v. 82. 23; vii. 78. 26, and see on c. 63. 8.
h(mei=s de/: the de/ marks the transition from the general introduction to the matter in hand, and should not be altered, with Kr., to dh/ either here or in i. 37. 7. See on c. 10. 7. and vi. 89. 3.—

dia/foroi e)geno/meqa prw=ton: (Mss. AC to\ prw=ton) as c. 10 7 cummaxi/a e)ge/neto prw=ton.—10. h(mw=n ktisa/ntwn: the Thebans substitute themselves for the Boeotians, who were driven out of Thessaly and occupied the country of the Cadmeans (afterwards called Boeotia), about sixty years after the Trojan war, acc. to Thuc. i. 12. § 3. Cf. Strabo ix. 2. 3 ff. See Muenscher, de Reb. Plataeens. p. 27 sqq.—11.
a)/lla xwri/a: i.e. ‘the region below Cithaeron toward the Euripus,’ Muenseh. ibid p. 27.—
a(/: includes Plataea also. See Muensch. ibid. p. 29.—
cummi/ktous a)nqrw/pous: Strabo l.c. mentions Pelasgians, Thracians, Hyantians.— 12.

ou)k h)ci/oun: were indignant at.
Cf. i. 102. 17; iv. 86. 7.—
w(/sper e)ta/xqh to\ prw=ton: prob. taken for granted, rather than based on historical tradition.—13.
h(gemoneu/esqai: found only here in pass., a sort of milder a)/rxesqai (c. 36. 9; 37. 10; ii. 41. 11). G. 1236; H. 819 a; Kr. Spr. 52, 4, 1; Kühn. 378, 7.—
e)/cw: apart from. See on —14.
parabai/nontes ta\ pa/tria: i.e. renouncing the Boeotian alliance. Cf. c. 65. 8; 66. 3; ii. 2. 27.—
proshnagka/zonto: were forced to it, i.e. pro\s to\ mh\ parabai/nein ta\ pa/tria. Cf. iv. 87. 8; v. 42. 19; viii. 76. 32. For the strengthening force of pro/s, see on i. 106. 2; vii. 18. 31.—15.
prosexw/rhsan pro\s *)aqhnai/ous: cf. c. 55. § 1. The simple dat. is more common, as in i. 74. 24; 103. 11; ii. 2. 29; v. 32. 14.—
met) au)tw=n . . . e)/blapton: cf. Hdt. vi. 108. 5 po/nous u(pe\r au)tw=n (i.e. tw=n *plataie/wn) oi( *)aqhnai=oi suxnou\s h)/dh a)naire/onto.

Only on account of their alliance with Athens did they oppose the Persians. We Thebans, however, were then under the rule of oligarchs, who expected advantage from the Persians. Afterwards at Coronea we won Boeotia's independence from Athens.
kai/: introduces the second point of consideration.—
h)=lqen e)pi/: as in l. 5; freq. of going to war. See on i. 78. 7.—2.
mo/noi: see on c. 54. 12. —3.
loidorou=sin: Schol. mhdi/santas dhlono/ti, which is implied in tou/tw|.

h(mei=s de\ . . . ou) fame/n: but we say that they did not medize. For the position of ou), which Cl. accents (ou)/) to show that it belongs to mhdi/sai au)tou/s, see Kr. Spr. 67, 1, 2. Cf. c. 64. 2.—4.
*)aqhnai/ous: assimilated to the case of au)tou/s, as after w(/sper, i. 69. 23; v. 99. 4; vi. 68. 9, and, after a rel. pron., vii. 21. 14.—
th=| au)th=| i)de/a|: on the same principle. Cf. vi. 76. 12. It belongs with mo/nous a)ttiki/sai.

e)n oi(/w| ei)/dei: i.e. tro/pw| politei/as, in quo statu. Cf. viii. 90. 2. i)de/a and ei)=dos are here contrasted as representing internal and external conditions, but the meaning common to both words, form, appearance, causes sometimes an interchange of use.
Cf. i. 109. 2, where i)de/a means outward appearance; vi. 77. 15; viii. 56. 7, where ei)=dos means mode of action. oi)=os in indir. ques., as i. 69. 12; vii. 64. 8. See on c. 47. 1.—7.
e(ka/teroi h(mw=n tou=to e)/pracan: i.e. we sided with the Persians, they with the Athenians. Cf. —
h(mi=n me\n kte(.: the remainder of the chapter contains the first part of the explanation announced in kai/toi ske/yasqe kte(., c. 63, 64 the second.—8.

kat) o)ligarxi/an i)so/nomon politeu/ousa: the const. politeu/ein kata/, as in c. 66. 3; i. 19. 2. An oligarchy is meant, in which all the nobles were o(mo/timoi or o(/moioi. Cf. Arist. Pol. iv. (vi.) 5, who likewise contrasts it with the dunastei/a. —10. tw=| swfronesta/tw|: not (= toi=s sw/frosin a)ndra/sin, Schol.), but the ideal of a well-ordered constitution (respublica optime constituta et temperata), to which is opposed, as the extreme of arbitrariness, the tu/rannos.—e)gguta/tw de\ tura/nnou kte(.: cf. Tac. Ann. vi. 42 paucorum dominatio regiae libidini propior est. Note the bold use of the concrete (tu/rannos) for the abstract.—11.

dunastei/a o)li/gwn a)ndrw=n: cf. Arist. Pol. iv. (vi.) 5 o(/tan . . . a)/rxh| mh\ o( no/mos, a)ll) oi( a)/rxontes . . ., kalou=si dh\ th\n toiau/thn o)ligarxi/an dunastei/an. Hdt. (ix. 86. 4) names e)n prw/toisi tw=n mhdisa/ntwn Timagenides and Attaginus. —

ei)=xe ta\ pra/gmata: as c. 72. 3. Cf. e)/xein th
 po/lin, viii. 66. 2; th
 politei/an, viii. 74. 14; th
 a)rxh/n, viii. 46. 6; th
 h(gemoni/an, v. 47. 41. See on c. 11. 11; 28. 1.
i)di/as duna/meis . . . sxh/sein: expecting that they will win power of their own in still greater measure. See Lupus, N. Jahrbb. exi. p. 167.— 13.
ei) . . . krath/seie: cf. Hdt. iv. 137. —
kate/xontes i)sxu/i to\ plh=qos: cf. the reverse in ii. 65. 33 katei=xe to\ plh=qos e)leuqe/rws. i)sxu/s of brute force, as in c. 39. 20; i. 76. 15. On the matter, cf. Plut. Aristid. 18.— 14.
e)phga/gonto: the verb is regularly used of inviting strangers into one's country. Cf. i. 3. 8; 104. 5; 114. 6; ii. 2. 12; Plato Menex. 243 b.—

kai\ h( cu/mpasa po/lis ou)/t) au)tokra/twr . . . e)/pracen, ou)/t) a)/cion kte(.: the vulg. is ou)k au)tokra/twr and ou)d) a)/cion. But the second clause must be a formal antithesis to the first, unless the speakers, in turning from the authorities to the state of Thebes, take into
consideration along with the facts also the decision, i.e. pass to something new. Cobet conjectures (Mnem. N.S. viii. p. 140), kai\ ou)x h( cu/mpasa po/lis au)tokra/twr . . . ou)d) a)/cion kte(. But this is inadmissible, since w(=n mh\ meta\ no/mwn h(/marten requires a positive subject (h( cu/mpasa po/lis).—15.
tou=t) e)/pracen: i.e. took the side of the Persians—a mild way of referring to their shameful conduct. As to the matter, see Plutarch's apology for the Thebans, de Malig. Herod. 31. 3.—16.
w(=n: i.e. tou/twn a(/. The gen. with o)neidi/sai is rare. In Hdt. i. 90. 16 tou/tou o)neidi/sai, Stein writes tou=to. G. 1126; H. 744; Kr. Spr. 47, 21; Matth. 368.—
mh\ meta\ no/mwn: i.e. a)/neu no/mwn. Cf. c. 40. 30 mh\ cu\n a)na/gkh|. For the effect of the neg., see on i. 91. 28; 141. 24. Kr. Spr. 67, 9 and 10, 4.
tou\s no/mous e)/labe: sc. h( po/lis, received its own laws, i.e. a constitution based on laws. Cf. c. 64. 11.— 18.

e)pio/ntwn th/n te a)/llhn . . . ta\ polla/: the parties. peirwme/nwn and e)xo/ntwn are both subord. to and explanatory of e)pio/ntwn. Steup thinks there is a slight anacoluthon, comparing c. 67. 24; 86. 16; ii. 46. 1.— 19.
kata\ sta/sin . . . ta\ polla/: after the battle at Oenophyta, 458 B. C. Cf. i. 108. § 2, 3. For kata\ sta/sin, see on c. 2. 10.—20.
ei): in indir. ques., as ii. 53. 10. G. 1605; H. 1016; Kr. Spr. 65, 1, 8.—
maxo/menoi: see on c. 113. 13.—
h)leuqerw/samen . . . cuneleuqerou=men: corresponds chiastically to l. 18 above.—22.

proqu/mws cuneleuqerou=men: proqu/mws, which, with its cognate forms, is used every where by Thuc. of a self-sacrificing spirit (cf. c. 57. 18; i. 74. 5), is here put into the mouths of the Thebans in order to indicate their hypocritical self-satisfaction. In like manner, cuneleuqerou=men (cf. c. 13. 10; ii. 72. 4) also claims a share in the doubtful Spartan boast of being the liberators of Greece (see on c. 13. 35; 32. 5; 59. 30).—23.

i(/ppous te pare/xontes kai\ paraskeuh\n kte(.: cf. ii. 100. 7 i(/ppois kai\ o(/plois kai\ th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=|. —i(/ppous pare/xontes: Thuc. uses the
mid. pare/xesqai/ ti, or the act. pare/xein ti, according as stress is to be laid on the part of the performer or upon the value and extent of the performance,—the mid. twenty-nine times, the act. ninety-one times. See on ii. 9. 9. For the cavalry of the Boeocians, cf. ii. 9. 11; 12. 18; 22. 11. The matter is mentioned here with a view to its effect on the Lacedaemonian judges.—25.
kai\ ta\ me\n . . . a)pologou/meqa: cf. c. 64. 20.
You Plataeans have misused your alliance with the Athenians by sharing in all their deeds of violence against other Hellenes, thereby voluntarily incurring a heavy burden of guilt.
w(s de\ u(mei=s kte(.: beginning of the second part of the explanation announced c. 62. 6. From here to the end of c. 66 the Plataeans are directly addressed.—
ma=llon h)dikh/kate tou\s *(/ellhnas: cf. c. 56. 1.— 2.
a)ciw/teroi: i.e. ma=llon a)/cioi. “You rather than we are worthy of every penalty.” Cf. i. 122. 11.
e)ge/nesqe: the asyndeton shows the earnestness of the speaker.—
e)pi\ th=| h(mete/ra| timwri/a|: for our punishment, i.e. for your protection against us. Cf. ii. 42. 17; vi. 76. 15. h(mete/ra| stands for the obj. gen.—
poli=tai: see on c. 55. 12.—
ou)kou=n kte(.: Cl. writes ou)k ou)=n, and makes the sent. (ending with proba/llesqe) a question.—
ta\ pro\s h(ma=s mo/non: only in that which pertains to us, i.e. only against us. —5.

au)tou/s: i.e. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.— 6. u(pa/rxon ge u(mi=n: when it was certainly open to you, sc. mh\ cunepie/nai. u(pa/rxein in this sense also c. 109. 20; i. 82. 26; vii. 63. 6. See on i. 124. l. For the acc. abs., see GMT. 851; H. 973.—

a)/kontes prosh/gesqe:=h)nagka/zesqe, as ii. 89. 14. Cf. vi. 54. 13 bi/a| prosaga/ghtai.—7. tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn tw=nde: the art. preceding the dem. tw=nde is unusual, but prob. the pron. was added with esp. reference to the judges. Kr. Spr. 50, 11, 19.— 8.

h)/dh e)pi\ tw=| *mh/dw|: placed before cummaxi/as, as au)toi/s before kaki/a in c. 61. 7. e)pi\ tw=| *mh/dw|, as in c. 13. 18; i. 102. 19, in hostile sense, for the more usual acc. Kühn. 438, ii. d. This const. with the dat. is the rule in epic, and is freq. also in Attic
poets.—9.
proba/llesqe: put forward as a cloak. Cf. i. 37. 16; ii. 87. 14. On the matter, cf. esp. c. 58. § 1; iv. 59. § 2.—

i(kanh/ ge: the asyndeton is justified by the order of the words. See on c. 37. 10. St. explains, ‘Particula ge sententias iungit hic et i. 40. 15; 70. 6; vi. 86. 8.’ Kr. proposes, after Reiske and Va., h(\ i(kanh/ ge, or i(kanh/n ge h(ma=s.—10. a)potre/pein: as c. 39. 1, doubtless only in the mild sense of restrain, not ward off.—
to\ me/giston: what is most important. Appos. to the inf. clause. H. 626 b; Kr. Spr. 57, 10, 12. See on i. 142. 1.—

pare/xein: sc. u(mi=n.—11. ou) biazo/menoi kte(.: in answer to c. 55. 3 o(/te *qhbai=oi h(ma=s e)bia/santo.— ei(/lesqe . . . ta\ *)aqhnai/wn: cf. c. 56. 23. The formula is similar to fronei=n ta/ tinos, c. 68. 17; bou/lesqai ta/ tinos, vi. 50. 12.
kai\ le/gete: cf. c. 55. § 3.—
ai)sxro/n, ai)/sxion: as in ii. 40. 4.— 14.
kataprodou=nai: kata- with intensive force, as in c. 109. 18; i. 86. 19; iv. 10. 10; vii. 48. 26; and katadouloume/nous below.—
oi=s cunwmo/sate: i.e. pro\s ou(\s cummaxi/an e)poih/sasqe. Cf. c. 64. 7, 10; i. 71. 23; ii. 72. 5; 74. 11.—15.
tou\s me\n katadouloume/nous, tou\s de\ e)leuqerou=ntas: joined chiastically to the preceding.—16.

tou\s de\ e)leuqerou=ntas: as in i. 124. 19 Corinthian speakers address to the representatives of the Peloponnesian alliance the words, tou\s nu=n dedoulwme/nous *(/ellhnas e)leuqerw/swmen, so here the whole Peloponnesian alliance, not merely the h(gemo/nes, are represented as the liberators of Greece.
ou)k i)/shn th\n xa/rin: the order and effect as in c. 30. 4 polu\ to\ a)fu/lakton, i. 34. 10 e)laxi/stas ta\s metamelei/as, the pred. adj. supplying the place of an adverb.—19.

toi=s de/: sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, a)dikou=sin a)/llous being pred. Jow. takes toi=s a)dikou=sin together in a general sense, wrongdoers, on the ground that toi=s de/ as dem. would introduce an opposition between it and au)tou/s, while both really refer to the same persons.—

kai/toi ta\s o(moi/as kte(.: “and indeed it
is a shame to refuse to repay favours with like favours, not however to omit the repayment of favours which, though justly due, cannot be returned without injustice.” Cf. Cic. de Off. i. 15. 48 non reddere bono non licet, modo id facere possit sine iniuria.—
mh\ a)ntidido/nai: cf. i. 41. 4. The words are to be supplied in the second clause.—
ma=llon h)/: as in c. 37. 12; 64. 9, completely subordinates the second member, so that ai)sxro/n applies only to the first. —21.

o)feilhqei/sas, a)podidome/nas: the change of time corresponds to the service already rendered and the still doubtful requital. The whole sentence serves to substantiate the words ou)de\ ai)sxu/nhs a)phllagme/nhn (l. 17), the charge ta\s o(moi/as xa/ritas mh\ a)ntidido/nai being, according to the Theban speakers, applicable to the Plataeans.—
e)s a)diki/an: cf. c. 37. 7; ii. 40. 22.
You have, therefore, no right on your earlier alliance with the Hellenes to base claims which you have forfeited by later conduct, that reveals your real sentiments.

dh=lo/n te e)poih/sate kte(.: and so you showed that not even then was it for the sake of the Hellenes that you did not medize, but because the Athenians did not and we did, since you preferred to act with them and to oppose us. So St. and Cl., who adopt h(mei=s (sc. e)mhdi/samen), the reading of several of the best Mss., for u(mei=s, and put a comma after h(mei=s de/. Cf. Plato Rep. 422 d ou)d) h(mi=n qe/mis, u(mi=n de/. The other editt. all retain the vulg. u(mei=s, which must be explained as a repetition on account of the intervening *)aqhnai=oi. If u(mei=s be read, supply ou)k e)mhdi/sate (Arn., Kr.), or ou) mhdi/santes (Bm.). The general sense is clear, “only attachment for Athens and hatred of us are the motives of your boasted patriotism.” Cf. c. 62. § 2.—2.
mhdi/santes: const. with dh=lon e)poih/sate. Cf. c. 84. 12; i. 21. 12; ii. 50. 4; Hdt. vi. 21. 8, and see on c. 40. 37. GMT. 904; H. 981; Kühn. 482, 2.—
o(/ti ou)d) *)aqhnai=oi: sc. e)mh/disan. Cf. App. Bell. Civ. i. 121 to\n strato\n ou) meqi/ei, dio/ti mhde\ *pomph/ios.—3. toi=s me/n: i.e. the Athenians.—
toi=s de/: i.e. the Thebans.

a)f) w(=n: this alone (=a)po\ tou/twn a(/) would have been grammatically sufficient. For the epanaleptic dem., notwithstanding the assimilation, see Kr. Spr. 51, 11, 2; Kühn. 555, N. l. Cf. Dem. viii. 23 kai\ peri\ w(=n fasi me/llein au)to\n poiei=n, kai\ peri\
tou/twn prokathgorou/ntwn a)kroa=sqe, ibid. 26 a)f) w(=n . . . danei/zetai, a)po\ tou/twn dia/gei.—di) e(te/rous: i.e. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, whereby the merit of e)ge/nesqe a)gaqoi/ is annulled.—5.
a)po\ tou/twn: from that source, mockingly added to indicate the groundlessness of the claim. Cf. l. 7, and see on c. 36. 12; 48. 3.—6.
tou/tois cunagwnizesqe: continue as allies with them.—7.
profe/rete: as the mid., c. 59. 11. As to the matter, cf. c. 57. § 4; 58. § 1; 59. § 2. —
to/te: often used of a time assumed to be well known. See on i. 101. 8.—
cunwmosi/an: of an alliance also v. 83. 16. Cf. l. 10 and c. 63. 14.
a)peli/pete: cf. c. 9. 3.—9.
ma=llon: see on c. 37. 12; 63. 20.—
*ai)ginh/tas: cf. i. 105; 108; ii. 27.—
a)/llous tina/s: it cannot be certainly determined who are meant. Pp. thinks the Euboeans, and possibly the Naxians (i. 98).—10.
cunomosa/ntwn: see on c. 63. 14.—

diekwlu/ete: sc. to\ e(te/rous katadoulou=sqai au)tou/s.—11. tou\s no/mous: as in 62. 17. From this it may perhaps be inferred that the Plataeans even at the time of the Aeginetan war had a popular form of government. See Muenscher, p. 78 ff.—
me/xri tou= deu=ro: elsewhere me/xri deu=ro. See Kr. Spr. 66, 1, 4.— 12.
w(/sper h(ma=s: cf. c. 62. § 3, 4.—

th\n teleutai/an te . . . a)mu/nein: exactly the demand made by Archidamus, ii. 72. 10 (cf. c. 68. 6); hence u(mw=n (obj. gen.) is to be preferred to h(mw=n (of most Mss.), since the Thebans did not make the proclamation.

ou)=n: wanting in most of the best Mss., but the asyndeton would be harsh, and ou)=n has not infreq. dropped out after a)/n.—toi=s *(/ellhsi: dat. of agent with the pass., as in c. 70. 4; 82. 45; 85. 10; i. 44. 7; 51. 3; ii. 35. 17; 41. 12; 77. 7; 101. 17; 102. 33; iv. 109. 10; vi. 2. 5; and see Steup, Thuk. Stud. ii. p. 55 f. G. 1186, 1187; H. 769.—16.

oi(/tines: refers to u(mw=n. o(/stis, esp. used in reproach or praise. Cf. Soph. Aj.
1055; El. 587; Ant. 696.—
prou/qesqe: displayed. Cf. viii. 85. 20.—17.
a(\ xrhstoi\ e)ge/nesqe: cf. c. 67. 26 w(=n pro/qumoi gegenh/meqa.— w(s fate/: cf. c. 54. § 3, 4.

ou) prosh/konta nu=n e)pedei/cate: you have now shown not to belong to you. prosh/kwn, as in c. 67. 7; ii. 61. 20; 89. 7; iv. 92. 35. In support of e)pedei/cate, meaning show, prove, St. cites Dem. xxi. 7 e)a\n e)pidei/cw *meidi/an toutoni\ . . . u(briko/ta, Plato Rep. 391 e e)p edei/camen ga/r pou, o(/ti e)k qew=n kaka\ gi/gnesqai a)du/naton. But Steup maintains that, acc. to Thuc.'s usage, this idea would have to be expressed either by the simple verb e)dei/cate (cf. iv. 73. 8; v. 9. 40; 72. 10, and with o(/ti, i. 143. 32; iv. 92. 39; vi. 77. 8; vii. 63. 21), or by a)p edei/cate, as Cl. wrote (cf. i. 6. 23; 25. 8; ii. 62. 3). He renders e)pedei/cate, showed afterwards, comparing e)pikata/getai, c. 49. 18; e)pignw=nai, c. 57. 6; e)pimaqw/n, i. 138. 13. In Thuc. e)pideiknu/nai occurs (outside of the documentary v. 77. 19, where it means lay before, communicate) certainly only twice, vi. 46. 13; 47. 8, meaning exhibit, display. In i. 26. 13 it is a doubtful reading, meaning point to.—19.
e)s to\ a)lhqe/s: this adv. phrase seems to occur only here, though Bl. compares Isa. xlii. 3 ei)s a)lhqh=. Cf. e)s to\ fanero/n, i. 6. 17; 23. 26; e)s to\ a)kribe/s, vi. 82. 15.—
a)/dikon o(do\n i)o/ntwn: for the acc., see G. 1057. Cf. Soph. O. R. 67 polla\s d' o(dou\s e)lqo/nta fronti/dos pla/nois.—22. ta\ me\n ou)=n . . . a)pofai/nomen: cf. c. 62. 25.
We undertook to surprise your city at the call of prominent men among you, who wished to bring you back into the Boeotian alliance, where you naturally and rightly belonged.
a(\ de\ teleutai=a/ fate kte(.: cf. c. 56. § 1, 2.—2.

i(eromhni/a|: the sing. as in c. 56. 4, adopted by Cl., St., Bm., following Meineke (Hermes iii. p. 364) and v. H. (Stud. Thuc. p. 46), for the pl. of all the Mss. The pl. is due to a slip of the pen after spondai=s, as in v. 27. 2 ai( cummaxi/ai after ai( spondai/. Arn. thinks the pl. indicates that the festival lasted several days.

ei) me\n . . . e)maxo/meqa . . . e)dh|ou=men: represented as a possible case,
as opp. to ei) de\ . . . e)pekale/santo, which introduces the real case in hypothetical form. au)toi/, nostra sponte. Cf. iv. 60. 11.—6.
a)dikou=men: for the pf. force, see GMT. 27; Kr. Spr. 53, 1, 3.—
ei) de\ a)/ndres kte(.: cf. ii. 2. § 2.—7.
th=s e)/cw cummaxi/as: of the alliance with a foreign, nonBoeotian state.—8.

e)s ta\ koina\ . . . katasth=sai: cf. c. 34. 14; 59. 23; also iv. 74. 16 e)s o)ligarxi/an ta\ ma/lista kate/sthsan th\n po/lin, v. 81. 6 ta\ e)n *sikuw=ni e)s o)li/gous ma=llon kate/sthsan.—ta\ koina\ . . . pa/tria: ta\ pa/tria, as in c. 61. 14; 66.3; ii. 2. 27. koina/ strengthens tw=n pa/ntwn *boiwtw=n. Cf. iv. 78. 19 a)/neu tou= pa/ntwn koinou=.— 10. oi( ga\r a)/gontes kte(.: parody on c. 55. § 4.
w(s h(mei=s kri/nomen: cf. w(s e)gw\ kri/nw, iv. 60. 3.—12.

plei/w paraballo/menoi: because they were the richest and most prominent. As to paraba/llesqai, see on c. 14. 5, and cf. Xen. Cyrop. ii. 3. 11 ou)k i)/sa paraba/llesqai.—to\ e(autw=n tei=xos . . . th\n au(tw=n po/lin: the repetition emphasizes the idea that the city belonged to the oligarchs as much as to the demos.—13.

fili/ous, ou) polemi/ous: so Steup (see Qu. Thuc. p. 31) emends the reading of the Mss. fili/ws, ou) polemi/ws (“with friendly, not with hostile intent”). His grounds are, viz.: not only does komi/santes require an obj., but it was necessary to be said here of those admitted into the city, that they were not enemies of Plataea; for it was an important point in this attempt to justify the action of the boeotizing Plataeans that at the time under consideration a state of hostilities did not exist between Thebes and Plataea. Besides, the terms used cannot be applied to the relations of citizens to their own state. Since the reference is to persons, fi/lous, it is true, not fili/ous, was to be expected, acc. to Thuc.'s usage; but in c. 58. 22 e)n gh=| te fili/a| kai\ par) a)ndra/si toiou/tois, it is generally agreed that toiou/tois represents fili/ois. Hude (Comm. Crit. p. 108), who adopts Steup's conjecture, cites also Plato Symp. 221 b; Dem. xxiii. 56.—14.

komi/santes: as in viii. 57.
3.—
tou\s u(mw=n xei/rous: part. gen. in attrib. position. G. 965; H. 730 d. See on c. 22. 26.—15.
mhke/ti ma=llon: sc. xei/rous. But since the adj. is not repeated, it is the positive that is really had in mind.—16.

swfronistai/: regulators, or moderators, as in vi. 87. 11; viii. 48. 43. Cf. Plato Rep. 471 a eu)menw=s swfroniou=sin, ou)k e)pi\ doulei/a| kola/zontes, ou)d) e)p) o)le/qrw|, swfronistai\ o)/ntes, ou) pole/mioi. The intrinsic falseness of the party attitude here maintained, Thucydides doubtless intended to intimate by the unusual forms of expression.—

tw=n swma/twn th
 po/lin ou)k a)llotriou=ntes: chiastically arranged with reference to the preceding. ta\ sw/mata, their persons, is here contrasted with h( gnw/mh, as in i. 70. 19. a)llotriou=ntes, depriving, chosen prob. on acc. of the antithesis to oi)keiou=ntes (cf. c. 13. 22; i. 36. 10; 70. 19; 78. 2), the natural expression being th
 po/lin tw=n swma/twn a)posterou=ntes. Kühn. 421, 3. Abresch compares Sirach xi. 35 a)pallotriw/sei se tw=n i)di/wn sou. —17. e)s th
 cugge/neian oi)keiou=ntes: “bringing them back into a natural union with their own kindred.” Cf. l. 8 above, e)s ta\ koina\ . . . pa/tria katasth=sai.—18. kaqista/ntes: sc. u(ma=s. But Steup objects that, as the Plataeans were already a(/pasin e)/nspondoi, e)xqrou\s ou)deni/ must refer to the Thebans admitted into the city, and would understand e)s th
 po/lin with kaqista/ntes (cf. iv. 78. 35; 103. 16).
You, however, when you discovered how small was the number of the Thebans, treacherously and cruelly took vengeance on them; so that even for this alone you deserve punishment.
tekmh/rion de\ . . . ga/r: as in ii. 15. 19; 39. 10; without ga/r in ii. 50. 7. See on i. 8. 3.—

w(s ou) polemi/ws e)pra/ssomen: braecketed by St. and v. H., following Meineke (Hermes iii. p. 365), on the ground that tekmh/rion refers to what immediately precedes, e)xqrou\s ou)deni\ kaqista/ntes, a(/pasi d' o(moi/ws e)nspo/ndous. But there the reference is to the attitude of the traitorous party in Plataea, here to the Thebans again, esp. to the idea expressed in c. 65. 4 ei) me\n . . . pole/mioi. Besides, the sent. ou)/te ga\r h)dikh/samen kte(. would not answer for a proof of the concluding words of c. 65 e)xqrou\s . . . e)nspo/ndous.—ou)/te ga\r kte(.: cf. ii. 2. 3.

ta\ pa/ntwn *boiwtw=n pa/tria: Hude (Comm. Crit. p.
108) would insert (with Laur.) tw=n before pa/ntwn, as in c. 65. 8; ii. 2. 27; Cf. also oi( pa/ntes *(/ellhnes, c. 63. 13; iv. 78. 11; tou\s a(/pantas *mutilhnai/ous, c. 36. 6; tou\s a(/pantas *megare/as, iv. 68. 7. But against these, cf. bohqei/as genome/nhs pa/ntwn *boiwtw=n, iv. 89. 11; cumpa/ntwn *sikeliwtw=n, vi. 18. 28; *)akarna=si pa=sin, c. 94. 6.—
kata\ . . . politeu/ein: see on c. 62. 8.
xwrh/santes: sc. pro\s h)ma=s. Cf. ii. 3. 5 pro\s cu/mbasin e)xw/rhsan.—5.
katanoh/santes kte(.: cf. ii. 3. § 2.— 6.
ei) a)/ra kai\ e)dokou=men . . . pra=cai: i.e. ei) e)kri/nete h(ma=s pra=cai, to which corresponds the apod. ou)k a)ntape/dote h(mi=n kte(. For ei) a)/ra, if possibly, see on c. 56. 15.—7.
a)nepieike/steron: found elsewhere only in late writers, like Dio C. and Arrian.—
ou) meta\ tou= plh/qous: without the consent of the majority. ou) meta/ (cf. mh\ meta\ no/mwn, c. 62. 16)=a)/neu, as in i. 98. 5; 128. 11, etc. Kühn. 515, N. 2.— 8.

mh/te newteri/sai . . . pei/qein: explanatory of o(moi=a. The pres. inf., pei/qein, is necessary to indicate the attempt to persuade—not pei=sai (one Ms.) or pei/sein (all the rest). newteri/sai, resort to violence, as in c. 79. 3; ii. 3. 7.—9.
w(/ste: see on c. 31. 10. —

e)piqe/menoi de\ kte(.: antithesis to ta\ me
 o(moi=a ou)k a)ntape/dote h(mi=n. Instead of simply stating the facts, the speakers express also their judgment of them, and an involved const. results. A more natural const. would have been e)pe/qesqe de\ para\ th
 cu/mbasin e)n w)=| ou)\s me
 kte(. (St.), or e)piqe/menoi de\ para\ th
 cu/mbasin tou\s me
 h(mw=n e)n xersi
 a)pektei/nate, tou\s de\ x<*>i=ras proisxome/nous . . . diefqei/rate (Steup). Kr. thinks the rel. sents. are respectively the objs. of a)lgou=men and ei)/rgasqe, comparing for a)lgei=n the const. a)lgei=n pa/qos. But it seems better, with Bm., to supply peri\ tou/twn from ou(\s me/n, or, with Cl., to consider that both the rel. clauses hold rather the relation of loosely connected protases, “as to those whom, etc.”— 10.

e)n xersi/n: in battle, i.e. with arms in their hands. The phrase is here applied to the combatants, as in iv. 96. 14; 113. 6; v. 72. 10; vii. 5. 6; to the combat (hand to hand), iv. 43. 8, 14; vi. 70. 1.—12.

xei=ras proisxome/nous kte(.: the three grounds on which the Thebans base the guilt of the Plataeans are expressed by three
partics., the first agreeing with the obj., the two last with the subj., and these are connected by kai/ (Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2) and te (introducing third member). The Thebans ignore, of course, the contrary assertions of the Plataeans, as stated by Thuc. ii. 5. § 6. See on c. 56. 4. For the expression xei=ras proisxome/nous, cf. c. 58. 12; 67. 22; and for the facts, cf. ii. 4. § 7.—

zwgrh/santes u(posxo/menoi/ te: zwgrh/santes, as opp. to a)pektei/nate, implies the intention not to kill the captives, while u(posxo/menoi adds the express promise, which the Plataeans, it is true, deny.—13.

u(/steron: Hude (l.c.) would put after mh\ ktenei=n and const. with diefqei/rate, comparing u(/steron qa/naton in But the reference to the u(/steros qa/natos does not exclude, of course, the possibility of the promise having been made u(/steron. —parano/mws: i.e. para\ to\n tw=n *(ellh/nwn no/mon. Cf. c. 67. 25.

ka)ntau=qa . . . pra/cantes kte(.: ka)ntau=qa is Naber's conjecture (Mnem. N. S. xiv. p. 137) for kai\ tau=ta of the Mss. If the common reading be retained, Cl. is prob. right in explaining tau=ta as obj. of pra/cantes and trei=s a)diki/as as pred., and committing these three wrongs in a short space. But parallel expressions seem to be wanting. Besides, tau=ta can refer only to the acts of the Plataeans, whereas, in the foregoing, judgments also are expressed (cf. l. 14 pw=s ou) deina\ ei)/rgasqe;). Cf. c. 45. 14, where a similar slip of the copyist occurs. —15.

th/n te luqei=san o(mologi/an: cf. l. 9 e)piqe/menoi para\ th\n cu/mbasin, and for the const. of the partic. here and in l. 17, cf. c. 53. 14 o( mh\ r(hqei\s lo/gos. —17. h(mi=n: for which Badham pro posed h)= mh/n, is construed with the verbal subst. u(po/sxesin, not with yeusqei=san. Kr. Spr. 48, 12, 4; Kühn. 424. See on i. 63. 9; 122. 3.—

mh\ ktei/nein: with u(po/sxesin, as c. 58. 5 with dwrea/n. St. writes, with v. H. Stud. Thuc. p. 46, mh\ ktenei=n, on the ground that everywhere else in Thuc. u(pisxnei=sqai is followed by the fut. inf., though he does not consider it absolutely necessary here. See Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 11.—
h)\n ta\ . . . a)dikw=men: cf. ii. 5. 21 ta\ e)/cw e)/legon au)toi=s mh\ a)dikei=n.
ou)/k: abs., as in v. 101. 1, i.e. ou) tou=to genh/setai (u(ma=s mh\ dou=nai di/khn). Kr. Spr. 67, 13, 1.—

h)/n ge ou(=toi ta\ o)rqa\ gignw/skwsi: answering to c. 56. 8 tou= o)rqou= fanei=sqe ou)k a)lhqei=s kritai\ o)/ntes, c. 57. 2 ei) . . . gnw/sesqe mh\ ta\ ei(ko/ta, and c. 58. 21 mh\ o)rqw=s
gno/ntes.—20. au)tw=n: emphatic, of the matters under discussion, as often. See on i. 1. 10.
You judges must, therefore, be influenced neither by inopportune pity nor by misrepresentations, and inflict just punishment.
w)= *lakedaimo/nioi: the speakers address themselves again to the judges. Cf. —

tau=ta e)pech/lqomen: we have gone over these things. Of statement here, as of inquiry in i. 22. 11. Cf. Aesch. Prom. 870 makrou= lo/gou dei= tau=t) e)pecelqei=n torw=s.—3. h(mei=s de\ e)/ti o(siw/teron tetimwrhme/noi: sc. ei)dw=men, as grammatical consistency demands; but logically rather a pass. or intr. verb, like fainw/meqa, seems to be in the mind of the speaker. Kr. conjectures either h(ma=s . . . tetimwrhme/nous, or h(mei=s de\ dei/cwmen. Rauchenstein proposes (Philol. XXXV. p. 588 f.), u(mei=s me
 fanh=te (l. 2). Steup also thinks the fault lies in l. 2, and conjectures that the original was u(mei=s me
 e)/ndhloi h(=te, which was first corrupted into u(mei=s me
 e)ndh=te, then changed to u(mei=s me
 ei)dh=te. The pf. tetimwrhme/noi expresses confident anticipation of the fulfillment of the wish.—4.

kai\ mh\ kte(.: it seems best, with Pp. and Kr., to begin here a new sent., for kai\ mh\ e)piklasqh=te can be appropriately taken neither as co-ord. with e)pech/lqomen nor as a third clause dependent on i(/na. After summing up the result of their previous arguments, the Theban speakers take up here the Plataean appeal for pity, continuing in mhde\ o)lofurmw=| kte(. (l. 8).—
mh\ . . . e)piklasqh=te: answering to c. 59. 5.—
ei)/ tis a)/ra kai\ e)ge/neto: if indeed there was any. See on c. 56. 15.—6.
e)pikou/rous: pred. adj., as bohqoi/, c. 69. 2; timwroi/, iv. 2. 12.—7.
diplasi/as zhmi/as: the same idea also i. 86. 5.—
ou)k e)k proshko/ntwn: i.e. e)c ou) proshko/ntwn =ou) proshko/ntws. Cf. c. 43. 5; i. 34. 10; 35. 7; ii. 44. 16. For the order, see on c. 57. 3.
o)lofurmw=|: sc. e)kei/nwn.—oi)/ktw|: sc. u(mw=n au)tw=n.—w)felei/sqwn: on the form, see App. on c. 39. 31.—
rwn te . . . e)pibow/menoi kte(.: the participial clause co-ord. as third member with o)lofurmw=| kai\ oi)/ktw|.—9. ta/fous . . . e)pibow/menoi: cf. c. 59. § 2.— 10.
e)rhmi/an: isolation, as in i. 71. 22. Cf. c. 57. § 4.—
pollw=| deino/tera paqou=san: cf. c. 59. 6 w(=n peiso/meqa deino/thta, 59. 17 nu=n ta\ deino/tata kinduneu/omen paqei=n.
th\n u(po\ tou/twn . . . diefqarme/nhn: cf. ii. 5. § 7. For the order, see on c. 54. 19. h(liki/a concrete (iuventus), like neo/ths, ii. 8. 3.—12.
w(=n: referring to the collective noun, h(liki/an. Cf. stratia\n . . . ou(/s, vii. 1. 9; strateu/mati . . . oi)=s, vii. 75. 39. G. 1021 b; H. 629. —
pate/res oi( me\n . . . oi( de/: part. apposition. See on c. 13. 17.—

pro\s u(ma=s . . . a)/gontes: cf. viii. 24. 33 e)nexei/rhsa/n tines pro\s *)aqhnai/ous a)gagei=n th\n po/lin.—13. e)n *korwnei/a|: as in c. 62. 20, a reminder flattering to the Lacedaemonians, which would increase the effect intended to be produced by pro\s u(ma=s th\n *boiwti/an a)/gontes.— oi( de\ presbu=tai leleimme/noi kat) oi)ki/as e)rh=moi: while others left behind as desolate (sonless) old men in their homes. kat) oi)ki/as is St.'s conjecture for kai\ oi)ki/ai of the Mss. Cl.'s explanation of the vulg., “left behind in old age and their houses desolate,” would require kai\ ai( oi)ki/ai, as Kr. proposed. Besides, the bringing together here of aged fathers and desolate houses, where after w(=n pate/res only the fathers should be spoken of, is quite unnatural. Bm.'s explanation, that oi)ki/ai e)rh=moi is a bold expression, pred., just as presbu=tai, to pate/res, “left behind as old men and as desolate households,” lacks the support of sure parallels for such an expression.—14.
u(mw=n: obj. gen. to i(ketei/an. Cf. c. 59. 13, 29.
a)prepe/s ti: cf. c. 57. 6.—
oi( de\ dikai/ws: sc. pa/sxonte/s ti.—17. ta\ e)nanti/a: adv., as in vi. 79. 15, and in the sing. iv. 86. 6; vii. 87. 5.—

e)pi/xartoi ei)=nai: sc. a)/cioi/ ei)si, from a)ciw/teroi. e)pi/xartoi, objects of rejoicing, i.e. those over whose sufferings men may rejoice. Cf. Aesch. Prom. 164 e)xqroi=s e)pi/xarta pe/ponqa, Dem. xlv. 85 mh\ u(peri/dhte/ me kai\ ta\s qugate/ras di) e)/ndeian toi=s e)mantou= dou/lois tou/tou ko/lacin e)pi/xarton geno/menon, Solomon, Prov. xi. 3 e)pi/xartos a)sebw=n a)pw/leia. Cf. also Aesch. Agam. 722; Soph. Trach. 1262. e)pixai/rein also generally
has this sense. Cf. Soph. Aj. 961; Ar. Pax, 1015; Dem. ix. 61; xxi. 134. Cf. also e)pi/xaris, Aesch. Sept. 910, and e)pi/xarma, Eur. H. F. 459; Phoen. 1555; Theocr. ii. 20.
th\n nu=n e)rhmi/an: see on — 19.
pareno/mhsan: on the reading, see App.—20.
ou)k a)ntapodo/ntes . . . timwri/an: on the reading, see App.—22.
ou)xi/: see on c. 53. 19. —23.
w(/sper fasi/n: cf. c. 58. § 3.—
a)po\ cumba/sews . . . parado/ntes: cf. c. 52. § 1, 2; 53. § 1.

a)mu/nate kte(.: a slight anacoluthon. The first kai/ anticipates a second obj. corresponding to tw=| . . . no/mw|, but the introduction of the new verb a)ntapo/dote changes the const. For similar irregularity of const., cf. c. 71. 2; iv. 105. 2; v. 88. 3, and see on ii. 46. 1. For similar irregularity after te, see on c. 94. 17; i. 16. 2.—

tw=| . . . no/mw| . . . parabaqe/nti: cf. c. 66. § 2, 3; 67. § 5. For the expression a)mu/nate tw=| no/mw|, cf. Eur. Or. 523 a)munw=, o(/sonper dunato/s ei)mi, tw=| no/mw|. bohqei=n is so used Plato Apol. 32 e; Aeschin. i. 33.—26.
w(=n pro/qumoi gegenh/meqa: referring to the service rendered at Coronea. Both pro/qumoi and periwsqw=men in parody of c. 57. 17, 18.— 27.
mh\ . . . periwsqw=men e)n u(mi=n: let us not be repulsed by you on account of their words. See on c. 57. 17. e)n u(mi=n seems to be used with reference to c. 57. 14.—28.

poih/sate . . . para/deigma . . . proqh/sontes: show that you will institute (set forth) contests not of words, but of deeds. Cf. Gorg. Palam. 34 u(ma=s de\ xrh\ mh\ toi=s lo/gois ma=llon h)\ toi=s e)/rgois prose/xein to
 nou=n. For the const., see on c. 40. 37. The art. is not pleonastic, the sense being, “the contests that you will set forth, you will set forth not of words, but of deeds.” (Bl.) a)gw=nas proqh/sontes as ste/fanon protiqei=sa, ii. 46. 4. The reference is to the oratorical gymnastics to which Cleon alludes in c. 37. § 4; 38. § 3, 4. Cf. Isoc. iv. 45 par) h(mi=n e)/stin a)gw=nas i)dei=n mh\ mo/non ta/xous kai\ r(w/mhs, a)lla\
kai\ lo/gwn kai\ gnw/mhs, and Dem. xviii. 226 r(hto/rwn a)gw=na.—29. w(=n: with the appos. parties. a)gaqw=n me
 o)/ntwn and a(martanome/nwn de/, dependent on h( a)paggeli/a and prokalu/mmata. Cf. ii. 65. 28 a(\ katorqou/mena me
 . . . w)feli/a h)=n, sfale/nta de\ . . . bla/bh kaqi/stato. —30. braxei=a: in pred. position, “though it be short.” See on c. 63. 16. The speakers once more (cf. c. 61. 2) hint reprovingly at the length of the speech of the Plataeans.—

a(martanome/nwn: pass., as in ii. 65. 45; vii. 18. 25; the act. a(marta/nein ti in i. 38. 13; 39. 7; iv. 114. 26. G. 1240; H. 819 c; Kühn. 378, 10. Cf. Plato Prot. 357 e h( e)camartanome/nh pra=cis, Xen. Anab. v. 8. 20 mikra\ a(marthqe/nta. For the pres. approaching the force of the pf., cf. c. 54. 9, and see GMT. 27; Kr. Spr. 53, 1, 3.—31.

lo/goi e)/pesi kosmhqe/ntes: speeches adorned with fine sentiments. Cf. ii. 41. 14, and Plato Apol. 17 b kekalliephme/nous lo/gous . . . r(h/masi/ te kai\ o)no/masin.— prokalu/mmata: cf. Luc. Pseudol. 31 proka/lumma th=s bdeluri/as, de Merc. Cond. 5 proka/lumma th=s au)tomoli/as, Dion. H. Ant. vi. 77 proka/lumma th=s a)pa/ths. With the sentiment of the passage, cf. Sall. Jug. 85. 31 ipsa se virtus satis ostendit: illis artificio opus est, ut turpia facta oratione tegant.

a)ll) h)\n oi( h(gemo/nes . . . zhth/sei: “but if leaders, as now you, sum up in a short question and make decisions that apply to all, men will strive less with fair words to justify wrong deeds.” The verb poih/shsqe is construed with u(mei=s instead of h(gemo/nes. For similar const., cf. i. 82. 9; Xen. Cyrop. iv. 1. 3; Dem. iv. 2.—32.
kefalaiw/santes: the reference is to the braxu\ e)perw/thma of c. 52. § 4.—

pro\s tou\s cu/mpantas: Cl., who construes these words with diagnw/mas poih/shsqe, explains, “as a warning example to all.” Jow. thinks the reference is to the question being asked of all the captives without distinction. Steup thinks best to connect pro\s tou\s cu/mpantas with kefalaiw/santes, comparing i. 36. 14 braxuta/tw| kefalai/w| toi=s te cu/mpasi kai\ kaq) e(/kaston, which he renders, “with a very short summary for all as well as for each.” In that case the meaning would be, “having settled the main point (here the braxu\ e)perw/thma) with reference to the interests of all the members of the alliance.” H. Weil (Revue de Philol. N. S. ii. p. 91 f.) would emend the passage so as to read, kefalaiw/santes pro\s to\ cu/mpan ta\s diagnw/mas poih/shsqe, and this is adopted by v. H.—33.

diagnw/mas poih/shsqe: cf. c. 36. 4 peri\ tw=n a)ndrw=n gnw/mas e)poi-
ou=nto. For diagnw/mas, see on c. 42. l. —
e)p) a)di/kois e)/rgois: e)pi/ with dat. of conditioning circumstances, similar to e)pi\ faneroi=s, i. 69. 9; e)pi\ toi=s deinoi=s, i. 70. 10.

In accordance with the decision of the Lacedaemonian judges, the Plataean and Athenian captives are put to death, the women enslaved, the city razed to the ground, and the lands leased to the Thebans.
tosau=ta de/: see on c. 49. 1.— 2.

sfi/sin o)rqw=s e(/cein: the emphatic position of sfi/sin indicates the effort of the Lacedaemonians to put their cruel decision in as fair a light as possible. “The question whether they have received any good at the hands of the Plataeans in the war would be in order for them.”—4.

dio/ti . . . kat) e)kei=na, w(s ou)k e)de/canto . . . peponqe/nai: these words should express the ground of the confidence of the Lacedaemonians in the justice of their question, but the traditional reading cannot be construed. The simplest remedy is, with Heilmann, Cl., St., Bm., and others, to bracket a(/ in The sense then is: “Because they not only at all other times had, forsooth, urged the Plataeans to neutrality according to the ancient agreements with Pausanias after the Persian wars, but especially when afterwards before the circumvallation they had proposed to them to be neutral according to those agreements, since the Plataeans did not accept (the proposals), considering that by their own just demand they themselves were now e)/kspondoi (i.e. released from treaty obligations) and had been wronged by the Plataeans.” With the view here taken of the relation of h(gou/menoi to the preceding (i.e. that w(s ou)k e)de/canto, h(gou/menoi . . . kakw=s peponqe/nai is an epexegetical explanation of nomi/zontes . . . dio/ti kte(.), any emendation of w(s ou)k e)de/canto is perhaps unnecessary. Cl. and Bm. follow St. (Jahrbb. 1868, p. 111) in inserting d) (w(s d' ou)k e)de/canto). Küppers (Curae Crit. p. 12 sq.) proposes kai\ w(/s. The simplest change would be ou)d) w(/s (v. 55. 11; 115. 6). For possible interpretations of the text as it stands, see Jow.— 4.

to/n te a)/llon xro/non h)ci/oun kte(.: cf. the words of Archidamus ii. 72. 9 a(/per kai\ to\ pro/teron h)/dh proukalesa/meqa, h(suxi/an a)/gete kte(.—h)ci/oun au)tou\s h(suxa/zein: belongs to both to/n te a)/llon xro/non and kai\ o(/te u(/steron kte(.—dh=qen: ironical, indicating Thuc.'s doubt of the sincerity of the admonitions here mentioned.—5.
*pausani/ou: cf. ii. 71. § 2 ff.; 72. § 1. —

meta\ to\n *mh=don: i.e. meta\ ta\ *mhdika/.—6. o(/te u(/steron kte(.: refers to the demand of Archidamus (c. 64. 13;
ii. 72. 10).—
proei/xonto: as i. 140. 24. Schol. proeba/llonto.—7. koinou/s: neutral, as in c. 53. 8.—

kat) e)kei=na: i.e. kata\ ta\s palaia\s sponda/s.—8. boulh/sei: as the word occurs nowhere else in Thuc. in the sense of demand, it may be better to render it by intention (voluntas), as Bl. does. Cf. v. 105. 4. Arn. considers the text (th=| e(autw=n dikai/a| boulh/sei) to be either corrupt or else a scholium. St. proposes th=| e(autw=n dikaiw/sei, of which he thinks th=| dikai/a| boulh/sei was prob. a gloss. Cf. i. 141. 6; iv. 86. 21; v. 17. 11. Rauchenstein (Philol. XXXV. p. 589) suggests th=| au)tw=n dikaiw/sei.—e)/kspondoi h)/dh: cf. ii. 74. § 3. These words contain the main point of the whole sentence. The result of Plataean obstinacy is at the same time the excuse for the Lacedaemonians not sparing them. —9.

e(/na e(/kaston paragago/ntes kai/: inserted between to\ au)to/ and e)rwtw=ntes. For similar breaks in the const., Cl. compares ii. 4. 20; 11. 9, and Bm. vi. 68. 17. But Steup, who objects that none of these is exactly parallel, and the first not above suspicion, thinks that kai/ is possibly to be bracketed, with Reiske and v. H.— 10.
paragago/ntes: bringing forward. Cf. v. 45. 19; 46. 34; viii. 53. 13; Dem. xviii. 170; xxvi. 17.—12.
o(po/te mh\ fai=en: when they answered ‘no.’ mh\ fa/nai, as in viii. 53. 19. For the opt. of general cond., see GMT. 532; H. 914, B 2.—
kai\ e)cai/reton e)poih/santo ou)de/na: cf. ii. 24. 5, 10.

*plataiw=n me\n au)tw=n ou)k e)la/ssous diakosi/wn, *)aqhnai/wn de\ pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosin: originally 400 Plataeans and 80 Athenians were besieged (ii. 78. § 3). Of these 480 defenders, 212 escaped in the sortie (c. 24. 11), and one was captured (c. 24. 13). Since now, acc. to the present passage, not less than 225 were killed after the surrender, about 42 must have perished during the siege, the most of these prob. before the sortie, for in c. 20. § 2 the Plataeans and Athenians who attempt to break out are represented as e)s a)/ndras diakosi/ous kai\ ei)/kosi ma/lista, and also as the half of the beleaguered men still surviving.— 15.

cunepoliorkou=nto: impf., from the beginning of the siege till this time. Kr. Spr. 53, 2, 8. Hence Meineke's conjecture, cunepepolio/rkhnto,
is unnecessary.—

gunai=kas: i.e. those remaining of the 110, who had stayed as sitopoioi/ in the city (ii. 78. 13). Müller-Strübing (Aristoph. etc. p. 44 f. and Thuk. Forsch. p. 138 ff.) objected to the words gunai=kas de\ h)ndrapo/disan, because the women in question were already slaves and not now first made so. But as v. Velsen replied (Philol. Anz. vii. p. 372), h)ndrapo/disan is only the antithesis to a)pe/kteinon (cf. c. 28. 9, 10; 36. 6, 8), and it makes no difference whether the captured women were slaves before or not. Indeed, a)ndrapodi/zein may be rendered here, with St. (Gött. Gel. Anz. 1882, p. 99), “to sell as prisoners of war.” That the women were salves before, a view held already by Grote, is now generally accepted, and seems to be supported by ii. 78. § 4, where, after giving the number of the defendants and of the sitopoioi/, Thuc. says, tosou=toi h)=san oi( cu/mpantes o(/te e)s th\n poliorki/an kaqi/stanto, kai\ a)/llos ou)dei\s h)=n e)n tw=| tei/xei ou)/te dou=los oi)/te e)leu/qeros. But even if the women were only salves, a remark about their fate was still by no means superfluous, as Müller-Strübing asserts.—16.
tina: “about,” with the definite period of time e)niauto/n, as elsewhere with numbers. Kr. Spr. 51, 16, 4. Cf. c. 111. 7; vii. 34. 19; 87. 15; viii. 21. 4.—[

*qhbai=oi]: St., Bm., and v. H. rightly follow Cl. in bracketing this word, for it seems clear from the context that the general subj. down to a)pemi/sqwsan inclusive is the Lacedaemonian leaders. See App.—17.
kata\ sta/sin: in consequence of a sedition. See on c. 2. 10.—
e)kpeptwko/si: cf. iv. 66. § 1 ff.; 74. § 2.—
ta\ sfe/tera fronou=ntes: cf. v. 84. 3; vi. 51. 7; viii. 31. 7.— 19.

e)s e)/dafos: also iv. 109. 2; here strengthened by e)k tw=n qemeli/wn, funditus. So Cl. explains, with most editors. Cf. Procop. de Aedif. p. 12 d kaqei=le me\n au)to\ e)s to\ e)/dafos e)k tw=n qemeli/wn, Jos. Ant. 174, 29 e)c au)tw=n a)naspa=n qemeli/wn kai\ mhde\ e)/dafos katalipei=n. But Steup follows St. in connecting e)k tw=n qemeli/wn with w)|kodo/mhsan, built out of the foundationstones (of the ruined houses). Cf. i. 93. 3.—20.

pro\s tw=| *(hrai/w|: cf. Hdt. ix. 52. 9; Plut. Aristid. 18; Paus. ix. 2. 7. The temples must have been left standing, and served doubtless as a starting-point for the rebuilding after the peace of Antalcidas (387 B.C.).—

katagw/gion: i.e. a pandokei=on for the accommodation of those who came to worship at the temple. This building, as well as the new\s e(kato/mpodos mentioned below, was evidently meant to propitiate the patron goddess of the land. Concerning such inns connected with temples, see
Becker, Charicles (ed. Göll), ii. p. 5 f. —21.

pantaxh=|: on every side, doubtless more prop. connected with diakosi/wn podw=n, 200 feet square, than with ku/klw|, though in vii. 79. 19 it is joined with ku/klw|.—ka/twqen kai\ a)/nwqen: i.e. ka/tw kai\ a)/nw. The designation has reference to the starting-point. See on ii. 102. 14.—22.
o)rofai=s kai\ qurw/masi: including all the woodwork of the buildings.—23.

toi=s a)/llois: connect with kataskeua/santes.—e)/pipla, xalko\s kai\ si/dhros: i.e. everything of metal found within the ruined city (e)n tw=| tei/xei, cf. ii. 78. 15) that could be applied to any use.—24.

kli/nas: couches for the katagw/gion.—27. e)ne/monto *qhbai=oi: the Thebans leased (e)misqw/santo) and used the land. ne/mesqai refers to occupation of the soil in any way. Cf. i. 2. 6. See App. on *qhbai=oi,

sxedo\n de/ ti kai\ to\ cu/mpan: pretty nearly or altogether. sxedo/n ti, as in v. 66. 16; vii. 33. 6. Kr. Spr. 51, 16, 5. For to\ cu/mpan, see Kr. Spr. 46, 3, 3. The advantage conceded to the Thebans in the usufruct of the Plataean territory induces the general remark, that in their whole conduct toward the Plataeans the Lacedaemonians were determined by regard for the Thebans, *qhbai/wn e(/neka, on which the stress of the sent. rests. —28.
a)potetramme/noi e)ge/nonto: this periphrasis is unusual in good prose. Kr. Di. 56, 1, 5.—29.
a)/rti to/te kaqista/menon: see on c. 3. 2.—30.
w)feli/mous ei)=nai: cf. c. 62. § 5.

e)/tei tri/tw| kai\ e)nenhkostw=|: i.e. 520 or 519 B.C. Cf. c. 55. 3. Grote (chap. 31) charges Thuc. with error, on the strength of Hdt. vi. 108, and thinks that the alliance of Plataea with Athens could not have been formed before the expulsion of Hippias in 510 B.C. But see, per contra, Curtius, Gr. Gesch. i.^{6} p. 678, N. 165. It does not seem necessary to assume here, with Gutschmid and others (see Busolt, Die Laked. i. p. 307, N. 49, and Gr. Gesch. i. p. 609, N. 3), even a slip of the copyist for
tri/tw| kai\ o)gdohkostw=|.—32. e)peidh\ *)aqhnai/wn cu/mmaxoi e)ge/nonto: cf. ii. 73. 10 a)f) ou)= cu/mmaxoi e)geno/meqa.— e)peidh/: after. Cf. c. 70. 4; i. 6. 9, 20; viii. 68. 27.

p.hi: Alcidas and Brasidas join in an expedition against Corcyra.

div2.p: ai( de\ tessara/konta nh=es kte(.: the account of the fleet of Alcidas, interrupted at c. 33. § 1, is here resumed. For the number of ships, see on c. 26. 2.—
*lesbi/ois bohqoi\ e)lqou=sai: const. as in i. 53. 14. See on c. 67. 6.—2.
to/te feu/gousai dia\ tou= pela/gous: i.e. in a southwesterly direction from Ephesus. Cf. c. 33. 1. to/te is freq. used of a time assumed to be well known. See on i. 101. 8.— 3.
e)k tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: e)k for u(po/, as i. 20. 10; ii. 49. 1; vi. 36. 9; Plato Theaet. 171 b; Xen. Anab. ii. 6. 1. H. 798 c; Kühn. 430, 2, 3 c.—
e)pidiwxqei=sai: sc. as far as Patmos, c. 33. 13.—

pro\s th=| *krh/th| . . . kathne/xqhsan: spora/des is correl. to the preceding parties. = spora/des geno/menai, i.e. diasparei=sai. Kühn. 491. Cf. c. 82. 6 ou)k a)\n e)xo/ntwn pro/fasin ou)d) e(toi/mwn parakalei=n au)tou/s, v. 64. 17 ou) r(a/|dion h)=n mh\ a(qro/ois kai\ a)llh/lous perimei/nasi dielqei=n th\n polemi/an. So most of the editors explain, but Cl. and St. take spora/des with katene/xqhsan, and consider kai/ after xeimasqei=sai an interpolation.—5.
katalamba/nousi: without partic. (see on i. 59. 3), as in ii. 18. 17; 94. 19.—5.
e)n th=| *kullh/nh|: the naval station of the Eleans (to\ *)hlei/wn e)pinei=on, i. 30. 9; ii. 84. 33). It was prob. designated as the place of rendezvous.—7.
*brasi/dan: first mentioned ii. 25. 7, and referred to everywhere by Thuc. with marked respect as the ablest Spartan leader. —

cu/mboulon *)alki/da| e)pelhluqo/ta: who had arrived as adviser to Alcidas. For the const., cf. viii. 20. 7 nau/arxos au)toi=s e)k *lakedai/monos *)astu/oxos e)ph=lqen. The cu/mboulos was a commissioner with irregular powers sent to advise the nauarch. Three cu/mbouloi are given to the nauarch in ii. 85. 1; eleven in viii. 39. 7. For the ten cu/mbouloi assigned to king Agis, see on v. 63. 15. See also on c. 42. 19.
dw/deka nausi/: cf. 75. 3; 77. 11. Twelve was the number under the command of Asopius at Naupactus (c. 7. 3).—11.

pri
 de\ . . . profqa/swsi: the natural const. would have been o(/pws de/, pri
 . . . nautiko/n, profqa/swsi, but o(/pws is placed after the pri/n clause, in order that the clauses dw/deka me
 . . . peri\ *nau/pakton and pri
 de\ . . . nautiko/n may be in direct antithesis. For the co-ordination of the different kinds of clauses, see Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3.—13.
pareskeua/zonto: were making preparation. The undertaking is described in c. 76 ff.— 14.
pro\s tau=ta: cf. ii. 77. 4 pro\s th\n peritei/xisin pareskeua/zonto. HISTORY OF THE POLITCAL CONFLICTS IN CORCYRA. c. 70-85.

p.hi: The bitter struggle between the Athenian and Corinthian parties in Corcyra from the beginning until the murder of the Athenian proxenus Pithias.

div2.p: e)stasi/azon: cf. c. 69. 10 e)s th\n *ke/rkuran pleu=sai stasia/zousan.—e)peidh/: see on c. 68. 32.—2.
h)=lqon au)toi=s: for dat. with e)lqei=n, see on c. 5. 12; 39. 22; i. 13. 12.

e)k tw=n peri\ *)epi/ damnon naumaxiw=n: more accurately, from the second of the two seafights, that at Sybota. Cf. i. 47-55. Acc. to i. 55. 6, the number of captives was 250, of whom it is said e)tu/gxanon duna/mei au)tw=n oi( plei/ous prw=toi o)/ntes th=s po/lews.—3. u(po\ *korinqi/wn a)feqe/ntes: as may be inferred from the context, not before the winter of 428-427 B.C., so that their captivity (e)n qerapei/a| ei)=xon pollh=|) must have lasted about five years. See App.—

o)ktakosi/wn tala/ntwn: gen. of price. The ransom of each man would be 3 1/5 talents, which seems enormous, even though the most of the captives were among the first men of the state (see above), and so would be, as a body of 250, a most valuable pledge in the hands of the Corinthians. Jow. thinks that the unusual amount is not a matter of much importance, as the sum was never meant to be paid. But Steup thinks that, even in a sham transaction, the demand would have to seem reasonable, in order not to excite suspicion. He cites from Philip's letter, Dem. xii. 3, a ransom of nine talents for a single man, and urges here the importance to the Corinthians of a body of 250 Corcy
raean captives of such prominence, referring to the advantage which the Athenians derived from the 292 Spartans captured at Sphacteria (iv. 41. § 1; 117). For the ordinary ransom, see Boeckh, p. 99 f.—4.

toi=s proce/nois dihgguhme/noi: bailed on the security of their proxeni, i.e. of Corinthian citizens who were the representatives of Corcyra at Corinth. For the dat., see on c. 64. 15. As to the relation of pro/cenos, see Schoemann, Gr. Ant. ii. p. 25.—5.

pepeisme/noi . . . prospoih=sai: cf. i. 55. 5 (oi( *kori/nqioi) tw=n *kerkurai/wn . . . penth/konta kai\ diakosi/ous dh/santes e)fu/lasson kai\ e)n qerapei/a| ei)=xon pollh=|, o(/pws au)toi=s th\n *ke/rkuran a)naxwrh/santes prospoih/seian. —prospoih=sai: to win over, as in i. 55. 8; ii. 8. 15.—7.
a)posth/swsin: subjv. after past tense of verb of striving, as in i. 57. 9. GMT. 339; H. 885 b.
a)fikome/nhs: sing. before two nouns, a)gousw=n following them. G. 901; H. 607. Cf. i. 29. 6.—8.
e)s lo/gous katasta/ntwn: sc. tw=n pre/sbewn e(kate/rwn toi=s *kerkurai/ois.—10. cu/mmaxoi ei)=nai kata\ ta\ cugkei/mena: i.e. an e)pimaxi/a, defensive alliance, as described i. 44. 8. —11.

w(/sper kai\ pro/teron: i.e. as before the conflict with Corinth and other members of the Peloponnesian alliance about Epidamnus. Cf. i. 28. 10, where Corcyraean ambassadors, warning the Corinthians against going to war about Epidamnus, remark, ei) de\ mh/, kai\ au)toi\ a)nagkasqh/sesqai e)/fasan, e)kei/nwn biazome/nwn, fi/lous poiei=sqai ou(\s ou) bou/lontai, e(te/rous tw=n nu=n o)/ntwn ma=llon, w)feli/as e(/neka. So that, although Corcyra had never belonged to the Peloponnesian alliance, she had had, before the contention about Epidamnus, not only peaceful, but even friendly, relations with the Peloponnesians. These were now to be renewed without affecting the treaty obligations of Corcyra to Athens. The whole decision was a kind of first triumph of the Corinthian party, since Corcyra's conflicts with Corinth and her allies about Epidamnus, and her participation in the ravaging of the Peloponnesian coasts in the summer of 425 B.C. (ii. 25. § 1), were disregarded, while the connexion with Athens was expressly restricted to existing conditions, e)pimaxi/a th=| a)llh/lwn bohqei=n, e)a/n tis e)pi\ *ke/rkuran i)/h| h)\ *)aqh/nas h)\ tou\s tou/twn cumma/xous (i. 44. 8).
kai\ (
h)=n ga\r . . . proeisth/kei): a causal sent. thus placed in parataxis before the main one is common in Hdt. and not rare in Thuc. For const. and punctuation, see on i. 31. 7.—
*peiqi/as: this name occurs in a late Corcyraean epitaph, in the form *peiqei/as (C. I. G. ii. 1911).—

e)qelopro/cenos: Schol. a)f) e(autou= geno/menos kai\ mh\ keleusqei\s e)k th=s po/lews. oi( ga\r pro/cenoi keleuo/menoi e)k th=s e(autw=n po/lews e)ge/nonto, i.e. as Boeckh (C. I. G. i. p. 731) explains, non a Corcyraeis constitutus. But Steup thinks that others prob. more correctly explain, non ab Atheniensibus declaratus. The word and the office occur only here and in the comments of the grammarians on this passage.—12.
proeisth/kei: i.e. prosta/ths h)=n tou= dh/mou. Cf. c. 75. 9; iv. 46. 14.—13.
u(pa/gousin: used with and without e)s di/khn. Cf. Hdt. vi. 136. 4; Xen. Hell. ii. 3. 12, 33; v. 4. 24.—
ou(=toi oi( a)/ndres: Schol. oi( a)po\ *kori/nqou e)panelqo/ntes.—14. katadoulou=n: i.e. trying to enslave. GMT. 25; H. 825.
a)pofugw/n: acquitted, as in c. 13. 34.—16.

te/mnein xa/rakas: acc. to the remark of the grammarians (xa/rac qhlukw=s e)pi\ tw=n a)mpe/lwn, a)rsenikw=s de\ e)pi\ tw=n pro\s poliorki/an), the xa/rakes are the stakes that support the vines. Cf. Phryn. Ecl. p. 61 h( xa/rac to\ th=s a)mpe/lou sth/rigma. See Lobeck ad loc. cit. Probably the more prominent citizens had the oversight and management of the temple and groves, and were now accused of having used these for their own private advantage. The pres. te/mnein indicates that the transgression charged had been a constant practice; and this may explain the large amount of the fine, which manifestly threatened their existence.—

e)k tou= te *dio\s tou= teme/nous kai\ tou= *)alki/nou: these were doubtless two teme/nh, as is clear both from the position of kai\ tou= *)alki/nou and the correlation with te . . . kai/. For e)k tou= *dio\s tou= teme/nous, cf. c. 81. 27; 96. 1; v. 47. 65. The reading of Vat. e)k tou= te *dio\s teme/nous is prob. due to a slip of the copyist, and Cobet's conjecture e)/k te tou= *dio\s teme/nous (Mnem. N. S. viii. p. 142) is hardly to be accepted. The sites of the two teme/nh are unknown. See B. Schmidt, p. 32 f.—17.
tou= *)alki/nou: the Homerie king of ‘Scheria,’ who was worshipped as a h(/rws.—e)pe/keito: here and viii. 15. 6, pf. pass. of e)pitiqe/nai (viii. 67. 13).—18.

stath/r: whether a gold coin worth twenty drachmae, or a silver coin worth two
drachmae, is meant, is doubtful. The context favours the former, as otherwise too large a number of xa/rakes must be assumed in order to bring the amount of the fine up to a sum that would make intelligible the conduct of the accused rich men. In the inscription cited by B. Schmidt, p. 71 (C. I. A. ii. 841), which belongs prob. to the beginning of the third century B.C., a fine of fifty drachmae is imposed, a)/n tis lhfqh=| ko/ptwn h)\ fe/rwn ti tw=n a)peirhme/nwn e)k tou= i(erou=.
o)flo/ntwn: condemned, as in v. 101. 3; Plato Legg. 754 c.—
pro\s ta\ i(era/: cf. ii. 47. 16 pro\s i(eroi=s i(ke/teusan, and c. 81. 25 pro\s au)toi=s (i.e. toi=s i(eroi=s) e)ktei/nonto.—i(ketw=n kaqezome/nwn: see on c. 28. 13; i. 24. 19.—19.
dia\ plh=qos th=s zhmi/as: plh=qos for me/geqos, with reference perhaps to the large number of the xa/rakes. Cf. stratia=s plh/qei, i. 129. 17.—

taca/menoi: getting themselves rated, i.e. arranging for payment by instalments. Cf. the use of ta/cis as a technical expression for such an arrangement with creditors, Plato Legg. 844 b. Cf. c. 50. 10; i. 99. 11, and see B. Schmidt, p. 71 f. —20.

kai\ boulh=s: cf. 1. 12 tou= dh/mou proeisth/kei. Both parties were represented in the boulh/. In l. 23 also boulh/ occurs without the article. Cf. Dio C. xxxvi. 11 boulh=s gegonw/s, Plut. Coriol. 30 a)po\ boulh=s.—21. pei/qei w(/ste: see on c. 31. 10.

tw=| no/mw| e)cei/rgonto: sc. tou= taca/menoi a)podou=nai.—23. me/llein . . . nomi/zein: whereby the relation with Athens would be effected, which the Athenians themselves had rejected, i. 44. § 1.—24.
cuni/stanto: of conspirators also ii. 88. 4; v. 82. 4; viii. 65. 6. The subj. is the five with their followers.—26.
kai\ a)/llous: i.e. the leaders of the democratic party.— 27.
kai\ i)diwtw=n: perhaps partisans of Pithias, who had come to his rescue.—

oi( de/ tines . . . o)li/goi: i.e. some few of the partisans of Pithias who were present in the bouleuth/rion, not of the democratic factions in general; for while most of the leaders doubtless perished at this time, the faction itself was not almost entirely destroyed. For tines o)li/goi, cf. i. 63. 7; iv. 46. 17; 56. 7.—

th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs: as in i. 113. 10; v. 46. 26. For the pred. gen., see G. 1094; H. 732;
Kr. Spr. 47, 6, 10.—28.
e)s th\n *)attikh\n trih/rh: cf.

p.hi: The victorious oligarchs take precautions for their security.

div2.p: tau=ta . . . doulwqei=en: tau=ta refers to what has already happened, the murder of the democratic leaders, hence ei)/h is used without a)/n of the past, but h(/kist) a)\n doulwqei=en of the future. For the position of kai/ before be/ltista, see on c. 67. 24.—3.
to/ te loipo\n kte(.: te introduces a third member, of which the verbs, as expressing a proposal after ei)pei=n, are in the inf., as ii. 13. 14. GMT. 99; H. 946 b; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 13.—
mhdete/rous de/xesqai a)ll) h)\ mia=| nhi/: similar formulae also ii. 7. 13; vi. 52. 7. a)ll) h)/, nisi, as in v. 60. 5; 80. 6; vii. 50. 23; viii. 28. 9. H. 1046, 2 c; Kr. Spr. 69, 4, 6.—4.
h(suxa/zontas: remaining quiet, i.e. taking neither side; to be construed with tou\s *kerkurai/ous, as a comparison with ii. 7. 13 shows.—
to\ de\ ple/on: any larger number. Cf. c. 108. 13; ii. 100. 26.
w(s cune/fere: “where their interest lay,” i.e. to put matters in the most favourable light for themselves. —8.

tou\s e)kei= katapefeugo/tas: i.e. those who had taken refuge first on the Attic trireme (c. 70. 28), and afterwards had fled to Athens. e)kei= instead of e)kei=se, because of the force of the pf. G. 1226; H. 788 b. Cf. e)n for e)s after pf., i. 87. 18; iv. 14. 7; vii. 71. 40; 87. 13. Kr. Spr. 68, 12, 2. —9.

o(/pws mh/ tis e)pistrofh\ ge/nhtai: that vengeance may not be taken on Corcyra, i.e. by the Athenians. e)pistrofh/ (lit. animadversio. a)/muna Suid. s.v.) in this sense also Polyb. iv. 4. 4 kai\ koinh=s au)tou\s e)pistrofh=s e)/fh teu/cesqai, xxii. 17. 7 kai\ e)pistrofh=s ei)=nai kai\ kola/sews. It expresses the purpose of pe/mpousi pre/sbeis, not a warning mhde
 a)nepith/deion pra/ssein. So also Kr. and Bm. explain. St. renders revolution (rerum conversio), comparing Soph. O. C. 537 i)w\ dh=ta mnri/wn g' e)pistrofai\ kakw=n, and Polyb. xxii. 13. 15 kai\ ta\ me
 kata\ tou\s *ai)twlou\s kai\ kaqo/lou tou\s *(/ellhnas toiau/thn e)/sxe th
 e)pistrofh/n (Ursinus's conjecture). Arn. and Jow. prefer counter-revolution.
The demos, attacked by the oligarchs, seizes the Acropolis and other high points, as well as the Hyllaic harbour. Their opponents take possession of the agora and the adjacent harbour.
e)lqo/ntwn: sc. tw=n pre/sbewn. For gen. abs. without expressed subj., when this can be easily supplied from the context, see on i. 2. 8. GMT. 848; H. 972 a.—2.
o(/sous e)/peisan: sc. of the e)kei= katapefeugo/tes.—kate/qento: see on c. 28. 14.
oi( e)/xontes ta\ pra/gmata: see on c. 11. 11; 28. 1.—4.
e)lqou/shs: placed first in agreement with the nearest noun, but belonging also to pre/sbewn. See on c. 70. 7.—5.
e)piti/qentai tw=| dh/mw|: the oligarchs thought they could not carry out their further plans without a second and greater butchery.

a) fikome/nhs nukto/s: Kr. conjectures e)fikome/nhs, acc. to analogy of e)pie/nai, e)fh/kein (iv. 129. 28; viii. 67. 7; 94. 4). But a)fiknei=sqai can be used with nu/c, as with no/sos ii. 48. 9, and with a)ggeli/a v. 64. 1; viii. 15. 1. e)fiknei=sqai is not found in Thuc. The approach of night is usually expressed by e)pigi/gnesqai (c. 112. 3; iv. 25. 9; 48. 16; 125. 6).—
e)s th\n a)kro/polin: regarding the site, see B. Schmidt, p. 27 f.—7.
ta\ mete/wra: the higher points. Cf. c. 89. 11; iv. 44. 11; 57. 9; 112. 8; 124. 19.— 8.
i(dru/qh: of a temporary occupation also iv. 44. 11; 131. 2.—

to\n *(ullai+ko\n lime/na: Leake (in Bloomfield's ed.), after careful investigation, concludes the Hyllaic harbour to be the now shallow bay which extends inward west of the southward projecting promontory on which the acropolis lay (now called the bay of Chalikiopulos). The harbour ‘by the agora and toward the mainland’ (l. 10), where the new/rion was (c. 74. 6), Leake considers to be the modern bay of Kastrades at the northern end of the peninsula. See also J. Partsch, die Insel Korfu, p. 65, and B. Schmidt, p. 22 ff.—
ei)=xon: easy transition to the plural. Cf. i. 13 6; 34. 5. Kühn. 359, 2.—9.
ou(=per: where, i.e. adjacent to which. See on c. 75. 19.

p.hi: Both parties get reinforcements.

div2.p: h)kroboli/santo: of light skirmishing as a prelude to severer fighting, also iv. 34. 2; a)krobolismo/s, vii. 25. 19, 37.—
o)li/ga: acc. neut. pl. of inner obj., approximating to an adverb. See on c. 40. 12; i. 38. 6; vii. 34. 23.—2.
tou\s dou/lous: in the case required by the nearest partic., but belonging to both.—4.
to\ plh=qos: the majority, as in i. 106. 8; 125. 4; iv. 96. 32; viii. 81. 4.—5.
e)pi/kouroi: see on c. 18. 3; i. 115. 18.
In a bitter conflict in the city itself, in which the oligarchs for their own protection set fire to all the houses about the agora, the demos is victorious.
dialipou/shs: intr., of time, as in i. 112. 1. The day between the two ma/xai is the one whose events have just been described in c. 73.—2.
ai(/ te gunai=kes kte(.: cf. ii. 4. 5.—3.
cunepela/bonto: intr., the obj. of the common effort being implied in the context. Cf. i. 115. 9; viii. 92. 31.—
ba/llousai a)po\ tw=n oi)kiw=n kte(.: as at Plataea, ii. 4. 7. 4.
tw=| kera/mw|: collective, as in ii. 4. 7; iv. 48. 10.—
para\ fu/sin: as in vi. 17. 1.

peri\ dei/lhn o)yi/an: as in viii. 26. 1. Schol. tou= h(li/ou peri\ dusma\s o)/ntos. —6. au)toboei/: with a sudden rush, lit. at the first cry. Cf. Liv. i. 11 primo impetu et clamore, vi. 4 primo clamore atque impetu. The word occurs also c. 113. 27; ii. 81. 21; v. 3. 9; viii. 23. 11; 62. 8; 71. 12, but is not found elsewhere except in late writers. Acc. to Marcell. Vit. 52, it is a)rxaio/teron tw=n kat) au)to\n xro/nwn. Kr. quotes Bekker's Anecd. p. 214 and 465, taxe/ws kai\ a(/ma tw=| polemikw=| a)lalagmw=|. ou(/tw *qoukudi/dhs, para\ *qeopo/mpw| de\ a)nti\ tou= kata\ kra/tos.—tou= newri/ou: apparently the strongest of the points occupied by the oligarchs (c. 72. § 3). The new/ria were usually enclosed by walls. See Hermann, Gr. Ant. ii. 2, p. 277. Thuc's silence as to the site of this new/rion would seem to indicate that he re
garded a new/rion as part of every harbour. See on c. 81. 8.—8.
th=s a)gora=s: cf. 72. 9.—

ta\s cunoiki/as: i.e. large tenement houses (=insulae at Rome). Cf. Aeschin. i. 124 o(/pou me\n polloi\ misqwsa/menoi mi/an oi)/khsin dielo/menoi e)/xousi cunoiki/an kalou=men, o(/pou d' ei(=s e)noikei= oi)ki/an. Also Ar. Eq. 1001; (Xen.) de Rep. Athen. 1. 17.—10.
xrh/mata: wares, as vi. 97. 27; vii. 24. 9; 25. 7.—11.

ei) a)/nemos e)pege/neto . . . e)pi/foros: cf. ii. 77. 20 pneu=ma ei) e)pege/neto au)th=| e)pi/foron.—ei) e)pege/neto: si ingruisset, since e)kindu/neuse diafqarh=nai is about equiv. to diefqa/rh a)/n. See on c. 10. 20. GMT. 427 a; Kühn. 392^{b}, 5.
w(s e(ka/teroi: utrique pro se (as w(s e(/kastoi, i. 3. 19), to be construed with h(suxa/santes.—h(suxa/santes: after they had become quiet, i.e. gone to rest again.—14.
e)n fulakh=| h)=san: cf. ii. 13. 52; iv. 55. 6. See on c. 75. 11.—
h( *korinqi/a nau=s: cf. c. 72. 4.—15.
u(pecanh/geto: slipped out to sea. The word seems to occur only here.—
tw=n e)pikou/rwn: cf. c. 73. 5.—16.
laqo/ntes diekomi/sqhsan: cf. c. 51. 9; vii. 29. 10. GMT. 893.
The Athenian strategus, Nicostratus, arriving at Corcyra from Naupactus with twelve ships, makes an unsuccessful effort to effect an adjustment.
*niko/stratos: mentioned as general also iv. 53. 5; 119. 10; 129. 11; v. 61. 3.—
*dieitre/fous: so acc. to inscriptions, although the Mss. have *diitre/fous. See St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 38; Meisterhans,^{2} p. 40.—2.

paragi/gnetai bohqw=n kte(.: a crisis in the sta/sis of the Corcyraeans is now reached, inasmuch as after this there is outside interference in the conflicts. Nicostratus prob. reached Corcyra (see App. on c. 70. 3) about the time when Alcidas arrived in Cyllene (c. 69. § 1; cf. c. 76), and MüllerStrübing is doubtless right in con
jecturing (N. Jahrbb. cxxxiii. p. 597), that his appearance was due to the news of the murder of Pithias (c. 70. 26), and that this intelligence was the occasion also of the voyage of the Peloponnesians to Corcyra (c. 69. § 2).—
e)k *naupa/ktou dw/deka nausi/: cf. c. 69. 10, and see App. on c. 77. 12.—4.
cu/mbasin e)/prasse: tried to effect an agreement.—
w(/ste: see on c. 31. 10.—5.
de/ka me\n a)/ndras . . . oi)kei=n: see on c. 48. 5.—
de/ka a)/ndras tou\s ai)tiwta/tous; for the order, see on c. 42. 4.—

ai)tiwta/tous: most to blame, sc. for the bloody conflicts that had occurred. This expression proves that all the ten men belonged to the o)li/goi, and this is confirmed by the circumstances under which the agreement was effected. See B. Schmidt, p. 73.—
oi(\ ou)ke/ti e)/meinan: parenthetical, “who no longer remained, after the conclusion of the agreement, but made off.”—6.

sponda\s poihsame/nous w(/ste: cf. i. 44. 4 cummaxi/an poih/sasqai w(/ste.—7. w(/ste . . . nomi/zein: belongs only to pro\s *)aqhnai/ous, not to pro\s a)llh/lous. For w(/ste, on condition that, see on c. 28. 4; i. 28. 18. The formula tou\s au)tou\s e)xqrou\s kai\ fi/lous nomi/zein also c. 70. 23; i. 44. 5; vii. 33. 29. Cf. also v. 48. 6 toi=s au)toi=s polemei=n kai\ ei)rh/nhn a)/gein.
o( me\n e)/mellen . . ., oi( de\ . . . pei/qousi: paratactic connexion, where a dependent const. in the first clause might have been expected.—11.
o(/pws . . . oi( e)nanti/oi: that their opponents might be less inclined to stir. For h(=sso/n ti, see on c. 45. 29.—

e)n kinh/sei w)=sin: a periphrasis indicating an enduring condition, as e)n taraxh=| kai\ a)pori/a| e)gi/gnonto, vii. 44. 1; e)n e)lpi/di ei)=nai, i. 74. 22; iv. 70. 20; vii. 25. 4, 43; 46. 6; e)n fulakh=| ei)=nai, c. 74. 14; ii. 13. 52; iv. 55. 6.—12.
i)/sas: after numerals, an equal number of. See on i. 115. 13.—
cumpe/myein: depends on e)pagge/llontai, or some such word, to be supplied from pei/qousin. For similar const., cf. c. 94. 19. Kr. Spr. 65, 11, 7.

kai\ o( me\n cunexw/rhsen kte(.: the objections urged by Müller-Strü
bing (ibid. p. 598) against the credibility of what is here related are refuted by B. Schmidt, p. 74 f.—
kate/legon: of levying troops for military or naval service. Cf. vii. 31. 27; viii. 31. 2, both in mid., the commander being subject.—15.
kaqi/zousin: see on c. 28. 13.—

to\ tw=n *diosko/rwn i(ero/n: *diosko/rwn (not *dioskou/rwn) with Bk. and others, acc. to Laur. See St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 46; Meisterhans,^{2} p. 21. The site of the sanctuary is unknown. See B. Schmidt, p. 33. f.—16.

a)ni/sth: the regular word for this action. Cf. l. 24; 28. 13; i. 126. 33; 128. 3; 137. 1. Acc. to the following narrative, a)ni/sth must be understood, with B. Schmidt, p. 75, not of the mere attempt, but of the actual accomplishment. The correlation te kai/ also supports this view. As Schmidt rightly observes (p. 73), a)ni/sth carries the idea of pledging the security of the i(ke/tai.
e)pi\ th=| profa/sei tau/th|: on this ground. Cf. i. 141. 3; iv. 80. 7; v. 42. 7.—18.

ou)de
 u(gie\s dianooume/nwn: lit. planning nothing wholesome for the state. They view the matter, of course, from a party point of view. Cf. iv. 22. 9; Dem. xli. 22 ta\ mhde
 u(gie\s o)/nta mhd) a)lhqh= gra/mmata, Plut. Otho 3 ou)de
 u(gie\s dianoei=sqai.—th=| tou= mh\ cumplei=n a)pisti/a|: by their refusal to sail. For mh/ with inf. after a)pisti/a|, which gets from the context the force of refusal arising from mistrust, see on c. 32. 13. Cf. i. 10. 3 a)pistoi/h mh\ gene/sqai to
 sto/lon tosou=ton.—19. e)k tw=n oi)kiw=n: acc. to Müller-Strübing (ibid. p. 599), this mention of the houses of the o)li/goi is incompatible with c. 72. 8 oi( de\ (i.e. oi( o)li/goi) th/n te a)gora
 kate/labon, ou)=per oi( polloi\ w)/|koun au)tw=n, and c. 74. 7 (oi( o)li/goi) e)mpipra=si ta\s oi)ki/as ta\s e)n ku/klw| th=s a)gora=s kai\ ta\s cunoiki/as. But Schmidt rightly observes (p. 75), that in c. 72. 8 only the most, not all, of the oligarchs are meant. Besides, it is not necessary to restrict ou(=per there to the immediate environment of the agora. —20.
au)tw=n tinas oi(=s e)pe/tuxon: these had doubtless left the place where Nicostratus had treated with the i(ke/tai, and gone home.
kaqi/zousin . . . i(ke/tai: see on c. 28. 13; i. 24. 19.—22.

e)s to\ *(/hraion: Bl. thinks that they removed from the temple of Castor and Pollux to
that of Hera, because the greater sanctity of the latter offered a surer asylum.—
gi/gnontai: with numerals, as in i. 107. 24; ii. 13. 27; 20. 11; 98. 14; iv. 9. 10.—23.

tetrakosi/wn: from the largeness of the number B. Schmidt concludes (p. 75 f.) that oi( a)/lloi in l. 21 refers to the rest of the oligarchs in general, not simply to the rest of those that refused to go upon the ships. But the latter view seems tenable. For, besides the substitutes for the proportional part of the 500 Messenian hoplites of Nicostratus (forty-two men for each ship), there may be reckoned for the five ships all the usual crew of Attic triremes, except the rowers, i.e. acc. to Boeckh i.^{2} p. 389, thirty men each. And even of the oarsmen some may not have been slaves or mercenaries.—
newteri/swsin: applied to any innovation in established order, esp. to harsh and violent changes. Cf. c. 66. 9; i. 58. 3; ii. 3. 7; iv. 51. 3.—24.

diakomi/zei . . . nh=son: cf. iv. 46. 11 au)tou\s e)s th
 nh=son oi( strathgoi\ th
 *htuxi/an e)s fulakh
 dieko/misan. e)s th
 pro\ tou= *(hrai/ou nh=son: Leake (in Bloomfield's ed., c. 72. 8) thinks the Heraeum stood on the esplanade between the modern city (Corfu) and its citadel on the opposite island; and this island, not Ptychia-Vido, as others think, he considers to be the nh=sos pro\ tou= *(hrai/ou. B. Schmidt (p. 34 ff.) follows Leake with reference to the island, but locates the Heraeum near the southern shore of the bay of Kastrades, on the hill where now is the monastery of Euphemia. The Heraeum seems certainly to have been on the mainland (see on c. 79. 4), though Partsch (die Insel Korfu, p. 66 ff.), who decides for Vido as the nh=sos, locates the temple on the modern citadel-island. See also Partsch, Wochenschr. f. kl. Phil. 1891, p. 593 ff.

p.hi: Fifty-three Peloponnesian ships under Alcidas and Brasidas appear before Corcyra.

div2.p: ai( e)k th=s *kullh/nhs . . . nh=es: cf. c. 69. 6. For e)k th=s, the usual prolepsis, see on c. 5. 1.—4.

e)f) o(/rmw|: with St. (Rh. Mus. xxvi. p. 345 f.), for e)/formoi of the Mss., which the Schol. explains by e)n o(/rmw| diatri/bousai. e)/formos as adj. seems not to be found; as a noun, it is found in c. 6. 6; iv. 27. 7; 32. 4. o(/rmos is a place of safe anchorage, not a harbour proper. Cf. iv. 26. 9; vi. 44. 12; vii. 41. 4. The expression e)r) o(/rmw| ei)=nai is not found elsewhere. Kr. conjectured e)n e)fo/rmw| ou)=sai, Meineke and v. H. e)formou=sai. That e)/formos
and e)formei=n do not always refer to a blockade is shown by the use of e)fo/rmhsis in vi. 48. 9. After the forty ships of Alcidas had returned from the Ionian coast and united with the thirteen of Brasidas, the fleet lay for some time at anchor at Cyllene, occupied with preparations for the voyage to Corcyra, c. 69. 13.—6.
cu/mboulos: see on c. 69. 7.—
e)pe/plei: was on board. See on c. 16. 17. It is quite different from e)pe/pleon in the next line.—7.

*su/bota: name of islands, promontory, and harbour on the Thesprotian coast (cf. i. 47. 4; 50. 14; 54. 4); still existing in S. Nicolo di Sivota. 77, 78. In a sea-fight the Corcyraean ships, advancing in disorder, are thrown into confusion. Their retreat is covered by the twelve Attic ships, which after an indecisive conflict retire before superior numbers.
oi( de/: i.e. the democratic authorities in Corcyra.—
pollw=| qoru/bw| kai\ pefobhme/noi: unlike elements combined in the same pred. relation. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3. Cf. c. 25. 8; 34. 17; 42. 23; i. 63. 7.—3.
ta\s ai)ei\ plhroume/nas e)ce/pempon: both impf. and pres. partic. are necessary with the iterative ai)ei/. See on c. 23. 11.—4.
parainou/ntwn *)aqhnai/wn: although the Athenians advised. Cf. c. 79. 10.— 5.
pa/sais a(/ma: i.e. with all at once, not tai=s ai)ei\ plhroume/nais.—e)pigene/sqai: to follow after. Cf. ii. 44. 12.
au)toi=s: the dat. placed first in the most general relation to the whole. Cf. i. 6. 8; 48. 9.—8.
oi( e)mple/ontes: only here=oi( e)piba/tai.—9. tw=n poioume/nwn: cf. vi. 87. 10; viii. 43. 14; 46. 27; 69. 9.

e)ta/canto: ‘direct middle,’ as in i. 48. 9; iv. 11. 2, etc. G. 1242, 1; H. 812. Cf. ku/klon ta/casqai, c. 78. 7;
ii. 83. 23.—12.
w(=n h)=san kte(.: cf. i. 116. 8 w(=n h(=san ai( ei)/kosi stratiw/tides. See App.—
*salamini/a kai\ *pa/ralos: see on c. 33. 2.
kakw=s: referring to ou)dei\s ko/smos of c. 77. 8.—
kat) o)li/gas: as described c. 77. § 1.—3.
e)talaipwrou=nto: see on c. 3. 1.—(
to\)

kaq) au(tou/s: in sua parte, Haase's conjecture (Lucubr. p. 44), adopted by Cl. and St., for the vulg. kaq) au(tou/s, suits the context better. Cf. c. 108. 10; i. 62. 24. The vulg. would mean either of themselves, inter se, i.e. without the enemy's help (cf. ii. 88. 4; iv. 71. 5), or alone, per se (cf. c. 39. 14; ii. 99. 6).—4.
to\ plh=qos: the superior number, as ii. 89. 5.—

a(qro/ais: like kata\ me/son, referring to the hostile ships, tai=s e)f) e(autou\s tetagme/nais.
