Both expressions supplement each other with this sense: The Athenians fear to attack the whole fleet of thirty-three ships in the centre, but throwing themselves with their whole strength upon one wing, kata\ ke/ras, sink one ship; whereupon the Peloponnesians concentrate (ku/klon tacame/nwn) their ships in the same manner as deseribed in ii. 83. § 5, and the Attic ships repeat the movement that was so successful on the former oceasion (perie/pleon kai\ e)peirw=nto qorubei=n), but a like result is prevented by timely aid to the Peloponnesians from the other division.—5.
me/son: the art. omitted as often. H. 661. Cf. i. 62. 14; ii. 81. 11; iv. 31. 8; 96. 10.—
e)f) e(autou/s: Palat. has e)f) e(autoi=s, which is supported by the const. of c. 13. 18; ii. 70. 8. But for the acc., cf. l. 14; 77. 10.
oi( pro\s toi=s *kerkurai/ois: i.e. oi( pro\s tou\s *kerkurai/ous tetagme/noi tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn. Cf. c. 77. 10. For the const., cf. c. 77. 6.—9.
o(/per e)n *naupa/ktw|: sc. e)ge/neto. Cf. ii. 84.— 10.
a(qro/ai: i.e. the hitherto separate divisions.

pru/mnan krouo(menoi: backing water, i.e. withdrawing without turning the vessel. See on i. 50. 21; vii.
40. 2.—13.

prokatafugei=n o(/ti ma/lista, e(autw=n sxolh=| kte(.: Cl. wrote, with Vat., prokatafugei=n, e(autw=n o(/ti ma/lista, remarking that it was unimportant whether or not the Corcyraeans outstripped the enemy as far as possible (o(/ti ma/lista), if only they gained time to reach their harbour. But there is no need to take o(/ti ma/lista (cf. i. 44. 13; v. 36. 9) in this sense. On the contrary, the fact that the Corcyraeans lost altogether thirteen ships (c. 79. 6) seems to indicate that o(/ti ma/lista means as much as possible, i.e. as many ships as possible. St. construes o(/ti ma/lista with e)bou/lonto, comparing c. 47. 11; i. 141. 29; ii. 90. 17; iv. 79. 11; v. 36. 8; vi. 9. 11; viii. 91. 15.—14.
u(poxwrou/ntwn: gen. abs. instead of u(poxwrou=ntes, on account of the parallelism with the following clause. See also on c. 13. 30.—
tetagme/nwn: cf. l. 6; 77. 10. Hude's conjecture (p. 110) tetramme/nwn is unnecessary.

toiau/th genome/nh: tacitly implying the success of the Athenian plan, —not only that they finished their retreat without loss, but also that the Corcyraeans reached the harbour, though with a loss, it is true, of thirteen ships (c. 79. § 2).—
e)teleu/ta e)s h(li/ou du/sin: lasted till sunset. Cf. c. 108. 18; i. 51. 9.
The Peloponnesians, afraid to attack the city, sail away with thirteen captured Corcyraean ships, and disembarking next day at Leucimme ravage the island.
tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou: proleptic, as c. 76. 3. Cf. c. 75. 24.—
newteri/swsi: resort to violence, as in c. 66. 9; ii. 3. 7. See on c. 75. 23.—4.
tou/s te . . . e)fu/lasson: from these words in connexion with the foregoing, B. Schmidt (p. 43) rightly infers that the Heraeum was inside of the city walls.—5.
e)fu/lasson:=e)n fulakh=| or dia\ fulakh=s ei)=xon.

e)pi\ me
 th
 po/lin: the real antithesis is not triskai/deka de\ nau=s e)/xontes, but, after the repetition of e)pi\ me
 th
 po/lin in l. 8, e)pi\ de\ th
 *leuki/mmhn (l. 11).—6.

kratou=ntes th=| naumaxi/a|: although superior in the naval battle. These words, wrongly rejected by
Kr. as an unnecessary repetition, are added in order that pleu=sai e)pi\ th\n po/lin may appear as the natural result of the advantage won. The indecision of Alcidas appears here, as in l. 9, in an unfavourable light.—
triskai/deka de\ nau=s: cf. viii. 22. 5 triskai/deka nausi/n.—8. o(/qenper a)nhga/gonto: cf. c. 76. 7.
o)/ntas: agreeing kata\ cu/nesin with po/lin. See on c. 2. 2.—

w(s le/getai: shows the prudence of the historian, who is not sure of the matter, and the special mention of Brasidas indicates the interest everywhere manifested by Thuc. in the Spartan leader. See on c. 69. 7; ii. 25. 7.—11.
i)soyh/fou ou)k o)/ntos: sc. as cu/mboulos of the nau/arxos. Cf. c. 69. 7; 76. 6.—
th\n *leuki/mmhn: the S.E. promontory of Corcyra, now Leukimo. Cf. i. 30. 2.
At nightfall news comes of the approach of an Athenian fleet of sixty ships, under the command of Eurymedon.
o( dh=mos h)=|san: collective noun with pl. verb, as in c. 75. 20; v. 82. 5.—G. 900; H. 609.—3.
toi=s a)/llois: the i(ke/tai of c. 75. 22, who were brought back to the Heraeum (c. 70. 4), formed only a part of the aristocratic party, the o)li/goi of c. 74. 6.—
kai/ tinas au)tw=n e)/peisan: with better success than before, c. 75. § 3. —4.
o(/mws: i.e. in spite of the sad experiences of c. 77, 78.—5. [

prosdexo/menoi to\n e)pi/ploun]: these words which are wanting in most Mss., and found on the margin of a few, state correctly the motive of e)plh/rwsan . . . tria/konta, but were doubtless added by an attentive reader from the preceding perideh\s geno/menos mh\ e)pipleu/swsin.

me/xri me/sou h(me/ras: me/son (neut.) with the gen. of a subst. seems to be found only here and vii. 52. 9 in Thuc.; for me/sos is an adj. in iv. 96. 2 me/xri me/sou tou= stratope/dou, vi. 101. 7 dia\ me/sou tou= e(/lous, just as in ii. 83. 20 kata\ me/son to\n porqmo/n, v. 9. 22 kata\
me/son to\ stra/teuma. As a noun, it is freq. in Xenophon. Kühn. 403, a g. See on c. 78. 5.—7.
e)fruktwrh/qhsan: i.e. by the fruktwroi/ appointed for the purpose (viii. 102. 2). See on c. 22. 34, and ii. 94. 1. This verb is found only here.—8.

a)po\ *leuka/dos: from its position more naturally connected, as Cl. and Bm. explain, with prosple/ousai than with e)fruktwrh/qhsan, but most editt. construe with the latter, on the ground, as some express it, that if the Athenian fleet had been already under way from Leucas it would have been at Corcyra before the Peloponnesian fleet could have escaped, or, as others, that the Athenian fleet would have got so far north by the time Alcidas reached Leucas that his fleet, even if it had sailed round Leucas, could hardly have been seen by Eurymedon's ships (c. 81. 4). For Steup's view, see App. It seems reasonable to infer from this passage that the number, as well as the approach, of the fleet was signalled, though e(ch/konta may be only an anticipatory explanation of the author.—10.

mellou/sas plei=n: pred., so that punqano/menoi has the double const. of the simple obj. acc. and of the supplem. partic. Between the coming of the first information and of the second there was prob. a slight interval; for the Peloponnesians doubtless decided upon the voyage to Corcyra (c. 69. § 2) only after the murder of Pithias (see on c. 75. 2), while the Athenians, as B. Schmidt (p. 77) rightly observes, had already learned of the outbreak of the sta/sis from the Attic trireme mentioned in c. 70. 7, 28, which must have returned immediately thereafter to Athens. It is to be noticed that, although in c. 72. § 1 mention is made of precautions taken in consequence of the sta/sis, here still the announcement of the outbreak is spoken of. This inconsistency would doubtless have been removed could the historian have revised his work.—
*eu)rume/donta: first mentioned here, but after this time freq. in active service until his death in Sicily, vii. 52. 11.

Hereupon the Peloponnesians sail homewards, and the democratic party in Corcyra, falling upon its defenceless enemies, perpetrates with all the horrors of hate and revenge a terrible butchery among them.
th=s nukto\s eu)qu\s kata\ ta/xos: the sarcastic tone noted at c. 29. 2; 31. 11, is perhaps observable here also. To flee with fifty-three ships at the approach of sixty is not very creditable.—

th=s nukto/s, para\ th\n gh=n: these two circumstances may account
for Alcidas not having been seen by Eurymedon, even if the Athenian fleet when announced was advancing from Leucas. See B. Schmidt, p. 78. —3.

u(perenegko/ntes . . . ta\s nau=s: sc. with the aid of o(lkoi/, such as are mentioned c. 15. 7. to\n i)sqmo/n is governed by u(per-, ta\s nau=s by the verb. Kühn. 411, 7. Cf. iv. 8. 8; viii. 7. 7. This isthmus (cf. iv. 8. 8), which then connected the island with the mainland, had been previously cut through by the Corinthians (Strab. p. 452 c). But the canal (o( *dio/ruktos, Polyb. v. 12) became filled with sand (Plin. Hist. Nat. iv. 1. 2, 5), and remained so until the Romans again opened it for a short time. Liv. xxxiii. 17. See Oberhummer, Akarnanien im Alterthum, p. 7 ff., and Partsch, Die Insel Leukas, p. 2 ff. (Petermann's Mitteilungen, Ergänzungsheft 95).—
o(/pws . . . o)fqw=sin: see App. on c. 80. 8.— 4.
a)pokomi/zontai: sc. to Cyllene or Gytheum; and thus ended the activity of the Peloponnesian fleet for this year.

labo/ntes: bracketed by Cl., following Kr., on the ground that it was prob. a gloss of ei)/ tina la/boien that crept into the text. But it is better to retain it, with St., for even though ii. 67. 21 oi( de\ labo/ntes e)ko/misan e)s ta\s *)aqh/nas may not be quite parallel, since there labo/ntes means having received, yet cf. Ar. Vesp. 1379 a)/gein tau/thn labw/n, Lysist. 1115, 1128; Thesm. 212; Ran. 888.—

tou\s *messhni/ous: i.e. the 500 whom Nicostratus had brought with him, c. 75. 3. The object in bringing them into the city was doubtless merely the intimidation of the oligarchs; that they participated directly in the butchery that followed, as Cl. thought, seems probable neither from Thuc.'s narrative nor in itself. See B. Schmidt, p. 78.—8.
a(\s e)plh/rwsan: cf. c. 80. 4. —

e)s to\n *(ullai+ko\n lime/na: the ships had been therefore in the harbour near the agora (c. 72. 10), which was esp. exposed to the attacks of enemies from without, since its entrance was not narrow like that of the Hyllaic harbour. They were ordered round to the Hyllaic harbour in order that the oligarehs on them might be cut off from their friends in the neighbourhood of the agora (c. 72. 9) and in the Heraeum. The matter is intelligible only if a new/rion be assumed also for the Hyllaic harbour. See on c. 74. 6.—9.
e)n o(/sw|: while, as in viii. 61. 5; 87. 23.—

ei)/ tina la/boien: the oligarchs perhaps tried to conceal
themselves.—10.
e)k tw=n new=n: these words, which belong to e)kbiba/zontes, imply that it was those that had remained in the city who were killed before this.—
o(/sous e)/peisan: cf. c. 80. 4.—11.

a)pexrw=nto: for which the most and best Mss. have a)pexw/rhsan, is sufficiently protected by the remark of ancient grammarians (Suidas, Zonaras, and in Bekker's Anecd. p. 423 *qoukudi/dhs a)pexrw=nto a)nti\ tou= a)nh/|roun), and is indispensable to the sense; for those on the ships were certainly killed immediately, not, as Kr. thinks, first tried along with the fifty i(ke/tai. Besides, te introduces the next clause (e)s to\ *(/hraio/n te) as the third act in this drama of horrors. a)poxrh=sqai meaning to kill is supported only by a citation from Aristophanes in Suidas (s.v. a)pexrh/santo) and Pollux ix. 153 (tou\s a)/ndras a)pexrh/santo). But the analogy of diaxrh=sqai (c. 36. 15; i. 126. 38, where some Mss. have a)pexrh/santo; vi. 61. 17; Antiph. i. 23; Hdt. i. 24. 12; 110. 18) and kataxrh=sqai (Hdt. i. 82. 42; 117. 5; iii. 36. 28; iv. 146. 7; vi. 135. 9, and late writers) is in its favour. The strong expression doubtless indicates the feeling of horror of the historian. The portion of the demos to be understood as subj. of a)pexrw=nto was of course different from that implied in a)pe/kteinon. See B. Schmidt, p. 79.—11.
e)s to\ *(/hraio/n te: cf. c. 79. 4. The particle is similarly placed also in vii. 84. 15 e)s ta\ e)pi\ qa/tera/ te. Kühn. 520, N. 5.—13.

e)/peisan kai\ kate/gnwsan: aors. to indicate summary process. That the sentence was immediately executed is plain from the following w(s e(w/rwn ta\ gigno/mena (partic. impf.). In all the rest of the description of the horrors, the impf. (a)pe/kteinon, a)pexrw=nto, a)ph/gxonto, a)nhlou=nto, e)fo/neuon, etc.) prevails, and hence in l. 15 die/fqeiron (three Mss.) is to be preferred to die/fqeiran, which most Mss. have, since there is no sufficient reason for the change of tense.
w(s e(w/rwn ta\ gigno/mena: these words, which are suspected by Müller-Strübing, p. 602 f., are quite in order, if, with B. Schmidt, p. 42 and 78 f., a high site be assumed for the Heraeum.—15.
au)tou= e)n tw=| i(erw=|: emphatic combination. Cf. c. 98. 11; ii. 25. 18; v. 22. 2; 83. 4. See Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 58 ff.—16.

a)nhlou=nto: —sfa=s au)tou\s a)nh/loun. Cf. iv. 48. 17. a)nalou=n, which Thuc. prefers to a)nali/skein, is, like a)poxrh=sqai, unusual in this sense. Cf. Aesch. Agam. 570;
Soph. O. T. 1174; Eur. El. 681. From c. 75. 23 o( de\ dh=mos dei/sas mh/ ti newteri/swsin kte(., it may be inferred that the i(ke/tai had arms.

o( *eu)rume/dwn: seems to have arrived during the first act of the horrors here related (l. 7 ta\s nau=s . . . a)pe/kteinon); hence the butchery of the oligarchs might be reckoned from his coming. Nicostratus prob. left Corcyra before the seven days ended (cf. c. 75. 9, and see on l. 6).—19.

e)fo/neuon: slaughtered, as in i. 50. 3; vii. 29. 20; 85. 8; viii. 95. 29. It is classed by Rutherford (New. Phryn. p. 15) among the old Ionisms that survived in Tragedy. It occurs, in this sense, also in legal language in Plato (Legg. 871 d; 873 c), and is freq. in late writers.—

th
 me
 ai)ti/an . . . katalu/ousin: i.e. lo/gw| me
 ai)tiw/menoi tou\s to
 dh=mon katalu/ontas. The following clause, if regular, would have been e)/rgw| de\ a)poktei/nontes kai/ tinas kte(., but there is a transition to the finite verb, owing to the moral significance of the individual occurrences. For similar change of const., cf. c. 87. § 1; ii. 47. § 3; vii. 47. § 2. “Though they asserted that they wished to bring to trial only the subverters of the democracy, yet many were killed also from other motives.” katalu/ein to
 dh=mon also v. 76. 5; viii. 54. 17; 86. 8; katalu/ein th
 dhmokrati/an, viii. 47. 17. katalu/ein is the technical word for this idea in Attic. Cf. Ar. Eccles. 453; Andoc. i. 95; Lys. xiii. 4; Dem. xviii. 182. —22.

u(po\ tw=n labo/ntwn: sc. ta\ xrh/mata, tw=n daneisame/nwn, Schol. So also most editt. explain, doubtless correctly, since thus the baseness of the motive is made manifest. Bm. renders by their captors.
pa=sa/ te i)de/a: as in c. 83. 1; 98. 15; 112. 23; ii. 19. 1; 77. 7; vii. 29. 26. For te in a résumé, see on c. 40. 16. —23.
e)n tw=| toiou/tw|: “in times like those just described.” o( toiou=tos as in iv. 56. 4; vii. 81. 13. See on c. 43. 12. —24.
ou)de\n o(/ ti ou): as in vii. 87. 14, 25, for the fuller form ou)de/n e)stin o(/ ti ou). Cf. ii. 62. 13. H. 1003 a; Kr. Spr. 51, 10, 11; Kühn. 555, 5. See on c. 39. 38.—

kai\ e)/ti peraite/rw: in this hyperbolical expression the adv. has the force of an adj., as in Ar. Thesm. 705 deina\ pra/gmat) e)sti\ kai\ peraite/rw, Av. 416 a)/pista kai\ pe/ra klu/ein, Soph. Epig. (ap. Stob. Flor. 73, 51) w)= pa=n su\ tolmh/sasa kai\ pe(ra gunh/. Cf. Sall.
Jug. 44 cuncta fuere et alia amplius.—25.
pro\s au)toi=s: see on c. 70. 18.—26.
perioikodomhqe/ntes: = a)poikodomhqe/ntes (i. 134. 13; vii. 73. 8). Found only here in Thuc. Cf. Hdt. vii. 60. 11; Xen. Cyrop. i. 4. 11.—

e)n tou= *dionu/sou tw=| i(erw=|: see on c. 70. 16. The site of this sanctuary is unknown. See B. Schmidt, p. 33. 82, 83. General reflections on the fearful results of party struggles, which the war produced everywhere in the Hellenic world.

ou(/tws w)mh/: pred. to prouxw/rhse, as in i. 23. 4 me/ga to prou/bh.—h( sta/sis: Kr.'s restoration of the art., which could easily have been lost after w)mh/, seems necessary, since the reference is to the sedition just described.—
e)/doce ma=llon: Schol. ma=llon w)mh\ e)/docen h)/per e)ge/neto.—2. e)n toi=s prw/th: see on c. 17. 2.—3.
w(s ei)pei=n: so always in Thuc., not w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n, as in Plato and the orators. GMT. 777, 1; H. 956. See on i. 1. 9. Cf. i. 138. 18; vii. 49. 18.—
to\ *(ellhniko/n: as in c. 57. 11; i. 1. 6; 6. 23, including all Hellenic states, even those outside of Greece proper.—
e)kinh/qh: as in iv. 76. 21, of profound political disturbance. See on ki/nhsis, i. 1. 8.—

diaforw=n ou)sw=n . . . tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous: “since everywhere the chiefs of the democracy and of the oligarchy were struggling, the one to bring in the Athenians, the other the Lacedaemonians.” Jow. e)pa/gesqai in loose connexion with diaforw=n ou)sw=n expresses the result. This verb is regularly used of inviting strangers into one's country. See on i. 3. 8.—5.

kai\ e)n me\n ei)rh/nh| . . . e)pori/zonto: and while, in time of peace, they would have no pretext, and were not even ready to call them in, being at war, those on either side who wished a revplution easily procured allies both to harass their enemies and to acquire for themselves power from the same source. See App.— 6.
ou)k a)\n e)xo/ntwn: gen. abs. without expressed subj., as often in Thuc. when it can be easily supplied from the context. GMT. 848; H. 972 a. See on c. 34. 17.—
e(toi/mwn: for omission of o)/ntwn, cf. v. 64. 18, and see on c. 69. 4.—7.

polemoume/nwn de/: corresponds to e)n me\n ei)rh/nh|. Instead of a
gen. abs. answering to ou)k a)\n e)xo/ntwn . . . ou)d) e(toi/mwn, the const. changes to a finite verb, e)pori/zonto. St. compares vi. 69. 9. Kr. Spr. 69, 16, 4.—

kai\ cummaxi/as a(/ma: depends on ai( e)pagwgai/, but is thus emphatically placed as containing the main idea and in order that the cummaxi/a may appear as the natural result of the state of war (polemoume/nwn). cummaxi/a, “help of allies,” as i. 32. 2; 42. 12; vi. 73. 5.—8.

e(kate/rois: (i.e. the democrats and the oligarchs) restricted by toi=s newteri/zein ti boulome/nois, and having therefore the force of e(kate/rwn. But Steup, who considers the Athenians and Lacedaemonians to be the subj. of polemoume/nwn, holds that, e(kate/rois also refers to those states. In that case, e(kate/rois would be dat. of agent with e)pori/zonto (see on c. 64. 15) and toi=s . . . boulome/nois dat. of advantage.—

th=| tw=n e)nanti/wn kakw/sei kai\ . . . prospoih/sei: the two substs. with common art. closely connected. See on c. 2. 6; 56. 7. The dats. express purpose, as pleoneci/a|, l. 39; w)feli/a|, l. 38; i. 123. 10; cummaxi/a|, vi. 33. 9. prospoi/hsis from the mid. prospoiei=sqai, which is used esp. of the acquisition of allies (i. 8. 16; ii. 30. 6; iv. 77. 13). The verbal subst. governs sfi/sin au)toi=s. Kr. Spr. 48, 12, 4; Kühn. 424, 1. Cf. i. 63. 9; 73. 1.—9.
ai( e)pagwgai/: the unusual subst. used on account of e)pa/gesqai above. See on c. 100. 6. Cf. v. 82. 24 e)pagwgh\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn.
kai\ e)pe/pese kte(.: and so befell, etc., i.e. after outside help was called in.—11.
kata\ sta/sin: see on c. 2. 10; 68. 17.—

gigno/mena me
 kai\ ai)ei\ e)so/mena:=oi(=a gi/gnetai kai\ ai)ei\ e)/stai. Cf. Dio C.'s imitation (xxxvi. 20) ou) ga e)/stin o(/te tau=t) ou)k e)ge/neto, ou)d) a)
 pau/saito/ pote e(/ws a)
 h( au)th\ fu/sis a)nqrw/pwn h)=|, Tac. Hist. iv. 74 vitia erunt, donec homines. For other passages expressing the same sentiment, see notes of Pp. and Bl. Steup thinks the simple gigno/mena with ai)ei\ e)so/mena kte(. strange, and suggests that e)so/mena may be an interpolation, comparing iv. 132. 2 boulo/menoi me
 kai\ ai)ei/, paresthko\s kte(.—12. tw=n a)nqrw/pwn: so with two Mss. (Vat. and H.) for a)nqrw/pwn of the rest. Cf. i. 20. 2; 77. 15; 140. 2; ii. 61. 19, etc. But the art. is wanting in i. 41. 11; iv. 97. 13; v. 111. 12, and even in the imitation of Dio C. just quoted.—13.

ma=llon: in a higher degree, referring to xalepa/. Supply gigno/mena. For adv. and adj. (h(suxai/tera) thus co-ord. as preds. to verb, see on c. 4. 4. Cf. Xen. Anab. iv. 7. 23 e)peidh\ de\ boh\ plei/wn te e)gi/gneto kai\ e)ggu/teron.— kai\ h(suxai/tera: for kai/, cf. iv. 63. 10
to\n eu)= kai\ kakw=s drw=nta.—toi=s ei)/desi: in their manifestations.—
dihllagme/na: pass. only here in Thuc. Bl. cites Dion. H. xxiii. 17 tai=s fwnai=s au)tw=n dihllagme/nais. for the act. in same sense, see on c. 10. 5.—14.
w(s: according as. Cf. c. 45. 18.—
tw=n cuntuxiw=n: of conditions of life, circumstances, as in c. 45. 18.—

e)fistw=ntai: present themselves, occur. Schol. pi/ptwsi. Cf. Soph. O. R. 776 pri/n moi tu/xh toia/d) e)pe/sth, Eur. Hipp. 819 w tu/xa, w(/s moi barei=a kai\ do/mois e)pesta/qhs, Med. 331 o(/pws a)\n parastw=sin tu/xai.—e)n me\n ga\r ei)rh/nh| kte(.: in proof of the asserted influence of changed circumstances.—15.
a)gaqoi=s pra/gmasin: rebus secundis; the phrase is prob. not found elsewhere.—16.
ta\s gnw/mas: convictions, as in i. 140. 4. See Introd. to Book I. p. 32.—
e)s a)kousi/ous a)na/gkas pi/ptein: “to fall under the dominion of imperious necessities, in which free choice is impossible.” Cf. l. 18 bi/aios dida/skalos, and see on i. 84. 24.—17.
u(felw/n: see on c. 13. 32.—

th\n eu)pori/an tou= kaq) h(me/ran: the comfortable provision of daily life. As tou= kaq) h(me/ran is unusual for tw=n kaq) h(me/ran, Kr. would insert, with the Schol., bi/ou before bi/aios.—18. bi/aios dida/skalos: Bl. compares, for the sentiment, Theophyl. Hist. i. 15 (p. 63 Bk.) o( po/lemos . . . tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn kakw=n a)rxhge/ths kai\ dida/skalos au)todi/daktos.—pro\s ta\ paro/nta: instead of the dat. Cf. viii. 57. 11 e)panisou=n tou\s *(/ellhnas pro\s a)llh/lous. Cf. i. 140. 4; vi. 34. 47.—19.

ta\s o)rga/s: dispositions, the old, chiefly poetic sense. Schol. nu=n o)rga\s ta\s gnw/mas kai\ tou\s tro/pous e)ka/lesen. Cf. i. 130. 11; 140. 3; viii. 83. 16; Hdt. iii. 131. 3; vi. 128. 5; Theog. 963. See Diener, De Serm. Thuc. p. 15 ff.; C. F. Smith, Proc. Amer. Phil. Assoc. xxii. p. xix.

e)stasi/aze/ te ou)=n kte(.: ou(=n resumptive and te correl. to following kai/. Therefore both the cities were disturbed by factions, and those which revolted later, through hearing of what had been done before, went much further still in the extravagance of their revolutionary spirit, both in the overingenuity of their enterprises and the strangeness of their revenges. With the sentiment, cf. Eur. Hipp. 939 o( d' u(/steros tou= pro/sqen ei)s u(perbolh\n panou=rgos e)/stai.—e)stasi/aze ta\ tw=n po/lewn: cf. Dem. xix. 320 e)stasi/aze ta\ tw=n *qettalw=n. ta\ tw=n po/lewn is a periphrasis for ai( po/leis. See on c. 59. 7. Steup would have expected here e)stasi/aze ta\ tw=n po/lewn tw=n pollw=n, or e)stasi/aze ta\ tw=n po/lewn e)pi\ polu/ (cf. l. 2 u(/stero/n ge kai\ pa=n w(s ei)pei=n to\ *(ellhniko\n e)kinh/qh). Hampke conjec
tured (Ztschr. f. d. Gymnasialw. xxxii. p. 396 f.) ta\ tw=n pollw=n.—20. ta\ e)fusteri/zonta/ nou: ai( po/leis ai( u(/steron tw=n a)/llwn stasia/zousai, Schol.— 21.
polu/: Schol. kata\ polu/. Cf. Xen. Anab. iii. 4. 33 polu\ perih=san. Kr. Spr. 48, 15, 13. For the text, see App. —22.
ta\s dianoi/as: see Introd. to Book I. p. 32.—
peritexnh/sei: kakourgi/a|, perinoi/a|, Schol. Only here in Thuc.; elsewhere only in Dio C. (xlvi. 19; liii. 11). See on c. 43. 9.—23.
a)topi/a|: tw=| a)h/qei, th=| deino/thti, Schol.

a)ci/wsin: value, or generally received meaning; the objective meaning, as opp. to th=| dikaiw/sei, subjective interpretation. This meaning of a)ci/wsis seems to be rare. Bl. cites Dion. H. Ant. vi. 73 th\n a)ci/wsin tw=n dikai/wn a)nastre/fontes, Heliod. Aeth. viii. 4 h( tw=n o)noma/twn a)ci/wsis.—24. e)s ta\ e)/rga: in relation to things, belonging to a)ci/wsin. o)no/mata and e)/rga in the same relation also vi. 78. 19.—

th=| dikaiw/sei: “as they thought fit.” th=| e(autw=n dikai/a| kri/sei, Schol. The noun is Thucydidean (i. 141. 6; iv. 86. 21; v. 17. 11). See on i. 141. 6. As to Thuc.'s fondness for verbal nouns in -sis, see on c. 23. 27.—25.

e)nomi/sqh: single characteristic examples are expressed by (empirical) aors. (cf. prosete/qh in l. 28; e)ge/neto, l. 37); general conduct by impfs. (cf. e)ph|nei=to in l. 35; e)kratu/nonto, l. 40, etc.—

file/tairos: i.e. ready to sacrifice one's self for one's friends; the political signifi-cation of e(tai=roi, as it appears below in e(tairi/a and e(tairiko/n, being esp. prominent. Found only here in Thuc. —26.
eu)preph/s: fair-sceming. Cf. c. 11. 10; 38. 12; i. 39. 6.—

to\ de\ sw=fron tou= a)na/ndrou pro/sxhma: cf. Plato Rep. 560 d swfrosiu/nhn a)nandri/an kalou=nte/s te kai\ prophlaki/zontes.—27. kai\ to\ . . . a)rgo/n: for the sentiment, cf. Eur. Oed. (frg. 556) po/tera gene/sqai dh=ta xrhsimw/teron suneto\n a)/tolmon h)\ qrasu/n te ka)maqh=;—e)pi\ pa=n a)rgo/n: cf. vii. 67. 18 a)rgo/terai e)s to\ dra=n ti.—to\ d' e)mplh/ktws o)cu\ a)ndro\s moi/ra| prosete/qh: inconsiderate rashness was held to be the part of a man. For e)mplh/ktws, cf. Soph. Aj. 1358; Plato Gorg. 482 a. a)ndro\s moi/ra| proseti/qh—e)n a)ndro\s moi/ra| (or e)n me/rei, Dem. ii. 14; iii. 31) e)ti/qh.—28. a)sfalei/a| de\ to\ e)pibouleu/sasqai . . . eu)/logos: prudent reflcrion a specious pretext for yielding, lit. in security
to take further thought, a specious pretext for turning away. So St. explains; but see App. e)nomi/sqh is to be supplied here, as well as with the following predicates (pisto/s and u(/poptos). See on c. 107. 25. a)sfalei/a| adv., as in c. 56. 20. e)pibouleu/sasqai, further deliberate, reflect. e)pi- as in e)pignw=nai, c. 57. 6; i. 70. 8; ii. 65. 48. See on e)pitalaipwrei=n, i. 123. 3. a)potroph/ not act., as in c. 45. 31, but belonging rather to the mid. a)potre/pesqai (ii. 40. 17; iv. 59. 7; viii. 10. 10), as a)postrofh/ (iv. 76. 25) to a)postre/fesqai, e)pagwgh/ (l. 9; 100. 6) to e)pa/gesqai, a)pokomidh/ (i. 137. 26) to a)pokomi/zesqai, cunallagh/ (l. 45) to cunalla/ssesqai. (St.)

o( me
 xalepai/nwn pisto\s ai)ei/: the hot-headed man was always trusted. Rauchenstein (Philol. xxxv. p. 590) conjectures o( me
 pa/nt) e)painw=n, Hampke ibid. p. 398 o( me
 xalepa\ e)painw=n.—31. e)pibouleu/sas tuxw/n: e)pibouleu/sas is subord. to tuxw/n (for which St. and Widmann read tuxw/n te, after Dion. H. p. 889), if one had succeeded in any plot. For the paronomasia, e)pibouleu/sas, probouleu/sas, see on c. 39. 10; i. 33. 26.—

u(ponoh/sas e)/ti deino/teros: if any one had suspected a plot (he was considered) still more clever. tis is understood with u(ponoh/sas as with probouleu/sas in the next line. deino/teros=cunetw/teros.— 32. au)tw=n: i.e. tou= te e)pibouleu/ein kai\ u(ponoei=n.—33. th=s te e(tairi/as dialuth\s kte(.: sc. because he took no part in the plots of his faction against their opponents.—

e)kpeplhgme/nos: smitten with fear of, pass. with acc. as in v. 10. 30; vi. 11. 14; 33. 16. All other examples of this const. seem to be Ionic or Tragic. Cf. Hdt. ix. 82. 11; Soph. Aj. 33; El. 1045; Phil. 1026. See Proc. Amer. Phil. Assoc. xxii. p. xviii.—34.
a(plw=s te: Haase's conjecture (Lucubr. p. 75) for a(plw=s de/. See on c. 40. 16; iv. 64. 11; vi. 37. 18.—
to\n me/llonta kako/n ti dra=n: refers, as to\n mh\ dianoou/menon in the next clause, to an associate, not an opponent.—35.

o( e)pikeleu/sas to\n mh\ dianoou/menon: with both parties. kako/n ti dra=n is understood. Kr. Spr. 55, 4, 11. e)pikeleu/sas, as Xen. Cyrop. iii. 3. 41, a strengthened keleu/sas, e)pi- having the same force as in e)pibouleu/sasqai, Cf. e)pidiw/kein, c. 33. 14; e)pixrh=sqai, i. 41. 4.

to\ cuggene\s . . . e)ge/neto: the tie of blood was weaker than that of party.
tou= e(tairikou=, as in viii. 48. 18.—37.

dia\ to\ e(toimo/teron ei)=nai: (sc. to\ e(tairiko/n) i.e. because restrained by no scruples. On account of the harshness of the ellipsis, Badham conjectured, and v. H. writes, a)netoimo/teron. If any change is to be made, Steup would rather insert to\ e(tairiko/n after e(toimo/teron.—38. ou) ga\r . . . pleoneci/a|: for such associations were not formed in accordance with the established laws for the (public) good, but contrary to the established laws for private advantage.—

w)feli/a|: correctly restored by St., for w)feli/as of the Mss., since it is evidently opp. to pleoneci/a|, as meta\ tw=n keime/nwn no/mwn to para\ tou\s kaqestw=tas. The emendation is supported not only by Valla's rendering of the passage, non enim huiusmodi conventus per leges ob utilitatem, sed contra leges ob avaritiam fiebant, but by Dion. H.'s paraphrase (p. 891), ou) ga\r e)pi\ tai=s kata\ no/mon w)feli/ais ai( tw=n e(tairiw=n e)gi/gnonto su/nodoi, a)ll) e)pi\ tw=| para\ tou\s no/mous ti pleonektei=n. w)feli/a| and pleoneci/a| are dats. of purpose. See on — 39.

cu/nodoi: Schol. susta/seis kai\ e(tairi/ai. Cf. Plut. Ages. 32 e)mhnu/qh sunwmosi/a kai\ su/nodos a)ndrw=n *spartiatw=n e)pi\ pra/gmasi newte/rois ei)s oi)ki/an kru/fa sunerxome/nwn.—40. e)s sfa=s au)tou/s: i.e. e)s a)llh/lous. G. 996; H. 686 b.—
ou) tw=| qei/w| no/mw|: on the decay of awe of the divine as a symptom of demoralization in society, see Introd. to Book I. p. 28.—
e)kratu/nonto: see on c. 18. 7.

a)po\ tw=n e)nanti/wn . . . gennaio/thti: i.e. fair words (here definite proposals) were not relied on; they were accepted, if the momentary superiority of opponents (ei) prou/xoien, sc. oi( e)nanti/oi) made this necessary, but only guardedly, not in a spirit of generous confidence. For a)po/ with the pass., see on c. 36. 24. Steup considers the subj. of prou/xoien to be the same as that of e)nede/xonto, comparing c. 83. 6 krei/ssous de\ o)/ntes kte(. —42. e)/rgwn fulakh=|: cf. tw=n e)/rgwn th=s e)pimelei/as, c. 46. 19; e)/rgw| fulassome/nh, vi. 40. 17.—43.
gennaio/thti: like to\ gennai=on, c. 83. 2.—

a)ntitimwrh/sasqai: though the simple verb expresses the idea of retaliation, this is intensified by a)nti-.—45. cunallagh=s: so far removed from o(/rkoi
that the connexion is rather loose, with a view to reconciliation.—
pro\s to\ a)/poron: in view of their perplexity; more expressive than kata/ ti a)/poron, i. 136. 6. pro/s as in pro\s to\ paro/n, c. 40. 35; ii. 22. 1; v. 9. 14.—
e(kate/rw| dido/menoi: for the dat. of agent with pass., see on c. 64. 15.—46.

ou)k e)xo/ntwn: without expressed subj. as in l. 6 above, but au)tw=n is easily supplied from e(kate/rw|, as they had no power from any other source. Hampke (ibid. p. 400) refers ou)k e)xo/ntwn to o(/rkoi, having authority for no other reason, sc. than their present helplessness. Steup, not satisfied with any interpretation that has been offered, suggests that the words have crept into the text from a marginal explanation of pro\s to\ a)/poron e(kate/rw| dido/menoi.—47. e)n tw=| paratuxo/nti: as in v. 38. 3, “in any event that might chance.” para- with the force of ai)ei/, of what presents itself from time to time; hence the sing. Cf. i. 122. 6 pro\s to\ paratugxa/non.—o( fqa/sas qarsh=sai: he who first made bold, i.e. without the help of oaths. As Thuc. nowhere else construes the inf. with fqa/nein, qarsh/sas was rather to be expected. Cf. c. 23. 21; 83. 11; 89. 11; 112. 5; ii. 91. 5; iv. 4. 11; v. 3. 5, 8; 10. 13; vi. 61. 11; 97. 11; vii. 6. 16; 42. 19; viii. 12. 3; 92. 3. The const. with inf. is rare in Attic, more freq. in late writers. Kr. Spr. 56, 5, 5. The inf. is doubtless used here to avoid the concurrence of two partics.—
a)/frakton: (sc. to\n e)nanti/on) unguarded, off his guard. Cf. c. 39. 8; vi. 33. 14.—48.

dia\ th\n pi/stin: i.e. because his enemy relied on the oath, and so was a)/fraktos.—a)po\ tou= profanou=s: adv., as in i. 35. 17; 66. 7; ii. 93. 15; v. 9. 13. The phrase seems to be peculiar to Thuc. Cf. e)k tou= profanou=s, c. 43. 10; 109. 10. —49.

kai\ to/ te a)sfale\s e)logi/zeto . . . prosela/mbane: and he reckoned not only the safety (of such a course), but also that proving superior by means of deceit he was winning besides the prize of shrewdness. logi/zesqai as in i. 76. 13; ii. 89. 24.—50.

cune/sews a)gw/nisma: cf. c. 37. 27 cune/sews a)gw/n. —r(a=|on d' oi( polloi\ . . . a)gaqoi/: “men in general, when dishonest, more easily gain credit for eleverness, than, when simple, for goodness.” r(a=|on ke/klhntai, lit. are more readily called. This is the view of Arn., Jow., and St. But Cl. and Steup follow Kr. in rendering, prefer to be called, which makes tw=| me\n ai)sxi/nontai . . . a)ga/llontai a mere repetition. The pf. ke/klhntai as in ii. 37. 4; v. 9. 35. GMT. 49 a; H. 849. Steup brackets o)/ntes, on the ground that predicates follow kalei=sqai without w)/n, and sees in it a marginal explanation of some one who mistook kakou=rgoi as equiv. to kakou=rgoi o)/ntes.
—51.
kakou=rgoi o)/ntes de/cioi . . . a)maqei=s a)gaqoi/: observe the chiasmus.— 52.

tw=| me\n . . . a)ga/llontai: chiastic with regard to the preceding. “They are ashamed of simple goodness, but glory in clever dishonesty.” Jow. Cf. Plut. de Garrul. 4 h(/dio/n ge toi=s ponhroi=s o(milou=sin e)pideci/ois, h)\ xrhstoi=s a)dole/sxais. For the order e)pi\ de\ tw=|, see on c. 61. 6.

ai)/tion: used as pred. subst., as often, without regard to gender of subj. See on i. 11. l. G. 925; H. 617. Madvig (Adv. i. p. 317) and Hampke (ibid. p. 400 f.) would bracket ai<*>on, Hude (p. 113 sq.) both ai)/tion and h(. H. Weil (Rev. de Philol. N. S. ii. p. 92) conjectures pa/ntwn d' au)tw=n a)rxh\ h( li/an pleoneci/a kai\ filotimi/a.—a)rxh/: Schol. h( e)piqumi/a tou= bou/lesqai a)/rxein. Cf. gloria=gloriac cupiditas. As to the order, a)rxh\ h( dia\ pleoneci/an, cf. i. 41. 15 filoniki/as e(/neka th=s au)ti/ka, 75. 1 proqumi/as e(/neka th=s to/te, 77. 9 duna/mei th=| dia\ th\n a)rxh/n.—54. e)k d' au)tw=n: i.e. th=s pleoneci/as kai\ filotimi/as.—kai\ e)s to\ filonikei=n kaqistame/nwn: with indef. pers. subj. (as in l. 6). When men were once embarked in strife.—55.
to\ pro/qumon: sc. h)=n, sprang zealous party-spirit.—
oi( ga\r . . . prosta/ntes: aor., those who had become leaders in the cities.—
met) o)no/matos eu)prepou=s: Sallust's (Cat. 38) honestis nominibus.—56.

plh/qous te . . . protimh/sei: explanation of met) o)no/matos . . . eu)prepou=s, the dat. protimh/sei being a variation of meta/ with the gen. The one party laid stress on the designation plh/qous i)sonomi/a politikh/ (the political equality of the many), rather than the objectionable dhmokrati/a,—the other on a)ristokrati/a sw/frwn (a moderate aristoeracy), rather than the hated o)li garxi/a. On the i)sonomi/a politikh/, see Schoemann. Antiq. Jur. p. 95; Niebuhr, Hist. of Rome, i. p. 315.— 57.
a)ristokrati/as sw/fronos: the o)li/goi were given to boasting of their swfrosu/nh. Cf. c. 65. 16; viii. 53. 21; 64. 21.—

ta\ me\n koina\ . . . e)poiou=nto: in name devoted to the public interests they made them prizes (for which they strove). ta\ koina/, as in i. 120. 4; 141. 31, obj. of qerapeu/ontes, as well as of a)/qla e)poiou=nto.— 59. a)gwnizo/menoi . . . mei/zous: for the sentiment, cf. Sall. Jug. 42. 4.—

perigi/gnesqai: for the inf. dependent on
a)gwnizo/menoi, see on c. 38. 10.—60.
e)pech=|san ta\s timwri/as: pursued revenges. Cf. c. 40. 28; v. 100. 5. Hampke's conjecture (ibid. p. 401 f.) e)pech/negkan, increased, seems unnecessary.—

e)/ti mei/zous: pred., still greater, sc. than the deino/tata tolmh/mata.— ou) me/xri . . . protiqe/ntes: not stretching their revenges up to the limits of right and the advantage of the state, i.e. not setting this limit to them. So Cl. explains, retaining the Vulg. But the signification of protiqe/nai which he gives seems to be without parallel. The ordinary meaning of protiqe/ntes, when referring to punishments, i.e. proponentes, does not suit the verb e)pech=|san. The reading prostiqe/ntes (Dion. H.) though slightly supported, is adopted by Kr., St., and Bm., and gives the best sense, inflicting punishments (or revenges). Cf. c. 39. 38.—62.
e)s de\ to\ e(kate/rois pou ai)ei\ h(donh\n e)/xon o(ri/zontes: limiting them according to what at any time afforded pleasure to either party. e)/xon = pare/xon. See on c. 53. 12; i. 97. 13.—63.

meta\ yh/fou a)di/kou katagnw/sews: katayhfizo/menoi a)di/kws, Schol. For the order of the words, cf. ii. 39. 20 meta\ no/mwn to\ plei=on h)\ tro/pwn a)ndrei/as. See on c. 23. 27; 46. 18. yh/fou a)di/kou is subjective (not as c. 16. 2 a)sqenei/as obj.) gen. Cf. i. 87. 17 h( diagnw/mh au(/th th=s e)kklhsi/as. A fraudulent count is prob. not meant, but a vote influenced by hate and thirst for revenge.—
h)\ xeiri\ ktw/menoi to\ kratei=n: the combination of a prepositional phrase with a partic. const. is freq. Cf. c. 25. 9; 42. 23; i. 39. 2; ii. 89. 22.—
xeiri/: by force, only here. Cf. ii. 13. 19 dia\ xeiro\s e)/xein.—64. e(toi=moi h)=san: were ready, i.e. unscrupulous as to the means employed (h)\ meta\ yh/fou a)di/kou katagnw/sews h)\ xeiri/).—
th\n au)ti/ka filoniki/an: also i. 41. 15.—
e)kpimpla/nai: explere, as a)poplh=sai, vii. 68. 5.—65.

w(/ste . . . a)/meinon h)/kouon: eu)prepei/a| de\ lo/gou, as antithesis to eu)sebei/a| me/n, is the ground of a)/meinon h)/kouon. “On piety neither side placed any value, but by fair pretences those had a better name who succeeded in accomplishing some odious purpose.” Many editors construe eu)prepei/a| lo/gou with the rel. clause (see on c. 39. 5; i. 5. 11).—
e)no/mizon: = e)xrw=nto, with dat. also i. 77. 26; ii. 38. 3; Hdt. ii. 50. 14. Kühn. 425, 5.—66.
e)pifqo/nws: as in i. 75. 3; Xen. Cyrop. vii. 5. 37.—

a)/meinon h)/kouon: i.e. were more praised
for plausibility of speech than for piety.—67.

ta\ me/sa tw=n politw=n: oi( mhdete/rw| me/rei prostiqe/menoi, Schol. Cf. viii. 75. 4 oi( dia\ me/sou, iv. 83. 9 e(toi=mos w)\n *brasi/da| me/sw| dikasth=| e)pitre/pein, Dio C. xliv. 29 kai\ oi(/tw kai\ ta\ me/sa tw=n politw=n stasia/zein para/getai.— 68. o(/ti ou) cunhgwni/zonto: i.e. because they did not furnish the aid demanded.—
fqo/nw| tou= periei=nai: = o(/ti e)fqonou=nto dia\ to\ periei=nai. Kr. compares Eur. I. T. 352 oi( dustuxei=s ga\r toi=sin eu)tuxeste/rois au)toi\ kakw=s pra/cantes ou) fronou=sin eu)=. —
diefqei/ronto: for the pl. verb with neut. pl. subj., see G. 899, 2; H. 604 a; Kr. Spr. 63, 2, 1; Kühn. 365 a. Cf. iv. 88. 6; vii. 57. 64.
pa=sa i)de/a: see on c. 81. 22. —

kakotropi/as: of wickedness, i.e. baseness of the whole mode of thought and conduct (i.e. tro/poi, ii. 36. 16; 39. 21; 41. 7). The word occurs elsewhere only in Dio C., Jos., and other late writers.—2.
tw=| *(ellhnikw=|: cf. c. 82. 3.—

kai\ to\ eu)hqe\s . . . h)fani/sqh: and simplicity, of which nobility partakes most largely, was laughed at and disappeared. to\ eu)hqe/s as eu)h/qeia, c. 45. 30. This passage is cited by grammarians (Photius, Thomas Mag., Moeris) as furnishing a characteristic example of the original meaning of the word.—

to\ gennai=on: cf. c. 82. 43 gennaio/thti.—3. plei=ston mete/xei: cf. i. 84. 12 ai)dw\s swfrosu/nhs ple<*>ton mete/xei.—to\ de\ a)ntiteta/xqai . . . dih/negken: but to be in mind distrustfully arrayed against each other prevailed far and wide. Cf. c. 82. 41 ff.—
a)ntiteta/xqai: as in war, v. 55. 7.— 4.
dih/negke: Schol. krei=tton e)ge/neto.

ou) ga\r h)=n . . . fobero/s: “for there was no word binding enough, no oath terrible enough, to bring about an adjustment.” Lit. for there was, that could bring about an adjustment, neither binding word nor fearful oath. o( dialu/swn (qui dirimeret) is construed by most editt. as pred. (see Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 4). But Steup objects that the implication would then be, that there was not indeed lo/gos e)xnro/s or o(/rlos fobero/s, but something else, o( dialu/swn. He makes therefore diali/swn attrib., and the complete subj. o( dialu/swn . . . fobero/s. Cf. ii. 62. 13 ou)k e)/stin o(/stis ou)/te basileu\s kwlu/sei ou)/te a)/llo ou)de\n e)/qnos.—
6.

krei/ssous de\ o)/ntes . . . ma=llon proesko/poun h)\ kte(.: all men when stronger (than their enemies), by consideration of the hopelessness of security (in word and oath), rather made provision not to suffer, than were able to trust others. This seems to be the meaning of this much discussed passage. krei/ssous o)/ntes = ei) prou/xoien, c. 82. 42. e)s, “with reference to.” St.'s explanation (Rh. Mus. xv. p. 475), adopted by Cl., is: “all men found more strength in calculations providing against the unexpected than in pledges of security (such as promises and oaths), and looked rather to suffering no ill, than were able to trust others.” With this view, tou= bebai/ou, depending on krei/ssous, = h)\ tw=| bebai/w|. Cf. vi. 1. 1 mei/zoni paraskeuh=| th=s meta\ *la/xhtos, and Xen. Anab. ii. 5. 13. Dobree supplies tou= lo/gou kai\ tou= o(/rkou with krei/ssous (cf. c. 84. 12 krei/sswn tou= dikai/ou), which Kr. rightly thinks harsh. The explanation of the Schol. is, r(e/pontes de\ oi( a)/nqrwpoi toi=s logismoi=s pro\s to\ mh\ e)lpi/zein tina\ pi/stin kai\ bebaio/thta (“the thoughts of all men tended to despair of security”), which Bl., Jow., and Hude prefer. Dio C.'s imitation of the passage (frg. 49) is viz. krei/ttous e)s to\ a)fane\s tou= prodh/lou (i.e. h)\ e)s to\ pro/dhlon) tw=| logismw=| gigno/menoi.
oi( faulo/teroi gnw/mhn: those inferior in intellect. Cf. c. 37. 17.—
w(s ta\ plei/w: = w(s e)pi\ to\ plei=on, c. 37. 18.—9.

to\ e)ndee/s: Schol. th\n e)/lleiyin th=s gnw/mhs.—10. mh\ . . . fqa/swsi proepibouleuo/menoi: epexegetical explanation of to/ te au(tw=n e)ndee\s kte(.— 11. e)k tou= polutro/pou au)tw=n: in consequence of their versatility. e)k as in i. 2. 17; 75. 7. to\ polu/tropon as polutropi/h, Hdt. ii. 121. e 12. Cf. polu/tropos, Hom. a 1. As noun not found elsewhere. au)tw=n, i.e. tw=n e)nanti/wn. —fqa/swsi proepibouleuo/menoi: the pres. partic. with fqa/nein as in vi. 99. 12, elsewhere in Thuc. always the aor. partic. (c. 23. 21; 89. 11; 112. 5; ii. 91. 5; iv. 4. 11; 104. 20; v. 3. 5; 10. 13; vi. 61. 11; 97. 11; 101. 34; vii. 6. 16; 23. 3; 25. 45; 42. 19; viii. 12. 3; 17. 7; 95. 20; 100. 3), except possibly viii. 92. 4, where Vat. has the pf. See Gildersleeve, Amer. J. of Ph. xii. p. 76.

oi( de/: their opponents, already characterized as oi( cunetw/teroi.—13. katafronou=ntes: in causal relation to a)/fraktoi, arrogantly presuming. Schol. dia\ katafro/nhsin pepoiqo/tes.
On katafronou=ntes depend both ka)
 proaisqe/sqai and e)/rgw| ou)de
 dei=n lamba/nein. Kr. Spr. 65, 11, 7; Kühn. 473, 1. Cf. Hdt. i. 66. 6 katafronh/santes *)arka/dwn kre/ssones ei)=nai, Xen. Hell. iv. 5. 12 katefro/noun dia\ ta\s e)/mprosqen tu/xas mhde/na a)
 e)pixeirh=sai sfi/sin.—proaisqe/sqai: Cl. adopted from Vat. and Aug. proai/sqesqai (as pres.). But since the only mark of distinction from the aor. is the accent, as to which the better Mss. agree hardly anywhere, it is best to consider this aor. here, as well as in ii. 93. 17; v. 26. 29; vi. 40. 9; vii. 75. 8. See Steup, App. on ii. 93. 17; St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 66.—14.
a)/fraktoi: see on c. 82. 47.—

ma=llon: i.e. in greater num bers. Cf. ii. 7. 15. Junghahn (N. Jahrbb. exix. p. 367 f.) unnecessarily objects to the statement in § 3, 4 that in the sta/seis inferior intellects generally got the better of the cleverer sort. Steup infers from the striking transitions and repetitions of c. 82 and 83 (cf. e.g. c. 83. § 1 f. with c. 82. § 7), that these two chapters are composed of reflexions written at several different times.
Reflexions of a later moralist on the contents of the two preceding chapters. (As to the authenticity of the chapter, see App.)
d) ou)=n: acc. to Thuc.'s usage, resumptive after a digression. See on i. 3. 19.—
au)tw=n: referring with emphasis to the ills described in the two preceding chapters, or perhaps, as Arn. explains, to ta\ e)/rga in c. 83. 12. See on i. 1. 10.—
proetolmh/qh: cf. c. 82. 2 e)n toi=s prw/th e)ge/neto. The word is not found elsewhere except in late authors. Cf. Dio C. xlvii. 4; Herodian vi. 7. See Steph. Thes. s.v. —2.

kai\ o(po/sa kte(.: explanatory of ta\ polla/, both whatsoever—. ‘The three principal causes of the crimes committed in civil disturbances: 1st, the desire of vengeance for oppression and insolence in the ruling party: 2nd, the thirst of plunder, which urges the needy to covet the property of the rich; 3rd, the mere bitterness of party spirit, which men contract by being habitually opposed to one another.’ Arn. The const. is, o(po/sa . . . dra/seian . . . gignw/skoien . . . e)pe/lqoien. After kai\ o(po/sa u(/brei the natural const. would have been kai\ o(po/sa peni/as, but the insertion of me/n causes the slight change.—

u(/brei me\n . . . parasxo/ntwn: “ruled more with insolence than with moderation by those who had now afforded them opportunity for revenge.” With th\n timwri/an paras<*>ei=n, cf. di/khn parasxei=n, Hes. Op. 710; Eur. Andr. 1107; Phoen.
1654.—4.

dra/seian: the opt. may be explained as that of general rel. cond. (all that men would naturally have done who). GMT. 532; H. 914, B 2. Cf. vii. 71. 22 a)/lla o(/sa e)n mega/lw| kindu/nw| me/ga strato/pedon polueidh= a)nagka/zoito fqe/ggesqai. If this explanation be adopted, the a)/n of l. 5 must be construed not with gignw/skoien, but with the partic. e)piqumou=ntes, forming with it a sort of parenthesis, as Kr. explains, ma/lista d' a)\n dia\ pa/qous e)pequ/moun ta\ tw=n pe/las e)/xein, and who would be above all men passionately covetous of their neighbour's goods. Or a)/n may be taken with gignw/skoien and supplied with dra/seian and e)pe/lqoien. It might indeed have easily dropped out after dra/seian.—a)pallacei/ontes: found only here and i. 95. 24.—5.

dia\ pa/qous: in passion, a use of the word which seems not to occur elsewhere before Aristotle. Nor does it seem appropriate to the context. Why should avarice of all the desires be esp. mentioned as passionate? For the const., cf. di) o)rgh=s, viii. 43. 24.—6.
gignw/skoien: determine on, purpose. Cf. i. 70. 7, 27.—
oi(/ te: the particle introduces, acc. to Thuc.'s usage, the third member. —7.

a)po\ i)/sou de\ ma/lista e)pio/ntes: i.e. ‘those who enter into revolution on an equality with their adversaries —not as oppressed men thirsting for vengeance, nor as needy men desiring plunder—and whose cruelties are owing merely to the fury of party spirit which they acquire in the course of the contest.’ Arn.—

a)paideusi/a| o)rgh=s plei=ston e)kfero/menoi: carried away for the most part by the ungovernableness of their passions. Cf. Eur. (apud Stob. Flor. 20. 12) po/ll) e)/stin o)rgh=s e)c a)paideu/tou kaka/, Jos. Antiq. xvii. 11. 3 a)paideusi/a| tou= pei/qesqai toi=s no/mois, xix. 2. 2 a)pai/deuton th\n o)rgh\n e)pafiei/s. See on a)paideusi/a gnw/mhs, c. 42. 6.
e)s to\n kairo\n tou=ton: at this crisis. For similar use of e)s, cf. iv. 89. 6; vi. 16. 33. Or can the sense be, to this point, degree?—10.

kai\ tw=n no/mwn krath/sasa: having got a complete mastery over the laws, i.e. no longer regarding them. For partics. in different cases thus co-ord., see on c. 66. 12; i. 65. 2. Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2.—11.

ei)wqui=a kai\ para\ tou\s no/mous a)dikei=n: cf. Dio C. lii. 34. 6 h( fu/sis kai\ para\ to
 no/mon pollou\s a(marta/nein e)ca/gei, 34. 7 o( no/mos . . . ou) du/na-
tai th=s fu/sews a)ei\ kratei=n.—a)sme/nh e)dh/lwsen . . . tou= dikai/ou: took delight in showing that its passions were ungovernable, that it was stronger than justice. Cf. c. 45. § 7. Bl. cites, as imitations of this passage, Jos. Antiq. xvii. 8. 1 (of Herod) a)nh w)mo\s me
 ei)s pa/ntas o(moi/ws, kai\ o)rgh=s me
 h(/sswn, krei/sswn de\ tou= dikai/ou, xix. 2. 2 krei/sswn me
 tou= dikai/ou geno/menos, h(/sswn de\ tou= kat) i)di/an h(donh/n, and xviii. 8. 8. But, as St. says, this imitation is uncertain, since such use of krei/sswn is freq.— 13.

polemi/a de\ tou= prou/xontos: cf. ii. 35. 16 tw=| d' u(perba/llonti au)tw=n fqonou=ntes h)/dh kai\ a)pistou=sin, Hdt. vii. 236. 7 tou= te eu)tuxe/ein fqone/ousi kai\ to\ kre/sson stuge/ousi.—14. prouti/qesan: for the const., see on c. 39. 20.— 15.

e)n w(=| . . . to\ fqonei=n: when (lit. in a case where) envy had not its fatal power. e)n w=| mh/ = ei) mh\ e)n tou/tw|. Cl. renders, “in which case envy would have had not its fatal effect.” But with this view, though the omission of a)/n would give no trouble (cf. vi. 55. 18; viii. 86. 22), it requires a strained interpretation to justify mh/.

a)ciou=si/ te kte(.: Arn. well expresses the sense, “Men in their violence set the example of doing away with those common laws of humanity which all parties alike might have appealed to in their adversity, and by their own previous conduct put themselves out of the pale of these laws, when they themselves might have occasion to solicit their protection.” a)ciou=si, presume, as in i. 42. 2; 74. 12; iv. 66. 9; vii. 63. 21.—17.

e)lpi\s u(pokei=tai: cf. vi. 87. 18 u(pei=nai e)lpi/da, Dem. xix. 24 pa/nta [ta)=ll)] oi)=mai to/te deu/ter) h)=n tw=n u(pokeime/nwn prosdokiw=n kai\ tw=n e)lpi/dwn.—sfalei=si: in case they should be unfortunate.—18.
au)tou/s: after preceding dat. G. 928, 1; H. 941; Kühn. 475, 2 a. See on i. 31. 10.—19.
u(polei/pesqai: mid., to let them stand, i.e. the laws.—
ei)/ pote a)/ra: if ever perchance.
Eurymedon leaves Corcyra. Those of the oligarchical party in Corcyra who had escaped establish themselves first on the mainland opposite, then on Mount Istone, and harass their opponents.

oi( kata\ th\n po/lin *kerkurai=oi:
opp. to oi( feu/gontes tw=n *kerkurai/wn in But since these fugitives were such as the result of the events described in c. 81, to which events also, in explanation of their existence, the parenthesis diesw/qhsan . . . e)s pentakosi/ous refers back, Steup suspects kata\ th\n po/lin to be an interpolation.—

toiau/tais o)rgai=s tai=s prw/tais: i.e. outbreaks of party passion. toiau/tais, pred. referring to c. 81. Cf. vi. 44. 1 tosau/th h( prw/th pro\s to\n po/lemon die/plei.—2. tai=s prw/tais: usually understood as contrasted with the cruelties described in iv. 46 ff. But Cl. and Jow. think it more natural to consider the words a repetition of c. 82. 2 e)n toi=s prw/th (i.e. h( sta/sis) e)ge/neto, supplying pasw=n. St. takes tai=s prw/tais as opp. to u(/steron in l. 4. But i(/steron prob. refers only to the departure of Eurymedon with his ships, after which the fugitives could make their venture. Besides, this seizure by the oligarchs of a point on the mainland does not come under the notion of the o)rgai/ above.—3.
a)pe/pleusan: sc. after remaining seven days, c. 81. 17.
diesw/qhsan: sc. nausi\ e)s th\n h)/peiron.—5. e)s pentakosi/ous: see on c. 20. 11.—6.
th=s pe/ran oi)kei/as gh=s: i.e. the territory belonging to Corcyra on the mainland opposite.— 7.
e)lh/|zonto: (not e)/lh|zon) with Bk. and most Mss., all of which have the mid. in i. 5. 15; 24. 14; v. 56. 12; 115. 7; and only in iv. 41. 8 all have the active. See on iv. 41. 8.—8.
kai\ limo\s i)sxuro\s kte(.: cf. iv. 2. 12. MüllerStrübing's objections to this statement are refuted by B. Schmidt, p. 80 f.
peri\ kaqo/dou: of fugitives, as in v. 16. 18; viii. 47. 3.—10.
ou)de\n au)toi=s e)pra/sseto: dat. of agent, as in ii. 101. 17. See on c. 64. 15. ou)de\n pra/ssesqai in this sense also v. 46. 31; 50. 26.—

u(/steron xro/nw|: denotes always a considerable interval. See on i. 8. 17. The conjectures of Köhler, Hermes xxvi. p. 45 ff., that the fugitives did not cross over to Corcyra till 425 B.C., and that in the winter of 426-25 they took part in the Amphilochian war, are very improbable. In the first case, Thuc. would hardly have mentioned the crossing over to the island until iv. 2; in the second, he could surely not have passed over
the matter in complete silence here, and still less in the detailed account of the Amphilochian war (c. 105 ff.). Köhler bases his assumption, that the 500 Corcyraeans belonged to those who were conquered by the Athenians in the Amphilochian war, forming part of the 3000 Ambracian hoplites of c. 105. § 1, on the very fragmentary remains of a popular decree, in which the word *kerkurai/wn occurs. But it is quite possible, of course, that in this decree *kerkurai/wn had a very different application from the one which Köhler assumes.—
ploi=a: i.e. transports, not warships. —11.
e)pikou/rous: see on c. 18. 3.— 12.
e(cako/sioi: compared with e)s pentakosi/ous, l. 5, this number seems rather small.—
oi( pa/ntes: in all. See on i. 60. 6; vii. 1. 31. Kr. Spr. 50, 11, 13.
a)po/gnoia: not found elsewhere. —
a)/llo ti h)/: as in v. 87. 2. After the negative a)po/gnoia there is the same ellipse of poiei=n as with ou)de\n a)/llo h)/, ii. 16. 10; iv. 14. 18; vii. 75. 25; viii. 5. 1. See on c. 39. 10.—

kratei=n th=s gh=s: the words th=s gh=s are bracketed by Kr., as borrowed from th=s gh=s e)kra/toun, l. 15, with the approval of B. Schmidt, p. 81, who thinks that Thuc. could not have used kratei=n th=s gh=s in two different senses in the same sentence. But th=s gh=s may be understood in both places of the open country as opp. to the po/lis. For the oligarchical Corcyraeans it sufficed for the time to establish themselves on the island and to get the upper hand in the open field; hence we need not think here, with the Schol., of the whole of Corcyra. kratei=n th=s gh=s occurs also in c. 6. 8; 18. 13; i. 111. 5; iv. 46. 6; vi. 23. 7; 37. 19; vii. 4. 31. Cf. also l. 6 above, and c. 115. 9 th=s gh=s au)tw=n e)kra/toun.—14. th\n *)istw/nhn: also iv. 46. 5. The situation is uncertain. See App.—

tei=xos e)noikodomhsa/menoi: Cf. iv. 46. 4 tou\s e)n tw=| o)/rei . . . kaqidrume/nous.—15. e)/fqeiron . . . kai\ . . . e)kra/toun: the impfs. represent the action as in progress. This state of affairs is to be regarded as lasting until the further events related in iv. 46. Cf. also iv. 2. § 3.
At the request of the Leontines the Athenians send to aid them against the Syracusans a fleet of twenty ships, which take their station at Rhegium.
e)s *sikeli/an: first fateful participation of Athens in Sicilian quarrels.—

*la/xhta: from this his first appearance, in constant activity (c. 90. 8; 103. 12; 115. 7; iv. 118. 45;
v. 19. 9; 24. 6; 43. 9) until his death at Mantinea 418 B.C. (cf. v. 61. 2; 74. 10). He is one of the speakers in Plato's Laches.—3.
*xaroia/dhn: killed in this campaign in Sicily, c. 90. 7.
ai( a)/llai *dwri/des po/leis: for particulars of these, as well as of the *xalkidikai\ po/leis (l. 9), cf. vi. 3-5.— 7.
pro\s th\n tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn . . . cummaxi/an: see on ii. 7. 9.—

to\ prw=ton a)rxome/nou tou= pole/mou: at the very beginning of the war, to be construed with e)ta/xqhsan. See on c. 63. 8. prw=ton is often joined with a)rxome/nou to emphasize the moment of beginning. See on i. 103. 16.—8.

ou) me/ntoi cunepole/mhsa/n ge: referring to pro\s th\n cummaxi/an e)ta/xqhsan. They had joined the alliance, but, in spite of the great things expected from them (ii. 7. § 2), had so far taken no active part in the war.—10.

*kama/rina: founded 599 B.C. by the Syracusans, who afterwards expelled the inhabitants for revolting. Later Hippocrates, the tyrant of Gela, having received the place as the ransom of some Syracusan captives, colonized it anew. But the inhabitants having been again driven out by Gelo, the city was colonized for the third time by the Geloans. See vi. 5. § 3.—
*surakosi/wn, *leonti/nwn: it is not necessary to understand cu/mmaxoi. Cf. v. 84. 13 ou)dete/rwn o)/ntes. —11. kata\ to\ cuggene/s: since both were Chalcidians. Cf. vi. 44. 19.
oi( tw=n *leonti/nwn cu/mmaxoi: including the Leontines themselves. At the head of this embassy was the celebrated rhetorician Gorgias. Diod. xii. 53; [Plato] Hipp. Maj. 282 b. See on c. 38. 31.—

kata/ te palaia\n cummaxi/an kte(.: belongs to pei/qousi pe/myai.—kata\ palaia\n cummaxi/an: in C. I. A. i. 33 (cf. Kirchhoff iv. p. 13) and iv. 33 a, there are fragments of treaties of alliance concluded under the archon Apseudes (433-32 B.C.) between Athens and the Rhegians and Leontines; probably there were still older treaties than these.—13.

*)/iwnes:
like the Athenians. Cf. iv. 61. 10; Strabo, p. 446 f.—15.
th=s me\n oi)keio/thtos profa/sei: on the pretext of relationship. Cf. iv. 61. 10; vi. 6. 5; 76. 10.—18.

pro/peira/n te poiou/menoi: the natural const. would have been pro/peira/n te poiei=sqai, but the sent, continues as if to\ d' a)lhqe\s ou)/te boulo/menoi had gone before. (St.) See on c. 67. 24. pro/peira, a first trial, only here in Thuc. Cf. Hdt. ix. 48. 10 e)n *)aqhnai/oisi th\n pro/peiran poieume/nous. —sfi/si: belongs to u(poxei/ria.— dunata\ ei)/h: as dunata\ ei)=nai in viii. 106. 22, in personal const. with ta\ pra/gmata.

katasta/ntes e)s *(rh/gion: when they had arrived at Rhegium. Cf. iv. 14. 23 katasta/ntes e)s to\ strato/pedon, iv. 75. 8 e)/nqa oi( feu/gontes tw=n *sami/wn katasta/ntes. See on i. 49. 10. They made Rhegium their base of operations. Cf. c. 88. 13; 115. 5.—20.
to\n po/lemon e)poiou=nto kte(.: for further account of events in Sicily, see c. 88, 90, 99, 103, 115.
In the winter of 427-6 the plague breaks out a second time in Athens, and at the same time numerous earthquakes occur at rarious places. (On the contents of this chapter, cf. Diod. xii. 58.)
h( no/sos: i.e. that described ii. 47 ff.—2.
e)pe/pese: as in ii. 48. 14. —
e)klipou=sa: eclipsing, as of the sun, ii. 28. 2; of the moon, vii. 50. 27. —3.
to\ panta/pasin: found with the art. only here, but protected by to\ para/pan, vi. 80. 4.—
e)ge/neto de/: for like change to finite verb, cf. c. 81. 20; i. 53. 8; 57. 10; ii. 47. 12; vii. 13. 10; 15. 15; 47. 8.—
diokwxh/: Schol. dia/leiyis, a)nabolh/, intermission, pause. It is not found elsewhere before Dio C. (xxxix. 47; xli. 25; xlvii. 27). On the form, see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 43 sq. See on c. 4. 12.

w(/ste . . . th\n du/namin: as was
recognized by Ullrich (Beitr. p. 90 ff.), these words could not have been written after the end of the Peloponnesian war. The reference, in explanation of this remark, to the losses of Athenian men-at-arms caused by the plague (§ 3) by no means justifies taking du/namis here in a narrower sense than power (cf. i. 118. 13; iv. 108. 20; v. 14. 14; vii. 28. 17); for the remaining bases of Athenian power (money, ships, allies) suffered little or nothing from the plague. But if du/namis does mean here power, there can be no doubt that this sent. was written without a knowledge of the later events of the war, esp. of the unhappy issue of the Sicilian expedition. Regarding this expedition, cf. vi. 43; 44. § 1; 94. § 4; vii. 16. § 2; 20. § 2; 42. § 1; 75. § 5; 87. § 4, 6; viii. i. § 2. Moreover, the remark is a general one, and not confined to the war which began in the spring of 431 B.C.—
*)aqhnai/wn ge: placed first with esp. emphasis because, as stated ii. 54. 19, no place in Greece had suffered so much as Athens.

tetrakosi/wn ga\r kte(.: Diod. xii. 58 gives the numbers as follows, stratiwtw=n u(pe\r tou\s tetrakisxili/ous, i(ppei=s de\ tetrakosi/ous, tw=n de\ a)/llwn e)leuqe/rwn te kai\ dou/lwn u(pe\r tou\s muri/ous. But in the absence of further proof, Thuc.'s statement is to be preferred.—7.
e)k tw=n ta/cewn: = e)k katalo/gou (vi. 43. 9; vii. 16. 7; 20. 8), i.e. all the men liable to military service of the three upper censusclasses.—8.

tou= a)/llou o)/xlou: i.e. qh=tes, me/toikoi, and dou=loi.—a)neceu/retos: not to be found out, because there were no lists. Cf. Arist. de Mundo ii. 8. The word seems not to occur elsewhere except in late authors.
e)ge/nonto: often used of natural phenomena. See on i. 54. 6.—

oi( polloi\ to/te seismoi/: the art. because the reference is to events well known. Acc. to c. 89, the earthquakes continued till the summer of 426 B.C. Cf. i. 23. 12 seismw=n te pe/ri, oi(\ e)pi\ plei=ston a(/ma me/ros gh=s kai\ i)sxuro/tatoi oi( au)toi\ e)pe/sxon.—10. kai\ e)n *eu)boi/a|: this reading of Vat. and Laur. is to be preferred, with earlier editt. and Hude, to kai\ *eu)boi/a| of most of the better Mss., since in an enumeration of the places visited by earthquakes a hint of the political connexion between Athens and Euboea would be out of place.—11.
tw=| *boiwti/w|: as opp. to the Areadian Orchomenos, v. 61. 13.

p.hi: The Attic fleet sails from Rhegium on an expedition against the Aeolian islands.

div2.p: kai\ oi( me\n kte(.: the anticipated de/ clause seems not to have been expressed in what follows. H. 1046, 1 b. —2.
tria/konta nausi/: the Rhegians had doubtless added ten to the Attic twenty. Cf. c. 86. 1.—3.

*ai)o/lou nh/sous: as in c. 115. 5. Cf. Strabo 275 c ai( *liparai/wn nh=soi a(\s *aio/lou tine\s prosagoreu/ousi, Plin. N. H. iii. 8. 92 Aeoliae, appellatae eaedem Liparaeorum, Hephaestiades a Graecis, a nostris Volcaniae. The islands are now called the Liparian or Aeolian.—
kaloume/nas: for this position of the attrib. partic., see on c. 54. 19.—4.
a)du/nata h<*>=n: as to the use of the neut. pl. of the adj., see on c. 16. 10; i. 7. 2.
ne/montai: implies possession or occupation of the soil in any way. See on i. 2. 6. Here = gewrgei=n, not oi)kei=n. —5. *knidi/wn a)/poikoi: cf. also Paus. x. 11. 3; Diod. v. 9.—6.
kalei=tai de/: paratactic connexion, as e)pi/keitai de/, iv. 53. 6. Kühn. 518, 7.—
*lipa/ra: from the adj. lipara/, with change of accent.—7.

*didu/mhn kte(.: to the four islands here named, Strabo and Pliny add three others, Erikussa or Erikodes, Phoenikussa or Phoenikodes, and Euonymos. Modern geographers mention eleven or twelve. See Holm, Gesch. Siciliens, i. p. 37 ff., 348 ff.—

*(iera/n: acc. to Diod. v. 7. 1, the full name seems to have been *(iera\ *(hfai/stou. Strabo, l.c., calls it Thermessa, but remarks, h(\n nu=n *(iera\n *(hfai/stou kalou=si, and Pliny, iii. 8. 93, says, antea Therasia appellata, nunc Hiera.
e)n th=| *(iera=|: before the conj. See on i. 77. 4. Kr. Spr. 54, 17, 7; Kühn. 606, 6.—
w(s: note the unusual const. after nomi/zw. Kr. Spr. 65, 1, 4; Kühn. 550, N. 1. Cf. e)lpi/zein w(s, v. 9. 8; oi)/esqai w(s, Xen. Mem. iii. 3. 14.— 9.

a)nadidou=sa: sending up. See on c. 58. 18. Cf. Diod. v. 7 au)=tai de\ (i.e. ai( nh=soi) pa=sai puro\s e)sxh/kasin a)nafush/ma<*>a m<*>ga/la, w)=n <*>ra<*>h=r<*> nhme/noi kai\ ta\ sto/mata me/xri tou= nu=n ei)si\ fanera/.—11. kata/: over against.
Cf. i. 46. 8; 48. 12; ii. 30. 8.—
*messhni/wn: since the territory of Messene included also a part of the north coast, which was mostly occupied by native Sicels.—
cu/mmaxoi *surakosi/wn: since they were Dorians, being descendants of the Cnidians. Cf. c. 86. 6.
prosexw/roun: sc. oi( *liparai=oi. Cf. c. 7. 12; 91. 8.—
e)s to\ *(rh/gion: cf. c. 86. 20.—14.

tw=| pole/mw| e)teleu/ta: so, acc. to the best Mss., instead of e)teleu/ta tw=| pole/mw|. The former is the regular order; only in ii. 70. 22, where, however, o( xeimw\n e)teleu/ta does not precede, all Mss. offer e)teleu/ta tw=| pole/mw| tw=|de. See on viii. 60. 17. SIXTH YEAR OF THE WAR. c. 89-116.

p.hi: The proposed invasion of Attica by the Peloponnesians is prevented by earthquakes. Other remarkable natural phenomena connected therewith.

div2.p: *)/agidos: his father Archidamus, the leader of the three first e)sbolai/ (c. 1. 3; ii. 10. 9; 47. 5), had died prob. not long before. See on c. 26. 7. —4.
seismw=n pollw=n: cf. c. 87. 9.— 5.
a)petra/ponto pa/lin: turned back, as v. 13. 4 a)petra/ponto e)p) oi)/kou. Cf. vi. 95. 2.
katexo/ntwn: prevailing, abs., as i. 10. 5; 11. 19.—
th=s *eu)boi/as: position as in c. 19. 6.—7.
e)n *)orobi/ais: on the northwest coast of the island, still recognizable in the village Rovias. See Bursian ii. p. 411.—

e)panelqou=sa: with the Schol. against all the Mss., which have e)pelqou=sa. Cf. ku/matos e)panaxw/rhsis, See App. Arn. gives the sense of the passage correctly: ‘The sea first retired from what was then the line of the coast, and afterwards rising in a heap or head of water it invaded a part of the city.’ For a similar description, see Plin. Epist. vi. 20. 9, and concerning the earthquake at Lisbon, Schaefer, Gesch. v. Portugal v. p. 246.—8.

kumatwqei=sa: prob. coined by Thuc.
and occurring elsewhere only in late writers.—9.
to\ me\n kate/kluse, to\ d' u(peno/sthse: one part of the tide made a (permanent) inundation, the other receded. u(ponostei=n only here in Thuc., as in Hdt. i. 191. 14; unusual in Attic. —11.
die/fqeiren: sc. h( qa/lassa.— ta\ mete/wra: see on c. 72. 7.
*)atala/nthn: this had been fortified by the Athenians (ii. 32. 1), e)rh/mh pro/teron ou)=sa. See Bursian i. p. 191.—
e)pi\ *lokroi=s: as in ii. 32. 3. —13.
paraplhsi/a gi/gnetai e)pi/klusis kte(.: on the occurrence, see Lolling, Mitt. Arch. Inst. Athen. i. p. 253 f. The passage is treated inexactly by Sen. Nat. Qu. vi. 24.—14.
tou= frouri/ou: part. gen., as in v. 2. 14. G. 1091; H. 736; Kühn. 416, 1, N. 2.— 15.
a)neilkusme/nwn: drawn up on shore, because not at the moment in use. Cf. vii. 24. 11.—
kate/acen: of ships also iv. 11. 20.
*peparh/qw|: northeast of Euboea. See Bursian ii. p. 387.—

ku/matos e)panaxw/rhsis: return of a wave. e)panaxw/rhsis, corresponding to e)panelqou=sa above, seems to occur elsewhere only in Diod. Excerpt. 510, 31; the verb is found in i. 131. 5. ku=ma is used in a collective sense. See on ke/ramos c. 74. 4.—
e)pe/kluse: more definite expression for e)ph=lqe (8), with to\ ku=ma as subj.—18.

ai)/tion nomi/zw: with inf., without art. as obj., as i. 23. 23 th\n a)lhqesta/thn pro/fasin tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h(gou=mai a)nagka/sai. —19. tou= toiou/tou: i.e. the recoil of the sea followed by an inundation. —
kata\ tou=to: after h(=| = tau/th|, at this point.—20.

a)poste/llein te . . . kai\ . . . th
 e)pi/klusin poiei=n: Jowett's explanation is doubtless correct. ‘Thuc. is pointing out the connexion between the earthquake and the inundation. Where the earthquake was most violent, there the inundation was greatest. But the effect was indirect, being immediately caused by the recoil of the sea after the earthquake was over; hence th
 qa/lassan, and not, as we might expect,
to
 seismo/n, is the subj. of poiei=n. a)poste/llein, either active or neuter.’ a)poste/llein and poiei=n are impf. infs. See App.—21.
biaio/teron: with the masc. ending of the positive, as dusesbolw/tatos, c. 101. 9; a)porw/teros, v. 110. 2. e)nnomwte/rou paidia=s, Plato Rep. 424 e. Kühn.^{3} 152 N.—

a)/neu seismou=: after h(=| . . . e)ge/neto (19), = ei) mh\ seismo\s e)ge/neto.—22. a)/n: belongs to cumbh=nai. The independent const. would have been a)\n cune/bh.—cumbh=nai gene/sqai: the pleonasm as in i. 56. 1; ii. 8. 12; viii. 73. 2.

p.hi: In Sicily Messene is forced to join the Athenian alliance.

div2.p:
kai\ a)/lloi kte(.: if the text is in order, kai\ a)/lloi must be regarded as the antithesis to kai\ au)toi\ oi( *sikeliw=tai kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi cu
 toi=s sfete/rois cumma/xois, and as referring to the Sicels (see on c. 103. 2). But supposing that Thuc. really intended to speak of the Sicels, it would be strange that he should have designated these so vaguely. Besides, a consideration of the especial warlike undertakings of the Sicels—and only of these could one think, since below it is said, kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi cu
 toi=s sfete/rois cumma/xois (cf. c. 103. 3)—would be quite out of place. Against Pp.'s conjecture (approved by Cl. and others), kai\ a)/lla, it may be urged that, aside from the fact that ta\ a)/lla cunepole/mei in i. 65. 10 is not sufficient support for such a const. as a)/lla polemei=n, even in Pp.'s text the subj. of the following rel. clause (a(\ de\ . . . a)ntipo/lemoi) does not agree with that of the first clause; whereas only with identity of subj. could the antithesis between less important and more important events have been emphasized in the manner assumed by Pp. As it seems, in the traditional text two separate sentences of Thucydides are united in one, namely, e)pole/moun me
 kai\ a)/lloi, w(s e(ka/stois cune/bainen, e)n th=| *sikeli/a| kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi cu
 toi=s sfete/rois cumma/xois and e)pole/moun me
 e)n th=| *sikeli/a| kai\ au)toi\ oi( *sikeliw=tai e)p) a)llh/lous strateu/ontes (“there warred indeed in Sicily also the Siceliots themselves, fighting against one another”). The latter sent., which, though shorter, is clearer, and with which a(\ de\ kte(. more naturally connects, seems to be the author's later conception.—2.
cune/bainen: sc. polemei=n. Kr. Spr. 55, 4, 11.—

au)toi\ oi( *sikeliw=tai e)p) a)llh/lous strateu/ontes: there is no account of such conflicts in Thuc., not even in iv. 25. 53 meta\ de\ tou=to oi( me\n e)n th=| *sikeli/a| *(/ellhnes a)/neu tw=n *)aqhnai/wn kata\ gh=n e)stra/teuon e)p) a)llh/lous.—4. lo/gou ma/lista a)/cia: that Thuc. did not communicate all even of the former
events in Sicily, in which the Athenians took part, but only certain selected ones, may be inferred from his remark about the death of Charoeades (7).—5.
pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous oi( a)ntipo/lemoi: in spite of this announcement there is neither in this chapter, nor in c. 99, an account of these undertakings.—6.

a)ntipo/lemoi: rightly restored by St. (for a)ntipole/mioi of the Mss.) acc. to the statement of Pollux i. 150 to\ tw=n a)ntipole/mwn o)/noma, ei) kai\ *qoukudi/dhs au)tw=| ke/xrhtai, sklhro/n e)sti. In Hdt. (iv. 134. 7; 140. 10; vii. 236. 17; viii. 68. b 2) this form has been generally adopted (by Stein in the last two places).
*xaroia/dou: cf. c. 86. 3.—7.
teqnhko/tos: prob. his death did not seem to Thuc. important enough to be stated among the events of the winter of 426 7, where it belonged. See on —8.

pole/mw|: in war. Cf. perie/sesqai tw=| pole/mw|, ii. 13. 59; perigene/sqai tw=| pole/mw|, ii. 65. 61; perigi/gnetai tw=| pole/mw| tw=n *korinqi/wn, i. 55. 11, and, on the other hand, tw=n e)n tw=|de tw=| pole/mw| prw/twn a)poqano/ntwn, ii. 34. 2.—9.
meta\ tw=n cumma/xwn: as c. 86. 20.—
*mula/s: on the northern coast, now Milazzo.—10.
fulai/: borrowed by the military from the civil classification, as also, in Athens and Syracuse, fulh/ occurs for ta/cis (vi. 98. 17; 100. 6).—12.
toi=s a)po\ tw=n new=n: of disembarked troops also c. 91. 10; 94. 2; viii. 23. 20, etc.
tw=| e)ru/mati: Schol. tw=| frouri/w|. Cf. iv. 31. 13; 35. 3; v. 4. 14; vi. 94. 7.—15.
o(mologi/a|: by capitulation, as i. 29. 22; 107. 10; 114. 15; 117. 13, etc.
oi( *messh/nioi: the position is rather unusual. But compare the similar arrangement in ii. 86. 12; iv. 135. 1; v. 47. 1; vi. 6. 13.—17.

kai\ au)toi/: also themselves, as before the garrison of Mylae. Cf. c. 61. 2;
i. 50. 18; 51. 6.—18.

kai\ ta\ a)/lla pista\ parasxo/menoi: arranging other matters in a trustworthy manner, i.e. satisfactory to the Athenians. pista/ is not a subst. (pledges), but pred. to ta\ a)/lla. Cf. i. 32. 8 kai\ tau=ta pisteu/ontes e)xura\ u(mi=n pare/cesqai a)pe/steilan h(ma=s. The further occurrences in Sicily are related in c. 99, 103, and 115.

p.hi: Operations of the Athenians on the Peloponnesian coast and against the island of Melos. Invasion of Bocotia and victory at Tanagra. Devastation of the coast of eastern Locris.

div2.p: nau=s e)/steilan peri\ *pelopo/nnhson: cf. c. 3. 10; 7. 3; 16. 12. The operations of this fleet are narrated c. 99 ff.—

*dhmosqe/nhs: from this his first appearance until his death in Sicily (vii. 82, 86), one of the most active and enterprising generals of the war. See Curtius, Hist. of Greece, iii. p. 137 ff.; Holm, Gr. Gesch. ii. p. 399 and 444.—3.
*proklh=s: perishes this very summer in the campaign against the Aetolians, c. 98. 23. —5.
*niki/as: already mentioned, c. 51, and henceforth of predominant influence in Athenian home, as well as foreign, affairs, until he also perishes in the Sicilian expedition (vii. 85, 86).
tou\s *mhli/ous: who, with the inhabitants of Thera, had, as Laconian colonists (v. 84. § 2), alone of all the Cyclades, held aloof from the Attic alliance. Cf. ii. 9. 19.—6.

e)s to\ au(tw=n cummaxiko\n i)e/nai: to come into their alliance. Cf. e)s ta\s *)attika\s sponda\s e)selqei=n, v. 36. 13; e)s ta\s sponda\s e)sagagei=n, v. 35. 24. au(tw=n, for au)tw=n of the Mss., is required both by its position and reference to the subj. of e)bou/lonto. See on c. 22. 31. e)s to\ cummaxiko/n is found only here and viii. 9. 10; elsewhere kata\ to\ cummaxiko/n. See on c. 3. 19.—7.
prosagage/sqai: to bring over, causative to prosxwrei=n, in the same sense also ii. 30. 7; iv. 86. 3; vii. 7. 8.

th=s *grai+khs: so, with St., for the Vulg. th=s pe/ran gh=s, acc. to the correct reading, as testified by Steph.
Byz. (s.v. *)wrwpo/s), of ii. 23. 12 th
 gh=n th
 *grai+kh
 kaloume/nhn, h(
 ne/montai *)wrw/pioi. For the assumption that h( pe/ran gh= was originally a local (Euboean), then a general designation for the territory of Oropos, there is no ground.—10.
sxo/ntes: putting in. See on c. 29. 5; vii. 1. 14.—

oi( o(pli=tai a)po\ tw=n new=n: to be construed together. See on c. 90. 12. For the order of the words, cf. ii. 80. 16 to\ me\n nautiko\n e)/k te *kori/nqou kai\ *sikuw=nos. —11. pezh=|: i.e. along the valley of the Asopus.—
e)s *ta/nagran: into the territory of Tanagra. See on l. 15; 102. 19; 106. 8; ii. 18. 2.—
oi( e)k th=s po/lews *)aqhnai=oi: proleptic, as c. 79. 4 tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou. See on c. 5. 1.—12.

*(ipponi/kou: son of Callias, head of the well-known aristocratic and wealthy family, particulars of which are given by Boeckh, P. E. p. 623 ff., and Welzel, Kallias (Gymn.-Progr. Breslau, 1888). His daughter Hipparete was the wife of Alcibiades.—13.
*eu)rume/dontos: see on c. 80. 10.—
a)po\ shmei/ou: implying that the action was concerted. Cf. ii. 90. 18.

e)n th=| *tana/gra|: i.e. in the territory of Tanagra. Cl. wrote e)n th=| *tanagrai/a|, on the ground that, with e)dh/|oun kai\ e)nhuli/santo, e)n with the name of the city is inadmissible. But the Vulg., which corresponds exactly to e)s *ta/nagran above (11), is sufficiently supported by such passages as ii. 31. 6 tou\s e)k th=s po/lews panstratia=| e)n *mega/rois o)/ntas, iv. 5. 4 o( strato\s e)/ti e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais w)/n, v. 55. 1 kaq) o(\n xro/non e)n th=| *)epidau/rw| oi( *)argei=oi h)=san. Cf. also c. 67. 13; i. 100. 15; iv. 118. 16; v. 58. 7; vii. 1. 18. —16.

th=| u(sterai/a| ma/xh|: the adj. is always fem. in Thuc., and most freq. signifies the following day, though h(me/ra| is never expressed. It accords best with the context to construe it independently here, and not with ma/xh|. But see on i. 44. 4 and Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 34.—

ma/xh| krath/santes: kratei=n takes the acc. in Thuc. when joined with ma/xh| or maxo/menos (c. 103. 15; i. 108. 18; ii. 39. 14; iv. 67. 29), or, more rarely, when the connexion clearly implies this (c. 99. 3; ii. 39. 18); otherwise always with the gen. See on i. 108. 19.—18.

kai\ o(/pla labo/ntes kai\ tropai=on sth/santes: the first kai/ does not connect what follows with krath/santes, when they had con-
quered, but the two co-ord. labo/ntes and sth/santes (both . . . and). That the Athenians did not retire without the usual tokens of victory is emphasized.—
o(/pla labo/ntes: sc. of the slain or of those who had lost their arms, as in c. 103. 15; vii. 45. 5.— 20.
parapleu/sas . . . e)/teme: cf. c. 7. 6 paraple/ousai ai( nh=es th=s *lakwnikh=s ta\ e)piqala/ssia xwri/a e)po/rqhsan. parapleu/sas, sailing along the coast. See on c. 7. 6.—

th=s *lokri/dos: i.e. Eastern Locris. The terms *lokroi/ and *lokri/s seem to refer in Thuc., without further designation, to the Eastern or Opuntian and Epicnemidian Locrians, unless the context fixes the reference to the Ozolian or Epizephyrian Locrians. See on ii. 9. 8.
The Lacedaemonians, for the protection of the Trachinians and Dorians, re-found the Trachinian Heraclea in the territory of Malis.

to\n xro/non tou=ton: as viii. 78. 1. Cl. wrote, with Vat., tou=ton to\n xro/non (cf. viii. 63. 9). The episode in this and the following chapter, which interrupts the narrative begun at c. 91, is inserted here because the re-settlement of Heraclea occurred without doubt immediately after the withdrawal of Nicias from the Locrian coast.—2.

th\n e)n *traxini/ois a)poiki/an kaqi/stanto: *traxini/ois seems to be the correct form. Cf. ta\s e)n *harrasi/ois po/leis, v. 33. 11; e)n *boiwtoi=s or e)n toi=s *boiwtoi=s, c. 87. 10; i. 107. 18; iv. 89. 3; 108. 24; e)n *xalkideu=sin, i. 65. 9; ii. 101. 25. Most, and nearly all good, Mss. have *traxini/ais, which Bernhardy (Syntax, p. 64) considers a secondary form of *traxi/s, and Cl. as a local name borrowed from the *traxi/niai pe/trai (“precipitate cliffs”), at whose foot the old Trachis lay (see Hdt. vii. 198. 7; Bursian i. p. 94). But neither view is probable. The reading of Laur., *traxini/a|, would be acceptable in itself (cf. Diod. xv. 57. 2); only it would be difficult to explain how the vulg. originated from it. Against the conjectures *traxini/a| e)s and *traxi=ni e)s, Pp. rightly objects that one would expect as obj. of e)s a)poiki/an kaqi/stanto, not *(hra/kleian, but *traxi=na, the name of the old city, as well as of the district. The fact that all the Mss. agree in e)n *traxi=ni in the four other passages where the name of the city occurs (*(hra/kleia h( e)n *traxi=ni, c. 100. 8; iv. 78. 3; v. 12. 4; *(hraklew=tai oi( e)n *traxi=ni, v. 51. 1), does not exclude the assumption here of a slightly different designation of the city.—
a)poiki/an kaqi/stanto: established as their colony. Cf. the pass. kaqi/stasqai, l. 14; 93. 3; v. 51. 6. On the significance of the whole enterprise, see Curtius, Hist. of Greece, iii. p. 135.—

kaqi/stanto: the intro
ductory impf. of the whole; the details follow, from § 5 on, in aors. See on c. 107. 15.—
a)po\ toia=sde: the following clause, as usual in Thuc., is without ga/r. See on i. 89. 2.

*mhlih=s oi( cu/mpantes kte(.: of the Malians all together there are three parts. Cf. Caes. B. G. i. 1. 1. The natural position of me/n would be after *mhlih=s.—4. *(ierh=s: both name and place uncertain. See Bursian i. p. 95 f. Steph. Byz. mentions *)ira/, with the gentile neun *)irieu/s, as a po/lis *malie/wn.—5. *oi)tai/wn: here, l. 10, and viii. 3. 4, as well as Hdt. vii. 217. 4; Xen. Hell. i. 2. 18, etc., mentioned as an independent mountain tribe. See Niebuhr, Vortr. ü. A. L. u. V.-K. p. 173, and Weil, Hermes vii. p. 380 ff. —
to\ prw=ton mellh/santes: having been at first about—.—6.
prosqei=nai sfa=s au)tou/s: with the dat. also viii. 46. 29; 50. 16.—8.
*teisameno/n: not *tisameno/n of the Mss., acc. to the constant usage of inscriptions. See St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 38; Meisterhans,^{2} p. 41. On the accent, see Goettling, p. 199.

*dwrih=s: applied to both district and inhabitants; hence the appos. h( mhtro/polis, as in i. 107. 4. Cf. Hdt. viii. 31. 7. h( mhtro/polis tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn distinguishes the Dorians here meant from the *dwrih=s *karsi\ pro/soikoi (ii. 9. 16), and from the Dorians as a race.
gnw/mhn ei)=xon: determined, with the inf., as in c. 31. 11; ii. 86. 17, 19; iv. 125. 20; viii. 44. 2.—13.
kai\ a(/ma . . . kaqi/stasqai: and at the same time the city seemed to be conveniently situated for the war against Athens. —
tou= pro\s *)aqhnai/ous pole/mou: governed by kalw=s kaqi/stasqai. Cf. i. 36. 11; 75. 3. See on 17 below. —14.

h( po/lis: i.e. the colony to be planted; hence the inf. pres. pass., as in c. 93. 3. Cf. also v. 51. 5 eu)qu\s kaqistame/nh| th=| po/lei.—15. e)pi/ te ga\r . . . xrhsi/mws e(/cein: the two
reasons explanatory of tou= pro\s *)aqhnai/ous kalw=s kaqi/stasqai, co-ordinated by te, te, to which is added, by way of summing up, to/ te cu/mpan . . . kti/zein.—e)pi\ th=| *eu)boi/a|: against Euboea. For the force of the prep., see on c. 13. 18. Cf. c. 93. 2, 7; v. 51. 4.—16.
w(/ste . . . gi/gnesqai: cf. c. 93. 3.—

th=s e)pi\ *qra/|khs paro/dou: const. with xrhsi/mws e(/cein. G. 1092, H. 757 a; Kühn. 419, 5. See on i. 22. 13. h( pa/rodos, the march along the coast, as iv. 82. 3. Cf. iv. 78. § 1; v. 12. § 1. The minds of the Lacedaemonians were already turned, for Athens's hurt, toward Thrace. Cf. iv. 78 ff.—17.
to/ te cu/mpan: see on c. 40. 16.—18.
w(/rmhnto: were eager. Cf. ii. 59. 6; iv. 27. 21; 29. 8; v. 29. 21; vi. 6. 3; viii. 73. 15.
e)n *delfoi=s: as to the influence of the Delphic oracle on Hellenic colonization, see Curtius, Hist. of Greece, ii. p. 37 ff.—19.

keleu/ontos: sc. au)tou=. The subj. is not expressed, as in viii. 6. 23. See on i. 2. 8. Jow. calls attention to the fact that ‘in this instance the god is stated to give his sanction to an enterprise which ends in complete failure.’—

tou\s oi)kh/toras au(tw=n te kai\ tw=n perioi/kwn: the settlers who belonged to themselves and to the Perioeci. Cf. c. 93. 12 oi( a)/rxontes au)tw=n tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn, and c. 109. 12 meta\ tw=n custrath/gwn *)akarna/nwn.—20. tw=n perioi/kwn: i.e. the old inhabitants, chiefly of Achaean stock, who had been reduced to a condition of dependence (not slavery) by the Dorians. See Müller, Dor. Book III. p. 16 ff. Cf. i. 101. 6.—21.
