to\n boulo/menon e)ke/leuon e(/pesqai: cf. i. 26. 3.—

plh\n *)iw/nwn kai\ *)axaiw=n: the Ionians were excepted on account of the difference of race, but the Achaeans, in spite of their federal relations (see on ii. 9. 7), from political aversion. See Curtius, Pelop. i. p. 415. The same will apply also to the a)/lla e)/qnh that are not named.—22.

e)qnw=n: used even of small states, but always with regard to race individuality. Cf. vi. 6. 1; vii. 58. 8. In Xen. Hell. i. 2. 18 those inhabitants of the new city who had previously occupied the district are called *)axaioi/ in contrast with the e)/poikoi.—trei=s: the number three, as often in important undertakings of the Lacedaemonians, c. 100. 3; iv. 132. 13; v. 12. 2. —23.

*)alki/das: without doubt the
nauarch already mentioned, c. 16, 26, 31, 76, 80. § 2.
katasta/ntes: having established themselves, abs. with e)tei/xisan th\n po/lin, as with e)ma/xonto, i. 49. 10; with e)pole/moun, i. 59. 7; v. 4. 15. See on c. 86. 19.—

e)k kainh=s: anew. Cf. e)k ne/hs, Hdt. i. 60. 6. For similar ellipses, see on i. 14. 15. Kr. Spr. 43, 3, 8. The new town was built on the site of the old. Cf. Strabo ix. 4. 13 *(hra/kleia h( *traxi\n kaloume/nh pro/teron, *lakedaimoni/wn kti/sma. Acc. to tradition, Trachis had been founded by Heracles, hence the new name.—25.
a)pe/xousa: the partic. construed with the rel., rather than with the main clause. —27.

ei)=rcan to\ kata\ *qermopu/las: they closed the side toward (the approach from) Thermopylae, i.e. they repaired the old fortifications, which, acc. to Hdt. vii. 176. 19 ff., the Phocians had built as a protection against the Thessalians, and which Leonidas used in his struggle with the Persians (Hdt. vii. 208, 223, 225). ei)/rgein, which usually has a personal obj. in Thuc., is here construed as in c. 18. 21; viii. 40. 6; Hom. h 88. to\ kata\ *qermopu/las as to\ e)k th=s h)pei/rou, c. 51. 13. See App.—28.
eu)fu/lakta: cf. viii. 55. 8 eu)fulakto/tera. For the use of the neut. pl. of the adj., see on c. 16. 10; i. 7. 2.
The new colony falls into a decline, owing to the hostility of its neighbours and the bad administration of the Lacedaemonians.

cunoikizome/nhs: rare use of the compound instead of the simple oi)kizome/nhs. Bl. compares Eur. Hec. 1138 f., e)/deisa mh\ soi\ pole/mios lhfqei\s o( pai=s *troi/an a)qroi/sai kai\ cunoiki/sai pa/lin. Cl. thinks that the compound is used on account of the various nationalities represented, c. 92. § 5.—3.
kaqi/stasqai: cf. c. 92. 14.—
braxu/s e)stin . . . *eu)boi/as: cf. c. 92. 16.—4.
to\ *kh/naion: the N. W. promontory of the island. See Bursian ii. p. 401. —5.

a)pe/bh: only here impers., elsewhere with general subj., as ou)de\n a)pe/bainen au)toi=s w(=n prosede/xonto, c. 26. 15. Cf. iv. 104. 10. Here the subj. to
be understood from the context is to\ th\n po/lin kaqi/stasqai.—a)p) au)th=s: i.e. th=s po/lews tau/ths.

ai)/tion de\ h)=n: oi(/ te *qessaloi\ kte(.: instead of a o(/ti clause, as in ii. 65. 31, or a partic. sent., as in iv. 26. 14; viii. 9. 12, the explanatory clause is added without connective, as in ii. 50. 7 after tekmh/rion de/. Cf. Dem. viii. 32 ai)/tion de\ tou/twn, pareskeua/kasin u(ma=s, xviii. 108 to\ ai)/tion, e)n toi=s pe/nhsin h)=n to\ leitourgei=n. Hence it is not necessary, with Cobet ad Hyper.^{2} p. 43, to write oi( ga/r for oi(/ te, nor indeed to bracket h)=n. For the analogy of the elliptical const. of tekmh/rion or martu/rion de/ (see on i. 8. 3) is not necessarily to be transferred to ai)/tion, which Thuc. construes with h)=n in i. 11. 1; ii. 65. 31; iv. 26. 14, and with e)ge/neto in viii. 9. 11, although the verb is omitted in c. 82. 53.—

oi(/ te *qessaloi/: to te answers irregularly ou) me/ntoi h(/kista in Thuc. had in mind from the start, doubtless, the two chief points of the ai)/tion,—hostile neighbours and the bad administration of the Lacedaemonian governors. Between te and kai/, there is, therefore, no connexion. —

e)n duna/mei o)/ntes tw=n tau/th| xwri/wn: who were predominant in that region. With this unusual expression, cf. Plato Rep. 328 c ei) me\n ga\r e)gw\ e)/ti e)n duna/mei h)=n tou= r(a|di/ws poreu/esqai pro\s to\ a)/stu.—7. kai\ w(=n . . . e)kti/zeto: sc. h( po/lis, this clause also explanatory of oi( *qessaloi/, and against whose territory it was being founded. Kr. took kai\ w(=n, with the Schol., in the sense of ka)kei=noi w(=n, i.e. as a second subject. But acc. to v. 51. 1 ff., there can be no doubt that, along with the Aenianians, Dolopians, and Malians, the Thessalians also considered themselves threatened by the new city: *(hraklew/tais ma/xh e)ge/neto pro\s *ai)nia=nas kai\ *do/lopas kai\ *mhlia=s kai\ *qessalw=n tinas: prosoikou=nta ga\r ta\ e)/qnh tau=ta th=| po/lei pole/mia h)=n: ou) ga\r e)p) a)/llh| tini\ gh=| h)\ th=| tou/twn to\ xwri/on e)teixi/sqh. Besides, after emphasizing the predominant position of the Thessalians in those regions, there would be little reason in referring still to the hostility of the little tribes of Aenianians, Dolopians, Malians, Oetaeans (v. 51. 2; viii. 3. 4 ff.), even though these tribes, as is clear from ii. 101. § 2, were not all actually u(ph/kooi to the Thessalians.—
e)pi\ th=| gh=|: see on c. 92. 15.—8.
paroikw=sin: sc. oi( *(hraklew=tai.—dia\ panto/s: continually, of time as usual. See on i. 38. 2.—9.
neokatasta/tois: not found elsewhere exceptin late writers Cf. neo/ktistos, c. 100. 9.—
e)cetru/xwsan: as in vii. 48. 11; elsewhere only in late writers. The simple verb occurs in i. 126. 24; iv. 60. 13; vii. 28. 23.—10.

kai\ pa/nu pollou/s: Diod., xii. 59, gives the number as 4000
Peloponnesians and 6000 other Hellenes.—
pa=s tis: see on c. 13. 33.— 11.
*lakedaimoni/wn oi)kizo/ntwn: “since the Lacedaemonians were the colonizers.”

oi( a)/rxontes au)tw=n tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn: for the expression, see on c. 92. 19; for the matter, cf. v. 51. § 2; 52. § 1. St. compares these governors with the e)pidhmiourgoi/, whom Potidaea received from her mother-city, Corinth, i. 56. 8.—13.

a)fiknou/menoi: placed after in apposition, as i. 95. 11 tw=n *(ellh/nwn tw=n a)fiknoume/nwn.—14. kate/sthsan: sc. th\n po/lin.—15. xalepw=s . . . ou) kalw=s: cf. the example of Hegesippidas, v. 52. § 1. xalepw=s, oppressively, as in c. 46. 22. For e)/stin a(/, see on c. 92. 22. a(/ is cognate acc., as in c. 55. 13.—
e)chgou/menoi: abs., exercising supremacy, as in i. 76. 3; 95. 26; ii. 65. 17.
Demosthenes with thirty ships first attacks Leucas; but is persuaded by the Messenians to turn against Aetolia. (On this and the following chapters, cf. Diod. xii. 60.)

kai\ peri\ to\n au)to\n xro/non kte(.: this reference to c. 91. § 3 is the more necessary because the episode of the two preceding chaps. (see on c. 92. 1) has reached a point of time considerably in advance.—2.
katei/xonto: as in ii. 86. 2, and referring to the vain attempt of c. 91. § 2, 3.—
oi( a)po\ tw=n tria/konta new=n: see on c. 90. 12. —3.
tw=n tria/konta new=n: cf. c. 91. 1. —
peri\ *pelopo/nnhson o)/ntes: placed after the noun, without article. Cf. i. 51. 11; ii. 31. 4; 100. 8. G. 968.— 4.

e)n *)ellomenw=|: so, not *)ellome/nw| with the Mss., acc. to the analogy of *)orxomeno/s. See St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 33 f. Acc. to Dodwell, Classical Tour, ii. p. 49, this place still retains its ancient name (Llomeno, identical with *)ello/menos), and is situated on the east coast of Leucadia, a little inland. But as the name occurs nowhere else in the ancient writers. Forchhammer (Hellenica, p. 102) conjectures e)n *klume/nw|, the real name being preserved in Klimeno, situated on a bay on the east coast of S. Maura. So also Leake; and Kiepert has adopted this form. But see Bursian i. p. 117.
—

th=s *leukadi/as: Thuc. uses the form *leukadi/a of the territory of the Leucadians, which, acc. to what follows, included, besides the peninsula (see on c. 81. 3), also a part of the neighbouring mainland. Cf. iv. 42. 17; viii. 13. 3.—
frourou/s tinas: cf. c. 7. 16; iv. 42. 17.—
loxh/santes die/fqeiran: as in i. 65. 10.—5.
e)/peita u(/steron: as in ii. 9. 7; v. 61. 15; vi. 66. 14; 88. 54; vii. 82. 7.—
e)pi\ *leuka/da: against the city of Leucas, which was situated on the peninsula near the isthmus (cf. l. 10).—6.
*)akarna=si/ te pa=sin: as to the omission of the art., see on c. 66. 3; ii. 9. § 2.—
plh\n *oi)niadw=n: cf. ii. 102. 10.
e)/cw: sc. tou= i)sqmou=. See on c. 81. 3.—10.
to\ i(ero\n tou= *)apo/llwnos: this sanctuary was on the promontory of Leucatas, the southernmost point of the peninsula.—11.
plh/qei biazo/menoi: forced by superior numbers, the cause of h(su/xazon.—12. *dhmosqe/nhn: see on c. 91. 2.—

a)poteixi/zein au)tou/s: to wall them off, i.e. tou\s *leukadi/ous. That a complete circumvallation is meant (cf. i. 65. 2; vii. 1. 4; viii. 26. 20), is clear from c. 95. 12 dia\ th=s *leuka/dos th\n ou) peritei/xisin.
a)napei/qetai: stronger term than the simple verb. Cf. c. 70. 23, and see on i. 84. 10.—15.
u(po\ *messhni/wn: sc. tw=n e)n *naupa/ktw|. Cf. c. 107. 5; ii. 25. 22; iv. 9. 8; v. 35. 31.—

w(s kalo\n au)tw=|: sc. e)sti/n. Cf. Plato Rep. p. 327 c h)\n pei/swmen u(ma=s w(s xrh\ h(ma=s a)fei=nai. pei/qein with inf. means persuade to do something; with w(s, convince, induce to believe, that. Kr. Spr. 65, 1, 4.—16.
cuneilegme/nhs: note the force of the perf. partic., already collected, and not just with a view to the e)piqe/sqai. GMT. 142.—17.

*naupa/ktw| te . . . ou)=si, kai\ . . . prospoih/sein: the two motives (co-ord. by te, kai/) for the attack on the Aetolians
stand in different grammatical relations to the main clause. For similar irregularities of const., cf. i. 129. 5; ii. 5. 21; iv. 3. 19, and see on i. 16. 2. prospoih/sein and the following infs. depend on a)napei/qetai, or some verb like e)/legon to be supplied from it. Kr. Spr. 65, 11, 7; Kühn. 593, N. 1.— 18.
to\ a)/llo h)peirwtiko\n to\ tau/th|: i.e. all the Lacedaemonian allies on this coast, as the Ambraciots, Oeniadae, Leucadians, etc.

dia\ pollou=: far apart. Cf. dia\ tosou/tou, ii. 29. 17; di) o)li/gou, ii. 89. 41; di) e)la/ssonos, vi. 75. 3; vii. 4. 19. ou)/sas is omitted, as w)/n in ii. 29. 19 basileu\s prw=tos e)n kra/tei.—skeuh=|: as in i. 8. 6, the equipment, dress, etc., of individuals. See on i. 2. 12.— 22.
ou) xalepo\n a)pe/fainon: xalepo/n pred. without o)/n, as is often the case with adjs. after o(ra=n. Cf. ii. 45. 2; iv. 24. 8; 25. 14; viii. 16. 8.—

xalepo\n katastrafh=nai: the less usual pass. inf. after an adj., as a)preph= lexqh=nai, ii. 36. 19; lo/gon prosh/konta r(hqh=nai, Plato Legg. 751 b; ka/llistos o)fqh=nai, Plut. Dem. 16. See on c. 40. 8.
*)apodwtoi=s: the accent acc. to Steph. Byz. s.v. See St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 34. The Aetolian tribes here named dwelt in the so-called *ai)twli/a e)pi/kthtos, above Naupactus.—25.
o(/per: assimilated to the pred. H. 631; Kr. Spr. 61, 7, 8.—

a)gnwsto/tatoi glw=ssan: because they had remained semi-barbarians (ou)k e)/lontes th\n dia/lekton eu)/kolon gnwsqh=nai, Schol.). Cf. Poly b. xviii. 5 *ai)twlw=n ou)k ei)si\n *(/ellhnes oi( plei=stoi.—26. w)mofa/goi: Niebuhr (Vortr. etc. p. 138) refers this to the custom of eating flesh smoked or dried. Regarding the Aetolians, cf. also i. 5. § 3.—27.
r(a|di/ws . . . prosxwrh/sein: as viii. 25. 28. The inf. depends on e)/legon to be supplied from e)ke/leuon. See on prospoih/sein above.
Having been joined by the Messenians, Cephallenians, and Zacynthians, Demosthenes advances into the interior.

tw=n *messhni/wn xa/riti peisqei/s:
induced by regard for the Messenians, as vi. 11. 10 without peisqei/s. —2.
toi=s h)peirw/tais cumma/xois: with the continental allies. Cf. i. 35. 21 h)peirw/tidos th=s cummaxi/as didome/nhs, and see on c. 103. 2.—3.

meta\ tw=n *ai)twlw=n: in agreement (alliance) with the Aetolians. Cf. c. 66. 7; vi. 86. 8. Dem. thought that the alliance of the Aetolians with Athens would enable him, with an army composed solely of continental allies, to attack Boeotia from the west. With this view, the sent. offers no difficulty, and hence there is no occasion for bracketing, with St., meta\ tw=n *ai)twlw=n, the most important words of the whole sent.— 4.

e)lqei=n e)pi\ *boiwtou/s: Demosthenes here first conceives the plan of attacking in the rear the most hated enemy of Athens, Boeotia. This plan is not now executed, owing to the failure of the attempt to subdue the Aetolians (c. 95. § 2-98), but is revived in another form in the eighth year of the war (iv. 76 f.), though without success (iv. 89). The goal (Boeotia) being named, the proposed route, through Locris, Doris, and along the northern slopes of Parnassus, is given in detail (though not accomplished), without doubt in order that the excellence of Demosthenes's plan might be recognized.—
dia\ *lokrw=n tw=n *)ozolw=n: these Locrians were at that time allies of Athens. Cf. l. 17; 97. 7; 101. 2. See on ii. 9. 8.—5.

*kuti/nion: at the northern outlet of the pass leading from the plain of Amphissa in Locris into the valley of the river Pindus. See Bursian i. p. 155; Lolling, Mitt. d. arch. Inst. in Athen ix. p. 313 ff.—6.
e(/ws katabai/h: donec descenderet. For the opt., see GMT. 613, 4; H. 921 b.—
kata\ th\n fili/an: the Phocians, though mentioned among the Lacedaemonian allies, ii. 9. 8, seem to have continued to favour the Athenians.— 7.
ai)ei/ pote: expresses forcibly the continual existence of a state of things, esp. of a friendly or hostile relation. See on i. 13. 16; ii. 102. 10. —

custrateu/ein h)\ ka)\n bi/a| prosaxqh=nai: the pres. of a relation confidently looked forward to as enduring, as l. 20, w)feli/a e)do/koun ei)=nai, the aor. with a)/n of a case possible, but hardly to be expected. So Cl. and Steup explain, but it would seem better to write, with St., custrateu/sein. See Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 11.—8.

h)/dh: local, as in ii. 96. 17; viii. 101. 15; Eur. Hipp. 1200 pro\s po/nton h)/dh keime/nh *sarwniko/n.
Kühn. 499, 2.—9.
ou)=n: resumes the narrative after the explanation and parenthesis. Cf. vi. 64. 13; vii. 6. 7; 42. 24.—10.
*so/llion: cf. ii. 30. 2. See Bursian i. p. 115.
ou) prosede/canto: did not approve. Cf. c. 15. 2; ii. 70. 10.—12.
th\n ou) peritei/xisin: see on c. 94. 12. For the adv. qualifying the subst., see G. 952, 1; H. 600; Kühn. 461, 6; Kr. Spr. 50, 8, 4. Cf. i. 137. 29; v. 35. 6; 50. 17; vii. 34. 26; 44. 42. —14.

triakosi/ois toi=s e)piba/tais: on thirty triremes (c. 94. 3), as iv. 76. 2; 101. 13 there are 400 on forty. ‘In the Peloponnesian war only ten heavy-armed epibatae used to be put on board of a trireme.’ Boeckh, P. E. p. 384. See on i. 49. 4.—15.
tw=n *kerkurai/wn: cf. c. 94. 8.
*oi)new=nos: northeast of Naupactus, on or near the coast. Steph. Byz. *oi)new/n, *lokri/dos limh/n. Cf. c. 98. 17; 102. 4. See Bursian i. p. 148.— 17.
cu/mmaxoi: cf. l. 3; ii. 9. 8.— 18.
e)/dei au)tou\s kte(.: i.e. acc. to agreement. Cf. c. 2. 7; ii. 5. 1; 92. 24; 95. 16; vi. 56. 11.—19.
o(/moroi kai\ o(mo/skeuoi: connected as in ii. 96. 7. —21.
ma/xhs: manner of fighting, as in iv. 34. 15.

p.hi: All the Aetolian peoples unite to repel the invasion.

div2.p: au)lisa/menos: doubtless after the first day's march. The temple of Nemean Zeus, in whose neighbourhood the troops first rested, was situated in Locris (possibly in the territory of Oeneon, Bursian i. p. 148), so that the enumeration of the days (l. 5 ff.) begins from the advance into Aetolia.—
e)n tou= *dio\s . . . tw=| i(erw=|: for the order, see on c. 70. 16. —2.

le/getai: for the particulars of
the tradition, cf. Plut. Sept. Sap. Conv. 19. See O. Friedl, Die Sage vom Tode Hesiods (Fleckeisens Jahrbb., Suppl. Bd. x. p. 233 ff.).—
u(po\ tw=n tau/th|: const. with a)poqanei=n. Cf. c. 90. 8; i. 9. 10.—3.

xrhsqe/n: neut. pass. partic. in acc. abs. GMT. 851; H. 973; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 5. Cf. i. 140. 13; vii. 18. 14. The cause of this mention is doubtless Thuc.'s critical interest in oracles which admitted of different interpretations. Cf. ii. 17. 11; 54. 6. This verb, in the sense give an oracle, occurs in Thuc. only in aor., act. five times, pass. once; to consult an oracle, once (xrw/menos, i. 126. 9). This use of the word seems to be mainly Ionic and poetic. See Diener, De Serm. Thuc. etc. p. 42.—

tou=to paqei=n: for the aor. inf. with xrhsqe/n, cf. Hdt. vii. 220. 10 e)ke/xrhsto ga\r u(po\ th=s *huqi/hs . . ., h)\ *lakedai/mona a)na/staton gene/sqai u(po\ tw=n barba/rwn, h)\ to\n basile/a sfe/wn a)pole/sqai.

*potidani/an, *kroku/leion, *tei/xion: places of the Apodotians, whose situations cannot be definitely fixed (Bursian i. p. 142), any more than the Locrian *eu)pa/lion mentioned in l. 7 and c. 102. 4 (Bursian i. p. 148). —8.
th\n gnw/mhn ei)=xe: see on c. 92. 11. —
ta)=lla: for which a less general expression might have been expected, must be understood prob. only of the territory of the Apodotians (c. 94. 23). —

ou(/tws: resumes emphatically ta)=lla katastreya/menos. H. 976 b; Kühn. 486, N. 5. Cf. i. 37. 4. The goal of the expedition was the distant Ophioneans (c. 94. 24), but his purpose was, after first subduing the intervening country, to advance from Naupactus with fresh forces.

ou)/te o(/te . . ., e)peidh/ te kte(.: the sent. has an anacoluthon, for instead of a second dependent temporal clause introduced by ou)/te, an independent and positive clause follows. See on c. 39. 14.—
e)pebouleu/eto: pass. with h( paraskeuh/, as subj. (cf. vi. 88. 43); often with pers. subj., as in c. 109. 21.—12.

xeiri/: in the sense of a military force only here in Thuc. but freq. in Hdt. Cf. also Aesch. Suppl. 958; Eur. Heracl. 337; El. 629. It occurs also in Xen.
Oec. 21. 8, and late writers.—13.
pro\s to\n *mhliako\n ko/lpon: towards the Malian gulf.—14.
*bwmih=s kai\ *kallih=s: for the little that is known of the seats of these peoples, see Bursian i. p. 141 f.
Pressing forward without waiting for the Locrians, Demosthenes is attacked at Aegitium by the Aetolians with superior numbers.
toio/nde ti: without following ga/r, as in ii. 75. 23; viii. 50. 5. See on c. 92. 2. In such connexions, Thuc. uses also the simple toio/nde, to/de and ta/de. See on ii. 75. 23.— 2.

o(/per kai\ to\ prw=ton: cf. c. 94. § 3 ff. Steup removes the colon after to\ prw=ton, on the ground that the words a)nadida/skontes . . . ai(/resis are confusing if connected with what follows rather than with to\ prw=ton. —a)nadida/skontes: = dida/skontes, teaching, as in i. 32. 4; viii. 86. 4, not teaching otherwise or better. Nothing indicates that Dem. had held a different opinion with regard to an attack upon the Aetolians.—
tw=n *ai)twlw=n . . . ai(/resis: cf. c. 94. § 4. —
tw=n *ai)twlw=n: emphatic position before the conj. See on c. 88. 8.— 4.
ta\s kw/mas: cf. c. 94. 20.—5.

th
 e)n posi
 ai)ei/: the first village in his way. kw/mhn can be supplied the more easily, since kai\ mh\ me/nein . . . a)ntita/cwntai is only inserted as an explanation of o(/ti ta/xista. For the expression th
 e)n posi/n, cf. Hdt. iii. 79. 7 e)/kteinon pa/nta tina\ tw=n *ma/gwn to
 e)n posi\ gino/menon, Soph. Ant. 1327 bra/xista ga kra/tista ta)n posi
 kaka/, Eur. Alc. 739 tou)n posi
 ga oi)ste/on kako/n, also Androm. 397; Pind. Pyth. 8. 33. It is used also by Dio C. and Lucian.

th=| tu/xh| e)lpi/sas: confident on account of his good fortune. The dat. with e)lpi/zein gives the ground of the hope, as in c. 98. 27; ii. 89. 24 with fobei=sqai; iv. 85. 9; vii. 63. 13 with qauma/zein, and freq. with pisteu/ein (c. 46. 1, etc.).—7.
tou\s *lokrou/s: cf. c. 95. 17.—8.
yilw=n a)kontistw=n: of this kind of yiloi/ consisted, acc. to the following account, the army of the Aetolians. Cf. c. 94. 21 skeuh=| yilh=| xrw/menon.—9.

*ai)giti/ou: in the territory of the Apodotians. See
Bursian i. p. 142.—
kata\ kra/tos: by storm, as in c. 18. 19; 103. 3, etc. See on i. 64. 14.—10.
e)piw/n: at the first onset.—
u(pe/fugon: had stolen away. So, with v. H., for u(pe/feugon of the Mss. After the impf., kai\ e)ka/qhnto would be unsuitable, since it denotes the holding, not the taking, of a position.—
oi( a)/nqrwpoi: i.e. the inhabitants of Aegitium.—12.

e)f) u(yhlw=n xwri/wn: cf. c. 105. 5. The pl. is doubtless to be explained by kata\ kw/mas oi)kei=n, c. 94. 20 (cf. l. 4), i.e. the open place consisted of a number of villages scattered over the hills. Steup explains, near, in the neighbourhood of, high points, comparing e)pi\ *qra/|khs (i. 56. 11, etc.) and v. 34. 7 kei/menon e)pi\ th=s *lakwnikh=s kai\ th=s *)hlei/as. Kr. would omit xwri/wn. But for xwri/on in this sense, cf. v. 65. 2 xwri/on e)rumno\n kai\ duspro/sodon, ibid. 6 xwri/on kartero/n, vii. 73. 9 ta\ steno/pora tw=n xwri/wn.
bebohqhko/tes h)=san: on the periphrasis, see on c. 2. 8 and App. on i. 1. 5.—14.

e)pi\ to\ *ai)gi/tion: for the const. bohqei=n e)pi\ to/pon, carry aid to a place, cf. iv. 8. 3; 72. 2; vi. 65. 20; Hdt. iv. 125. 18; bohqei=n e)s to/pon, iv. 42. 15; vii. 18. 4; viii. 60. 15; Hdt. vi. 103. 2. bohqei=n e)pi/ tina = carry aid against one, as c. 110. 8; i. 107. 21; 126. 22, etc.—16.
o(/te me\n e)pi/oi . . . e)pe/keinto: const. of sent. and tactics as in ii. 79. 24; vii. 79. 21. —19.

u(pagwgai/: a)naxwrh/seis, Schol. Only here in Thuc. For this signification, which seems not to occur elsewhere in the earlier Greek writers, cf. the use of the verb u(pa/gein in iv. 126. 34; v. 10. 15; viii. 10. 8.—

oi(=s a)mfote/rois: neut. after two fem. substs., as in vi. 72. 20. Cf. Dem. xviii. 171; Sall. Cat. 5 inopia rei familiaris et conscientia scelerum, quae utraque his artibus auxerat. Kr. Spr. 58, 3, 5.

p.hi: Demosthenes is forced to retreat and suffers heavy losses in his flight. On that account he avoids returning to Athens for some time.

div2.p:
me/xri: here and c. 10. 12 with the impf., so long as; iv. 4. 3, with aor.
ind. of an historical, and i. 137. 13 with the aor. subjv. of a hypothetical, case. There are no other instances of the simple me/xri as conj. in Thuc.; for me/xri ou(=, however, see on c. 28. 15.—

au)toi=s: on their side, dat. of interest in loose relation, as in l. 9; i. 6. 8; 48. 9. G. 1170; H. 771. Schol. a)nti\ tou= oi( toco/tai au)tw=n. Reiske's proposed change in the order, kai\ au)toi=s . . . xrh=sqai, is unnecessary.— 2.
toceuo/menoi . . . a)neste/llonto: i.e. so long as they were exposed to the arrows of the archers they were driven back. a)neste/llonto, as in vi. 70. 15. —3.

a)/nqrwpoi yiloi/: cf. c. 94. 21. The words are bracketed by v. H., as a gloss from l. 12 a)/nqrwpoi podw/keis kai\ yiloi/, on the ground that hoplites also could have been wounded with arrows, and that the archers were yiloi/ as well as the Aetolians. But hoplites, could, at any rate, protect themselves far better, and the toco/tai are not reckoned among the yiloi/ also in iv. 36. 3; 94. 4; v. 47. 39; viii. 71. 18.—4.
ou(=toi: oi( toco/tai.— 5. au)toi/: the main body of the army, esp. the hoplites.—
kai\ e)pi\ polu/: for quite a long time. kai/, as in kai\ ma/la or kai\ pa/nu. Cf. i. 91. 3 kai\ safw=s, quite positively. Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 18. e)pi\ polu/, as c. 97. 18; i. 6. 12.—
tw=| au)tw=| po/nw|: referring to the manner of fighting described in c. 97. § 3.—
cunexo/menoi: hard pressed, as in ii. 49. 24.—6.
oi(/ te *ai)twloi/: te introducing third cause.—
ou(/tw dh/: introducing the decisive moment, as in i. 131. 8; ii. 12. 16; 19. 3. Cf. to/te dh/, i. 49. 30; 58. 9.—7.
e)spi/ptontes . . . diefqei/ronto: cf. c. 112. 22.—
xara/dras: here, as in c. 25. 4; 107. 14; 112. 22, the deep beds of mountain streams, whether filled with water or not.—10.
e)tu/gxane teqnhkw/s: i.e. in the preceding battle.
au)tou= e)n th=| troph=|: see on au)tou= e)n tw=| i(erw=|, c. 81. 15.—
kata\ po/das ai(rou=ntes: Schol. sunto/mws. Cf. iv. 126. 38; v. 64. 8; viii. 17. 15.—12.
dw/keis: poetic word, found also in Plato Rep. 467 e; Xen. Mem. iii. 11. 8; de Eq. 3. 12.—14.
e)sferome/nous: falling into. Bk. proposed e)kferome/nous, which Cobet (Mnem. N. S. viii. p. 144) approves as the proper expression for those who have lost their way.
pa=sa i)de/a: see on c. 81. 22.— 16.
tw=| stratope/dw|: Reiske's emendation, for tw=n stratope/dwn of all the Mss., restores the proper number (c. 97. 17) and case (c. 83. 2).—17.
to\n *oi)new=na: cf. c. 95. 16. The masc., as to\n *krommuw=na in iv. 42. 22. See Göttling, p. 266.

tosou=toi me\n . . . diefqa/rhsan: the removal of the colon before ou)=toi, as Haase suggested (Lucubr. p. 7), brings the two modifiers, of number and age, into a pred. relation to ou)=toi. “So many in number and all of the same age, these were the best men from the city of Athens that perished in this war.” h(liki/a h( au)th/ collective and pregnant in meaning = i)/soi th\n h(liki/an. Arn. prob. rightly infers from this remark, ‘that the epibatae on this occasion were not taken solely from the class of the Thetes, but that some young men of higher families had been induced to serve on this expedition.’ See on c. 16. 5. The emphasis laid by Thuc. upon the greatness of the Athenian loss makes strongly against the view of Swoboda (Thuk. Quellenstud. p. 50 ff.), approved by Köhler (Hermes xxvi. p. 46), that Thuc.'s account of the Aetolian campaign and its results is too favourable to Demosthenes.—21.
be/ltistoi dh\ a)/ndres: since Thuc. gives no explanation of this high praise, it is left uncertain whether e)n tw=| pole/mw| tw=|de refers to the ten years', or to the twenty-seven years', war.
*proklh=s: cf. c. 91. 3.—24.

u(pospo/ndous a)nelo/menoi: an acknowl
edgment of defeat. In ii. 22. 15, the words a)nei/lonto au)tou\s a)spo/ndous show that the defeat was not decisive. See on i. 63. 17.—27.
u(pelei/fqh: sc. until he returned to Athens with the booty from the Amphilochian campaign, c. 114. § 1.—
toi=s pepragme/nois . . . *)aqhnai/ous: cf. c. 114. 7. For the causal dat., see on c. 97. 6.

p.hi: The Attic ships in the Sicilian waters make a landing in the territory of the Italian Locri.

div2.p: oi( peri\ *sikeli/an *)aqhnai=oi: cf. c. 90.—3.
tou\s prosbohqh/santas: one of the few cases where kratei=n takes the acc. without ma/xh|. See on c. 91. 16.—4.
peripo/lion: i.e. a fort for the protection of the plain, called frou/rion c. 115. 21. Cf. vi. 45. 6; vii. 48. 32.—
tw=| *(/alhki potamw=|: cf. Strabo, p. 260 c o( diori/zwn th\n *(rhgi/nhn a)po\ th=s *lokri/dos.

p.hi: At the request of the Aetolians the Spartans send an army under Eurylochus against Naupactus.

div2.p:
prope/myantes pro/teron: the pleonasm as in c. 53. 9; i. 23. 21; vi. 57. 10. The reference is generally explained to be to the time before the invasion of Dem., the hostility of the Aetolians to Naupactus being assumed to have been of long standing (cf. c. 94. 17). But Steup urges against this view the absence of any definite date, as well as of any statement as to the object of the embassy; further, that no one has explained how Corinthians, as well as Lacedaemonians, are the implied object of pei/qousin, although the pe/myai stratia/n seems to have been the business of the Lacedaemonians alone (cf. l. 6 kai\ e)ce/pemyan *lakedaimo/nioi kte(.). He assumes, therefore, that the text is corrupt, and that originally perhaps it was said, that the Aetolians, before sending to Sparta, had already asked Corinth and some other state for help, viz.: *ai)twloi/, prope/myantes pro/teron e)/s te *ko/rinqon kai\ e)s *boiwtou/s, a)postei/lantes e)s *lakedai/mona pre/sbeis kte(.—3. *to/lofo/n te to\n *)ofione/a kte(.: sc. as the representatives of the chief tribes, c. 94. § 5. For the art. with these names, see on —
4.
*tei/sandron: for the form, see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 38; Meisterhans,^{2} p. 41, 144. See on c. 92. 8.—
pei/qousin w(/ste: see on c. 31. 10.—5.

dia\ th\n tw=n *)aqhnai/wn e)pagwgh/n: on account of their bringing on the Athenians against the Aetolians. Cf. c. 94. § 3 ff.; 95. § 2; 97. § 1; 98. § 1. e)pagwgh/ is from the act. e)pa/gein, not the mid. e)pa/gesqai. See on c. 82. 9.
peri\ to\ fqino/pwron: see on c. 18. 15; ii. 31. 1.—8.

e)c *(hraklei/as . . . ou)/shs: cf. c. 92 f. A mention of the Mantineans might have been expected here (cf. c. 107. 27; 108. 16; 109. 12; 111. 2, 14; 113. 4), esp. as there is no further mention of the 500 Heracleots.—
th=s e)n *traxi=ni: see on c. 92. 2. —9.
neokti/stou: found only here in Thuc. Cf. Hdt. v. 24. 20; Pind. Nem. 9. 3. Cf. neokata/statos, c. 93. 9.— 10.
cunhkolou/qoun: acc. to the law, a)/rxein, ei)/ ti e)kei=nos pa/sxoi (iv. 38. 9), as it really happened in this case, c. 109. § 1. As to the usual number of three, see on c. 92. 22.—11.

*meneda/ios: doubtless the correct form, restored by Dind. in Steph. Thes. (not *mene/daios, or *mene/datos). It is Doric for *menedh/ios.—oi( *spartia=tai: for the art., cf. ll. 3, 4; 25. 2; 98. 9; i. 126. 41; iv. 132. 6; viii. 26. 8; 35. 2. Acc. to L. Herbst (Philol. xl. p. 281), the art. is used here on account of the antithesis between the leaders and an army composed only of allies. But that Thuc. should have stressed this antithesis in the case of the associates of Eurylochus more than of the chief commander, is not probable.

p.hi: The army of Eurylochus collects at Delphi and compels most of the tribes of the Ozolian Locrians to join the expedition.

div2.p: e)s *delfou/s: at that time on the Lacedaemonian side. Cf. i. 118. § 3; 123. § 1 f.; ii. 54. § 4.—3.
dia\ tou/twn: i.e. through their territory. Cf. c. 110. 4.—
tw=n *)aqhnai/wn a)posth=sai: cf. c. 95. § 3.

tw=n *lokrw=n: depends not upon ma/lista, but upon *)amfissh=s. Cf. i.
27. 11 *halh=s *kefallh/nwn, v. 67. 7 *)arka/dwn *(hraih=s. There is no ground for the assumption that other Locrian tribes besides the Amphissians had from the beginning supported the efforts of Eurylochus. One might have expected, too, from the context, to find the relation of the Amphissians to the Locrians more sharply emphasized; hence possibly the text should read au)tw=n tw=n *lokrw=n. With cune/prasson it would be easy to supply au)tw=|. Cf. iv. 76. 13; 103. 9; v. 43. 21; viii. 60. 2.—

dia\ to\ tw=n *fwke/wn e)/xqos dedio/tes: i.e. because they feared, if they did not join the expedition, it would go hard with them, on account of their hostility to their Phocian neighbours, who were in alliance with Sparta. That the Phocians, as a state, were in alliance with Sparta, may be inferred from ii. 9. 8; iv. 118. 5, and from the whole manner of Eurylochus's expedition against Naupactus. The fact that Demosthenes, acc. to c. 95. 6, had hoped that the Phocians would join him, in an attack upon Boeotia from the west, proqu/mws kata\ th\n *)aqhnai/wn ai)ei/ pote fili/an, is scarcely applicable in explanation of the present passage, since in c. 95. 7 it is added h)\ ka)\n bi/a| prosaxqh=nai. Besides, the state of affairs in those regions at that time was not such as to excite fear of the Athenians.— 6.
kai\ au)toi\ prw=toi do/ntes: see App. —7.

tou\s a)/llous foboume/nous to\n e)pio/nta strato/n: the const. as in i. 44. 15 toi=s a)/llois nauti<*>o\n e)/xousin, i. 91. 2 tw=n a)/llwn a)fiknoume/nwn. That not all the rest of the Locrians are meant, is clear from c. 102. § 1.—
e)/peisan dou=nai: for the position, see on c. 63. 8.—8.
me\n ou)=n: in explanation of tou\s a)/llous foboume/nous unusual, since no new finite verb follows. But cf. iv. 104. 20.—

*muone/as: this form is attested for Thuc. not only by the Mss., but also by Paus. vi. 19. 5 and Steph. Byz. s.v. *muoni/a. The Delphian inscriptions have always *muaneu/s. The forms *mua=nes (Paus.) and *mu/ones (Steph. Byz.) seem to be due to misconceptions. See Dittenberger, Sylloge Inscr. no. 462 N. The place is called *muwni/a in Paus. x. 38. 8, but in Steph. Byz. *muoni/a and *mu/wn. As to its site, see Bursian i. p. 152. —9.

dusesbolw/tatos: fem., see on c. 89. 21. The Amphilochians seem to have given a first proof of their zeal for their new allies by winning over the inhabitants of the region which in nature and situation was most important for the proposed expedition of the Peloponnesians.—
e)/peita *)ipne/as kte(.: for the Locrian tribes mentioned in the remainder of the chapter, whose locality generally cannot be exactly determined, see Bursian i. p. 149 f. and 152.—10.

*messapi/ous: cf. Steph. Byz. s.v. *xa/-
laion, where, citing the words from *messapi/ous to *oi)anqe/as, the Mss. read *metapi/ous. But since several of the following names are unquestionably cited incorrectly in Steph., the preference can hardly be given here to the Mss. of Steph., as Niese claims in Hermes xiv. p. 427 f.—

*tritaia=s: as *hlataia=s, c. 52. 15. The Mss. of Thuc. have *tritaie/as, those of Steph. Byz. l.c. *tritai/ous. St. read *triteie/as, acc. to Steph. Byz. s.v. *tri/teia, but in Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 43 has declared for Meineke's conjecture *trite/as, which is based on Hdt. viii. 33. 4 and Hesych. *trith=es geneh/n. The city seems to have been called *tri/teia as well as *tri/taia.—12. *)olpai=oi: these Locrians are prob. to be distinguished from the inhabitants of the Amphilochian *)/olpai or *)/olph, mentioned c. 105. 5 and freq.—13.
*(uai=oi: Steph. Byz. *(uai/a: po/lis *lokrw=n *)ozolw=n. to\ e)qniko\n *(uai=os.
The attack on Naupactus fails, because Demosthenes throws Acarnanian reinforcements into the town. Eurylochus then turns, at the request of the Ambraciots, against the Amphilochian Argos.
kate/qeto: sc. *eu)ru/loxos, c. 101. 2. See on c. 28. 14.—
*kuti/nion: see on c. 95. 5; i. 107. 5.—4.
*oi)new=na . . . kai\ *eu)pa/lion: the reverse of the geographical order. See on c. 29. 6. For the former place, see on c. 95. 16; 98. 17; for the latter, c. 96. 7.—
au)tw=n: for the part. gen., cf. 101. 5 tw=n *lokrw=n, 86. 10 th=s *)itali/as *lokroi\ me\n kte(.

kai\ . . . prosbebohqhko/tes: supplementary addition to geno/menoi e)n th=| *naupakti/a| (sc. oi( cu\n *eu)rulo/xw|). The pf. partic. has reference to the union already effected before the entry into the territory of Naupactus. The undeniable harshness of the const. involved in joining by means of kai\ . . . a(/ma a second subject to one merely implied in an appositive partic. (geno/menoi) would be removed by assuming, with Steup (Quaest. Thuc. p. 50 sq.), that au)toi/ has been lost before kai\ oi(. Cf. iv. 90. 2; 131. 1. —6.
h)/dh prosbebohqhko/tes: cf. c. 6. 10.—7.

*molu/kreion: cf. ii. 84. 28,
—8.
th\n *korinqi/wn me\n a)poiki/an kte(.: concerning Potidaea, cf. i. 56. 6.—
u(ph/koon: sc. po/lin. Doubtless to be construed subst., as cummaxi/da, ii. 2 11, and cu/mmaxon, v. 35. 2.

o( *)aqhnai=os: the mention of Demosthenes among the distant cu/mmaxoi causes the addition of the e)qniko/n.—10. meta\ ta\ e)k th=s *ai)twli/as: for meta\ ta\ e)n th=| *ai)twli/a|, with reference to the retreat, c. 98. Cf. iv. 81. 9 e)s to
 meta\ ta\ e)k *sikeli/as po/lemon, vi. 89. 5 peri\ th
 e)k *hu/lou cumfora/n, viii. 2. 1 pro\s th
 e)k th=s *sikeli/as . . . kakopragi/an. Kr. Spr. 50, 8, 13. For the attraction of the prep., see also on c. 5. 1.—
peri\ *nau/pakton: c. 98. 26.—11.
tou= stratou=: the gen. with proaisqo/menos, as with the simple verb. See on i. 57. 14. G. 1102; H. 742.—
peri\ au)th=s: sc. th=s *naupa/ktou, as viii. 93. 17 e)fobei=to peri\ tou= politikou=. Elsewhere peri/ after verbs of fear takes the dat. See on i. 60. 3.— 12.
xalepw=s dia\ th\n . . . a)naxw/rhsin: Inserted almost parenthetically. As to the matter, cf. c. 95. § 1.

e)pi\ tw=n new=n: can refer only to ships of the Acarnanians, for the thirty Athenian ships, which Dem. had commanded in the spring and summer, had returned to Athens (c. 98. 25), and the twenty mentioned c. 105. 15 sailed later. The fifteen Corcyraean ships (c. 94. 8), to which Müller-Strübing refers (Aristoph. etc. p. 491 N.), had also returned home (c. 95. 15). That the Acarnanians possessed ships is, with their extensive coast, altogether probable, even though there be a lack of good harbours. Since these ships are not mentioned before, and their number cannot have been great (cf. ii. 9. § 4, 5), Steup proposes e)pi/ tinwn new=n, comparing, for the order of the words, iv. 76. 5; viii. 32. 12.—
periepoi/hsan: cf. ii. 25. 13.—15.
deino\n ga\r h)=n: sc. before aid came. deino/n, as in iv. 75. 7; vii. 25. 31.
e)selhluqui=an: the pf. partic. emphasizes the fact that it was now too late for an attack.—19.

*ai)oli/da: this ancient name of the district is not
found elsewhere in ancient writers, but is supported by Strabo's remark (p. 464 c), th\n *hleurwni/an u(po\ *kourh/twn oi)koume/nhn *ai)olei=s e)pelqo/ntes a)fei/lonto. Cf. also the remark of Hesychius, h( ga\r *kaludw\n *ai)oli\s e)kalei=to. See Niebuhr, Vortr. etc. p. 146; Bursian i. p. 130. On the text, see App.— 20.
*kaludw=na kai\ *pleurw=na: see Bursian i. p. 129 ff.—21.
*pro/sxion: on the site of the Homeric Pylene (B 639). Bursian i. p. 131.
*)/argei te . . . kai\ *)akarnani/a|: the Ambraciots recur to their plans of the year 430 and 429 B.C. Cf. ii. 68, and 80-82.—24.

kai\ *)akarnani/a| a(/ma, le/gontes kte(.: so with Bk., Pp., and Kr., not kai\ *)akarnani/a|, a(/ma le/gontes kte(., since a(/ma would be out of place in a statement of the means by which the Ambraciots persuaded Eurylochus over to their plans, whereas the correlation te, kai\ a(/ma occurs often in Thuc. (c. 40. 17; v. 69. 4; vi. 15. 8; vii. 19. 3). Cf. ii. 80. § 1, where the const. pei/qousi. . ., le/gontes o(/ti occurs in a similar passage.— 25.
pa=n to\ h)peirwtiko\n kte(.: similar promises were made ii. 80. § 1. to\ h)peirwtiko/n, as in c. 94. 18.—
cu/mmaxon kaqesth/cei: see on c. 37. 13.

tou\s *ai)twlou\s a)fei/s: thus abandoning the enterprise undertaken at their instance. Cf. c. 7. 13; ii. 78. 3; v. 75. 2. The Locrians also (cf. c. 101. § 2) seem to have been dismissed at that time by Eurylochus. —28.

e(/ws . . . de/oi bohqei=n: “until the right moment should have come to lend aid,” which is expressed by the aor. partic. e)kstrateusame/nois, “when the Ambraciots should have taken the field.” This occurs c. 105. 1, *)amprakiw=tai . . . e)kstrateu/ontai e)pi\ *)/argos. For the opt., see GMT. 614; H. 921. —
peri\ to\ *)/argos: const. with bohqei=n.

p.hi: Beginning of the winter of 426-25 B.C. Further operations of the Athenians in Sicily and on the Italian coast.

div2.p: oi( e)n th=| *sikeli/a| *)aqhnai=oi: continuation of c. 90 and 99.—2.

tw=n *(ellh/nwn cumma/xwn: sc. tw=n *sikeliwtw=n, who are enumerated c. 86. § 2. For the adj. use of *(ellh/nwn, cf. i. 62. 16; iv. 25. 34; v. 6. 21, and see on c. 95. 2; ii. 36. 13; vi. 62. 9. See Rutherford, New Phrynichus, p. 21; Diener, De Serm. Thuc. p. 43 sq.— 3.
kai\ o(/soi *sikelw=n: i.e. kai\ meta\ tou/twn tw=n *sikelw=n, o(/soi—. The Sicels were the barbarian aborigines; the Siceliots the inhabitants of the Greek cities in Sicily.—

kata\ kra/tos a)rxo/menoi:—bi/a| a)rxo/menoi (c. 46. 21). Cf. Plut. Lyc. et Num. 3, [ai( gunai=kes] tw=n oi)/kwn a)/rxousai kata\ kra/tos.— a)rxo/menoi kai\ cu/mmaxoi o)/ntes: partics. impf., and as such preceding a)posta/ntes, “being subjects and allies of the Syracusans had now revolted from them.” Regarding the matter, cf. vi. 88. 21.—4.
au)toi=s: sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, with cunepole/moun. This connexion becomes clearer if, with v. H. (Stud. Thuc. p. 147) a)po\ *surakosi/wn be bracketed as an unnecessary gloss.—5.
e)p *)/inhssan: const. with e)pelqo/ntes. This was situated not far from Catana, acc. to Strab. p. 268 c. Cf. vi. 94. 15.—6.

prose/balon, a)ph=|san: prose/balon, with Bk. and some inferior Mss., for prose/ballon, since the context requires the comprehensive aor. But a)ph=|san is quite in place, since in what follows matters are narrated which occurred during the retreat.
u(ste/rois *)aqhnai/wn: after the Athenians. Cf. c. 49. 17.—11.
meta\ tou=to: includes the return to the coast and the voyage back to Rhegium (c. 86. 19; 88. 13; 115. 5), whence the following expeditions set out.— 12.
*la/xhs: cf. c. 90. 8.—
a)poba/seis tina/s: as already c. 99. 2.—13.

kata\ to\n *kaiki=non potamo/n: on the accent of *kaiki=nos, see Göttling, p. 203. This river is without doubt to be distinguished from the Halex (c. 99. 4), although Pausanias (vi. 6. 4) says the same thing of it as Strabo of the Halex, th\n *lokri/da kai\ *(rhgi/nhn o(ri/zwn. Either the courses of the rivers must have changed, or the boundary must have been different at different times.
The Athenians purify the island of Delos, and institute the Delian Penteteris.

*dh=lon e)ka/qhran: cf. i. 8. 3; Diod. xii. 58; Strab. p. 486, and see Curtius, Hist. of Greece, iii. p. 142. The occasion of this extraordinary homage to Apollo was doubtless the pestilence, which had reappeared in 427-26 B.C. (c. 87. § 1-3) with undiminished force, and the object of the festival seems to have been, not to give thanks to the god for the cessation of the plague, but to bring about its cessation. So at least Diodorus, l.c., represents the matter, and the narrative of Thuc. seems compatible with this view. For there is no reason why the beginning of the period during which the pestilence raged the second time (ou)k e)/lasson e)niautou=, c. 87. 4) should not be put far back into the winter of 427-26 B.C., whereas the purification of Delos must have been taken in hand early in the winter of 426-25, since acc. to c. 102. § 7; 105. § 1 the irruption of the Ambraciots into the territory of Argos (c. 105. § 1) could have happened only shortly after the end of the preceding summer. So it was deemed proper to propitiate the wrath of the god, to which many had ascribed the pestilence (cf. ii. 54. § 4 f.), in esp. solemn wise. The oracle directing the purification may have had some connexion with Nicias's influence at that time. Cf. Thuc. vii. 50. 30 h)=n ga/r ti kai\ a)/gan qeiasmw=| te kai\ tw=| toiou/tw| proskei/menos. The interest manifested by Thuc. in the occurrence was prob. due not only to its historical importance, but also to the wish to correct erroneous views of his contemporaries with regard to earlier and later *dh/lia. Hence here, as in vi. 54 ff., the digression with all its details is justifiable. See A. Baumeister, Hymn. Hom. p. 113, against G. Hermann, Philol. i. p. 372 (= Opusc. viii. p. 388 f.).—2.
dh/: in a supplementary explanation (cf. i. 24. 5; ii. 102. 28); not ironical, as Bl. thought possible. —3.

*peisi/stratos . . . ou)x a(/pasan: cf. Hdt. i. 64. 10 kaqh/ras de\ w(=de: e)p) o(/son e)/poyis tou= i(rou= ei)=xe, e)k tou/tou tou= xw/rou panto\s e)coru/cas tou\s nekrou\s metefo/ree e)s a)/llon xw=ron th=s *dh/lou.—4. o(/son . . . th=s nh/sou: cf. e)p) o(/son . . . tou= i(rou=, just cited from Hdt., and Thuc. vii. 37. 6 prosh=ge tw=| tei/xei tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, kaq) o(/son pro\s th\n po/lin au)tou= e(w/ra.

qh=kai o(/sai: without ga/r after toiw=|de. See on c. 92. 2; 97. 1. The subst. thus placed acquires a char
acter of generality, with nearly the effect of a part. gen. Cf. c. 113. 21, and see on i. 1. 8. qh=kai means here, doubtless, movable coffins, as in i. 8. 4; v. 1. 6, not “graves,” as in c. 58. 15. As to such coffins, see Müller, Handbuch iv. p. 463 b.—6.
a)nei=lon: as in i. 8. 4; v. 1. 6.—

to\ loipo/n: to be construed with e)napoqnh/|skein and e)nti/ktein. Cf. Diod. l.c. mh/te ti/ktein e)n *dh/lw| mh/te qa/ptein, Strabo 486 c ou) ga\r e)/cestin e)n au)th=| th=| *dh/lw| qa/ptein ou)de\ kai/ein nekro/n.—proei=pon: of a distinctly expressed order, as i. 45. 6.— 8.

e)s th\n *(rh/neian: cf. Strabo l.c. o(/pou ta\ mnh/mata toi=s *dhli/ois e)sti/n.—diakomi/zesqai: sc. tou/s te a)poqnh/|skontas kai\ ta\s tiktou/sas.—9. ou(/tws o)li/gon: four stadia, acc. to Strabo l.c.—
*polukra/ths . . . tw=| *)apo/llwni tw=| *dhli/w|: cf. i. 13. § 6.—10.

i)sxu/sas tina\ xro/non nautikw=|: who for some time was powerful in naval affairs. Cf. nautikw=| i)sxu/wn, i. 13. 28. The temporal modifier (tina xro/non) makes the above rendering seem necessary (cf. e)kra/thsa/n tina xro/non, i. 13. 27); though Cl., Kr., and Bm. take the aor. partic. as ingressive, like a)/rcas in —11.
*nh/swn: for the vulg. nh/<*>wn, since here, as in i. 13. 29; vii. 57. 15, and freq., not islands in general, but only the Cyclades are to be understood. See Steup, Rh. Mus. xxv. p. 328, N.—
a)/rcas: = u(phko/ous poihsa/menos (i. 13. 29), as the connexion with e(lw/n shows. Cf. i. 4. 3. This ingressive force is nearly confined to the first aor. GMT. 55; H. 841.— 12.
a(lu/sei dh/sas pro\s th\n *dh=lon: the chief stress of the sent. is on these words. The chaining of Rhenea to Delos indicates the proximity of the two islands.—

a(lu/sei dh/sas: ‘as a symbolical expression of indissoluble union.’ Curtius, ii. p. 142. Weiske (N. Jahrbb. cxxxvii. p. 555 f.) explains the a(lu/sei dh/sas as symbolically indicating the hanging up or setting up of an offering in the precinets of the temple of the god (a)natiqe/nai). But that a)natiqe/nai does not necessarily imply a hanging up or setting up of something in a sacred precinct, or indeed any local connexion with such a precinct, but may have the general meaning “consecrate,” is clear from i. 13. 29 *(rh/neian e(lw
 a)ne/qhke tw=| *)apo/llwni tw=| *dhli/w|, where the manner of the consecration must have been stated, had a)natiqe/nai only the narrower meaning claimed by Weiske. Cf. Hdt. <*>6 5 <*>h
 <*>o/ <*> h=| *)arte/midi.—13. th
 pentethri/da . . .

oi( *)aqhnai=oi: the quadrennial festival was celebrated by the Athenians then for the first time after the purification. th\n pentethri/da, cf. Poll. viii. 107. poiei=n, not the mid., of the celebration of a festival, as in ii. 15. 17; Plato Rep. 327 a. Cf. also l. 17; ii. 15. 24; v. 80. 18; vi. 28. 4; 58. 10. Since the celebration of the festival, acc. to the present passage, followed directly upon the purification undertaken at the beginning of the winter (see on l. 1), it could not have occurred, as Boeckh thinks (Sthlt. d. Athen. ii.^{2} p. 82), in the Attic month Thargelion, and hardly, as C. Robert conjectures (Hermes xxi. p. 161 ff.), in Anthesterion.—14. [

ta\ *dh/lia]: rightly bracketed by v. H., Stud. Thuc. p. 48, as a gloss to th\n pentethri/da. The context renders the addition unnecessary; besides, the term ta\ *dh/lia was not restricted to the pentethri/s. Cf. Xen. Mem. iv. 8. 2.
cu/nodos e)s th\n *dh=lon: as i. 96. 10 cu/nodoi e)s to\ i(ero\n e)gi/gnonto, and, similarly, l. 17 e)s ta\ *)efe/sia, sc. e)qew/roun (cf. viii. 10. 2).—

tw=n *)iw/nwn kte(.: acc. to l. 40, mention of the Athenians might have been expected here. Possibly *)aqhnai/wn kai\ has dropped out after kai/. *)iw/nwn refers, as *)/iwnes in l. 17, to the Ionians of Asia Minor. These Ionians, whose participation in the older festival was one of the chief distinctions between that and the later (1.39 ff.), are esp. emphasized by te, which would naturally follow directly after the art. belonging to both nouns. Cf. i. 6. 2.—
periktio/nwn nhsiwtw=n: i.e. the inhabitants of the Cyclades. perikti/ones, found only here in Thuc., is poetic (Hom. P 220; *s 212; b 65), and possibly taken from some ancient hymn.—16.
cu/n te ga\r kte(.: in explanation of mega/lh cu/nodos (cf. l. 39).—
e)qew/roun: of the whole celebration of the festival, as in v. 18. 4; 50. 8. qewrei=n e)s also viii. 10. 2; Ar. Vesp. 1183; Luc. Tim. 50.—17.
ta\ *)efe/sia: sc. at the temple of Artemis; of which Dion. H. (iv. 25) gives a similar deseription.—
a)gw\n e)poiei=to: a contest was instituted. Cf. l. 43; v. 80. 17, and see on 18.

xorou\s a) n h=gon: brought out, conducted, choral dances. Cf. Hes. Sc. 280; Callim. Del. 279 pa=sai de\ xorou\s a)na/gousi, Eur. Troad. 325 pa/lle po/d) ai)qe/rion, a)/nage xoro/n, 332 xo/reue, ma=ter, a)/nage. Hdt. has o(rth\n a)na/gein (ii. 40. 4; 48. 4; 61. 2). Cf. o(rta/zousi mega/las a)na/gontes qusi/as, Hdt. ii. 60. 13.

*(/omhros: clearly regarded by Thuc. as the author of the hymn here cited. How definite a personality he was to Thuc., is shown esp. by See Sengebusch, Hom. Diss.
i. p. 140.—
e)n toi=s e)/pesi: ta\ e)/ph used by Thuc. only of verses or poetic expressions. Cf. i. 3. 16; ii. 41. 14; 54. 4, and see on c. 67. 31.—20.

e)k prooimi/ou: Schol. e)c u(/mnou: tou\s ga\r u(/mnous prooi/mia e)ka/loun, i.e. introductions to the recitation of other songs. See Wolf, Proleg. ad Hom. p. evii. The two following citations are from the hymn to the Delian Apollo, 146 ff. and 165 ff. Several deviations in Thuc.'s version from that of the hymn are due without doubt to his following a different original, not to quoting from memory. See Baumeister, ibid. p. 141; Guttmann, de Hymn. Hom. Hist. Crit. p. 17 sq.; Bücheler, Coniectanea (Index Schol., Bonn, W. 1878-79), p. 3 sq.—21.

a)ll) o(/te: most recent editors write a)/llote, with Camerarius; but even thus, Steup thinks, no proper connexion with the preceding verses is established (see Gemoll, Hom. Hymnen, p. 143). He proposes, therefore, a)ll) o(/ti, and to take e)/nqa of l. 22 not as rel., but dem., as in l. 24.—23.
a)/guian: i.e. the street leading to the temple. —25.
kaqe/swsin a)gw=na: certamen instituant. Guttmann, p. 22, compares Hom. y 258 <*>anen eu)ru\n <*> w=na.

kai\ mousikh=s a)gw/n: in l. 24 f. only a gumniko\s a)gw/n (pugmaxi/h|) was implied beyond all doubt, since o)rxhstui= kai\ a)oidh=| might refer to the xoroi/ of l. 18 (cf. l. 40). Thuc. adds, therefore, special testimony for the musical contests.—
a)gwniou/menoi: sc. mousikh/n. Cf. l. 34 f.—27.
to\n . . . xoro\n tw=n gunaikw=n: hymn v. 156164.—28.

e)teleu/ta . . . e)s ta/de ta\ e)/ph: cf. ii. 51. 5; iv. 48. 23 e)s tou=to e)tel<*>i/ta, Soph. O. C. 476 to\ d' e)/nqen poi= teleuth=sai/ me xrh/;—tou= e)pai/nou: sc. tou= tw=n gunaikw=n. For the gen. with teleuta=n, see on c. 59. 19.
—33.
a)/llos e)pelqw/n: Bücheler, ibid. p. 4, proposes a)/lloqen e)lqw/n.
tosau=ta me/n: adv. so far.—

e)tekmhri/wsen: used by Thuc. alone of Attic writers, and only of Homer's evidence. Cf. i. 3. 12; 9. 24. It is common in the writers of the koinh\ dia/lektos.—40. meq) i(erw=n: i.e. with the sacrifices and all that pertained to the festal offerings.—41.

kai\ ta\ plei=sta: and indeed most things, as Bm. explains. Not only did the contests fall into disuse, but the Ionians came no more, women and children were no longer brought along, and otherwise the number of participants seems to have greatly diminished. Cl. explained as = vel plurima, with St., a sort of limiting appos. to ta\ peri\ tou\s a)gw=nas. But the a)gw=nes unquestionably ceased entirely. For this reason Kr. is certainly wrong in bracketing kai/.—42. pri\n dh/: until, see on c. 29. 5.—
to\n a)gw=na: i.e. the contest held afterwards every four years.—43.
e)poi/hsan: see on

The Ambraciots, in order to bring the Amphilochian Argos to terms, occupy Olpae in its territory: the Acarnanians summon to the protection of the place Demosthenes and twenty Athenian ships, which happened to be on the Peloponnesian coast.
w(/sper u(posxo/menoi: cf. c. 102. § 6, 7.—2.

e)kstrateu/ontai: to be construed only with w(/sper u(posxo/menoi *eu)rulo/xw|, for th\n stratia\n kate/sxon expresses merely the result of the promise, and has no effect on e)kstrateu/ontai. The chief emphasis of the sent. is on the partic., as in c. 53. 14. The sense of the passage is, as Jow. renders, “in fulfilment of the promise by which they had induced Eurylochus and his army to remain, the Ambraciots make an expedition—.”
—3.
*)/argos to\ *)amfiloxiko/n: on the inmost recess of the Ambracian gulf. On its relation to Ambracia, cf. ii. 68. § 1.—5.

*)/olpas: the sing. in c. 107. 13; 111. 5; 113. 2. Cf. *)idomenh/ (c. 112. 2; 113. 14) and *)idomenai/ (113. 10); *plataiai/ (ii. 7. 1; 10. 1) and *plataia/ (everywhere in Thuc. except the two places just cited); *kegxreiai/ (viii. 10. 5; 20. 6; 23. 2), *kegxreia/ (iv. 42. 21; 44. 14). As to the site of this fortress, with which the *)olpai=oi of c. 101. 12 have nothing to do, as well as of *krh=nai (l. 10), see Bursian i. p. 38, and Oberhummer, Akarnanien, p. 27 f.—

o(\ . . . e)xrw=nto: o(/ with teixisa/menoi, from which w(=| is to be supplied with e)xrw=nto. The sent. is best explained with Schoemann, Gr. Alterth. ii.^{3} p. 76, that the Acarnanians after fortifying Olpae had once used it as a common place of justice for their alliance. For the impf. with pote expressing what formerly existed for some time, cf. ii. 44. 8; viii. 52. 12; 62. 13, and the pres. partic., i. 132. 30; v. 43. 11; vi. 92. 5. Prob. the occupation of the Amphilochian Olpae by the Acarnanians fell in the time of the cumforai/ of the Amphilochian Argos, mentioned in ii. 68. 12. After the Amphilochians had joined the Acarnanians (dido/asin e(autou\s *)akarna=si, ii. 68. 18), the place was doubtless restored to its former possessors and the federal court removed elsewhere. See App.
oi( *)akarna=nes oi( me\n . . . oi( de/: part. appos. See on c. 13. 17.— 9.
cuneboh/qoun: the impf. represents continuance, whereas e)stratopedeu/santo in l. 12 simply states the matter as a fact.—
th=s *)amfiloxi/as: the name of the country precedes that of the place, as in c. 19. 6; 89. 7; i. 100. 15.—10.
fula/ssontes tou\s . . . *peloponnhsi/ous mh\ la/qwsi: proleptic const. as in i. 26. 6; ii. 67. 22. Kr. Spr. 61, 6, 5.—11.

mh\ la/qwsi . . . dielqo/ntes: ‘for Crenae, now *palaio\ *au)li/, guarded the entrance to the district from the south.’ Bursian (l.c.), after Heuzey, Le Mont Olympe et l'Acarnanie, p. 290. Cf. c. 106. 14. —13.

*dhmosqe/nhn to
 . . . strathgh/santa: the designation recalls indeed
an undertaking unwelcome to the Acarnanians (c. 95. § 1 f.), but better relations had been already restored (c. 102. § 3 f.). Further, the aor. partic. refers only to what had happened in the summer of 426 B.C. (who had led the army of the Athenians to Aetolia), and does not indicate the expiration of the office of strategus. Had Demosthenes been at that time no longer strategus, he could hardly have obeyed the here mentioned invitation of the Acarnanians and hastened with 200 Messenian hoplites and sixty Athenian bowmen to the scene of action (c. 107. 6), and at any rate it could not have been said of him, in iv. 2. 14, o)/nti i)diw/th| meta\ th
 a)naxw/rhsin th
 e)c *)akarnani/as. For clearly, acc. to these words, his term of office did not expire before his return from Acarnania to Athens (c. 114. § 1).—14.
h(gemw\n gi/gnhtai: cf. c. 107. 11, and see on c. 2. 11.—15.

e)pi\ ta\s ei)/kosi nau=s *)aqhnai/wn: which, after the return of the thirty ships (c. 98. 25), had been sent out again, under the generals named, peri\ *pelopo/nnhson, prob. in consequence of news of the operations of Eurylochus against the Ozolian Locrians and Naupactus (c. 101 f.). Their real goal was Naupactus (cf. c. 114. 8), but they turned aside for the moment, in consequence of the appeal of the Acarnanians, to the Ambracian gulf (c. 107. 4).— 16.
h)=rxen: Bm. proposed h)=rxon. But cf. iv. 37. 1; 38. 9, and see Kr. Spr. 63, 4.—*)aristote/lhs: later prob. one of the Thirty. Cf. Xen. Hell. ii. 3. 2.
a)pe/steilan de\ kai/: emphatic repetition after pe/mpousi (l. 13). See on c. 18. 8; i. 28. 8; ii. 7. 3.—18.

e)s th\n po/lin: sc. th\n *)ampraki/an.—19. pandhmei/: i.e. with all the forces which they could raise after sending out the 3000 hoplites (l. 3). For the execution of this request, cf. c. 110. —21. (
mh\)
ou)k h)=| a)sfale/s: with indef. subj., as iv. 36. 1 a)pe/ranton h)=n, viii. 105. 7 a)fane\s h)=n.
Eurylochus, with the Peloponnesians, marches safely from Proschium in Aetolia through Acarnania and Agrais to Amphilochia, and unites with the Ambraciols in Olpae.
tou\s e)n *)/olpais . . . h(/kontas: that the Ambraciots had arrived at Olpae, lit. that the Ambraciots in Olpae had arrived. This is a case of anticipation. Kühn. 447, N. 4.—3.
e)k tou= *prosxi/ou: sc. th=s *ai)twli/as. Cf. c. 102. 21.—4.
to\n *)axelw=|on: i.e. the boundary of Acarnania.—
ou)/shs e)rh/mou: i.e. without military protection, since the population able to bear arms had gone to Argos. Cf. ii. 81. 7 (where the adj. has the fem. ending).—6.
th\n *strati/wn po/lin: megi/sthn th=s *)akarnani/as, ii. 80. 38.—
th\n froura\n au)tw=n: sc. tw=n *strati/wn, i.e. the garrison of the city.

th=s *futi/as: the reading of all the Mss., though Polyb. (iv. 63. 7, 10) has *foiti/ai and Steph. Byz. *foiti/ai and *foi/tion. Several inscriptions, too, read *foi- (see Oberhummer, Akarnanien, p. 38), though local coins have *f*u- (see Head, Hist. Numorum, p. 281). The reference is to the territory belonging to the place, as also in the case of *m<*>d<*>w=nos and *aimnai/as. See on c. 91. 11, 15.—
*medew=nos: Polybius calls the place *medi/wn (Steph. Byz.), the inhabitants *mediw/nioi, the district *mediwni/a, and Livy also (xxxvi. 11 sq.) has Medion and Medionii.—9.

par) e)/sxata: i.e. to the frontier. Cf. viii. 95. 19 e)p) e)/sxata.—dia\ *limnai/as: cf. ii. 80. 37. This is the name both of a place and of the whole swampy lowland on the southern slopes of the Thyamus mountains. See Bursian i. p. 110. —10.

th=s *)agrai/wn: this district, which in c. 111. 18 is called h( *)agrai+/s, and had a king of its own, Salynthius, must be sought, acc. to ii. 102. 13 (where the Agraeans are placed between the Dolopians and Amphilochians), north of the road followed up to this point. Eurylochus made, evidently to avoid the Acarnanian garrison at Crenae (c. 105. 10), a detour through the mountains and from there descended into the Argive district, and thence marched along the coast to Olpae.—

ou)ke/ti *)akarnani/as: chorographi<*> gen., to which in the next clause an adj. corresponds. Strabo, p. 449 c, calls the Agraeans *ai)twliko\n <*>)/qnos. They belonged to the e)pi/kthtos *ai)twli/a. See Bursian i. p. 140.

labo/menoi tou= . . . o)/rous: see on
c. 24. 10.—11.

tou= *qua/mou o)/rous: now *spartobou=ni, forming the northeast boundary of Acarnania toward Aetolia, but belonging for the most part to the Agraean district. Hence O. Müller's conjecture (Dorians ii.^{2} p. 529; see Bursian i. p. 105, N. 1), *)agrai+ko/n, has been adopted for a)groi=kon of the Mss. See App.—12.
nukto\s h)/dh: already night. For other examples of h)/dh thus used, see on i. 30. 20.—13.
th=s . . . fulakh=s: sc. which awaited the advance of Eurylochus on the direct road from Limnaea to Argos. Cf. c. 105. § 2.—14.

prose/meican toi=s . . . *)amprakiw/tais: joined the Ambraciots in Olpae. Cf. v. 58. 3 boulo/menoi toi=s a)/llois prosmei=cai. 107, 108. Demosthenes, elected commander-in-chief by the Acarnanians, by means of a skilfully-planned ambush wins a decisive victory over the Peloponnesians and Ambraciots.
geno/menoi a(qro/oi: sc. the Ambraciots and Peloponnesians.—2.
kaqi/zousin: encamp, intr. as in iv. 93. 5. The const. kaqi/zein strato/n is more freq. in Thuc. (ii. 71. 4; iv. 90. 5; v. 7. 14; vi. 66. 2; vii. 82. 16).—
th\n *mhtro/polin: seems from the context (cf. l. 13) to have been a place very near Olpae.—3.
tai=s ei)/kosi nausi/n: cf. c. 105. 15.—4.

to\n *)amprakiko/n: sc. ko/lpon, which a few Mss. have in the text. But a copyist would be much more likely to add than omit it. o( *)amprakiko/s alternates with o( *)amprakiko\s ko/lpos (i. 29. 11; 55. 3; ii. 68. 9; iv. 49. 3), as o( *)io/nios (vi. 30. 6; 34. 24; 104. 10; vii. 33. 14) with o( *)io/nios ko/lpos (i. 24. 1; ii. 97. 26; vi. 13. 11; 44. 8; vii. 57. 57). See also App. on ii. 92. 22.—5.

kai\ *dhmosqe/nhs kte(.: Demosthenes (sc. paragi/gnetai e)s to\n *)amprakiko/n) came from Naupactus (cf. c. 102. § 3) with two hundred Messenian hoplites and sixty Athenian bowmen. As was remarked on c. 105. 13, he could hardly have brought these troops, if he was no longer general. From, the manner in which he is mentioned here after the twenty ships, it seems impossible that his sixty bowmen were taken from these ships. Probably there was at that time an Athenian garrison permanently stationed at Naupactus, so that he, even after the return (c.
98. 25) of the thirty ships of c. 91. 1, had control of some Athenian forces. —
*messhni/wn: see on c. 94. 15.

ta\s *)/olpas to
 lo/fon: = to\ tei=xos e)pi\ tou= lo/fou (c. 105. 5), to
 lo/fon being appos. to ta\s *)/olpas. Kr. Spr. 50, 7, 2. Steup follows v. H. in bracketing to
 lo/fon, on the ground that, after c. 105. 4 katalamba/nousin *)/olpas, tei=xos e)pi\ lo/fou i)sxuro
 pro\s th=| qala/ssh|), the expression peri\ ta\s *)/olpas e)k qala/sshs e)fw/rmoun needs no explanation, and, if it did, that this would hardly be added in the form of a simple appositive (to
 lo/fon).—8.
*)amfilo/xwn: the inhabitants of the whole district, whose chief city was Argos. They remained ba/rbaroi even after Argos had become hellenized, ii. 68. 14.—9.
oi( plei/ous . . . katei/xonto: they were kept from taking part in the war by the fact that the Ambraciots had seized their territory or taken hostages from them. Cf. c. 114. 19.—10.

h)/dh cunelhluqo/tes: the Acarnanians of Crenae (c. 105. 10; 106. 14) had also meanwhile gone to Argos, to whose aid the rest of the Acarnanians marched at the outset (c. 105. 9 oi( me\n e)s *)/argos cuneboh/qoun).—11.

tou= panto\s cummaxikou=: of the whole allied army, i.e. of all the Acarnanian and Amphilochian forces. Cf. i. 62. 5 strathgo\n tou= pezou= panto\s oi( cu/mmaxoi h(/|rhnto *)ariste/a.—12. *dhmosqe/nhn: the form *dhmosqe/nh, of the most and best Mss., is against the usage of Thuc.—
meta\ tw=n sfete/rwn strathgw=n: i.e. these commanded the various contingents under Demosthenes as general-in-chief.
prosagagw/n: without obj., as ducere, only here in Thuc.—
th=s *)/olphs: see on c. 105. 5.—14.
xara/dra: see on c. 25. 4; 98. 7.—15.
e)ta/ssonto: introductory impf., the details following. Cf. l. 22 h)=|san e)s xei=ras. See on c. 92. 2.—
w(s e)s ma/xhn: with the intention to fight, as i. 62. 20; iv. 93. 6; vi. 67. 2. Cf. w(s e)pi\ naumaxi/an, i. 48. 2, and see on c. 4. 6.—16.
kai\ (
mei=zon ga\r kte(.): paratactic structure of the period, just as in c. 70. 11; i. 31. 7; hence here too the causal sent. must be regarded as parenthetical. —

perie/sxe: intr. extended beyond, out-flanked, as in c. 108. 1; v. 71. 12,
16, and perii/sxein, v. 71. 4. Schol. u(pere/teinen, u(pere/sxen. The aors. e)ge/neto and perie/sxe express a result of the drawing up (e)ta/ssonto).—18.
loxi/zei: in insidiis collocat. e)ne/dran kaqi/zei, Schol. Cf. loxisqe/ntes (ambushed), v. 115. 2; Dio C. xli. 51; e)lo/xise, distributed into companies, Hdt. i. 103. 4.—

koi/lhn kai\ loxmw/dh: cf. Dio c. 13, 9 e)n koi/lw| tini\ kai\ loxmw/dei to/pw|, 1279, 17 e)s koi=lo/n tina kai\ loxmw/dh to/pon, Polyaen. iii. 1. 2 e)s to\ koi=lon kai\ loxmw=des e)nelo/xisen o(pli/tas kai\ yilou\s tetrakosi/ous. loxmw/dhs occurs only here in Thuc.—20.

kata\ to\ u(pere/xon: i.e. at the part of the enemy's line which extended beyond their own and threatened to outflank them. Cf. Polyaen. l.c. o(/pws, e)peida\n u(perfalaggh/swsin oi( e)nanti/oi kata\ to\ u(perba/llon au)tw=n, e)canasta/ntes kata\ nw/tou ge/nointo. For similar consts., cf. l. 29; i. 48. 10, 12; 62. 24; iv. 36. 7; v. 71. 22. For u(pere/xon, cf. viii. 104. 15. Acc. to c. 108. 2, it was the left wing, not, as was usually the case, the right (cf. v. 71. § 1).—
e)canasta/ntes: rushing out from their ambush. Cf. Xen. Hell. iv. 8. 37.— 21.
ou(=toi: for which Hude (Comm. Crit. p. 116 sq.) proposed ou(/tw, is opposed to the remaining troops of Demosthenes.—
kata\ nw/tou: as in c. 108. 4; i. 62. 13, etc. kata\ nw=ton, which some good Mss. have, is contrary to Thuc.'s usage.
e)pei\ de\ pareskeu/asto a)mfote/rois: for the impers. pass., see on c. 22. 1. —22.
h)=|san e)s xei=ras: see on —23.
e)/xwn: the regular verb in such tactical statements. See on i. 48. 10. —

*)aqhnai/wn o)li/gwn: Steup thinks that, as the small number of Athenian bowmen (sixty) has already been stated in l. 6, and there was no cause for emphasizing their fewness here, whereas one might have expected some mention of the Amphilochians that were not a)kontistai/, prob. some words have been lost between *)aqhnai/wn and o)li/gwn,—perhaps kai\ *)amfilo/xwn o(plitw=n or kai\ *)amfilo/xwn sfendonhtw=n. That the main body of the Amphilochians were yiloi/, is clear from c. 112. 20.—24.
to\ a)/llo: i.e. the centre and left.—24.
w(s e(/kastoi tetagme/noi: i.e. arrayed by tribes and under their own leaders (l. 12). —25.
e)pei=xon: occupied, as in i. 48. 7; Hdt. ix. 31. 7.—
de\ kai\ *)amprakiw=tai: sc. h)=|san e)s xei=ras, not the nearest but the most important verb being understood.— 26.
a)nami/c: only here in Thuc. Cf. Hdt. i. 103. 6; vii. 40. 4.—26.
plh\n *mantine/wn . . . h)=san: acc. to these words, as well as c. 108. 16; 109. 12; 111. 2, 14; 113. 4, a considerable portion of the Peloponnesians under Eurylochus must have been Mantineans.—27.
ou(=toi de/: epexegetical, as in c. 34. 4; i. 26. 23; 143. 20.—
ou) to\ ke/ras a)/kron e)/xontes: pred., like e)/sxaton, having not the extreme point of the wing. G. 978, 1; H. 671; Kr. Spr. 50, 11, 5.—29.

oi( met) au)tou=: this part of the army, which in c. 108. 6 is described as to\ kat) *eu)ru/loxon kai\ o(\ kra/tiston h)=n, acc. to what goes before must have consisted of contingents from various states. Some statement as to its composition might have been expected.—
kata\ *messhni/ous: see on l. 20.
perie/sxon: see on c. 107. 16. —2.
tw=| ke/ra|: i.e. tw=| e(autw=n eu)wnu/mw| ke/ra|.—3. e)pigeno/menoi: see on c. 30. 6.—
au)toi=s kata\ nw/tou: const. with e)pigeno/menoi. Cf. c. 107. 21.—5.

e)s a)lkh\n u(pomei=nai: cf. e)s xei=ras u(pomei=nai, v. 72. 23; ei)s xei=ras de/xesqai, Xen. Hell. ii. 4. 34; An. iv. 3. 31; e)s a)lkh\n tre/pesqai, ii. 84. 24; Hdt. ii. 45. 7; iii. 78. 5; iv. 125. 21; ix. 102. 18. See on c. 30. 7.—
fobhqe/ntas te . . . katasth=sai: and in their panic put to flight also the greater part of the army.—

e)s fugh\n katasth=sai: as in iv. 14. 4; vii. 43. 47. Cf. e)s a)po/noian katasth=sai, i. 82. 20; vii. 67. 22; e)s a)pori/an, ii. 81. 37; vii. 75. 14; e)s u(poyi/an, v. 29. 18; e)s taraxh/n, iv. 75. 10; e)s e)/kplhcin, vi. 36. 7; e)s ki/ndunon, ii. 100. 25; e)s logismo/n, vi. 34. 25.—6.

to\ kat) *eu)ru/loxon: i.e. the part of the army with him and under his personal command (oi( met) au)tou=, c. 107. 29), characterized also as to\ kra/tiston. Cf. iv. 33. <*> oi( peri\ to\n *)epita/dan kai\ o(/per h)=n plei=ston. kata/, as in l. 10; in a different sense from c. 107. 20, 29.—8.

tau/th|: i.e. on the
right wing, c. 107. 23.—9.

to\ polu\ tou= e)/rgou e)ch=lqon: performed the chief part of the work. Cf. i. 70. 21 a(\ me\n a)\n e)pinoh/santes mh\ e)ce/lqwsin, Soph. Tr. 505 e)ch=lqon a)/eql) a)gw/nwn, i. 70. 9 ta)nagkai=a e)cike/sqai. Hence e)ch=lqon, of Vat. and other good Mss., is adopted instead of e)pech=lqon of most Mss., which Haase prefers (Lucubr. p. 100).
oi( de\ *)amprakiw=tai kte(.: see App. —10.
e)ni/kwn to\ kaq) e(autou/s: were victorious in their own quarter. Cf. c. 78. 3.—11.

a)pedi/wcan: i.e. pursued from their position. Cf. vi. 102. 15 tw=n *)aqhnai/wn a)podiwca/ntwn tou\s e)kei=, also Xen. Hell. iv. 5. 14; vi. 2. 20; Ar. Nub. 1296. These passages support the Mss. reading sufficiently against Haase's conjecture (Lucubr. p. 62) e)p edi/wcan.

e)panaxwrou=ntes . . . nenikhme/non: cf. i. 63. 1. e)panaxwrou=ntes, returning, sc. from the pursuit (i. 63. 1 e)panaxwrw=n a)po\ th=s diw/cews), during which the flight of the greater part of the army (l. 5) had occurred; hence the pf. partic. nenikhme/non.— 14. diesw/|zonto: as in c. 85. 4; 109. 5; i. 82. 10; ii. 60. 10; iv. 96. 33. —15.

au)tw=n: if the text be sound, it seems necessary to adopt Jowett's explanation, that au)tw=n is used not of the right wing of the Peloponnesian army just mentioned, for the Mantineans were on the left, but generally “of their army.” But see App.—

a)ta/ktws kai\ ou)deni\ ko/smw| prospi/ptontes: cf. vi. 97. 17 prospeso/ntes a)takto/teron. Vat. and other Mss. read a)fula/ktws, prob. because a)ta/ktws and ou)deni\ ko/smw| are so nearly synonymous, but the reading of the text is supported by iv. 126. 34 ko/smw| kai\ ta/cei, Herod. ii. 4 to\ ko/smion kai\ eu)/takton.—16. prospi/ptontes: sc. tw=| tei/xei, rushing to the fort, as in vi. 97. 17; viii. 84. 5. The Schol. wrongly explains, toi=s e)nanti/ois dhlono/ti.—17. tou= stratou=: dependent on ma/lista. G. 1088; Kr. Spr. 47, 28, 8.—18.

e)s o)ye/: as viii. 23. 7; Dem. lvii. 15; me/xri o)ye/, vii. 83. 13. Cf. c. 78. 16 e)teleu/ta e)s h(li/ou du/sin, i. 51. 9 h( naumaxi/a e)teleu/ta e)s nu/kta. Kühn. 446 b; Kr. Spr. 66, 1, 4. The reading of Vat. and other good Mss., e(/ws o)ye/, is explained by Lobeck, ad Phryn.
p. 47, pare/teine e(/ws o)ye\ kai\ o)ye\ e)teleu/ta,—which seems too artificial.
Menedaius, who assumes command after the death of Eurylochus and Macarius, makes a secret agreement by which he and a part of the Peloponnesians are allowed to withdraw undisturbed.
*meneda/i+os: see on c. 100. 11.— 2.

pareilhfw/s: not paralabw/n, since this act stands for itself, without causal connexion with prosfe/rei lo/gon.—3. mega/lhs h(/sshs gegenhme/nhs: the art., though it would be in order, is not necessary. Cf. i. 18. 15, and see on ii. 5. 13.—
o(/tw| tro/pw|: with fut. ind. for the more usual o(/pws. See on i. 107. 18.—
poliorkh/setai: pass. and with the same meaning, as in c. 52. 2. —4.
e)/k te gh=s kai\ e)k qala/sshs: answers to pantaxo/qen, v. 60. 12; viii. 42. 14.—5.
a)pokeklh|me/nos: pf. partic. because he is already in this situation.—6.
prosfe/rei lo/gon: as in viii. 32. 12; Hdt. iii. 134. 3; v. 30. 15; more freq. lo/gous, c. 4. 8; i. 57. 11; ii. 70. 6.

tou\s a)poqano/ntas: the fallen, almost a subst., as in c. 113. 23; ii. 34. 2. It is a relic of the Hom. usage; cf. H 457 to\ ga\r ge/ras e)sti\ qano/ntwn. See Classen, Beob. über den Hom. Sprachgebrauch, p. 57 ff.—
ma/lista: see on c. 21. 4.—10.
a)naxw/rhsin: for acc. with spe/ndesqai, see on c. 24. 19.—
e)k tou= profanou=s: as c. 43. 10; viii. 68. 2. See on c. 43. 5; 82. 48. —12.
meta\ tw=n custrath/gwn *)akarna/nwn: cf. c. 107. 12. For the gen. *)akarna/nwn, see on c. 92. 19. On the recessive accent here and ii. 58. 2, see Göttling, p. 321.—

spe/ndontai: pl. after *dhmosqe/nhs meta\ tw=n custrath/gwn. A rare const., the more striking since boulo/menos (l. 15) agrees only with *dhmosqe/nhs. Kr. Spr. 63, 4, 3; Kühn. 359, N. 5. Cf. Xen. Hell. i. 1. 10 *)alkibia/dhs e)k *sa/rdewn meta\ *mantiqe/ou i(/ppwn eu)porh/santes a)pe/drasan. Steup would prefer spe/ndetai, on the
ground that the pl. conflicts with the manifest intention to emphasize Demosthenes, as shown by the addition of *dhmosqe/nhs meta\ tw=n custrath/gwn *)akarna/nwn after e)spei/santo.—13. toi=s a)/llois a)/rxousi: i.e. the higher officers. Cf. c. 30. 1; v. 9. 33; vi. 32. 7. —14.
a)ciologw/tatoi: most influential, as ii. 10. 11.—
a)poxwrei=n: inf. after spe/ndontai, as iv. 114. 9; vii. 83. 4; spei/sasqai . . . h)= mh\n e)mmenei=n, iv. 118. 57.—15.
yilw=sai: only here in Thuc. monw=sai, yilou\s tw=n cumma/xwn poih=sai, Schol. Cf. Hdt. ii. 151. 17; Xen. Cyr. iv. 5. 12. The synonymous monou=n is used in Attic only in the passive.—16.

to\n misqofo/ron o)/xlon: understood by Bl., Cl., and Jow. as mercenaries in the pay of the Ambraciots, prob. from the neighbouring Epirot tribes, and constituting part of the 3000 hoplites of c. 105. 3. This view assumes that the Peloponnesians were all included in the secret agreement. ‘The subject of a)poxwrei=n is “the Peloponnesians” to be supplied from “the leaders of the Peloponnesians.” Demosthenes negotiated with the Mantineans, Menedaius, and the leaders of the Peloponnesians, not for their personal safety only, but for the safe withdrawal of their forces; the Ambraciots, their allies, being left to their fate.’ (Jow.) But Steup holds that to\n misqofo/ron o)/xlon covers all the army of Menedaius that were not Mantineans or a)/rxontes or a)ciologw/tatoi. His grounds are viz.: that not all the Peloponnesians were included in the agreement is clear both from the plain meaning of l. 12 ff. and from the expressions oi)=s e)de/doto h( a)poxw/rhsis, l. 21, and oi( *mantinh=s kai\ oi)=s e)/speisto, c. 111. 2. Later, it is true, those entitled to withdraw are designated simply as oi( *peloponnh/sioi (c. 111. 10), or oi( *mantinh=s kai\ oi( *peloponnh/sioi (c. 111. 14), but again in c. 113. 4 they are called oi( *mantinh=s kai\ oi( u(po/spondoi, and in c. 114. 10 the remnants of the other part of the army are spoken of as oi( w(s *salu/nqion katafugo/ntes *)amprakiw=tai kai\ *peloponnh/sioi. A comparison with vii. 57. 48 makes it prob. that the Mantineans also were mercenaries. The trisxi/lioi o(pli=tai tw=n cumma/xwn under Eurylochus's command (c. 100. 7) seem, then, to have been all mercenaries, just as Brasidas led, along with 700 Helots, also 1000 Peloponnesian mercenaries to the Thracian coast (iv. 78. 2; 80. 21). That the passage assumes as known that the Peloponnesian army was composed of mercenaries, though no mention is made of this fact, must be attributed, doubtless, to the lack of a final revision of his work by the author.—[

to
 ceniko/n]: rightly bracketed by v. H. (Stud. Thuc. p. 49) as a gloss (see on viii. 25. 10). If to
 misqofo/ron o)/xlon includes a part of the Peloponnesians, ceniko/n is unin
telligible. Cl., who retains to
 ceniko/n, thinks that Thuc. wished possibly to define both features (mercenary and foreign) of a military relation then still rare.—17.
*lakedaimoni/ous kai\ *peloponnhsi/ous: the two names connected, because the shameful agreement affected Peloponnesians commanded by a Spartan.—
diabalei=n e)s tou\s e)kei/nh|: to bring into discredit with those in that quarter, as in iv. 22. 12. diaba/llein, in this sense, with the dat., viii. 88. 9; 109. 4.— 18.
xrh/|zwn: wishing, only here in Thuc., and indeed seldom in Attic prose. Cf. Xen. Cyrop. i. 6. 15; Arist. Plant. i. 1. 21. It occurs several times in Aristophanes and numberless times in Tragedy.—

*(/ellhnas w(s kataprodo/ntes kte(.: because they had betrayed Hellenes and considered their own advantage more important. See Steup, Quaest. Thuc. p. 29 sq. Usually *(/ellhnas is connected with e)s tou\s e)kei/nh|. But, first, there is no reason why regard should have been had only to the Hellenes of that quarter, when the barbarian Amphilochians were participants in the war (cf. c. 112. 29; ii. 68. 16); secondly, kataprodo/ntes requires an obj., and the thought of the w(s clause is greatly strengthened by making *(/ellhnas this object. For thus it is esp. emphasized, that while Sparta proclaimed that the whole war was waged for the freedom of the Hellenes (see on c. 13. 35; 32. 5), now Hellenes (i.e. the Ambraciots and the Peloponnesian misqofo/ros o)/xlos) are betrayed by Lacedaemonians and Peloponnesians. For the emphatic position of *(/ellhnas before the conj., cf. ii. 64. 17, and see on c. 88. 8. The objection of St., that the treachery had been committed, non in omnes Graecos, sed in illorum socios, would be admissible only if not *(/ellhnas, but tou\s *(/ellhnas were to be connected with kataprodo/ntes.—19. prourgiai/teron e)poih/santo: cf. Isoc. vi. 35; Isae. ix. 25; Polyb. i. 1. 6. The comp. prourgiai/teron from the adv. prou/rgou (iv. 17. 8), as plhsiai/teron from plhsi/on.

w(/sper u(ph=rxe: “as well as possible under the circumstances,” = e)k tw=n u(parxo/ntwn or paro/ntwn. Cf. Xen. Anab. vi. 4. 9 e)/qayan e)k tw=n u(parxo/ntwn w(s e)du/nanto ka/llista.— 21. th
 a<*>poxw/rhsin . . . e)pebou/leuon: those to whom it had been granted were making secret preparations for retreat. With th
 a)poxw/rhsin e)pebou/leuon, cf. vii. 51. 5 to
 e)/kploun e)pibouleu=sai, vi. 54. 14 e)pibouleu/ei kata/lusin th=| turanni/di, viii. 60. 4 e)pibouleu/ontes a)po/stasin. See on c. 96. 11. oi)=s e)de/doto, i.e. e)kei=noi oi)=s, those named above, l. 12 ff.

p.hi: Advance of fresh auxiliaries from Ambracia.

div2.p: a)gge/lletai, (5)
kai\ pe/mpei: parataxis, by which cause and effect are brought into close connexion, as in i. 61. 1, 2.—2.
tou\s e)k th=s po/lews: sc. *)ampraki/as, as distinguished from those who after the battle were shut up in Olpae (c. 108. 14; 111. § 2). —
kata\ th\n prw/thn . . . a)ggeli/an: cf. c. 105. § 4.—3.
dia\ tw=n *)amfilo/xwn: i.e. through the hostile Amphilochian territory. Cf. c. 101. 3. —4.
cummei=cai: as in ii. 84. 34; vii. 26. 4. For the form, see on c. 22. 4.
proloxiou=ntas: pl. after me/ros ti. See on c. 2. 2; 79. 10; 80. 1. The word occurs also in c. 112. 22; ii. 81. 24; elsewhere prob. only in late writers.—7.
ta\ kartera/: i.e. natural strongholds, as in c. 18. 19; ii. 100. 3.—
th=| a)/llh| stratia=|: dat. of means with bohqei=n. Cf. i. 81. 5. —8.
bohqei=n e)p) au)tou/s: as in i. 107. 22; 126. 22. See on c. 97. 14.
Meanwhile the Acarnanians fall upon the Ambraciots, who are trying to join the fleeing Peloponnesians, and kill many of them.
oi(=s e)/speisto: with whom the agreement had been made, not for whom. Cf. 1. 12; 109. 11.—
pro/fasin: adv. on the pretext, as in v. 80. 17; vi. 33. 9; Eur. I. A. 362; Dem. xviii. 77. Kr. Spr. 46, 3, 5; Kühn. 462 i.

laxanismo/n: a(/nac in Thuc. laxa/nwn suna/qroisin, Schol. Cf. Poll. i. 162 e)ch=lqon e)pi\ laxanismo/n, e)pi\ fruganismo/n. la/xana are wild cabbage, still used in Greece. Gell, Morea, p. 191. See also Leake, Northern Greece, iv. p. 248.—3.
fruga/nwn cullogh/n: = fruganismo/n, vii. 4. 30; 13. 7. Cf. fru/gana sulle/gein, Lycurg. 86.—
u(paph=|san: withdrew gradually. Cf. v. 9. 17.—4.
kat) o)li/gous: a few at a time. Cf. c. 78. 2; Hdt. viii. 113. 14. <*>
dh=qen: “as they pretended.” Cf. c. 68. 4; i. 92. 3; 127. 2; iv. 99. 7.—5.

qa=sson a)pexw/roun: cf. c. 109. 14 a)poxwrei=n
kata\ ta/xos. a)pexw/roun, impf., covers the time in which the following events occurred.
oi( a)/lloi o(/soi kte(.: the misqofo/ros o)/xlos of c. 109. 16.—
o(/soi men † e)tu/gxanon ou(/tws: the passage is certainly corrupt. See App.—7.

a(qro/oi cunelqo/ntes: in their critical situation they first came together to take counsel, but when they learned that the Peloponnesians were already withdrawing, they set off also themselves (kai\ au)toi/), and were hastening to overtake them. But see App.—8.
e)/qeon dro/mw|: = e)xw/roun dro/mw|, v. 3. 7. Cf. iv. 67. 21; 112. 2; v. 10. 26; vi. 100. 14; Xen. Anab. i. 8. 8; iv. 6. 25. —
e)pikatalabei=n: overtake, as in ii. 90. 23. Cf. Plato Tim. 39 c; Jos. Antiq. xviii. 9. 5; Polyb. i. 66. 4; Diod. xviii. 71.
oi( de\ *)akarna=nes: since Dem. had let only their leaders into the secret.—10.
kai\ pa/ntas: i.e. not merely the Ambraciots.—

tou\s *peloponnhsi/ous: this and tou\s *mantine/as kai\ tou\s *peloponnhsi/ous (l. 14) are not quite exact expressions for tou\s *mantine/as kai\ oi)=s e)/speisto (l. 2). See on c. 109. 16. The *)amprakiw=tai kai\ oi( a)/lloi of l. 6 are not mentioned, perhaps because reference is not yet had to the time when they too set off from Olpae (w(/rmhsan kai\ au)toi\ kte(.). —11.
au)tw=n tw=n strathgw=n: of the generals themselves, indicating a great degree of excitement, on which account alone indeed the whole occurrence is narrated.—12.
h)ko/ntise: with acc. without prep. Kr. Spr. 47, 14, 1.—13.

tis: the sing, of the partic. nomi/sas is against taking tis here in the sense of one and another, as Arn., Goell., and St. do. In Xen. An. i. 8. 20 toceuqh=nai/ tis e)le/geto, which Arn. compares, tis doubtless refers to a single person.—
sfa=s: refers to the subj. of the leading clause (tis), though including more than this. For the pl. thus used after a sing. subj., cf. iv. 36. 3; vi. 49. 9. Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 3.—14.

tou\s *mantine/as kai\ tou\s *peloponnhsi/ous: the same emphasis of the part beside the whole, as in l. 2 oi( *mantinh=s kai\ oi)=s e)/s<*>sto.<*>a)fi/esan: the use of the augment of this verb in Thuc., as well as in other Attic writers, is inconstant. Cf. h)fi/ei, ii. 49. 8; a)fi/ei, iv. 122. 11; viii. 41. 13. See Kr. on
ii. 49. 8. The impf. here, as well as e)/kteinon (15), because the action is represented as in progress. Cf. a)pexw/roun (6), e)/qeon (8), e)pedi/wkon (11). But in l. 17 the aor. (a)pe/kteinan) occurs, because only the result is to be stated.
e)s diakosi/ous me/n tinas: about two hundred, as in viii. 21. 4. For the force of tinas, see on c. 68. 16. The prepositional phrase represents the obj., as in c. 114. 22. See on c. 20. 11.—
