au)tw=n: refers only to the Ambraciots, as is clear from oi( d' a)/lloi die/fugon kte(.—18.
e)s th\n *)agrai+/da: see on c. 106. 10.

p.hi: The Ambraciots from the city coming to bring aid to their friends are surprised by Demosthenes before daybreak and most of them destroyed.

div2.p: oi( e)k th=s po/lews *)amprakiw=tai: cf. c. 110.—2.

e)p) *)idomenh/n: in c. 113. 10 *)idomenai/. See on c. 105. 5. The Mss. have *)idome/nh and *)idome/nai, but see St. Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 34, and on c. 94. 4. For the position of these two heights, which acc. to l. 20 and c. 110. 3, are to be sought on Amphilochian territory, see Bursian i. p. 39, and Oberhummer, Akarnanien, p. 110.—
e)sto/n: construed with the pred. Cf. iv. 102. 13; Hdt. vi. 112. 3. G. 904; H. 610; Kr. Spr. 63, 6; Kühn. 369, 3.—
h( *)idomenh/: rejected as a gloss by v. H. and St.; but cf. ii. 18. 3, 5; 30. 6, 8.—3.
oi( proapostale/ntes: cf. c. 110. 5.—4.
a)po\ tou= stratope/dou: i.e. detached from the main army.—5.

e)/fqasan prokatalabo/ntes: cf. fqa/santes prokate/labon, iv. 127. 14. For similar pleonasms, see on c. 53. 9. prokatalabo/ntes belongs to e)/laqon as well as to e)/fqasan.—to\n e)la/ssw: the const. with proanaba/ntes without prep. is rather surprising, since Thuc. never construes a)nabai/nein with the simple acc.; but this const. is found in Plato Phaedo 113d, and later authors, e.g. Dio C. lx. 23; App. i. p. 175; Paus. vi. 16. 9. Kr. conjectured e)s to\n d' e)la/ssw, and Rauchenstein (Philol. xxxv. p. 592) proposed ei)=xon for e)/tuxon.
e)xw/rei: went forward; the decisive events following in the pres., e)pipi/ptei (10) tre/pousi (17), and the narration continuing in the aor.—
kai\ to\ a)/llo stra/teuma: opp. to oi( proapostale/ntes (3). Cf. th=| a)/llh| stratia=|, c. 110. 7.—8.
a)po\ e(spe/ras eu)qu/s: immediately after nightfall, as in viii. 27. 27 (without eu)qu/s, vii. 29. 8). Cf. a)po\ prw/tou u(/pnou, vii. 43. 17. The march lasted, therefore, all night. —

e)pi\ th=s e)sbolh=s: with e)xw/rei, toward the pass, which led up from the plain between the two hills, and so to the ascent to that occupied by the Ambraciots. e)sbolh/, as in iv. 83. 6; 127. 13; Hdt. vii. 172. 9; 175. 10; Xen. Anab. i. 2. 21; Hell. v. 4. 48.

a(/ma o)/rqrw|: at daybreak, which comports with nukto\s e)/ti ou)/shs, Cf. ii. 3. 17 e)/ti nu/kta kai\ au)to\ to\ peri/orqron, iv. 110. 4 nukto\s e)/ti kai\ peri\ o)/rqron, vi. 101. 13 peri\ o)/rqron, Plato Prot. 310 a th=s par<*>lqou/s hs nunto\s tanthsi\ e)/ti baqe/os o)/rqrou. On the meaning of o)/rqros (the interval between the first cock-crow and morning twilight), see Unger, Philol. xliii. p. 594 f. —10.
e)/ti e)n tai=s eu)nai=s: as in iv. 32. 2. Cf. Tac. Ann. i. 50 strati etiam tum per cubilia.—12.
tou\s e(autw=n ei)=nai: sc. tou\s e)pipi/ptontas.
tou\s *messhni/ous: cf. c. 107. 5, 23; 108. 8.—13.
prw/tous prou/tace: for the pleonasm, see on —
e)pi/thdes: prudently. Schol. e)skemme/nws. The adv. is found only here in Thuc.—14.
e)ke/leue: for the impf. where the aor. would seem more natural, see GMT. 57; Kr. Spr. 53, 2, 8; Kühn. 383, 3. —
*dwri/da glw=ssan: cf. i. 138. 4; ii. 68. 14; and vi. 5. 5 *dwri\s fwnh/. See on c. 103. 2.—

glw=ssan i(e/ntas: as in Hdt. i. 57. 1; ix. 16. 13; Soph. El. 596. The const., which occurs only here in Thuc., is common in Hom., Hdt., and the Attic poets. Cf. o)/pa i(e/nai, Hom. *g 152, 221; m 192; fwnh\n i(e/nai, Hdt. ii. 2. 11; iv. 23. 7; 135. 15; Ar. Acharn. 747; Eq. 522; Vesp. 562; Aesch. Choeph. 563; gh=run i(e/nai, Ar. Aves 233; fqogga\s i(e/nai, Eur. Hec. 338; kw<*>to\n i(e/nai, Soph. Aj. 851. It occurs twice in Plato (Legg. 890 d; Phileb. 51 d). Cf. Lat. vocem mittere.—15.
pi/stin parexome/nous: inspiring confidence. Cf. vi. 17. 3.—16.

th=| o)/yei: by sight, with
the eyes (cf. c. 38. 20; iv. 34. 5; 126. 32; vii. 75. 8), added here because the antithesis a)kouome/nous me\n th=| a)koh=| is in mind. For similar pleonasms, cf. e)/qeon dro/mw|, c. 111. 8; lo/gw| ei)=pon, i. 23. 1; proloxi/zousi e)ne/drais, ii. 81. 24 (cf. l. 22 below). Others render “not distinguished by their appearance.”
tre/pousi: sudden transition from the general to his troops. See on c. 51. 16, and cf. Xen. An. iii. 3. 7. —
au)tou=: on the spot. Cf. c. 81. 15; 98. 11.
prokateilhmme/nwn tw=n o(dw=n: cf. l. 5; 110. 7.—
tw=n *)amfilo/xwn: cf. c. 107. 8, 25.—21.
pro\s o(pli/tas: cf. c. 105. 3. For pro/s, against, see on c. 43. 15.—

tw=n de\ a)pei/rwn kai\ a)nepisthmo/nwn: closely connected with and balancing tw=n me\n . . . e)mpei/rwn o)/ntwn, and hence also in gen. abs., although the subj. is the same as that of the leading verb. Cf. c. 49. 13; 55. 5, and see on c. 13. 30.— 22.
e)spi/ptontes . . . die/fqeironto: cf. c. 98. 7.—
ta\s proleloxisme/nas: cf. c. 110. 6.
pa=san i)de/an: see on c. 81. 22. —24.
e)tra/ponto/ tines: the partial subj. is separated from the general one contained in xwrh/santes, as in i. 49. 14.—25.
ta\s *)attika\s nau=s: cf. c. 107. 3, 7.—26.

a(/ma tou= e)/rgou th=| cuntuxi/a|: to be taken with parapleou/sais, sailing along the coast at the moment of the occurrence of the action. Cf. i. 33. 1 h( cuntuxi/a . . . th=s h(mete/ras xrei/as. to\ e)/rgon in this sense also i. 105. 24; 107. 28; ii. 89. 42; iv. 32. 24; 72. 21; viii. 42. 12.—
prose/neusan: the verb, which is found only here in Thuc., occurs also in Plut. Mar. 37; Luc. Bis Acc. 21; Ael. V. H. i. 1.—28.

ei) dei=: if it must be, as in ii. 74. 3; vii. 48. 30; Dem. xx. 53. Thuc. does not tell the fate of these fugitives, but the expression ei) dei=, diafqarh=nai favours the inference that they received no mercy from the
Athenian crew.—29.

tw=n barba/rwn: adj. Cf. ii. 68. 15 oi( de\ a)/lloi *)amfi/loxoi ba/rbaroi( ei)sin. ‘The Ambraciots affected to regard the Amphilochians as barbarians, because they were in reality a mixed race.’ Arn.
o)li/goi a)po\ pollw=n e)sw/qhsan: this formula as in i. 110. 2; vii. 87. 26. Kühn. 414, N. 4. See on c. 24. 12.— 32.
tropai=a: the pl. as in v. 3. 16; vii. 24. 3; 41. 12; 45. 1. Here to be accounted for prob. by the divisions of the army mentioned in c. 110. § 2; 112. § 2.

p.hi: The severity of the blow to Ambracia is vividly portrayed in the demeanor of the herald at Argos.

div2.p: au)toi=s h)=lqe: cf. c. 5. 12; 39. 22; 70. 2, and see on i. 13. 12.—2.
e)s *)agrai/ous: cf. c. 111. 18.—3.
tw=n nekrw=n ou(\s a)pe/kteinan: “the corpses of those whom they killed.” Cf. c. 111. 17. v. H. (Stud. Thuc. p. 49) unnecessarily objects to the pleonasm.—4.
th=s prw/ths ma/xhs: near Olpae, c. 108; not prote/ras, because it is the first of the three battles, c. 108, 111, and 112.—
tw=n u(pospo/ndwn: = oi)=s e)/speisto, c. 111. 2. The part joined to the whole, as in c. 111. 2, 14. Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 2. Cf. c. 109. § 2.—5.
cunech=|san: attempted to depart with. Steup thinks the impf. is used with reference to the continuance of the occurrence, as in c. 34. 5; 68. 12; 96. 11. Regarding the matter, cf. c. 111. § 1.
tw=n a)po\ th=s po/lews: cf. c. 112. l. —7.
to\ pa/qos: i.e. the fatal nightbattle of Idomene.—
tw=n meta\ sfw=n: i.e. tw=n e)s *)agrai/ous katafugo/ntwn, the messenger representing those by whom he was sent. Cf. tw=n meq) h(mw=n maxome/nwn, —8.
ei)=nai: sc. ta\ o(/pla.
qauma/zoi kai\ . . . teqna=sin: change of mood, as in ii. 80. 9. GMT. 670 a. Cf. c. 22. 38; vi. 96. 18.—9.

au)=: in
turn. The emphasizing of this antithesis causes the repetition of the subj. o( e)rwtw=n.—10. tw=n e)n *)idomenai=s: as ii. 34. 14 tou\s e)n *maraqw=ni. For the pl. alternating with the sing. (l. 14; 112. 2), see on c. 105. 5.—
diakosi/ous ma/lista: cf. c. 111. 17. The statement of the number answers indirectly also the first question of the Acarnanian (o(/ ti qauma/zoi). For ma/lista, see on c. 21. 4.

ou)k ou)=n ta\ o(/pla tauti\ . . . xili/wn: you see, then, that these here are not the arms of two hundred, but of more than a thousand. Cl. adopted into his text, and Steup retains, diakosi/wn, on Kr.'s conjecture that s/ had dropped out. But this seems unnecessary. St. renders, apparet vero haec non esse arma eorum, etc. The Schol. says, lei/pei to\ diakosi/wn ei)=nai mo/nwn. ou)k ou)=n, as ou)k a)/ra (13), draws an inference from what lies before the eye. Kalinka, Diss. Phil. Vindobon. ii. p. 184 would understand ou)k ou)=n = ou)damw=s.—13. maxome/nwn: partic. impf., which tense follows in The aor. might have been expected; but in Thuc. e)maxo/mhn is used also in an aoristic sense, e)maxesa/mhn occurring only in v. 34. 4. See Steup, Thuk. Stud. ii. p. 44.—14.
ei)/per ge: sc. e)/sti me/ntoi before these words.— 15.

prw/|hn: day before yesterday, as appears from c. 112. § 2 f. and c. 113. § 1. Cf. Plato Prot. 309 a, and the formula xqe\s kai\ prw/|hn.—16. kai\ me\n dh/: at vero, in strong asseveration, as often kai\ mh/n. Kr. Spr. 69, 35, 1; Kühn. 503, 3 f.
die/fqartai: pf. ind., expressing hopeless certainty.—20.
a)/praktos: without doing his errand. With a)pelqei=n also iv. 61. 28; 99. 10; v. 38. 21; 56. 19; 85. 15; 86. 23.—21.
ou)ke/ti a)ph/|tei: in the desperation of grief, just as in the case of the Athenians, vii. 72. § 2.

pa/qos . . . me/giston dh\ kte(.: Thuc. often puts a pronominal subj., as tou=to, after a pred. subst. and before a sup. adj. which belongs to it. This posi
tion of the subst. gives it a character of generality with nearly the effect of a part. gen. See on i. 1. 8. For similar concluding formulae, cf. vii. 29. 29; 30. 19. Whether this remark of Thuc.'s—in which the restrictive expressions, mia=| po/lei *(ellhni/di and e)n i)/sais h(me/rais, are to be esp. noted —refers to the ten years', or to the twenty-seven years' war, cannot be determined; for neither here is the number of the total loss of the Ambraciots given, nor in regard to all the great losses of the later periods of the Peloponnesian war are definite numbers for individual states known. L. Herbst (Philol. xxxviii. p. 521 f.) cites vii. 29 f. in favour of understanding kata\ to\n po/lemon to/nde only of the ten years' war. But since Mycalessus is called in vii. 29. 12 a po/lis ou) mega/lh (cf. vii. 30. 20 w(s e)pi\ mege/qei, sc. th=s po/lews), the number of Mycalessians, including even women and children, slain by the Thracians, may very well have been less than the number of the Ambraciots that fell in the three days.—22.
e)n i)/sais h(me/rais: i.e. in three days. See on c. 75. 12.—23.

a)riqmo/n: i.e. the sumtotal of the fallen. As this number has not been directly stated, it is not possible to make an approximately accurate estimate of it from c. 108. 15 (polloi\ a)pe/qanon), c. 111. 17, and the dialogue here (§ 3, 4). Grote, Hist. of Greece, c. 51, on an arbitrarily assumed ratio between the 300 panopli/ai assigned to Demosthenes (c. 114. 5) and those set apart for the Athenian government (namely 1:6), and without taking into consideration the fact that a part of the booty had been taken from the Peloponnesians, reckons the loss of the Ambraciots at about 6000, which is certainly too high.—
tw=n a)poqano/ntwn: see on c. 109. 9.—24.

a)/piston to\ plh=qos: the pred. adj. has the effect of a rel. clause, a)/piston to\ plh=qo/s e)sti, o(\ le/getai. Cf. c. 30. 4; 57. 3; 63. 16. With the sentiment, cf. Xen. Hier. 2. 16 xalepo\n eu(rei=n, o(/pou ou)xi\ kai\ e)piyeu/dontai, ple/onas fa/skontes a)pektone/nai h)\ o(/soi a)\n tw=| o)/nti a)poqa/nwsin.— 25. w(s pro\s to\ me/geqos: in proportion to the size. Cf. vii. 30. 20 w(s e)pi\ mege/qei. w(s, as in i. 10. 34; 21. 8; ii. 65. 44; iv. 34. 10. Kr. Spr. 69, 63, 4 and 6; Kühn. 581, 5.—
*)ampraki/an: placed first, almost abs. See on c. 15. 4; i. 32. 17.—26.

oi)=da: the confidence of the assertion perhaps justifies the inference that Thuc. made careful inquiry in Ambracia itself. See Köhler, Hermes xxvi. p. 47. How weak Ambracia was even after the return of the remnants of the 3000 hoplites of c. 105. 3 (c. 114. § 2), may be inferred from c. 114. § 4.—
27.
e)celei=n: a stronger term than e(lei=n. Cf. iv. 69. 5; 122. 24; v. 43. 16; viii. 100. 12; Dem. ii. 7.—
au)toboei/: see on c. 74. 6.—28.
nu=n de/: introduces the real state of the case, as in i. 71. 8.—29.
pa/roikoi: only here in Thuc., and elsewhere mostly in the poets. Cf. Aesch. Pers. 869; Soph. Ant. 1139. It is used fig. in Hdt. vii. 235. 13, as in Dio C. lxxv. 5; St. Paul Eph. ii. 19.

p.hi: Demosthenes returns with rich booty to Athens. Peace and alliance between the Ambraciols on the one side and the Acarnanians and Amphilochians on the other.

div2.p: meta\ tau=ta: i.e. after the departure of the Ambracian herald, and the rejection of the proposition of Demosthenes to attack Ambracia.—
nei/mantes: sc. oi( *)akarna=nes, as the real belligerents. Cf. c. 112. 31.—2.
kata\ ta\s po/leis: in ii. 78. 4; v. 114. 4; vii. 19. 5, kata\ po/leis is used in the same connexion, and so Cobet (Mnem. N. S. viii. p. 144) would write here.— 3.
ple/onta: of things, as freq. e)kplei=n and e)splei=n (c. 51. 11; Dem. xx. 31). —
e(a/lw: by whom and how the rich booty was taken is not stated, perhaps because its capture was not strictly an event of the war.—4.
a)nakei/mena: pf. pass. of a)nati/qhmi. Cf. cu/gkeitai, i. 22. 20.—
e)ch|re/qhsan: pl. agreeing with the appos. panopli/ai. Kr. Spr. 63, 1, 3. This meaning of the word occurs already in Homer (*d 627; h 10).—5.

a)/gwn au)ta\s kate/pleuse: sc. e)s ta\s *)aqh/nas. Cf. ii. 103. 3. These words balance ple/onta e(a/lw (3). While the ships bearing the rest of the booty were captured, Demosthenes reached Athens safely with his share of the spoils. Since, acc. to l. 8, the twenty Athenian triremes of c. 105. 15 returned to Naupactus, the ships bearing the booty seem to have been insufficiently or not at all protected by war-ships.—6.

kai\ e)ge/neto a(/ma kte(.: the brilliant success of Demosthenes not only brought him rich spoils, but rendered his return to Athens a)deeste/ra.—th=s *ai)twli/as: = e)n th=| *ai)twli/a|. The fact that in later times the simple gen. was felt to be unusual doubtless caused the readings e)k th=s *ai)twli/as (Laur. and Palat.; cf. c. 102. 10) and e)n *ai)twli/a| (inferior Mss.).—

a)po/: in consequence of. Cf. c. 64. 5; ii. 62. 28.—
7.

tau/ths th=s pra/cews: pra=cis, in Thuc. only here and vi. 88. 57. On pra/ceis in the interpolated passage i. 39. § 3, see App. on i. 39. 15. The reference is to the brilliant repulse of the Ambracian-Peloponnesian attack upon Acarnania and Amphilochia.—

a)deeste/ra: with less apprehension. Cf. c. 98. 26 *dhmosqe/nhs peri\ *nau/pakton kai\ ta\ xwri/a tau=ta u(pelei/fqh, toi=s pepragme/nois fobou/menos tou\s *)aqhnai/ous. The expression a)deeste/ra, however, does not necessarily prove that the Aetolian disaster had no unpleasant consequences for Demosthenes. To it may have been due the fact that the next summer Demosthenes was i)diw/ths (iv. 2. 14). Indeed, if one take literally the words in iv. 2. 14 *dhmosqe/nei o)/nti i)diw/th| meta\ th\n a)naxw/rhsin th\n e)c *)akarnani/as, and add the fact that, acc. to Arist. *)aq. pol. 44 (p. 116 Kenyon), the election of strathgoi/ took place at earliest in the seventh prytany of the year, the inference seems possible that Demosthenes was not left in office even till the usual time of change of strathgoi/. For since the Amphilochian campaign began early in the winter (cf. c. 102. § 7; 105. § 1) and was of short duration, the return of Demosthenes to Athens must have occurred before mid-winter.
oi( e)n tai=s ei)/kosi nausi\n *)aqhnai=oi: cf. c. 105. 15; 107. 3; 112. 25. —10.
toi=s w(s *salu/nqion kte(.: cf. c. 111. 18; 113. 2.—11.

a)naxw/rhsin . . . para\ *salunqi/ou: a)naxw/rhsin e)spei/santo, as in c. 109. 10. They now obtained by treaty an unmolested departure by sea. They had already succeeded in reaching, prob. through Aetolian territory, the friendly Oeniadae (c. 7. 11; 94. 7; ii. 102. 10), hoping to be able to embark there. This is the meaning of the passage as happily emended by G. Hermann, oi)=per (for oi(/per of the Mss.) kai\ metane/sthsan para\ *salunqi/ou (*salu/nqion, Mss.), whither they had withdrawn from Salynthius. kai/, as in c. 86. 6; 98. 18. Oberhummer, Akarnanien, p. 112, conjectures e)p) *oi)niadw=n, but does not explain why the Ambraciots should have withdrawn, not home, but to Oeniadae. In ii. 82, which he cites, the situation was quite different, for then there was no difficulty about the withdrawal of the Peloponnesians by sea, since two Peloponnesian fleets were not far from Oeniadae.

e(kato\n e)/th: without e)s, as v.
47. 1. Cf. iv. 21. 17 sponda\s poih/sasqai o(po/son a)\n dokh=| xro/non a)mfote/rois, and ii. 73. 1; vi. 7. 8; iv. 114. 8.— 15.

e)pi\ toi=sde: in ii. 70. 13 and Hdt. vi. 108. 25 e)pi\ toi=sde is followed by the inf. without w(/ste, in viii. 18. 1 by the imv. The combination with w(/ste is unusual. Cf. Hdt. v. 65. 11 e)p) oi)=si . . . w(/ste, vii. 154. 18 e)pi\ toisi/de . . . e)p) w(=|. The conditions are those of a defensive alliance, e)pimaxi/a, as in i. 44. 8; v. 48. 8, and were evidently due to the treaties existing between the Ambraciots and Spartans and between the Acarnanians and Athenians.—16.

meta\ *)akarna/nwn, *)akarna=nas: without mention of the Amphilochians, which the author seems to have considered superfluous after the words *)akarna=nes kai\ *)amfi/loxoi pro\s *)amprakiw/tas (14). Besides, the Acarnanians were unquestionably the main force. Cf. c. 112. 31, and see on c. 1. 1; ii. 13. 1.—

strateu/ein: as opp. to bohqei=n, of the offensive, as rightly recognized by X. in Philol. Anz. xiii. p. 303. Cf. v. 48. 8 a)llh/lois bohqei=n, cunepistrateu/ein de\ mhdeni/, and v. 47. 42 strateu/esqai.—18. bohqei=n th=| a)llh/lwn: sc. gh=|, as in i. 44. 8. X. (l.c.) would supply, “against the Peloponnesians, or the Athenians, as the case might be.” Steup, who thinks the idea is, “under all circumstances,” suggests that kai\ pa/ntws (cf. v. 41. 19; vi. 20. 1) has dropped out before the following kai/. The sense is doubtless as Steup suggests, but it seems unnecessary to suppose that anything has been lost.—19.

o(mh/rous: the reading adopted since Bk. for the meaningless o(mo/rous of most of the Mss. These are included in the o(po/sa, the hostages being one of the means whereby the Amphilochians u(po\ *)amprakiwtw=n bi/a| katei/xonto, c. 107. 9.—
e)pi\ *)anakto/rion mh\ bohqei=n: not to come to the aid of Anactorium. See on c. 97. 14.—
die/lusan to\n po/lemon: also viii. 46. 2.—

*kori/nqioi . . . a)pe/steilan: Corinth was the ‘mother-city’ of Ambracia (cf. ii. 80. 15 cumproqumou/menoi ma/lista toi=s *)amprakiw/tais a)poi/kois ou)=si). The precaution was taken doubtless because Ambracia was so much weakened. See on c. 113. 26.—
fulakh/n: i.e. as a garrison.—22.
e(autw=n: i.e. of their own citizens, as in i. 26. 4; 61. 3; 64. 9.—
o(pli/tas: for the prepositional phrase representing an acc., see on c. 20. 11; 111. 17.—23.
*cenoklei/dan: Doric form. Without doubt the strathgo/s of i. 46. 7.—24.
komizo/menoi xalepw=s: i.e. by a difficult march.—25.

ta\ me\n kat) *)ampraki/an ou(/tws e)ge/neto: conclusion of the account of the fortunes of Ambracia, which have been carefully followed since ii. 68. § 1. The formula is similar to that with regard to Lesbos c. 50. 15, and Plataea, c. 68. 31. ta\ me/n without kai/, as in c. 50. 15.

p.hi: New enterprises of the Athenians in Sicily. Their strategus Pythodorus is defeated by the Locrians.

div2.p: oi( e)n th=| *sikeli/a| *)aqhnai=oi: resumes the narrative interrupted at c. 103. § 3.—2.
th\n *(imerai/an: the Himeraean territory, h(/per mo/nh e)n tou/tw| tw=| me/rei th=s *sikeli/as *(ella\s po/lis e)sti/, vi. 62. 9 (cf. vi. 5. § 1).—3.

meta\ tw=n *sikelw=n: Bl.'s conjecture *sikelw=n, for *sikeliwtw=n of the Mss., is adopted by most recent editors. The expression a)/nwqen e)sbeblhko/twn suits much better the *sikeloi/, who lived in the interior (vi. 88. 22), than the more distant *sikeliw=tai. Besides, since part of the Siceliots held with the Syracusans (c. 86. § 2), those that were allied with Athens could not properly be designated simply as oi( *sikeliw=tai. Only a part, it is true, of the Sicels were allied to Athens (c. 103. § 1), but it was the greater part (vii. 57. 61), and in iv. 25. 31 these allies are called simply oi( *sikeloi/. In this last place, too, u(pe\r tw=n a)/krwn is doubtless, as St. says, to be compared with a)/nwqen here. Furthermore, it is not likely that the Siceliot allies of Athens, of whom it is said, l. 9, th=s me\n ga\r gh=s au)tw=n oi( *surako/sioi e)kra/toun, would have made this long march across the island at the risk of having their retreat cut off. In vii. 57. 61, the same mistake of *sikeliwtw=n for *sikelw=n, though found in all the Mss. except three, has been corrected by all recent editors. See App.—4.
a)/nwqen: from the interior. Cf. i. 59. 8; ii. 99. 16.—
e)s ta\ e)/sxata th=s *(imerai/as: i.e. toward the interior. Cf. c. 106. 8 *medew=nos par) e)/sxata, Tac. Ann. iv. 74 imperii extrema.— 5.
e)pi\ ta\s *ai)o/lou nh/sous: as already before, c. 88. 2.

*puqo/dwron: this man, whose generalship in Sicily is mentioned also
in iv. 2. 7; 65. 11, is perhaps the same as the archon mentioned in ii. 2. 5. See also on vi. 105. 12.—7.

e)pi\ ta\s nau=s dia/doxon: taken together as pred. to katalamba/nousin, which in the sense find, discover, usually takes the supplementary partic. (but see on c. 69. 5), and indeed always in the pres. or pf., never aor. (see on i. 59. 3). But here the idea of transition implied in di/adoxon supplies the place of the partic. h(/konta (which v. H. thinks has dropped out) or e)pelhluqo/ta (cf. c. 69. 8); and so is explained also e)pi/ with the acc., for which St. compares Xen. Hell. iii. 4. 20 tou/twn *cenokle/a me\n kai\ a)/llon e)/tacen e)pi\ tou\s i(ppei=s, and Cyr. iv. 5. 58.—
o( *la/xhs: see on c. 86. 2. He seems to have been recalled on some charge, prob. of embezzlement, as Bl. shows from Ar. Vesp. 240 and the Schol. thereon.
oi( e)n *sikeli/a| cu/mmaxoi: i.e. the Hellenic allies of Athens (cf. c. 86. § 2; 90. § 4).—

pleu/santes e)/peisan: these aors., including a)pe/steilan in l. 16, give, as in c. 33. 2; ii. 2. 11, the supplementary explanation for the arrival of the new strategus, who was to be followed by two others. “The allies in Sicily had sent an embassy to Athens (pleu/santes), and there had obtained the promise of more effective assistance (e)/peisan tou\s *)aqhnai/ous bohqei=n sfi/si plei/osi nausi/n.” Hude's conjecture (Comm. Crit. p. 118) pe/myantes for pleu/santes seems unnecessary.—9.
th=s me\n ga\r gh=s . . . e)kra/toun: just as before the interference of the Athenians in the conflicts of the Siceliots (c. 86. 14). For th=s gh=s kratei=n, see on c. 85. 13.— 10.

th=s de\ qala/sshs kte(.: at sea the situation had indeed become quite different from that before the appearance of the Athenians, when the Leontines and their allies were excluded by the Syracusans also from the sea (c. 86. 15); but with the small number of Athenian ships it was to be feared that the Syracusans might, with the preparations they were making, be able to face their opponents even at sea with prospect of success. —
th=s qala/sshs . . . ei)rgo/menoi: cf. ii. 85. 4 u(p) o)li/gwn new=n ei)/rgesqai th=s qala/sshs, and see on c. 6. 7; 86. 15; i. 141. 16.—12.
w(s ou) perioyo/menoi: sc. ei)/rgesqai.

kai\ e)plh/roun: and they were manning. The impf. because the preparation continued beyond the appear
ance of Pythodorus in Sicily.—15.
mele/thn . . . poiei=sqai: cf. i. 18. 33.— 16.
a)pe/steilan; this very winter; the other two follow in the spring. Cf. iv. 2. § 2.—17.
*sofokle/a: Roscher conjectures (Leben des Thuk. p. 416) that he was the Sophocles who was afterwards one of the Thirty Tyrants. —
*eu)rume/donta: see on c. 80. 10.
h)/dh e)/xwn: sc. after the ships had returned from the Aeolus islands. —

th\n tou= *la/xhtos tw=n new=n a)rxh/n: subj. and obj. gen. both in attrib. position, whereas the obj. gen. is placed after its noun in c. 12. 10; i. 25. 21; vii. 34. 25. v. H.'s bracketing of tw=n new=n is the less to be approved, since in c. 90. 8 it is remarked, concerning the position of Laches after the death of Charoeades, a(/pasan e)/xwn tw=n new=n th\n a)rxh/n.—21. o(\ *la/xhs ei(=le: cf. c. 99. 4; the fort on the Halex, which must therefore meanwhile have been recaptured by the Locrians.—22.
a)nexw/rhsen: sc. e)s *(rh/gion. Cf.

p.hi: Eruption of Aetna.

div2.p: peri\ au)to\ to\ e)/ar tou=to: “just at the beginning of this spring.” tou=to refers to the words teleutw=ntos tou= xeimw=nos, c. 115. 20, in which there is a hint of the nearness of spring. On this, as well as the relation of the present passage to tau=ta me\n kata\ to\n xeimw=na tou=ton e)ge/neto (l. 7), see App. on ii. 2. 7. The eruption began doubtless in the last days of winter and extended a little beyond the commencement of spring, i.e. into the summer, as Thuc. uses the term.—

o( r(u/ac: used esp., as to\ r(eu=ma l. 6, of volcanic eruptions, with and without tou= puro/s. Cf. Plato Phaedo 111 e; Lycurg. c. Leocr. 95; Arist. de Ausc. Mirab. 38 to
 d' e)n th=| *ai)/tnh| r(u/aka ou)/te flogw/dh fasi
 ou)/te sunexh=, a)lla\ dia\ pollw=n e)tw=n gi/nesqai, 40 to\ e)n *sikeli/a| peri\ to
 r(u/aka gino/menon. ‘The art. is used because the “fire-flood” was a well known phenomenon peculiar to Aetna. So App. B. C. v. 117 e)mpesei=sqai sfi/si kai\ to
 r(u/aka, and Strabo vi. 2. 3.’ Arn. See Kr. Spr. 47, 8, 5.

w(/sper kai\ to\ pro/teron: Unger, N. Jahrbb. exli. p. 183, understands the meaning to be, that the two eruptions occurred in the same season of the year. But the tou=to added
to peri\ au)to\ to\ e)/ar is against this explanation. Besides, it is incredible that Thuc., who acc. to what follows did not venture a definite statement even with regard to the year of the preceding eruption, should have distinctly designated the season of the year. In w(/sper kai\ to\ pro/teron, as also before (cf. ii. 72. 9 a(/per kai\ to\ pro/teron h)/dh proukalesa/meqa), Thuc. seems to have intended to indicate only that the eruption of 425 B.C. was not the first. This he regards as certain, whereas he does not vouch (le/getai, l. 4) for the correctness of the statement, that since the Hellenic settlement of Sicily, in all three eruptions had occurred, nor for that of his authority as to the interval between the eruption of 425 B.C. and the preceding.—3.
e)pi\ th=| *ai)/tnh|: near Actna. Cf. c. 89. 12; i. 105. 3, 6; ii. 32. 3; 86. 11; iv. 101. 20; v. 14. 5. The reading of Laur. u(po\ th=| *ai)/tnh| is certainly a gloss. —

tw=| o)/rei: considered an interpolation by Cobet, v. H., and Kallenberg (Studien über d. griech. Artikel, ii. p. 21). But the repetition of o)/ros in the following rel. clause should not give offence, since Thuc. is by no means careful to avoid the repetition of a word after a short interval (e.g. cf. r(uh=nai, 1. 5, and r(eu=ma twice in l. 6). Nor can much weight be laid upon the circumstance that, allowing with Kallenberg that in viii. 108. 16 dia\ th=s *)/idhs tou= o)/rous the gen. th=s *)/idhs depends upon tou= o)/rous, the present passage is the only one in Thuc. in which to\ o)/ros follows the name of a mountain likewise connected with the art. For, disregarding Hdt. i. 43. 3 e)s to\n *)/olumpon to\ o)/ros, the following passages, Thuc. iv. 96. 28 pro\s *pa/rnhqa to\ o)/ros, ii. 23. 3 metacu\ *pa/rnhqos kai\ *brilhssou= o)/rous, ii. 102. 12 e)k *pi/ndou o)/rous, and esp. c. 79. <*> e)pi\ th\n *leuki/mmhn to\ a)krwth/rion (cf. i. 47. 7), if considered without bias, are not so essentially different from the present passage that one must object to the latter. And, finally, the transition from the simple th=s *ai)/tnhs to th=| *ai)/tnh| tw=| o)/rei does not seem more remarkable than e.g. the change of expression in ii. 23. 3 metacu\ *pa/rnhqos kai\ *brilhssou= o)/rous. At any rate, objection could more properly be raised, with Badham, against the remark o(/per . . . *sikeli/a|, since it is not coupled with the first mention of Aetna. But this too may be due to the lack of revision on the part of the historian. —5.
tou=to: the present eruption of 425 B.C.—

to\ pro/teron r(eu=ma: refers without doubt to the eruption of Aetna mentioned in the Parian Marble 52, 67 ff. as contemporaneous with the battle of Plataea. But this is not sufficient reason why penthkostw=| e)/tei, which taken strictly would lead to the year 475 or 474 instead of 479 B.C. should either be considered as a round number (see Boeckh in C. I. G. ii. p. 339), or changed, acc. to Kr.'s conjecture, into penthkostw=| pe/mptw| (or
ne/) e)/tei. For unquestionably Thuc. indicates by le/getai that he does not vouch for the correctness of the number given by him. The expression le/getai is also decidedly against the assumption of Büdinger, Poesic und Urkunde bei Thuk. i. p. 39, that Thuc. chose the date penthkostw=| e)/tei with reference to the first Pythian ode of Pindar (474 B.C.), in which, v. 21 ff., an eruption of Aetna is deseribed. At most, Thuc.'s authority may have fixed the date by inference from Pindar's ode.—6.

tri\s gegenh=sqai kte(.: from his manner of expression it is clear that Thuc. can have had no knowledge, when he wrote this passage, of an eruption of Aetna later than that of 425 B.C. Otherwise he must have expressed himself definitely as to three eruptions, and not with le/getai tri\s gegenh=sqai to\ r(eu=ma, since acc. to l. 2 two eruptions are regarded by him as facts. Evidently, then, Thuc.'s authority must have mentioned, in addition to the pro/teron r(eu=ma of l. 5, a still earlier eruption. See Ullrich, Beitr. p. 92 f., and Introd. to Book 1. p. 18, N. 38. Another eruption is said by Diod. xiv. 59 and Orosius ii. 18 to have occurred in the year 396. Thuc., therefore, must have either died before 396, or never revised this passage.—
a)f) ou(= . . . oi)kei=tai: i.e. from about the middle of the 8th century B.C. See on vi. 3. 1.—7.
tau=ta me\n . . . e)ge/neto, kai\ . . . cune/grayen: cf. the similar conclusion of ii. 70. 21.
